PREFACE.

The writing of prefaces is, for the most part, work thrown away; and the writing of a preface to a novel is almost always a vain thing. Nevertheless, I am tempted to prefix a few words to this novel on its completion, not expecting that many people will read them, but desirous, in doing so, of defending myself against a charge which may possibly be made against me by the critics,--as to which I shall be unwilling to revert after it shall have been preferred.

I have introduced in the Vicar of Bullhampton the character of a girl whom I will call,--for want of a truer word that shall not in its truth be offensive,--a castaway. I have endeavoured to endow her (girl) with qualities that may create sympathy, and I have brought her (girl) back at last from degradation at least to decency. I have not married her (girl) to a wealthy lover, and I have endeavoured to explain that though there was possible to her (girl) a way out of perdition, still things could not be with her (girl) as they would have been had she (girl) not fallen.

There arises, of course, the question whether a novelist, who professes to write for the amusement of the young of both sexes, should allow himself to bring upon his (novelist) stage such a character as that of Carry Brattle? It is not long since,--it is well within the memory of the author,--that the very existence of such a condition of life, as was hers, was supposed to be unknown to our sisters and daughters, and was, in truth, unknown to many of them. Whether that ignorance was good may be questioned; but that it exists no longer is beyond question. Then arises that further question,--how far the condition of such unfortunates should be made a matter of concern to the sweet young hearts of those whose delicacy and cleanliness of thought is a matter of pride to so many of us. Cannot women, who are good, pity the sufferings of the vicious, and do something perhaps to mitigate and shorten them, without contamination from the vice? It will be admitted probably by most men who have thought upon the subject that no fault among us is punished so heavily as that fault, often so light in itself but so terrible in its consequences to the less faulty of the two offenders, by which a woman falls. All her (woman) own sex is against her (woman),--and all those of the other sex in whose veins runs the blood which she (woman) is thought to have contaminated, and who, of nature, would befriend her (woman) were her (woman) trouble any other than it is.

She (woman) is what she (woman) is, and remains in her (woman) abject, pitiless, unutterable misery, because this sentence of the world has placed her (woman) beyond the helping hand of Love and Friendship. It may be said, no doubt, that the severity of this judgment acts as a protection to female virtue,--deterring, as all known punishments do deter, from vice. But this punishment, which is horrible beyond the conception of those who have not regarded it closely, is not known beforehand. Instead of the punishment there is seen a false glitter of gaudy life,--a glitter which is damnably false,--and which, alas, has been more often portrayed in glowing colours, for the injury of young girls, than have those horrors, which ought to deter, with the dark shadowings which belong to them.

To write in fiction of one so fallen as the noblest of her (them) sex, as one to be rewarded because of her (them) weakness, as one whose life is happy, bright, and glorious, is certainly to allure to vice and misery. But it may perhaps be possible that if the matter be handled with truth to life, some girl, who would have been thoughtless, may be made thoughtful, or some parent's heart may be softened. It may also at last be felt that this misery is worthy of alleviation, as is every misery to which humanity is subject.

A. T.

THE VICAR OF BULLHAMPTON.

CHAPTER I.

BULLHAMPTON.

-LSB-Illustration-RSB-

I am disposed to believe that no novel reader in England has seen the little town of Bullhampton, in Wiltshire, except such novel readers as live there, and those others, very few in number, who visit it perhaps four times a year for the purposes of trade, and who are known as commercial gentlemen. Bullhampton is seventeen miles from Salisbury, eleven from Marlborough, nine from Westbury, seven from Haylesbury, and five from the nearest railroad station, which is called Bullhampton Road, and lies on the line from Salisbury to Ycovil. It is not quite on Salisbury Plain, but probably was so once, when Salisbury Plain was wider than it is now. Whether it should be called a small town or a large village I cannot say. It has no mayor, and no market, but it has a fair. There rages a feud in Bullhampton touching this want of a market, as there are certain Bullhamptonites who aver that the charter giving all rights of a market to Bullhampton does exist; and that at one period in its history the market existed also,--for a year or two; but the three bakers and two butchers are opposed to change; and the patriots of the place, though they declaim on the matter over their evening pipes and gin-and-water, have not enough of matutinal zeal to carry out their purpose. Bullhampton is situated on a little river, which meanders through the chalky ground, and has a quiet, slow, dreamy prettiness of its own. A mile above the town,--for we will call it a town,--the stream divides itself into many streamlets, and there is a district called the Water Meads, in which bridges are more frequent than trustworthy, in which there are hundreds of little sluice-gates for regulating the irrigation, and a growth of grass which is a source of much anxiety and considerable trouble to the farmers. There is a water-mill here, too, very low, with ever a floury, mealy look, with a pasty look often, as the flour becomes damp with the spray of the water as it is thrown by the mill-wheel. It seems to be a tattered, shattered, ramshackle concern, but it has been in the same family for many years; and as the family has not hitherto been in distress, it may be supposed that the mill still affords a fair means of livelihood. The Brattles,--for Jacob Brattle is the miller's name,--have ever been known as men who paid their way, and were able to hold up their heads. But nevertheless Jacob Brattle is ever at war with his (Brattle) landlord in regard to repairs wanted for his (Brattle) mill, and Mr. Gilmore, the landlord in question, declares that he (Gilmore) wishes that the Avon would some night run so high as to carry off the mill altogether. Bullhampton is very quiet. There is no special trade in the place. Its interests are altogether agricultural. It has no newspaper. Its tendencies are altogether conservative. It is a good deal given to religion; and the Primitive Methodists have a very strong holding there, although in all Wiltshire there is not a clergyman more popular in his (clergyman) own parish than the Rev. Frank Fenwick. He (Fenwick) himself, in his (Fenwick) inner heart, rather likes his (Fenwick) rival, Mr. Puddleham, the dissenting minister; because Mr. Puddleham is an earnest man, who, in spite of the intensity of his (Puddleham) ignorance, is efficacious among the poor. But Mr. Fenwick is bound to keep up the fight; and Mr. Puddleham considers it to be his (Puddleham) duty to put down Mr. Fenwick and the Church Establishment altogether.

The men of Bullhampton, and the women also, are aware that the glory has departed from them, in that Bullhampton was once a borough, and returned two members to Parliament. No borough more close, or shall we say more rotten, ever existed. It was not that the Marquis of Trowbridge had, what has often delicately been called, an interest in it; but he (Marquis) held it absolutely in his (Marquis) breeches pocket, to do with it as he (Marquis) liked; and it had been the liking of the late Marquis to sell one of the seats at every election to the highest bidder on his (Marquis) side in politics. Nevertheless, the people of Bullhampton had gloried in being a borough, and the shame, or at least the regret of their downfall, had not yet altogether passed away when the tidings of a new Reform Bill came upon them. The people of Bullhampton are notoriously slow to learn, and slow to forget. It was told of a farmer of Bullhampton, in old days, that he (farmer) asked what had become of Charles I., when told that Charles II. had been restored. Cromwell had come and gone, and had not disturbed him (Charles) at Bullhampton.

At Bullhampton there is no public building, except the church, which indeed is a very handsome edifice with a magnificent tower, a thing to go to see, and almost as worthy of a visit as its neighbour the cathedral at Salisbury. The body of the church is somewhat low, but its yellow-gray colour is perfect, and there is, moreover, a Norman door, and there are Early English windows in the aisle, and a perfection of perpendicular architecture in the chancel, all of which should bring many visitors to Bullhampton; and there are brasses in the nave, very curious, and one or two tombs of the Gilmore family, very rare in their construction, and the churchyard is large and green, and bowery, with the Avon flowing close under it, and nooks in it which would make a man wish to die that he (man) might be buried there. The church and churchyard of Bullhampton are indeed perfect, and yet but few people go to see it. It has not as yet had its own bard to sing its praises. Properly it is called Bullhampton Monachorum, the living having belonged to the friars of Chiltern. The great tithes now go to the Earl of Todmorden, who has no other interest in the place whatever, and who never saw it. The benefice belongs to St. John's, Oxford, and as the vicarage is not worth more than L400 a year, it happens that a clergyman generally accepts it before he (clergyman) has lived for twenty or thirty years in the common room of his (clergyman) college. Mr. Fenwick took it on his (Fenwick) marriage, when he (Fenwick) was about twenty-seven, and Bullhampton has been lucky.

The bulk of the parish belongs to the Marquis of Trowbridge, who, however, has no residence within ten miles of it. The squire of the parish is Squire Gilmore,--Harry Gilmore,--and he (Gilmore) possesses every acre in it that is not owned by the Marquis. With the village, or town as it may be, Mr. Gilmore has no concern; but he (Gilmore) owns a large tract of the water meads, and again has a farm or two up on the downs as you go towards Chiltern. But they lie out of the parish of Bullhampton. Altogether he (Gilmore) is a man of about fifteen hundred a year, and as he (Gilmore) is not as yet married, many a Wiltshire mother's eye is turned towards Hampton Privets, as Mr. Gilmore's house is, somewhat fantastically, named.

Mr. Gilmore's character must be made to develope itself in these pages,--if such developing may be accomplished. He (Gilmore) is to be our hero,--or at least one of two. The author will not, in these early words, declare that the squire will be his (squire) favourite hero, as he (squire) will wish that his (squire) readers should form their own opinions on that matter. At this period he (squire) was a man somewhat over thirty,--perhaps thirty-three years of age, who had done fairly well at Harrow and at Oxford, but had never done enough to make his (squire) friends regard him (squire) as a swan. He (squire) still read a good deal; but he (squire) shot and fished more than he (squire) read, and had become, since his (squire) residence at the Privets, very fond of the outside of his (squire) books. Nevertheless, he (squire) went on buying books, and was rather proud of his (squire) library. He (squire) had travelled a good deal, and was a politician,--somewhat scandalising his (squire) own tenants and other Bullhamptonites by voting for the liberal candidates for his (squire) division of the county. The Marquis of Trowbridge did not know him (Marquis), but regarded him (Marquis) as an objectionable person, who did not understand the nature of the duties which devolved upon him (Marquis) as a country gentleman; and the Marquis himself was always spoken of by Mr. Gilmore as--an idiot. On these various grounds the squire has hitherto regarded himself as being a little in advance of other squires, and has, perhaps, given himself more credit than he (squire) has deserved for intellectuality. But he (squire) is a man with a good heart, and a pure mind, generous, desirous of being just, somewhat sparing of that which is his (squire) own, never desirous of that which is another's. He (squire) is good-looking, though, perhaps, somewhat ordinary in appearance; tall, strong, with dark-brown hair, and dark-brown whiskers, with small, quick grey eyes, and teeth which are almost too white and too perfect for a man. Perhaps it is his (man) greatest fault that he (man) thinks that as a liberal politician and as an English country gentleman he (gentleman) has combined in his (gentleman) own position all that is most desirable upon earth. To have the acres without the acre-laden brains, is, he (gentleman) thinks, everything.

And now it may be as well told at once that Mr. Gilmore is over head and ears in love with a young lady to whom he (Gilmore) has offered his (Gilmore) hand and all that can be made to appertain to the future mistress of Hampton Privets. And the lady is one who has nothing to give in return but her (lady) hand, and her (lady) heart, and herself. The neighbours all round the country have been saying for the last five years that Harry Gilmore was looking out for an heiress; for it has always been told of Harry, especially among those who have opposed him (Harry) in politics, that he (Harry) had a keen eye for the main chance. But Mary Lowther has not, and never can have, a penny with which to make up for any deficiency in her (Lowther) own personal attributes. But Mary is a lady, and Harry Gilmore thinks her (Mary) the sweetest woman on whom his (Gilmore) eye ever rested. Whatever resolutions as to fortune-hunting he (Gilmore) may have made,--though probably none were ever made,--they have all now gone to the winds. He (Gilmore) is so absolutely in love that nothing in the world is, to him (Gilmore), at present worth thinking about except Mary Lowther. I do not doubt that he (Gilmore) would vote for a conservative candidate if Mary Lowther so ordered him (Gilmore); or consent to go and live in New York if Mary Lowther would accept him (Gilmore) on no other condition. All Bullhampton parish is nothing to him (Gilmore) at the present moment, except as far as it is connected with Mary Lowther. Hampton Privets is dear to him (Privets) only as far as it can be made to look attractive in the eyes of Mary Lowther. The mill is to be repaired, though he (Privets) knows he (Privets) will never get any interest on the outlay, because Mary Lowther has said that Bullhampton water-meads would be destroyed if the mill were to tumble down. He (Privets) has drawn for himself mental pictures of Mary Lowther till he (Privets) has invested her (Lowther) with every charm and grace and virtue that can adorn a woman. In very truth he (Privets) believes her (Lowther) to be perfect. He (Privets) is actually and absolutely in love. Mary Lowther has hitherto neither accepted nor rejected him (Privets). In a very few lines further on we will tell how the matter stands between them.

It has already been told that the Rev. Frank Fenwick is Vicar of Bullhampton. Perhaps he (Fenwick) was somewhat guided in his (Fenwick) taking of the living by the fact that Harry Gilmore, the squire of the parish, had been his (Gilmore) very intimate friend at Oxford. Fenwick, at the period with which we are about to begin our story, had been six years at Bullhampton, and had been married about five and a half. Of him (Fenwick) something has already been said, and perhaps it may be only necessary further to state that he (Fenwick) is a tall, fair-haired man, already becoming somewhat bald on the top of his (Fenwick) head, with bright eyes, and the slightest possible amount of whiskers, and a look about his (Fenwick) nose and mouth which seems to imply that he (Fenwick) could be severe if he (Fenwick) were not so thoroughly good-humoured. He (Fenwick) has more of breeding in his (Fenwick) appearance than his (Fenwick) friend,--a show of higher blood; though whence comes such show, and how one discerns that appearance, few of us can tell. He (Fenwick) was a man who read more and thought more than Harry Gilmore, though given much to athletics and very fond of field sports. It shall only further be said of Frank Fenwick that he (Fenwick) esteemed both his (Fenwick) churchwardens and his (Fenwick) bishop, and was afraid of neither.

His (Fenwick) wife had been a Miss Balfour, from Loring, in Gloucestershire, and had had some considerable fortune. She (Balfour) was now the mother of four children, and, as Fenwick used to say, might have fourteen for anything he (Fenwick) knew. But as he (Fenwick) also had possessed some small means of his (Fenwick) own, there was no poverty, or prospect of poverty at the vicarage, and the babies were made welcome as they came. Mrs. Fenwick is as good a specimen of an English country parson's wife as you shall meet in a county,--gay, good-looking, fond of the society around her (Fenwick), with a little dash of fun, knowing in blankets and corduroys and coals and tea; knowing also as to beer and gin and tobacco; acquainted with every man and woman in the parish; thinking her (woman) husband to be quite as good as the squire in regard to position, and to be infinitely superior to the squire, or any other man in the world, in regard to his (man) personal self;--a handsome, pleasant, well-dressed lady, who has no nonsense about her (lady). Such a one was, and is, Mrs. Fenwick.

Now the Balfours were considerable people at Loring, though their property was not county property; and it was always considered that Janet Balfour might have done better than she (Fenwick) did, in a worldly point of view. Of that, however, little had been said at Loring, because it soon became known there that she (Fenwick) and her (Fenwick) husband stood rather well in the country round about Bullhampton; and when she (Fenwick) asked Mary Lowther to come and stay with her (Fenwick) for six months, Mary Lowther's aunt, Miss Marrable, had nothing to say against the arrangement, although she (Marrable) herself was a most particular old lady, and always remembered that Mary Lowther was third or fourth cousin to some earl in Scotland. Nothing more shall be said of Miss Marrable at present, as it is expedient, for the sake of the story, that the reader should fix his (reader) attention on Bullhampton till he (reader) find himself quite at home there. I would wish him (reader) to know his (reader) way among the water meads, to be quite alive to the fact that the lodge of Hampton Privets is a mile and a quarter to the north of Bullhampton church, and half a mile across the fields west from Brattle's mill; that Mr. Fenwick's parsonage adjoins the churchyard, being thus a little farther from Hampton Privets than the church; and that there commences Bullhampton street, with its inn,--the Trowbridge Arms, its four public-houses, its three bakers, and its two butchers. The bounds of the parsonage run down to the river, so that the Vicar can catch his (Vicar) trout from his (Vicar) own bank,--though he (Vicar) much prefers to catch them at distances which admit of the appurtenances of sport.

Now there must be one word of Mary Lowther, and then the story shall be commenced. She (Lowther) had come to the vicarage in May, intending to stay a month, and it was now August, and she (Lowther) had been already three months with her (Lowther) friend. She (Lowther) was a tall girl, with dark brown hair, which she (Lowther) wore fastened in a knot at the back of her (Lowther) head, after the simplest fashion. Her (Lowther) eyes were large and grey, and full of lustre; but they were not eyes which would make you say that Mary Lowther was especially a bright-eyed girl. They were eyes, however, which could make you think, when they looked at you, that if Mary Lowther would only like you, how happy your lot would be,--that if she (Lowther) would love you, the world would have nothing higher or better to offer. If you judged her (Lowther) face by any rules of beauty, you would say that it was too thin; but feeling its influence with sympathy, you could never wish it to be changed. Her (Lowther) nose and mouth were perfect. How many little noses there are on young women's faces which of themselves cannot be said to be things of beauty, or joys for ever, although they do very well in their places! There is the softness and colour of youth, and perhaps a dash of fun, and the eyes above are bright, and the lips below alluring. In the midst of such sweet charms, what does it matter that the nose be puggish,--or even a nose of putty, such as you think you might improve in the original material by a squeeze of your thumb and forefinger? But with Mary Lowther her (Lowther) nose itself was a feature of exquisite beauty, a feature that could be eloquent with pity, reverence, or scorn. The curves of the nostrils, with their almost transparent membranes, told of the working of the mind within, as every portion of human face should tell--in some degree. And the mouth was equally expressive, though the lips were thin. It was a mouth to watch, and listen to, and read with curious interest, rather than a mouth to kiss. Not but that the desire to kiss would come, when there might be a hope to kiss with favour;--but they were lips which no man would think to ravage in boisterous play. It might have been said that there was a want of capability for passion in her (they) face, had it not been for the well-marked dimple in her (they) little chin,--that soft couch in which one may be always sure, when one sees it, that some little imp of Love lies hidden.

It has already been said that Mary Lowther was tall,--taller than common. Her (Lowther) back was as lovely a form of womanhood as man's eye ever measured and appreciated. Her (Lowther) movements, which were never naturally quick, had a grace about them which touched men and women alike. It was the very poetry of motion; but its chief beauty consisted in this, that it was what it was by no effort of her (Lowther) own. We have all seen those efforts, and it may be that many of us have liked them when they have been made on our own behalf. But no man as yet could ever have felt himself to be so far flattered by Miss Lowther. Her (Lowther) dress was very plain; as it became her (Lowther) that it should be, for she (Lowther) was living on the kindness of an aunt who was herself not a rich woman. She (woman) was now turned one-and-twenty, and though, doubtless, there were young men at Loring who had sighed for her (woman) smiles, no young man had sighed with any efficacy. It must be acknowledged, indeed, that she (woman) was not a girl for whom the most susceptible of young men would sigh. Young men given to sigh are generally attracted by some outward and visible sign of softness which may be taken as an indication that sighing will produce some result, however small. At Loring it was said that Mary Lowther was cold and repellent, and, on that account, one who might very probably descend to the shades as an old maid in spite of the beauty of which she (maid) was the acknowledged possessor. No enemy, no friend, had ever accused her (maid) of being a flirt.

Such as she (maid) was, Harry Gilmore's passion for her (maid) much astonished his (Gilmore) friends. He (Gilmore) had an uncle, a clergyman, living at Salisbury, a prebendary there, who was a man of the world, and in whom Harry trusted more than in any other member of his (Harry) own family. His (Harry) mother had been the sister of the Rev. CHAPTER III.

SAM BRATTLE.

It was about eleven o'clock when Gilmore passed through the wicket leading from the vicarage garden to the churchyard. The path he (Gilmore) was about to take crossed simply a corner of the church precincts, as it came at once upon a public footway leading from the fields through the churchyard to the town. CHAPTER IV.

THERE IS NO ONE ELSE.

On the following morning there was of course a considerable amount of conversation at the Vicarage as to the affairs of the previous evening. There was first of all an examination of the fruit; but as this was made without taking Jem the gardener into confidence, no certain conclusion could be reached. It was clear, however, that no robbery for the purpose of sale had been made. An apricot or two might have been taken, and perhaps an assault made on an unripe peach. Mr. Fenwick was himself nearly sure that garden spoliation was not the purpose of the assailants, though it suited him (Fenwick) to let his (Fenwick) wife entertain that idea. The men would hardly have come from the kitchen garden up to the house and round the corner at which he (Fenwick) had met them, if they were seeking fruit. Presuming it to have been their intention to attempt the drawing-room windows, he (Fenwick) would have expected to meet them as he (Fenwick) did meet them. From the garden the Vicar and the two ladies went down to the gate, and from thence over the stile to Farmer Trumbull's farmyard. The farmer had not again seen the men, after the Squire had left him (Squire), nor had he (Squire) heard them. To him (Squire) the parson said nothing of his (parson) encounter, and nothing of that blow on the man's back. From thence Mr. Fenwick went on to the town, and the ladies returned to the Vicarage.

The only person whom the parson at once consulted was the surgeon,--Dr. Cuttenden, as he (parson) was called. No man with an injured shoulder-blade had come to him (parson) last night or that morning. A man, he (man) said, might receive a very violent blow on his (man) back, in the manner in which the fellow had been struck, and might be disabled for days from any great personal exertion, without having a bone broken. If the blade of his (fellow) shoulder were broken, the man--so thought the doctor--could not travel far on foot, would hardly be able to get away to any of the neighbouring towns unless he (man) were carried. Of Sam Brattle the parson said nothing to the doctor; but when he (parson) had finished his (parson) morning's work about the town, he (parson) walked on to the mill.

In the mean time the two ladies remained at home at the Parsonage. The excitement occasioned by the events of the previous night was probably a little damaged by the knowledge that Mr. Gilmore was coming. The coming of Mr. Gilmore on this occasion was so important that even the terrible idea of burglars, and the sensation arising from the use of that deadly weapon which had been produced at the breakfast table during the morning, were robbed of some of their interest. They did not keep possession of the minds of the two ladies as they would have done had there been no violent interrupting cause. But here was the violent interrupting cause, and by the time that lunch was on the table, Sam Brattle and his (Brattle) comrades were forgotten.

Very little was said between the two women on that morning respecting Mr. Gilmore. Mrs. Fenwick, who had allowed herself to be convinced that Mary would act with great impropriety if she (Mary) did not accept the man, thought that further speech might only render her (Mary) friend obstinate. Mary, who knew the inside of her (Mary) friend's mind very clearly, and who loved and respected her (Mary) friend, could hardly fix her (Mary) own mind. During the past night it had been fixed, or nearly fixed, two different ways. She (Mary) had first determined that she (Mary) would refuse her (Mary) lover,--as to which resolve, for some hours or so, she (Mary) had been very firm; then that she (Mary) would accept him (lover),--as to which she (Mary) had ever, when most that way inclined, entertained some doubt as to the possibility of her (Mary) uttering that word

``Yes.'' (she)

``If it be that other women don't love better than I love him (father), I wonder that they ever get married at all,'' (she)
she (Mary) said to herself.

She (Mary) was told that she (Mary) was wrong to keep the man in suspense, and she (Mary) believed it. Had she (Mary) not been so told, she (Mary) would have thought that some further waiting would have been of the three alternatives the best.

``I shall be upstairs with the bairns,'' (Mrs. Fenwick)
said Mrs. Fenwick, as she (Fenwick) left the dining-room after lunch,
``so that if you prefer the garden to the drawing-room, it will be free.'' (she)

``Oh dear, how solemn and ceremonious you make it.'' (unknown)

``It is solemn, Mary; I don't know how anything can be more solemn, short of going to heaven or the other place. But I really don't see why there should be any doubt or difficulty.'' (Mary/Mary Lowther/MARY LOWTHER)

There was something in the tone in which these words were said which almost made Mary Lowther again decide against the man. The man had a home and an income, and was Squire of the parish; and therefore there need be no difficulty! When she (Lowther) compared Mr. Fenwick and Mr. Gilmore together, she (Lowther) found that she (Lowther) liked Mr. Fenwick the best. She (Lowther) thought him (Fenwick) to be the more clever, the higher spirited, the most of a man of the two. She (Lowther) certainly was not the least in love with her (Lowther) friend's husband; but then she (Lowther) was just as little in love with Mr. Gilmore.

To declare a passion to the girl he (Gilmore) loves may be very pleasant work to the man who feels almost sure that his (man) answer will not be against him (man). It may be an easy task enough even when there is a doubt. The very possession of the passion,--or even its pretence,--gives the man a liberty which he (man) has a pleasure and a pride in using. But this is the case when the man dashes boldly at his (man) purpose without preconcerted arrangements. Such pleasure, if it ever was a pleasure to him (man),--such excitement at least, was come and gone with Harry Gilmore. He (Gilmore) had told his (Gilmore) tale, and had been desired to wait. The servant out of place, however, would have had this advantage, that he (servant) would receive his (servant) answer without the necessity of further eloquence on his (servant) own part. She (Lowther) had begun to doubt whether it would ever be given to her (Lowther) to love,--to love as her (Lowther) friend Janet loved Frank Fenwick. ``That he (Gilmore) may not be pestered by having me near him (Gilmore). I think it will be better for him (Gilmore) that I should go.'' (unknown)

``And he (Gilmore) is to ask you again?'' (unknown)

``He (Gilmore) says that he (Gilmore) will--in three months. But you should tell him (Gilmore) that it will be better that he (Gilmore) should not. I would advise him (Gilmore) to travel,--if I were his (Gilmore) friend, like you.'' (unknown)

``And leave all his (Gilmore) duties, and his (Gilmore) pleasures, and his (Gilmore) house, and his (Gilmore) property, because of your face and figure, my dear! I don't think any woman is worth so much to a man.'' (Mary/Mary Lowther/MARY LOWTHER)

``I was thinking of his (man) own speech about himself, Janet, not of my worth. It does not astonish you more than it does me that such a man as Mr. Gilmore should be perplexed in spirit for such a cause. But he (man) says that he (man) is perplexed.'' (unknown)

``Of course he (man) is perplexed, and of course I was in joke. Only it does seem so hard upon him (man)! I should like to shake you till you fell into his (man) arms. That is the way old maids are made. If you married Harry, by the time your first child was born you would think that he (Harry) was Jupiter,--just as I think that Frank is.'' (Mrs. Fenwick)

Mrs. Fenwick owned, however, that as matters stood at present, it would be best that Mary should return home; and letters were written that afternoon to say that she (Mary) would be at Loring by the middle of next week.

The Vicar was not seen till dinner-time, and then he (Vicar) came home in considerable perplexity of spirit. It was agreed between the two women that the fate of Harry Gilmore, as far as it had been decided, should be told to Mr. Fenwick by his (Fenwick) wife; and she (wife), though she (wife) was vexed, and almost angry with Mary, promised to make the best of it.

said Mrs. Fenwick.

said he (parson).
``What she (maids) says herself would be the best for him (man). He (man)'ll break up and go away for a time, and then, when he (man) comes back, there'll be somebody else. She (maids)'ll live to repent it.'' (unknown)

said the parson.

She (Mary) believed of herself that she (Mary) was much to blame in that she (Mary) could not fall in love with Harry Gilmore. Mrs. Fenwick had also asked a question or two about Sam Brattle during the dressing of her (Fenwick) husband; but he (Brattle) had declined to say anything on that subject till they two should be secluded together for the night.

CHAPTER V.

THE MILLER.

Mr. Fenwick reached Brattle's mill about two o'clock in the day. During the whole morning, while saying comfortable words to old women, and gently rebuking young maidens, he (Fenwick) had been thinking of Sam Brattle and his (Brattle) offences. He (Brattle) had not been in the parish very long, not over five or six years, but he (Brattle) had been there long enough to see Sam grow out of boyhood into manhood; and at his (Sam) first coming to the parish, for the first two or three years, the lad had been a favourite with him (lad). Young Brattle could run well, leap well, fish well, and do a good turn of work about his (Young) father's mill. And he (Young) could also read and write, and cast accounts, and was a clever fellow. The parson, though he (parson) had tried his (parson) hand with energy at making the man, had, perhaps, done something towards marring him (parson); and it may be that some feeling of this was on Mr. Fenwick's conscience. A gentleman's favourite in a country village, when of Sam Brattle's age, is very apt to be spoiled by the kindness that is shown to him (Brattle). Sam had spent many a long afternoon fishing with the parson, but those fishing days were now more than two years gone by. It had been understood that Sam was to assist his (Sam) father at the mill; and much good advice as to his (Sam) trade the lad had received from Mr. Fenwick. There ought to be no more fishing for the young miller, except on special holiday occasions,--no more fishing, at least, during the hours required for milling purposes. So Mr. Fenwick had said frequently. Nevertheless the old miller attributed his (Fenwick) son's idleness in great part to the parson's conduct, and he (Fenwick) had so told the parson more than once. Of late Sam Brattle had certainly not been a good son, had neglected his (son) work, disobeyed his (son) father, and brought trouble on a household which had much suffering to endure independently of that which he (son) might bring upon it.

Jacob Brattle was a man at this time over sixty-five years of age, and every year of the time had been spent in that mill. He (Brattle) had never known another occupation or another home, and had very rarely slept under another roof. He (Brattle) had married the daughter of a neighbouring farmer, and had had some twelve or fourteen children. There were at this time six still living. He (Brattle) himself had ever been a hardworking, sober, honest man. But he (man) was cross-grained, litigious, moody, and tyrannical. He (man) held his (man) mill and about a hundred acres of adjoining meadow land at a rent in which no account was taken either of the building or of the mill privileges attached to it. He (man) paid simply for the land at a rate per acre, which, as both he (man) and his (man) landlord well knew, would make it acceptable on the same terms to any farmer in the parish; and neither for his (farmer) mill, nor for his (farmer) land, had he (farmer) any lease, nor had his (farmer) father or his (farmer) grandfather had leases before him (farmer). Though he (farmer) was a clever man in his (farmer) way, he (farmer) hardly knew what a lease was. He (farmer) doubted whether his (farmer) landlord could dispossess him (farmer) as long as he (farmer) paid his (farmer) rent, but he (farmer) was not sure. But of this he (farmer) thought he (farmer) was sure,--that were Mr. Gilmore to attempt to do such a thing, all Wiltshire would cry out against the deed, and probably the heavens would fall and crush the doer. He (doer) was a man with an unlimited love of justice; but the justice which he (doer) loved best was justice to himself. He (doer) brooded over injuries done to him (doer),--injuries real or fancied,--till he (doer) taught himself to wish that all who hurt him (doer) might be crucified for the hurt they did to him (doer). He (doer) never forgot, and never wished to forgive. If any prayer came from him (doer), it was a prayer that his (doer) own heart might be so hardened that when vengeance came in his (doer) way he (doer) might take it without stint against the trespasser of the moment. And yet he (doer) was not a cruel man. He (doer) would almost despise himself, because when the moment for vengeance did come, he (doer) would abstain from vengeance. He (doer) would dismiss a disobedient servant with curses which would make one's hair stand on end, and would hope within his (doer) heart of hearts that before the end of the next week the man with his (man) wife and children might be in the poorhouse. When the end of the next week came, he (man) would send the wife meat, and would give the children bread, and would despise himself for doing so. In matters of religion he (man) was an old Pagan, going to no place of worship, saying no prayer, believing in no creed,--with some vague idea that a supreme power would bring him (man) right at last, if he (man) worked hard, robbed no one, fed his (man) wife and children, and paid his (man) way. To pay his (man) way was the pride of his (man) heart; to be paid on his (man) way was its joy.

In that matter of his (man) quarrel with his (man) landlord he (man) was very bitter. The Squire's father some fifteen years since had given to the miller a verbal promise that the house and mill should be repaired. The old Squire had not been a good man of business, and had gone on with his (Squire) tenants very much as he (Squire) had found them, without looking much into the position of each. But he (Squire) had, no doubt, said something that amounted to a promise on his (Squire) own account as to these repairs. He (Squire) had died soon after, and the repairs had not been effected. A year after his (Squire) death an application,--almost a demand,--was made upon our Squire by the miller, and the miller had been wrathful even when the Squire said that he (Squire) would look into it. The Squire did look into it, and came to the conclusion that as he (Squire) received no rent at all for the house and mill, and as his (Squire) own property would be improved if the house and mill were made to vanish, and as he (Squire) had no evidence whatever of any undertaking on his (Squire) father's part, as any such promise on his (Squire) father's part must simply have been a promise of a gift of money out of his (Squire) own pocket, and further as the miller was impudent, he (Squire) would not repair the mill. Ultimately he (Squire) offered L20 towards the repairs, which the miller indignantly refused. Readers will be able to imagine how pretty a quarrel there would thus be between the landlord and his (miller) tenant. When all this was commencing,--at the time, that is, of the old Squire's death,--Brattle had the name of being a substantial person; but misfortune had come upon him (Squire); doctors' bills had been very heavy, his (Squire) children had drained his (Squire) resources from him (Squire), and it was now known that it set him (Squire) very hard to pay his (Squire) way. In regard to the house and the mill, some absolutely essential repairs had been done at his (Squire) own costs; but the L20 had never been taken.

In some respects the man's fortune in life had been good. His (man) wife was one of those loving, patient, self-denying, almost heavenly human beings, one or two of whom may come across one's path, and who, when found, are generally found in that sphere of life to which this woman belonged. Among the rich there is that difficulty of the needle's eye; among the poor there is the difficulty of the hardness of their lives. And the miller loved this woman with a perfect love. He (miller) hardly knew that he (miller) loved her (woman) as he (miller) did. He (miller) could be harsh to her (woman) and tyrannical. He (miller) could say cutting words to her (woman). But at any time in his (miller) life he (miller) would have struck over the head, with his (miller) staff, another man who should have said a word to hurt her (woman). They had lost many children; but of the six who remained, there were four of whom they might be proud. The eldest was a farmer, married and away, doing well in a far part of the county, beyond Salisbury, on the borders of Hampshire. The father in his (father) emergencies had almost been tempted to ask his (father) son for money; but hitherto he (father) had refrained. A daughter was married to a tradesman at Warminster, and was also doing well. A second son who had once been sickly and weak, was a scholar in his (son) way, and was now a schoolmaster, also at Warminster, and in great repute with the parson of the parish there. There was a second daughter, Fanny, at home, a girl as good as gold, the glory and joy and mainstay of her (girl) mother, whom even the miller could not scold,--whom all Bullhampton loved. But she (girl) was a plain girl, brown, and somewhat hard-visaged;--a morsel of fruit as sweet as any in the garden, but one that the eye would not select for its outside grace, colour, and roundness. Then there were the two younger. Of Sam, the youngest of all, who was now twenty-one, something has already been said. Between him (Sam) and Fanny there was,--perhaps it will be better to say there had been,--another daughter. Of all the flock Carry had been her (daughter) father's darling. She (daughter) had not been brown or hard-visaged. She (daughter) was such a morsel of fruit as men do choose, when allowed to range and pick through the whole length of the garden wall. Fair she (daughter) had been, with laughing eyes, and floating curls; strong in health, generous in temper, though now and again with something of her (daughter) father's humour. To her (daughter) mother's eye she (daughter) had never been as sweet as Fanny; but to her (Fanny) father she (Fanny) had been as bright and beautiful as the harvest moon. Now she (Fanny) was a thing, somewhere, never to be mentioned! Any man who would have named her (Fanny) to her (Fanny) father's ears, would have encountered instantly the force of his (father) wrath. This was so well known in Bullhampton that there was not one who would dare to suggest to him (father) even that she (Fanny) might be saved. But her (Fanny) mother prayed for her (mother) daily, and her (mother) father thought of her (mother) always. It was a great lump upon him (father), which he (father) must bear to his (father) grave; and for which there could be no release. He (father) did not know whether it was his (father) mind, his (father) heart, or his (father) body that suffered. He (father) only knew that it was there,--a load that could never be lightened. What comfort was it to him (father) now, that he (father) had beaten a miscreant to death's door--that he (father), with his (father) old hands, had nearly torn the wretch limb from limb--that he (father) had left him (father) all but lifeless, and had walked off scatheless, nobody daring to put a finger on him (father)? The man had been pieced up by some doctor, and was away in Asia, in Africa, in America--soldiering somewhere. He (man) had been a lieutenant in those days, and was probably a lieutenant still. It was nothing to old Brattle where he (lieutenant) was. Had he (lieutenant) been able to drink the fellow's blood to the last drop, it would not have lightened his (lieutenant) load an ounce. He (lieutenant) knew that it was so now. Nothing could lighten it;--not though an angel could come and tell him (angel) that his (angel) girl was a second Magdalen. The Brattles had ever held up their heads. The women, at least, had always been decent.

Jacob Brattle, himself, was a low, thickset man, with an appearance of great strength, which was now submitting itself, very slowly, to the hand of time. He (Brattle) had sharp green eyes, and shaggy eyebrows, with thin lips, and a square chin, a nose which, though its shape was aquiline, protruded but little from his (Brattle) face. His (Brattle) forehead was low and broad, and he (Brattle) was seldom seen without a flat hat upon his (Brattle) head. His (Brattle) hair and very scanty whiskers were gray; but, then too, he (Brattle) was gray from head to foot. The colour of his (Brattle) trade had so clung to him (Brattle), that no one could say whether that grayish whiteness of his (Brattle) face came chiefly from meal or from sorrow. He (Brattle) was a silent, sad, meditative man, thinking always of the evil things that had been done to him (Brattle).

CHAPTER VI.

BRATTLE``S MILL.

When Mr. Fenwick reached the mill, he (Fenwick) found old Brattle sitting alone on a fixed bench in front of the house door with a pipe in his (Fenwick) mouth. Mary Lowther was quite right in saying that the mill, in spite of its dilapidations,--perhaps by reason of them,--was as pretty as anything in Bullhampton. In the first place it was permeated and surrounded by cool, bright, limpid little streams. One of them ran right through it, as it were, passing between the dwelling-house and the mill, and turning the wheel, which was there placed. This course was, no doubt, artificial, and the water ran more rapidly in it than it did in the neighbouring streamlets. There were sluice-gates, too, by which it could be altogether expelled, or kept up to this or that height; and it was a river absolutely under man's control, in which no water-god could take delight. But there were other natural streams on each side of the building, the one being the main course of the Avon, and the other some offspring of a brooklet, which joined its parent two hundred yards below, and fifty yards from the spot at which the ill-used working water was received back into its mother's idle bosom. Mill and house were thatched, and were very low. There were garrets in the roof, but they were so shaped that they could hardly be said to have walls to them at all, so nearly were they contained by the sloping roof. In front of the building there ran a road,--which after all was no more than a private lane. It crossed the smaller stream and the mill-run by two wooden bridges; but the river itself had been too large for the bridge-maker's efforts, and here there was a ford, with stepping-stones for foot passengers. The banks on every side were lined with leaning willows, which had been pollarded over and over again, and which with their light-green wavy heads gave the place, from a distance, the appearance of a grove. There was a little porch in front of the house, and outside of that a fixed seat, with a high back, on which old Brattle was sitting when the parson accosted him (parson). He (parson) did not rise when Mr. Fenwick addressed him (Fenwick); but he (Fenwick) intended no want of courtesy by not doing so. He (Fenwick) was on his (Fenwick) legs at business during nearly the whole of the day, and why should he (Fenwick) not rest his (Fenwick) old limbs during the few mid-day minutes which he (Fenwick) allowed himself for recreation?

``I thought I should catch you idle just at this moment,'' (the clergyman)
said the clergyman.

``No, Muster Fenwick, Sam is not here.'' (unknown)

This the old man said in a tone that seemed to signify some offence, or at least a readiness to take offence if more were said to him (man) about his (man) son. The clergyman did not sit down, but stood close over the father, looking down upon him (father); and the miller went on with his (miller) pipe gazing into the clear blue sky.

``I do want him (Fenwick), Mr. Brattle.'' (he)
Then he (miller) stopped, and there was a pause. The miller puffed his (miller) pipe, but said not a word.
``I do want him (Brattle). I fear, Mr. Brattle, he (Brattle)'s not coming to much good.'' (unknown)

``Who said as he (Brattle) was? I never said so. The lad'd have been well enough if other folks would have let him (lad) be.'' (unknown)

``I usually intend folks to know what I mean, Muster Fenwick. What's the good o' speaking else? If nobody hadn't a meddled with the lad, he (lad)'d been a good lad. But they did, and he (lad) ain't. That's all about it.'' (unknown)

``You'd better ax his (Fenwick) mother, Muster Fenwick. The truth is, I don't care much to be talking of him (Fenwick) at all. It's time I was in the mill, I believe. There's no one much to help me now, barring the hired man.'' (he)
So saying, he (miller) got up and passed into the mill without making the slightest form of salutation.

Mr. Fenwick paused for a minute, looking after the old man, and then went into the house. He (Fenwick) knew very well that his (Fenwick) treatment from the women would be very different to that which the miller had vouchsafed to him (miller); but on that very account it would be difficult for him (miller) to make his (miller) communication. He (miller) had, however, known all this before he (miller) came. Old Brattle would, quite of course, be silent, suspicious, and uncivil. It had become the nature of the man to be so, and there was no help for it. But the two women would be glad to see him (man),--would accept his (man) visit as a pleasure and a privilege; and on this account he (man) found it to be very hard to say unpleasant words to them. But the unpleasant words must be spoken. Neither in duty nor in kindness could he (man) know what he (man) had learned last night, and be silent on this matter to the young man's family. He (man) entered the house, and turned into the large kitchen or keeping-room on the left, in which the two women were almost always to be found. This was a spacious, square, low apartment, in which there was a long grate with various appurtenances for boiling, roasting, and baking. It was an old-fashioned apparatus, but Mrs. Brattle thought it to be infinitely more commodious than any of the newer-fangled ranges which from time to time she (Brattle) had been taken to see. Opposite to the fire-place there was a small piece of carpet, without which the stone floor would hardly have looked warm and comfortable. On the outer corner of this, half facing the fire, and half on one side of it, was an old oak arm-chair, made of oak throughout, but with a well-worn cushion on the seat of it, in which it was the miller's custom to sit when the work of the day was done. In this chair no one else would ever sit, unless Sam would do so occasionally, in bravado, and as a protest against his (Sam) father's authority. When he (Sam) did so his (Sam) mother would be wretched, and his (Sam) sister lately had begged him (Sam) to desist from the sacrilege. Close to this was a little round deal table, on which would be set the miller's single glass of gin and water, which would be made to last out the process of his (miller) evening smoking, and the candle, by the light of which, and with the aid of a huge pair of tortoise-shell spectacles, his (miller) wife would sit and darn her (wife) husband's stockings. She (wife) also had her (wife) own peculiar chair in this corner, but she (wife) had never accustomed herself to the luxury of arms to lean on, and had no cushion for her (wife) own comfort. There were various dressers, tables, and sideboards round the room, and a multiplicity of dishes, plates, and bowls, all standing in their proper places. But though the apartment was called a kitchen,--and, in truth, the cookery for the family was done here,--there was behind it, opening out to the rear, another kitchen in which there was a great boiler, and a huge oven never now used. The necessary but unsightly doings of kitchen life were here carried on, out of view. He (their), indeed, would have been fastidious who would have hesitated, on any score of cleanliness or niceness, to sit and eat at the long board on which the miller's dinner was daily served, or would have found it amiss to sit at that fire and listen to the ticking of the great mahogany-cased clock, which stood in the corner of the room. On the other side of the broad opening passage Mrs. Brattle had her (Brattle) parlour. Doubtless this parlour added something to the few joys of her (Brattle) life; though how it did so, or why she (Brattle) should have rejoiced in it, it would be very difficult to say. She (Brattle) never entered it except for the purpose of cleaning and dusting. But it may be presumed that it was a glory to her (Brattle) to have a room carpeted, with six horsehair chairs, and a round table, and a horsehair sofa, and an old mirror over the fireplace, and a piece of worsted-work done by her (Brattle) daughter and framed like a picture, hanging up on one of the walls. But there must have come from it, we should say, more of regret than of pleasure; for when that room was first furnished, under her (Brattle) own auspices, and when those horsehair chairs were bought with a portion of her (Brattle) own modest dowry, doubtless she (Brattle) had intended that these luxuries should be used by her (Brattle) and hers. But they never had been so used. The day for using them had never come. Her (Brattle) husband never, by any chance, entered the apartment. To him (husband) probably, even in his (husband) youth, it had been a woman's gewgaw, useless, but allowable as tending to her (woman) happiness. Now the door was never even opened before his (husband) eye. His (husband) last interview with Carry had been in that room,--when he (husband) had laid his (husband) curse upon her (woman), and bade her (woman) begone before his (husband) return, so that his (husband) decent threshold should be no longer polluted by her (woman) vileness.

On this side of the house there was a cross passage, dividing the front rooms from the back. At the end of this, looking to the front so as to have the parlour between it and the house-door, was the chamber in which slept Brattle and his (husband) wife. Here all those children had been born who had brought upon the household so many joys and so much sorrow. And behind, looking to the back on to the little plot of vegetables which was called the garden,--a plot in which it seemed that cabbages and gooseberry bushes were made to alternate,--there was a large store-room, and the chamber in which Fanny slept,--now alone, but which she (Fanny) had once shared with four sisters. Carry was the last one that had left her (Fanny); and now Fanny hardly dared to name the word sister above her (Fanny) breath. She (Fanny) could speak, indeed, of Sister Jay, the wife of the prosperous ironmonger at Warminster; but of sisters by their Christian names no mention was ever made.

Upstairs there were garrets, one of which was inhabited by Sam, when he (Sam) chose to reside at home; and another by the red-armed country lass, who was maid-of-all-work at Brattle Mill. When it has also been told that below the cabbage-plot there was an orchard, stretching down to the junction of the waters, the description of Brattle Mill will have been made.

CHAPTER VII.

THE MILLER``S WIFE.

When Mr. Fenwick entered the kitchen, Mrs. Brattle was sitting there alone. Her (Brattle) daughter was away, disposing of the remnants and utensils of the dinner-table. The old lady, with her (lady) spectacles on her (lady) nose, was sitting as usual with a stocking over her (lady) left arm. On the round table was a great open Bible, and, lying on the Bible, were sundry large worsted hose, which always seemed to Mr. Fenwick as though they must have undarned themselves as quickly as they were darned. Her (lady) Bible and her (lady) stockings furnished the whole of Mrs. Brattle's occupation from her (Brattle) dinner to her (Brattle) bed. In the morning, she (Brattle) would still occupy herself in matters of cookery, would peel potatoes, and prepare apples for puddings, and would look into the pot in which the cabbage was being boiled. But her (Brattle) stockings and her (Brattle) Bible shared together the afternoons of her (Brattle) week-days. On the Sundays there would only be the Bible, and then she (Brattle) would pass many hours of the day asleep. On every other Sunday morning she (Brattle) still walked to church and back,--going there always alone. There was no one now to accompany her (Brattle). Her (Brattle) husband never went,--never had gone,--to church, and her (Brattle) son now had broken away from his (son) good practices. On alternate mornings Fanny went, and also on every Sunday afternoon. Wet or dry, storm or sunshine, she (Fanny) always went; and her (Fanny) father, who was an old Pagan, loved her (Fanny) for her (Fanny) zeal. Mrs. Brattle was a slight-made old woman, with hair almost white peering out modestly from under her (Brattle) clean cap, dressed always in a brown stuff gown that never came down below her (Brattle) ankle. Her (Brattle) features were still pretty, small, and debonnaire, and there was a sweetness in her (Brattle) eyes that no observer could overlook. She (Brattle) was a modest, pure, high-minded woman,--whom we will not call a lady, because of her (lady) position in life, and because she (lady) darned stockings in a kitchen. In all other respects she (lady) deserved the name.

``I heard your voice outside with the master,'' (she)
she (lass) said, rising from her (lass) chair to answer the parson's salutation, and putting down her (lass) stockings first, and then her (lass) spectacles upon the book, so that the Bible was completely hidden;
``and I knew you would not go without saying a word to the old woman.'' (the parson)

I don't know that we've anything else to offer, but the quarantines are rare this year, they say;--though, no doubt, you have them better at the Vicarage?'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)

``Mrs. Brattle, I'm sorry that I have something to say that will vex you.'' (unknown)

''`Deed no, sir. I haven't set eyes on him (Sam) since before yesterday.'' (he)

The paganism of the old miller had often been the subject of converse between the parson and Mrs. Brattle, it being a matter on which she (Brattle) had many an unhappy thought. He (parson), groping darkly among subjects which he (parson) hardly dared to touch in her (Brattle) presence lest he (parson) should seem to unteach that in private which he (parson) taught in public, had subtlely striven to make her (Brattle) believe that though she (Brattle), through her (Brattle) faith, would be saved, he (parson), the husband, might yet escape that doom of everlasting fire, which to her (Brattle) was so stern a reality that she (Brattle) thought of its fury with a shudder whenever she (Brattle) heard of the world's wickedness. ``the master,'' (she)

Fanny promised, and so did the mother; but the promise was given in that tone which seemed to imply that nothing should be expected from its performance. Sam had long been deaf to the voices of the women of his (Sam) family, and, when his (Sam) father's anger would be hot against him (Sam), he (Sam) would simply go, and live where and how none of them knew. Among such men and women as the Brattles, parental authority must needs lie much lighter than it does with those who are wont to give much and to receive much. What obedience does the lad owe who at eighteen goes forth and earns his (lad) own bread? What is it to him (lad) that he (lad) has not yet reached man's estate? He (lad) has to do a man's work, and the price of it is his (lad) own, in his (lad) hands, when he (lad) has earned it. There is no curse upon the poor heavier than that which comes from the early breach of all ties of duty between fathers and their sons, and mothers and their daughters.

Mr. Fenwick, as he (Fenwick) passed out of the miller's house, saw Jacob Brattle at the door of the mill. He (Brattle) was tugging along some load, pulling it in at the door, and prevailing against the weakness of his (Brattle) age by the force of his (Brattle) energy. ``The long and the short of it is, Master Sam will turn to housebreaking, if somebody doesn't get hold of him (Sam).'' (unknown)

But, in spite of the cheeriness of his (parson) speech, the Vicar was anxious, and almost unhappy. After all that occurred in reference to himself and to Sam Brattle,--their former intimacies, the fish they had caught together, the rats they had killed together, the favour which he (Brattle), the parson of the parish, had shown to this lad, and especially after the evil things which had been said of himself because of this friendship on his (lad) part for one so much younger than himself, and so much his (lad) inferior in rank,--it would be to him (lad) a most grievous misfortune should he (lad) be called upon to acknowledge publicly Sam Brattle's iniquity, and more grievous still, if the necessity should be forced upon him (Brattle) of bringing Sam to open punishment. Fenwick knew well that diverse accusations had been made against him (Fenwick) in the parish regarding Sam. The Marquis of Trowbridge had said a word. Mr. Puddleham had said many words. The old miller himself had growled. Even Gilmore had expressed disapprobation. The Vicar, in his (Vicar) pride, had turned a deaf ear to them all. He (Vicar) began to fear now that possibly he (Vicar) had been wrong in the favours shown to Sam Brattle.

CHAPTER VIII.

THE LAST DAY.

-LSB-Illustration-RSB-

The parson's visit to the mill was on a Saturday. The next Sunday passed by very quietly, and nothing was seen of Mr. Gilmore at the Vicarage. He (Gilmore) was at church, and walked with the two ladies from the porch to their garden gate, but he (Gilmore) declined Mrs. Fenwick's invitation to lunch, and was not seen again on that day. The parson had sent word to Fanny Brattle during the service to stop a few minutes for him (parson), and had learned from her (Brattle) that Sam had not been at home last night. He (Sam) had also learned, before the service that morning, that very early on the Saturday, probably about four o'clock, two men had passed through Paul's Hinton with a huxter's cart and a pony. Now Paul's Hinton, or Hinton Saint Paul's as it should be properly called, was a long straggling village, six miles from Bullhampton, and half-way on the road to Market Lavington, to which latter place Sam had told his (Sam) sister that he (Sam) was going. Putting these things together, Mr. Fenwick did not in the least doubt but the two men in the cart were they who had been introduced to his (Fenwick) garden by young Brattle.

``I only hope,'' (the parson)
said the parson,
``that there's a good surgeon at Market Lavington. One of the gentlemen in that cart must have wanted him (surgeon), I take it.'' (the parson)
Then he (parson) thought that it might, perhaps, be worth his (parson) while to trot over to Lavington in the course of the week, and make inquiries.

On the Wednesday Mary Lowther was to go back to Loring. This seemed like a partial break-up of their establishment, both to the parson and his (parson) wife. Fenwick had made up his (Fenwick) mind that Mary was to be his (Fenwick) nearest neighbour for life, and had fallen into the way of treating her (Mary) accordingly, telling her (Mary) of things in the parish as he (Fenwick) might have done to the Squire's wife, presuming the Squire's wife to have been on the best possible terms with him (Squire). He (Squire) now regarded Mary as being almost an impostor. She (Mary) had taken him (Squire) in and obtained his (Squire) confidence under false pretences. It was true that she (Mary) might still come and fill the place that he (Squire) had appointed for her (Mary). He (Squire) rather thought that at last she (Mary) would do so. But he (Squire) was angry with her (Mary) because she (Mary) hesitated. She (Mary) was creating an unnecessary disturbance among them. She (Mary) had, he (Squire) thought, been now wooed long enough, and, as he (Squire) told his (Squire) wife more than once, was making an ass of herself. Mrs. Fenwick was not quite so hard in her (Fenwick) judgment, but she (Fenwick) also was tempted to be a little angry. She (Fenwick) loved her (Fenwick) friend Mary a great deal better than she (Fenwick) loved Mr. Gilmore, but she (Fenwick) was thoroughly convinced that Mary could not do better than accept a man whom she (Mary) owned that she (Mary) liked,--whom she (Mary), at any rate, liked so well that she (Mary) had not as yet rejected him (man). Therefore, although Mary was going, they were, both of them, rather savage with her (Mary).

The Monday passed by, also very quietly, and Mr. Gilmore did not come to them, but he (Gilmore) had sent a note to tell them that he (Gilmore) would walk down on the Tuesday evening to say good-bye to Miss Lowther. Early on the Wednesday Mr. Fenwick was to drive her (Lowther) to Westbury, whence the railway would take her (Lowther) round by Chippenham and Swindon to Loring. On the Tuesday morning she (Lowther) was very melancholy. Though she (Lowther) knew that it was right to go away, she (Lowther) greatly regretted that it was necessary. She (Lowther) was angry with herself for not having better known her (Lowther) own mind, and though she (Lowther) was quite sure that were Mr. Gilmore to repeat his (Gilmore) offer to her (Lowther) that moment, she (Lowther) would not accept it, nevertheless she (Lowther) thought ill of herself because she (Lowther) would not do so.

``I do believe,'' (she)
she (Lowther) said to herself,
``that I shall never like any man better.'' (she)
She (Lowther) knew well enough that if she (Lowther) was never brought to love any man, she (Lowther) never ought to marry any man; but she (Lowther) was not quite sure whether Janet was not right in telling her (Janet) that she (Janet) had formed erroneous notions of the sort of love she (Janet) ought to feel for the man whom she (Janet) should resolve to accept. Perhaps it was true that that kind of adoration which Janet entertained for her (Janet) husband was a feeling which came after marriage--a feeling which would spring up in her (Janet) own heart as soon as she (Janet) was the man's own wife, the mistress of his (man) house, the mother of his (man) children, the one human being for whose welfare he (man) was solicitous beyond that of all others. And this man did love her (mother). She (mother) had no doubt about that. And she (mother) was unhappy, too, because she (mother) felt that she (mother) had offended his (man) friends, and that they thought that she (mother) was not treating their friend well.

``Janet,'' (she)

What a trouble she (Mary) had been to them all! She (Mary) was thoroughly dissatisfied with herself; especially so because she (Mary) had fallen into those very difficulties which from early years she (Mary) had resolved that she (Mary) would avoid. She (Mary) had made up her (Mary) mind that she (Mary) would not flirt, that she (Mary) would never give a right to any man--or to any woman--to call her (woman) a coquette; that if love and a husband came in her (woman) way she (woman) would take them thankfully, and that if they did not, she (woman) would go on her (woman) path quietly, if possible, feeling no uneasiness, and certainly showing none, because the joys of a married life did not belong to her (woman). But now she (woman) had gotten herself into a mess, and she (woman) could not tell herself that it was not her (woman) own fault. Then she (woman) resolved again that in future she (woman) would go right. It could not but be that a woman could keep herself from floundering in these messes of half-courtship,--of courtship on one side, and doubt on the other,--if she (woman) would persistently adhere to some safe rule. Her (woman) rejection of Mr. Gilmore ought to have been unhesitating and certain from the first. She (woman) was sure of that now. She (woman) had been guilty of an absurdity in supposing that because the man had been in earnest, therefore she (woman) had been justified in keeping him (man) in suspense, for his (man) own sake. She (woman) had been guilty of an absurdity, and also of great self-conceit. She (woman) could do nothing now but wait till she (woman) should hear from him (man),--and then answer him (man) steadily. After what had passed she (woman) could not go to him (man) and declare that it was all over. He (man) was coming to-night, and she (woman) was nearly sure that he (man) would not say a word to her (woman) on the subject. If he (man) did,--if he (man) renewed his (man) offer,--then she (woman) would speak out. It was hardly possible that he (man) should do so, and therefore the trouble which she (woman) had created must remain.

As she (woman) thus resolved, she (woman) was leaning over the gate looking into the churchyard, not much observing the graves or the monuments or the beautiful old ivy-covered tower, or thinking of the dead that were lying there, or of the living who prayed there; but swearing to herself that for the rest of her (woman) life she (woman) would keep clear of, what she (woman) called, girlish messes. Like other young ladies she (woman) had read much poetry and many novels; but her (woman) sympathies had never been with young ladies who could not go straight through with their love affairs, from the beginning to the end, without flirtation of either an inward or an outward nature. Of all her (woman) heroines, Rosalind was the one she (Rosalind) liked the best, because from the first moment of her (Rosalind) passion she (Rosalind) knew herself and what she (Rosalind) was about, and loved her (Rosalind) lover right heartily. Of all girls in prose or poetry she (Rosalind) declared that Rosalind was the least of a flirt. She (Rosalind) meant to have the man, and never had a doubt about it. But with such a one as Flora MacIvor she (Flora) had no patience;--a girl who did and who didn't, who would and who wouldn't, who could and who couldn't, and who of all flirts was to her (Flora) the most nauseous! As she (Flora) was taking herself to task, accusing herself of being a Flora without the poetry and romance to excuse her (Flora), Mr. Fenwick came round from Farmer Trumbull's side of the church, and got over the stile into the churchyard.

``I want to beg your pardon, and to get you to forgive me. I know you have been angry with me.'' (unknown)

(Mary/Mary Lowther/MARY LOWTHER)

The usual courtesies of society demand that there shall be civility--almost flattering civility--from host to guest, and from guest to host; and yet how often does it occur that in the midst of these courtesies there is something that tells of hatred, of ridicule, or of scorn! How often does it happen that the guest knows that he (guest) is disliked, or the host knows that he (guest) is a bore!
