CHAPTER IX.

MISS MARRABLE.

Whatever may be the fact as to the rank and proper calling of Bullhampton, there can be no doubt that Loring is a town. There is a market-place, and a High Street, and a Board of Health, and a Paragon Crescent, and a Town Hall, and two different parish churches, one called St. Peter Lowtown, and the other St. Botolph's Uphill, and there are Uphill Street, and Lowtown Street, and various other streets. I never heard of a mayor of Loring, but, nevertheless, there is no doubt as to its being a town. Nor did it ever return members to Parliament; but there was once, in one of the numerous bills that have been proposed, an idea of grouping it with Cirencester and Lechlade. All the world of course knows that this was never done; but the transient rumour of it gave the Loringites an improved position, and justified that little joke about a live dog being better than a dead lion, with which the parson at Bullhampton regaled Miss Lowther at the time.

All the fashion of Loring dwelt, as a matter of course, at Uphill. Lowtown was vulgar, dirty, devoted to commercial and manufacturing purposes, and hardly owned a single genteel private house. There was the parsonage, indeed, which stood apart from its neighbours, inside great tall slate-coloured gates, and which had a garden of its own. But except the clergyman, who had no choice in the matter, nobody who was anybody lived at Lowtown. There were three or four factories there,--in and out of which troops of girls would be seen passing twice a day, in their ragged, soiled, dirty mill dresses, all of whom would come out on Sunday dressed with a magnificence that would lead one to suppose that trade at Loring was doing very well. Whether trade did well or ill, whether wages were high or low, whether provisions were cheap in price, whether there were peace or war between capital and labour, still there was the Sunday magnificence. What a blessed thing it is for women,--and for men too certainly,--that there should be a positive happiness to the female sex in the possession, and in exhibiting the possession, of bright clothing! It is almost as good for the softening of manners, and the not permitting of them to be ferocious, as is the faithful study of the polite arts. At Loring the manners of the mill hands, as they were called, were upon the whole good,--which I believe was in a great degree to be attributed to their Sunday magnificence.

The real West-end of Loring was understood by all men to lie in Paragon Crescent, at the back of St. Botolph's Church. The whole of this Crescent was built, now some twenty years ago, by Mrs. Fenwick's father, who had been clever enough to see that as mills were made to grow in the low town, houses for wealthy people to live in ought to be made to grow in the high town. He (father) therefore built the Paragon, and a certain small row of very pretty houses near the end of the Paragon, called Balfour Place,--and had done very well, and had made money; and now lay asleep in the vaults below St. Botolph's Church. No inconsiderable proportion of the comfort of Bullhampton parsonage is due to Mr. Balfour's success in that achievement of Paragon Crescent. There were none of the family left at Loring. The widow had gone away to live at Torquay with a sister, and the only other child, another daughter, was married to that distinguished barrister on the Oxford circuit, Mr. Quickenham. Mr. Quickenham and our friend the parson were very good friends; but they did not see a great deal of each other, Mr. Fenwick not going up very often to London, and Mr. Quickenham being unable to use the Vicarage of Bullhampton when on his (Quickenham) own circuit. As for the two sisters, they had very strong ideas about their husbands' professions; Sophia Quickenham never hesitating to declare that one was life, and the other stagnation; and Janet Fenwick protesting that the difference to her (Fenwick) seemed to be almost that between good and evil. They wrote to each other perhaps once a quarter. But the Balfour family was in truth broken up.

Miss Marrable, Mary Lowther's aunt, lived, of course, at Uphill; but not in the Crescent, nor yet in Balfour Place. She (Marrable) was an old lady with very modest means, whose brother had been rector down at St. Peter's, and she (Marrable) had passed the greatest part of her (Marrable) life within those slate-coloured gates. When he (Peter) died, and when she (Marrable), almost exactly at the same time, found that it would be expedient that she (Marrable) should take charge of her (Marrable) niece, Mary, she (Marrable) removed herself up to a small house in Botolph Lane, in which she (Marrable) could live decently on her (Marrable) L300 a year. It must not be surmised that Botolph Lane was a squalid place, vile, or dirty, or even unfashionable. It was narrow and old, having been inhabited by decent people long before the Crescent, or even Mr. Balfour himself, had been in existence; but it was narrow and old, and the rents were cheap, and here Miss Marrable was able to live, and occasionally to give tea-parties, and to provide a comfortable home for her (Marrable) niece, within the limits of her (Marrable) income. Miss Marrable was herself a lady of very good family, the late Sir Gregory Marrable having been her (Marrable) uncle; but her (Marrable) only sister had married a Captain Lowther, whose mother had been first cousin to the Earl of Periwinkle; and therefore on her (mother) own account, as well as on that of her (mother) niece, Miss Marrable thought a good deal about blood. She (Marrable) was one of those ladies,--now few in number,--who within their heart of hearts conceive that money gives no title to social distinction, let the amount of money be ever so great, and its source ever so stainless. Rank to her (Marrable) was a thing quite assured and ascertained, and she (Marrable) had no more doubt as to her (Marrable) own right to pass out of a room before the wife of a millionaire than she (Marrable) had of the right of a millionaire to spend his (millionaire) own guineas. She (Marrable) always addressed an attorney by letter as Mister, raising up her (Marrable) eyebrows when appealed to on the matter, and explaining that an attorney is not an esquire. She (Marrable) had an idea that the son of a gentleman, if he (son) intended to maintain his (son) rank as a gentleman, should earn his (son) income as a clergyman, or as a barrister, or as a soldier, or as a sailor. Those were the professions intended for gentlemen. She (Marrable) would not absolutely say that a physician was not a gentleman, or even a surgeon; but she (Marrable) would never allow to physic the same absolute privileges which, in her (Marrable) eyes, belonged to law and the church. There might also possibly be a doubt about the Civil Service and Civil Engineering; but she (Marrable) had no doubt whatever that when a man touched trade or commerce in any way he (man) was doing that which was not the work of a gentleman. He (gentleman) might be very respectable, and it might be very necessary that he (gentleman) should do it; but brewers, bankers, and merchants, were not gentlemen, and the world, according to Miss Marrable's theory, was going astray, because people were forgetting their landmarks.

As to Miss Marrable herself nobody could doubt that she (Marrable) was a lady; she (Marrable) looked it in every inch. There were not, indeed, many inches of her (Marrable), for she (Marrable) was one of the smallest, daintiest, little old women that ever were seen. But now, at seventy, she (Marrable) was very pretty, quite a woman to look at with pleasure. Her (Marrable) feet and hands were exquisitely made, and she (Marrable) was very proud of them. She (Marrable) wore her (Marrable) own grey hair of which she (Marrable) showed very little, but that little was always exquisitely nice. Her (Marrable) caps were the perfection of caps. Her (Marrable) green eyes were bright and sharp, and seemed to say that she (Marrable) knew very well how to take care of herself. Her (Marrable) mouth, and nose, and chin, were all well-formed, small, shapely, and concise, not straggling about her (Marrable) face as do the mouths, noses, and chins of some old ladies--ay, and of some young ladies also. Had it not been that she (Marrable) had lost her (Marrable) teeth, she (Marrable) would hardly have looked to be an old woman. Her (Marrable) health was perfect. She (Marrable) herself would say that she (Marrable) had never yet known a day's illness. She (Marrable) dressed with the greatest care, always wearing silk at and after luncheon. She (Marrable) dressed three times a day, and in the morning would come down in what she (Marrable) called a merino gown. But then, with her (Marrable), clothes never seemed to wear out. Her (Marrable) motions were so slight and delicate, that the gloss of her (Marrable) dresses would remain on them when the gowns of other women would almost have been worn to rags. She (Marrable) was never seen of an afternoon or evening without gloves, and her (Marrable) gloves were always clean and apparently new. She (Marrable) went to church once on Sundays in winter, and twice in summer, and she (Marrable) had a certain very short period of each day devoted to Bible reading; but at Loring she (Marrable) was not reckoned to be among the religious people. Indeed, there were those who said that she (Marrable) was very worldly-minded, and that at her (Marrable) time of life she (Marrable) ought to devote herself to other books than those which were daily in her (Marrable) hands. Pope, Dryden, Swift, Cowley, Fielding, Richardson, and Goldsmith, were her (Marrable) authors. She (Marrable) read the new novels as they came out, but always with critical comparisons that were hostile to them. Fielding, she (Marrable) said, described life as it was; whereas Dickens had manufactured a kind of life that never had existed, and never could exist. The pathos of Esmond was very well, but Lady Castlemaine was nothing to Clarissa Harlowe. As for poetry, Tennyson, she (Clarissa) said, was all sugar-candy; he (Tennyson) had neither the common sense, nor the wit, nor, as she (Clarissa) declared, to her (Clarissa) ear the melody of Pope. All the poets of the present century, she (Clarissa) declared, if put together, could not have written the Rape of the Lock. Pretty as she (Clarissa) was, and small, and nice, and lady-like, I think she (Clarissa) liked her (Clarissa) literature rather strong. It is certain that she (Clarissa) had Smollett's novels in a cupboard up-stairs, and it was said that she (Clarissa) had been found reading one of Wycherley's plays.

The strongest point in her (Clarissa) character was her (Clarissa) contempt of money. Not that she (Clarissa) had any objection to it, or would at all have turned up her (Clarissa) nose at another hundred a year had anybody left to her (Clarissa) such an accession of income; but that in real truth she (Clarissa) never measured herself by what she (Clarissa) possessed, or others by what they possessed. She (Clarissa) was as grand a lady to herself, eating her (Clarissa) little bit of cold mutton, or dining off a tiny sole, as though she (Clarissa) sat at the finest banquet that could be spread. When she (Clarissa) went out herself she (Clarissa) never took one of the common street flies, but paid eighteen pence extra to get a brougham from the Dragon. He (Gilmore) was a country gentleman, living on his (Gilmore) own acres, a justice of the peace, whose father and grandfather and great-grandfather had occupied exactly the same position. ``Yes, my dear, I am glad to have you back again. Of course I have been a little lonely, but I bear that kind of thing better than most people. Thank God, my eyes are good.'' (unknown)

CHAPTER X.

CRUNCH``EM CAN``T BE HAD.

Mr. Fenwick had intended to have come home round by Market Lavington, after having deposited Miss Lowther at the Westbury Station, with the view of making some inquiry respecting the gentleman with the hurt shoulder; but he (gentleman) had found the distance to be too great, and had abandoned the idea. After that there was not a day to spare till the middle of the next week; so that it was nearly a fortnight after the little scene at the corner of the Vicarage garden wall before he (gentleman) called upon the Lavington constable and the Lavington doctor. From the latter he (gentleman) could learn nothing. No such patient had been to him (patient). But the constable, though he (patient) had not seen the two men, had heard of them. One was a man who in former days had frequented Lavington, Burrows by name, generally known as Jack the Grinder, who had been in every prison in Wiltshire and Somersetshire, but who had not,--so said the constable,--honoured Lavington for the last two years, till this his (constable) last appearance. He (constable) had, however, been seen there in company with another man, and had evidently been in a condition very unfit for work. He (constable) had slept one night at a low public-house, and had then moved on. The man had complained of a fall from the cart, and had declared that he (man) was black and blue all over; but it seemed to be clear that he (man) had no broken bones. Mr. Fenwick therefore was all but convinced that Jack the Grinder was the gentleman with whom he (gentleman) had had the encounter, and that the grinder's back had withstood that swinging blow from the life-preserver. Of the Grinder's companions nothing could be learned. The two men had taken the Devizes road out of Lavington, and beyond that nothing was known of them. When the parson mentioned Sam Brattle's name in a whisper, the Lavington constable shook his (constable) head. He (constable) knew all about old Jacob Brattle. A very respectable party was old Mr. Brattle in the constable's opinion. Nevertheless the constable shook his (Brattle) head when Sam Brattle's name was mentioned. Having learned so much, the parson rode home.

Two days after this, on a Friday, Fenwick was sitting after breakfast in his (Fenwick) study, at work on his (Fenwick) sermon for next Sunday, when he (Fenwick) was told that old Mrs. Brattle was waiting to see him (Fenwick). He (Fenwick) immediately got up, and found his (Fenwick) own wife and the miller's seated in the hall. It was not often that Mrs. Brattle made her (Brattle) way to the Vicarage, but when she (Brattle) did so she (Brattle) was treated with great consideration. It was still August, and the weather was very hot, and she (Brattle) had walked up across the water mead, and was tired. A glass of wine and a biscuit were pressed upon her (Brattle), and she (Brattle) was encouraged to sit and say a few indifferent words, before she (Brattle) was taken into the study and told to commence the story which had brought her (Brattle) so far. And there was a most inviting topic for conversation. The mill and the mill premises were to be put in order by the landlord. Mrs. Brattle affected to be rather dismayed than otherwise by the coming operations. The mill would have lasted their time, she (Brattle) thought,

``and as for them as were to come after them,--well! she (Brattle) didn't know. As things was now, perhaps, it might be that after all Sam would have the mill.'' (she)
But the trouble occasioned by the workmen would be infinite. How were they to live in the mean time, and where were they to go? It soon appeared, however, that all this had been already arranged. Milling must of course be stopped for a month or six weeks.
``Indeed, sir, feyther says that there won't be no more grinding much before winter.'' (unknown)
But the mill was to be repaired first, and then, when it became absolutely necessary to dismantle the house, they were to endeavour to make shift, and live in the big room of the mill itself, till their furniture should be put back again. Mrs. Fenwick, with ready good nature, offered to accommodate Mrs. Brattle and Fanny at the Vicarage; but the old woman declined with many protestations of gratitude. She (woman) had never left her (woman) old man yet, and would not do so now. The weather would be mild for awhile, and she (woman) thought that they could get through. By this time the glass of wine had been sipped to the bottom, and the parson, mindful of his (parson) sermon, had led the visitor into his (parson) study. She (woman) had come to tell that Sam at last had returned home.

``Why didn't you bring him (Sam) up with you, Mrs. Brattle?'' (an lady none)
Here was a question to ask of an old lady, whose dominion over her (lady) son was absolutely none! Sam had become so frightfully independent that he (Sam) hardly regarded the word of his (Sam) father, who was a man pre-eminently capable of maintaining authority, and would no more do a thing because his (Sam) mother told him (Sam) than because the wind whistled.

``It ain't a doing in that way, Mr. Fenwick. The Squire is allowing L200, and feyther is to get it done. Mister Mitchell is to see that it's done proper, no doubt.'' (unknown)

``And now tell me, Mrs. Brattle, what has Sam been about all the time that he (Sam) was away?'' (unknown)

``That's just what I cannot tell you, Mr. Fenwick.'' (unknown)

``Your husband has asked him (Fenwick), I suppose?'' (unknown)

``If he (Fenwick) has, he (Fenwick) ain't told me, Mr. Fenwick. I don't care to come between them with hints and jealousies, suspecting like. Our Fan says he (Fan)'s been out working somewhere Lavington way; but I don't know as she (Lavington) knows.'' (unknown)

``Was he (Fan) decent looking when he (Fan) came home?'' (unknown)

``He (Fan) wasn't much amiss, Mr. Fenwick. He (Fenwick) has that way with him (Fenwick) that he (Fenwick) most always looks decent;--don't he (Fenwick), sir?'' (unknown)

``Had he (Fenwick) any money?'' (unknown)

``He (Fenwick) had a some'at, because when he (Fenwick) was working, moving the big lumber as though for bare life, he (Fenwick) sent one of the boys for beer, and I see'd him (Fenwick) give the boy the money.'' (unknown)

``I'm sorry for it. I wish he (Fenwick)'d come back without a penny, and with hunger like a wolf in his (wolf) stomach, and with his (wolf) clothes all rags, so that he (wolf) might have had a taste of the suffering of a vagabond's life.'' (unknown)

``Just like the Prodigal Son. He (Son) would not have come back to his (Son) father had he (Son) not been driven by his (Son) own vices to live with the swine.'' (the mother)

``Perhaps it may be all well as it is. We will hope so at least, and to-morrow I will come down and see him (Son). You need not tell him (Son) that I am coming, unless he (Son) should ask where you have been.'' (he)
Then Mrs. Brattle took her (Brattle) leave, and the parson finished his (parson) sermon.

That afternoon he (parson) drove his (parson) wife across the county to visit certain friends at Charlicoats, and, both going and coming, could not keep himself from talking about the Brattles. In the first place, he (parson) thought that Gilmore was wrong not to complete the work himself.

``Of course he (Son)'ll see that the money is spent and all that, and no doubt in this way he (Son) may get the job done twenty or thirty pounds cheaper; but the Brattles have not interest enough in the place to justify it.'' (unknown)

``I suppose the old man liked it best so.'' (unknown)

Much as I like him (Sam),--or at any rate did like him (Sam),--I fear he (Sam) is going, or perhaps has gone, to the dogs. That those two men were housebreakers is as certain as that you sit there; and I cannot doubt but that he (Sam) has been with them over at Lavington or Devizes, or somewhere in that country.'' (unknown)

``But he (Sam) may, perhaps, never have joined them in anything of that kind.'' (unknown)

``A man is known by his (man) companions. I would not have believed it if I had not found him (man) with the men, and traced him (man) and them about the county together. You see that this fellow whom they call the Grinder was certainly the man I struck. I tracked him (man) to Lavington, and there he (man) was complaining of being sore all over his (man) body. I don't wonder that he (man) was sore. He (man) must be made like a horse to be no worse than sore. Well, then, that man and Sam were certainly in our garden together.'' (unknown)

``Give him (man) a chance, Frank.'' (unknown)

``Of course, I will give him (Frank) a chance. I will give him (Frank) the very best chance I can. I would do anything to save him (Frank),--but I can't help knowing what I know.'' (He)

He (Gilmore) had made very little to his (Gilmore) wife of the danger of the Vicarage being robbed, but he (Gilmore) could not but feel that there was danger. His (Gilmore) wife had brought with her (wife), among other plenishing for their household, a considerable amount of handsome plate, more than is, perhaps, generally to be found in country parsonages, and no doubt this fact was known, at any rate, to Sam Brattle. Had the men simply intended to rob the garden, they would not have run the risk of coming so near to the house windows. But then it certainly was true that Sam was not showing them the way. The parson did not quite know what to think about it, but it was clearly his (Sam) duty to be on his (Sam) guard.

That same evening he (Sam) sauntered across the corner of the churchyard to his (Sam) neighbour the farmer. Looking out warily for Bone'm, he (Sam) stood leaning upon the farm gate. Bone'm was not to be seen or heard, and therefore he (Sam) entered, and walked up to the back door, which indeed was the only door for entrance or egress that was ever used. There was a front door opening into a little ragged garden, but this was as much a fixture as the wall. As he (Sam) was knocking at the back door, it was opened by the farmer himself. Mr. Fenwick had called to inquire whether his (Fenwick) friend had secured for him (Fenwick),--as half promised,--the possession of a certain brother of Bone'm's, who was supposed to be of a very pugnacious disposition in the silent watches of the night.

``It's no go, parson.'' (unknown)

``Why not, Mr. Trumbull?'' (unknown)

``The truth is, there be such a deal of talk o' thieves about the country, that no one likes to part with such a friend as that. Muster Crickly, over at Imber, he (friend) have another big dog it's true, a reg`lar mastiff, but he (friend) do say that Crunch'em be better than the mastiff, and he (friend) won't let `un go, parson,--not for love nor money. I wouldn't let Bone'm go, I know; not for nothing.'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)
Then Mr. Fenwick walked back to the Vicarage, and was half induced to think that as Crunch'em was not to be had, it would be his (Fenwick) duty to sit up at night, and look after the plate box himself.

CHAPTER XI.

DON``T YOU BE AFEARD ABOUT ME.

On the following morning Mr. Fenwick walked down to the mill. There was a path all along the river, and this was the way he (Fenwick) took. He (Fenwick) passed different points as he (Fenwick) went, and he (Fenwick) thought of the trout he (Fenwick) had caught there, or had wished to catch, and he (Fenwick) thought also how often Sam Brattle had been with him (Brattle) as he (Brattle) had stood there delicately throwing his (Brattle) fly. In those days Sam had been very fond of him (Sam), had thought it to be a great thing to be allowed to fish with the parson, and had been reasonably obedient. Now Sam would not even come up to the Vicarage when he (Sam) was asked to do so. For more than a year after the close of those amicable relations the parson had behaved with kindness and almost with affection to the lad. He (parson) had interceded with the Squire when Sam was accused of poaching,--had interceded with the old miller when Sam had given offence at home,--and had even interceded with the constable when there was a rumour in the wind of offences something worse than these. Then had come the occasion on which Mr. Fenwick had told the father that unless the son would change his (Fenwick) course evil would come of it; and both father and son had taken this amiss. The father had told the parson to his (father) face that he (father), the parson, had led his (parson) son astray; and the son in his (son) revenge had brought housebreakers down upon his (son) old friend's premises.

``One hasn't to do it for thanks,'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)
said Mr. Fenwick, as he (Fenwick) became a little bitter while thinking of all this.
``I'll stick to him (son) as long as I can, if it's only for the old woman's sake,--and for the poor girl whom we used to love.'' (he)
Then he (Fenwick) thought of a clear, sweet, young voice that used to be so well known in his (Fenwick) village choir, and of the heavy curls, which it was a delight to him (Fenwick) to see. It had been a pleasure to him (Fenwick) to have such a girl as Carry Brattle in his (Fenwick) church, and now Carry Brattle was gone utterly, and would probably never be seen in a church again. These Brattles had suffered much, and he (Brattle) would bear with them, let the task of doing so be ever so hard.

The sound of workmen was to be already heard as he (Brattle) drew near to the mill. There were men there pulling the thatch off the building, and there were carts and horses bringing laths, lime, bricks, and timber, and taking the old rubbish away. As he (Brattle) crossed quickly by the slippery stones he (Brattle) saw old Jacob Brattle standing before the mill looking on, with his (Brattle) hands in his (Brattle) breeches pockets. He (Brattle) was too old to do much at such work as this,--work to which he (Brattle) was not accustomed--and was looking up in a sad melancholy way, as though it were a work of destruction, and not one of reparation.

``We shall have you here as smart as possible before long, Mr. Brattle,'' (the parson)
said the parson.

``I don't know much about smart, Muster Fenwick. The old place was a`most tumbling down,--but still it would have lasted out my time, I'm thinking. If t' Squire would 'a done it fifteen years ago, I'd 'a thanked un; but I don't know what to say about it now, and this time of year and all, just when the new grist would be coming in. If t' Squire would 'a thought of it in June, now. But things is contrary--a`most allays so.'' (the miller)
After this speech, which was made in a low, droning voice, bit by bit, the miller took himself off and went into the house.

At the back of the mill, perched on an old projecting beam, in the midst of dust and dirt, assisting with all the energy of youth in the demolition of the roof, Mr. Fenwick saw Sam Brattle. He (Fenwick) perceived at once that Sam had seen him (Sam); but the young man immediately averted his (Sam) eyes and went on with his (Sam) work. Then he (Sam) called to the lad, and Sam was constrained to answer

``Yes, Mr. Fenwick, I am here;--hard at work, as you see.'' (Sam/Sam Brattle/Brattle)

``I do see it, and wish you luck with your job. Spare me ten minutes, and come down and speak to me.'' (unknown)

``I am in such a muck now, Mr. Fenwick, that I do wish to go on with it, if you'll let me.'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)

But Mr. Fenwick, having taken so much trouble to get at the young man, was not going to be put off in this way.

``Never mind your muck for a quarter of an hour,'' (he)
he (Fenwick) said.

``Must!'' (Sam/Sam Brattle/Brattle)

``Afeard! Who talks of being afeard? Stop a moment, Mr. Fenwick, and I'll be with you;--not that I think it will do any good.'' (he)
Then slowly he (Sam) crept back along the beam and came down through the interior of the building.
``What is it, Mr. Fenwick? Here I am. I ain't a bit afeard of you at any rate.'' (unknown)

``No, I am not,'' (Sam/Sam Brattle/Brattle)

``You are a-harking back on it, ever so often.'' (unknown)

Do you know that the Squire recognised you that night as well as I?'' (unknown)

``The Squire ain't nothing to me, and if you've done with me now, Mr. Fenwick, I'll go back to my work.'' (Sam/Sam Brattle/Brattle)
So saying, Sam Brattle again mounted up to the roof, and the parson returned discomfited to the front of the building. He (parson) had not intended to see any of the family, but, as he (parson) was crossing the little bridge, meaning to go home round by the Privets, he (parson) was stopped by Fanny Brattle.

``I hope it will be all right now, Mr. Fenwick,'' (the girl)
the girl said.

``I hope so too, Fanny. But you and your mother should keep an eye on him (Fenwick), so that he (Fenwick) may know that his (Fenwick) goings and comings are noticed. It will be better always to ask him (Fenwick), though he (Fenwick) be ever so cross. Tell your mother I say so.'' (unknown)

CHAPTER XII.

BONE``M AND HIS (Fenwick) MASTER.

After leaving the mill Mr. Fenwick went up to the Squire, and, in contradiction, as it were, of all the hard things that he (Fenwick) had said to Sam Brattle, spoke to the miller's landlord in the lad's favour. He (Brattle) was hard at work now, at any rate; and seemed inclined to stick to his (Brattle) work. And there had been an independence about him (Brattle) which the parson had half liked, even while he (Brattle) had been offended at it. Gilmore differed altogether from his (Gilmore) friend.

``What was he (Gilmore) doing in your garden? What was he (Gilmore) doing hidden in Trumbull's hedge? When I see fellows hiding in ditches at night, I don't suppose that they're after much good.'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)
Mr. Fenwick made some lame apology, even for these offences. Sam had, perhaps, not really known the extent of the iniquity of the men with whom he (Sam) had associated, and had come up the garden probably with a view to the fruit. The matter was discussed at great length, and the Squire at last promised that he (Squire) would give Sam another chance in regard to his (Sam) own estimation of the young man's character.

On that same evening,--or, rather, after the evening was over, for it was nearly twelve o'clock at night,--Fenwick walked round the garden and the orchard with his (Fenwick) wife. There was no moon now, and the night was very dark. They stopped for a minute at the wicket leading into the churchyard, and it was evident to them that Bone'm, from the farmyard at the other side of the church, had heard them, for he (Fenwick) commenced a low growl, with which the parson was by this time well acquainted.

``Good dog, good dog,'' (the parson)
said the parson, in a low voice.
``I wish we had his (Gilmore) brother, I know.'' (unknown)

``He (Gilmore) would only be tearing the maids and biting the children,'' (Mrs. Fenwick)
said Mrs. Fenwick.
``I hate having a savage beast about.'' (unknown)

``But it would be so nice to catch a burglar and crunch him (burglar). I feel almost bloodthirsty since I hit that fellow with the life-preserver, and find that I didn't kill him (fellow).'' (unknown)

``I know, Frank, you're thinking about these thieves more than you like to tell me.'' (unknown)

``I was thinking just then, that if they were to come and take all the silver it wouldn't do much harm. We should have to buy German plate, and nobody would know the difference.'' (unknown)

``Suppose they murdered us all?'' (unknown)

``They never do that now. The profession is different from what it used to be. They only go where they know they can find a certain amount of spoil, and where they can get it without much danger. I don't think housebreakers ever cut throats in these days. They're too fond of their own.'' (unknown)
Then they both agreed that if these rumours of housebreakings were continued, they would send away the plate some day to be locked up in safe keeping at Salisbury. After that they went to bed.

On the next morning, the Sunday morning, at a few minutes before seven, the parson was awakened by his (parson) groom at his (parson) bedroom door.

``What is it, Roger?'' (he)
he (parson) asked.

``For the love of God, sir, get up! They've been and murdered Mr. Trumbull.'' (Mrs. Fenwick)

Mrs. Fenwick, who heard the tidings, screamed; and Mr. Fenwick was out of bed and into his (Fenwick) trousers in half a minute. In another half minute Mrs. Fenwick, clothed in her (Fenwick) dressing-gown, was up-stairs among her (Fenwick) children. No doubt she (Fenwick) thought that as soon as the poor farmer had been despatched, the murderers would naturally pass on into her (Fenwick) nursery. Mr. Fenwick did not believe the tidings. If a man be hurt in the hunting-field, it is always said that he (Fenwick)'s killed. If the kitchen flue be on fire, it is always said that the house is burned down. Something, however, had probably happened at Farmer Trumbull's; and down went the parson across the garden and orchard, and through the churchyard, as quick as his (parson) legs would carry him (parson). In the farmyard he (parson) found quite a crowd of men, including the two constables and three or four of the leading tradesmen in the village. The first thing that he (parson) saw was the dead body of Bone'm, the dog. He (parson) was stiff and stark, and had been poisoned.

``How's Mr. Trumbull?'' (he)
he (parson) asked, of the nearest by-stander.

``Laws, parson, ain't ye heard?'' (the man)
said the man.
``They've knocked his (parson) skull open with a hammer, and he (parson)'s as dead--as dead.'' (the parson)

Hearing this, the parson turned round, and made his (parson) way into the house. There was not a doubt about it. The farmer had been murdered during the night, and his (farmer) money carried off. Upstairs Mr. Fenwick made his (Fenwick) way to the farmer's bedroom, and there lay the body. Mr. Crittenden, the village doctor, was there; and a crowd of men, and an old woman or two. Among the women was Trumbull's sister, the wife of a neighbouring farmer, who, with her (sister) husband, a tenant of Mr. Gilmore's, had come over just before the arrival of Mr. Fenwick. The body had been found on the stairs, and it was quite clear that the farmer had fought desperately with the man or men before he (farmer) had received the blow which despatched him (farmer).

``I told `um how it be,--I did, I did, when he (parson) would 'a all that money by `um.'' (Mr. Trumbull/Trumbull)
This was the explanation given by Mr. Trumbull's sister, Mrs. Boddle.

It seemed that Trumbull had had in his (Trumbull) possession over a hundred and fifty pounds, of which the greater part was in gold, and that he (Trumbull) kept this in a money-box in his (Trumbull) bedroom. One of the two women who lived in his (Trumbull) service,--he (Trumbull) himself had been a widower without children,--declared that she (sister) had always known that at night he (Trumbull) took the box out of his (Trumbull) cupboard into bed with him (Trumbull). She (sister) had seen it there more than once when she (sister) had taken him (Trumbull) up drinks when he (Trumbull) was unwell. When first interrogated, she (sister) declared that she (sister) did not remember, at that moment, that she (sister) had ever told anybody; she (sister) thought she (sister) had never told anybody; at last, she (sister) would swear that she (sister) had never spoken a word about it to a single soul. She (sister) was supposed to be a good girl, had come of decent people, and was well known by Mr. Fenwick, of whose congregation she (sister) was one. Her (sister) name was Agnes Pope. The other servant was an elderly woman, who had been in the house all her (sister) life, but was unfortunately deaf. She (sister) had known very well about the money, and had always been afraid about it; had very often spoken to her (sister) master about it, but never a word to Agnes. She (Agnes) had been woken in the night,--that was, as it turned out, about 2 A.M.,--by the girl who slept with her (girl), and who declared that she (girl) had heard a great noise, as of somebody tumbling,--a very great noise indeed, as though there were ever so many people tumbling. For a long time, for perhaps an hour, they had lain still, being afraid to move. Then the elder woman had lighted a candle, and gone down from the garret in which they slept. The first thing she (woman) saw was the body of her (woman) master, in his (master) shirt, upon the stairs. She (woman) had then called up the only other human being who slept on the premises, a shepherd, who had lived for thirty years with Trumbull. This man had thrown open the house, and had gone for assistance, and had found the body of the dead dog in the yard.

Before nine o'clock the facts, as they have been told, were known everywhere, and the Squire was down on the spot. The man,--or, as it was presumed, men,--had entered by the unaccustomed front door, which was so contrived as to afford the easiest possible mode of getting into the house; whereas, the back door, which was used by everybody, had been bolted and barred with all care. The men must probably have entered by the churchyard and the back gate of the farmyard, as that had been found to be unlatched, whereas the gate leading out on to the road had been found closed. The farmer himself had always been very careful to close both these gates when he (farmer) let out Bone'm before going to bed. Poor Bone'm had been enticed to his (farmer) death by a piece of poisoned meat, thrown to him (farmer) probably some considerable time before the attack was made.

Who were the murderers? That of course was the first question. It need hardly be said with how sad a heart Mr. Fenwick discussed this matter with the Squire. Of course inquiry must be made of the manner in which Sam Brattle had passed the night. Heavens! how would it be with that poor family if he (Brattle) had been concerned in such an affair as this! And then there came across the parson's mind a remembrance that Agnes Pope and Sam Brattle had been seen by him (Brattle) together, on more Sundays than one. In his (Brattle) anxiety, and with much imprudence, he (Brattle) went to the girl and questioned her (girl) again.

``For your own sake, Agnes, tell me, are you sure you never mentioned about the money-box to--Sam Brattle?'' (The girl)

The girl blushed and hesitated, and then said that she (girl) was quite sure she (girl) never had. She (girl) didn't think she (girl) had ever said ten words to Sam since she (girl) knew about the box.

``But five words would be sufficient, Agnes.'' (unknown)

``Then them five words was never spoke, sir,'' (the girl)
said the girl. But still she (girl) blushed, and the parson thought that her (girl) manner was not in her (girl) favour.

It was necessary that the parson should attend to his (parson) church; but the Squire, who was a magistrate, went down with the two constables to the mill. There they found Sam and his (Sam) father, with Mrs. Brattle and Fanny. No one went to the church from the mill on that day. The news had reached them of the murder, and they all felt,--though no one of them had so said to any other,--that something might in some way connect them with the deed that had been done. Sam had hardly spoken since he (Sam) had heard of Mr. Trumbull's death; though when he (Sam) saw that his (Sam) father was perfectly silent, as one struck with some sudden dread, he (Sam) bade the old man hold up his (Sam) head and fear nothing. Old Brattle, when so addressed, seated himself in his (Sam) arm-chair, and there remained without a word till the magistrate with the constables were among them.

There were not many at church, and Mr. Fenwick made the service very short. He (Fenwick) could not preach the sermon which he (Fenwick) had prepared, but said a few words on the terrible catastrophe which had occurred so near to them. This man who was now lying within only a few yards of them, with his (man) brains knocked out, had been alive among them, strong and in good health, yesterday evening! And there had come into their peaceful village miscreants who had been led on from self-indulgence to idleness, and from idleness to theft, and from theft to murder! We all know the kind of words which the parson spoke, and the thrill of attention with which they would be heard. Here was a man who had been close to them, and therefore the murder came home to them all, and filled them with an excitement which, alas! was not probably without some feeling of pleasure. But the sermon, if sermon it could be called, was very short; and when it was over, the parson also hurried down to the mill.

It had already been discovered that Sam Brattle had certainly been out during the night. He (Brattle) had himself denied this at first, saying, that though he (Brattle) had been the last to go to bed, he (Brattle) had gone to bed about eleven, and had not left the mill-house till late in the morning;--but his (Brattle) sister had heard him (Brattle) rise, and had seen his (Brattle) body through the gloom as he (Brattle) passed beneath the window of the room in which she (sister) slept. She (sister) had not heard him (Brattle) return, but, when she (sister) arose at six, had found out that he (Brattle) was then in the house. He (Brattle) manifested no anger against her (sister) when she (sister) gave this testimony, but acknowledged that he (Brattle) had been out, that he (Brattle) had wandered up to the road, and explained his (Brattle) former denial frankly,--or with well-assumed frankness,--by saying that he (Brattle) would, if possible, for his (Brattle) father's and mother's sake, have concealed the fact that he (Brattle) had been away,--knowing that his (Brattle) absence would give rise to suspicions which would well-nigh break their hearts. He (Brattle) had not, however,--so he (Brattle) said,--been any nearer to Bullhampton than the point of the road opposite to the lodge of Hampton Privets, from whence the lane turned down to the mill. What had he (Hampton) been doing down there? He (Hampton) had done nothing, but sat and smoked on a stile by the road side. Had he (Hampton) seen any strangers? Here he (Hampton) paused, but at last declared that he (Hampton) had seen none, but had heard the sound of wheels and of a pony's feet upon the road. The vehicle, whatever it was, must have passed on towards Bullhampton just before he (Hampton) reached the road. Had he (Hampton) followed the vehicle? No;--he (Hampton) had thought of doing so, but had not. Could he (Hampton) guess who was in the vehicle? By this time many surmises had been made aloud as to Jack the Grinder and his (Jack) companion, and it had become generally known that the parson had encountered two such men in his (parson) own garden some nights previously. Sam, when he (Sam) was pressed, said that the idea had come into his (Sam) mind that the vehicle was the Grinder's cart. He (Sam) had no knowledge, he (Sam) said, that the man was coming to Bullhampton on that night;--but the man had said in his (man) hearing, that he (man) would like to strip the parson's peaches. He (man) was asked also about Farmer Trumbull's money. He (man) declared that he (man) had never heard that the farmer kept money in the house. He (farmer) did know that the farmer was accounted to be a very saving man,--but that was all that he (man) knew. He (man) was as much surprised, he (man) said, as any of them at what had occurred. Had the men turned the other way and robbed the parson he (parson) would have been less surprised. He (parson) acknowledged that he (parson) had called the parson a turn-coat and a meddling tell-tale, in the presence of these men.

All this ended of course in Sam's arrest. He (Sam) had himself seen from the first that it would be so, and had bade his (Sam) mother take comfort and hold up her (mother) head.

``It won't be for long, mother. I ain't got any of the money, and they can't bring it nigh me.'' (He)
He (Sam) was taken away to be locked up at Heytesbury that night, in order that he (Sam) might be brought before the bench of magistrates which would sit at that place on Tuesday. Squire Gilmore for the present committed him (Gilmore).

The parson remained for some time with the old man and his (man) wife after Sam was gone, but he (Sam) soon found that he (Sam) could be of no service by doing so. The miller himself would not speak, and Mrs. Brattle was utterly prostrated by her (Brattle) husband's misery.

``I do not know what to say about it,'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)
said Mr. Fenwick to his (Fenwick) wife that night.
``The suspicion is very strong; but I cannot say that I have an opinion one way or the other.'' (unknown)
There was no sermon in Bullhampton Church on that Sunday afternoon.

CHAPTER XIII.

CAPTAIN MARRABLE AND HIS (Fenwick) FATHER.

Only that it is generally conceived that in such a history as is this the writer of the tale should be able to make his (writer) points so clear by words that no further assistance should be needed, I should be tempted here to insert a properly illustrated pedigree tree of the Marrable family. The Marrable family is of very old standing in England, the first baronet having been created by James I., and there having been Marrables,--as is well known by all attentive readers of English history,--engaged in the Wars of the Roses, and again others very conspicuous in the religious persecutions of the children of Henry VIII. I do not know that they always behaved with consistency; but they held their heads up after a fashion, and got themselves talked of, and were people of note in the country. They were cavaliers in the time of Charles I. and of Cromwell,--as became men of blood and gentlemen,--but it is not recorded of them that they sacrificed much in the cause; and when William III. became king they submitted with a good grace to the new order of things. A certain Sir Thomas Marrable was member for his (Thomas) county in the reigns of George I. and George II., and enjoyed a lucrative confidence with Walpole. Then there came a blustering, roystering Sir Thomas, who, together with a fine man and gambler as a heir, brought the property to rather a low ebb; so that when Sir Gregory, the grandfather of our Miss Marrable, came to the title in the early days of George III. he (George) was not a rich man. His (George) two sons, another Sir Gregory and a General Marrable, died long before the days of which we are writing,--Sir Gregory in 1815, and the General in 1820. That Sir Gregory was the second of the name,--the second at least as mentioned in these pages. He (Gregory) had been our Miss Marrable's uncle, and the General had been her (Marrable) father, and the father of Mrs. Lowther,--Mary's mother. A third Sir Gregory was reigning at the time of our story, a very old gentleman with one single son,--a fourth Gregory. Now the residence of Sir Gregory was at Dunripple Park, just on the borders of Warwickshire and Worcestershire, but in the latter county. The property was small,--for a country gentleman with a title,--not much exceeding L3000 a year; and there was no longer any sitting in Parliament, or keeping of race-horses, or indeed any season in town for the present race of Marrables. The existing Sir Gregory was a very quiet man, and his (Gregory) son and only child, a man now about forty years of age, lived mostly at home, and occupied himself with things of antiquity. He (Gregory) was remarkably well read in the history of his (Gregory) own country, and it had been understood for the last twenty years by the Antiquarian, Archaeological, and other societies that he (Gregory) was the projector of a new theory about Stonehenge, and that his (Gregory) book on the subject was almost ready. Such were the two surviving members of the present senior branch of the family. But Sir Gregory had two brothers,--the younger of the two being Parson John Marrable, the present rector of St. Peter's Lowtown and the occupier of the house within the heavy slate-coloured gates, where he (Marrable) lived a bachelor life, as had done before him (Marrable) his (Marrable) cousin the late rector;--the elder being a certain Colonel Marrable. The Colonel Marrable again had a son, who was a Captain Walter Marrable,--and after him (Marrable) the confused reader shall be introduced to no more of the Marrable family. The enlightened reader will have by this time perceived that Miss Mary Lowther and Captain Walter Marrable were second cousins; and he (Marrable) will also have perceived, if he (Marrable) has given his (Marrable) mind fully to the study, that the present Parson John Marrable had come into the living after the death of a cousin of the same generation as himself,--but of lower standing in the family. It was so; and by this may be seen how little the Sir Gregory of the present day had been able to do for his (Gregory) brother, and perhaps it may also be imagined from this that the present clergyman at Loring Lowtown had been able to do very little for himself. Nevertheless, he (clergyman) was a kindly-hearted, good, sincere old man,--not very bright, indeed, nor peculiarly fitted for preaching the gospel, but he (clergyman) was much liked, and he (clergyman) kept a curate, though his (clergyman) income out of the living was small. Now it so happened that Captain Marrable,--Walter Marrable,--came to stay with his (Marrable) uncle the parson about the same time that Mary Lowther returned to Loring.

``You remember Walter, do you not?'' (Miss Marrable/Marrable/MISS MARRABLE)
said Miss Marrable to her (Marrable) niece.

``Not the least in the world. I remember there was a Walter when I was at Dunripple. But that was ten years ago, and boy cousins and girl cousins never fraternise.'' (unknown)

``I suppose he (Walter) was nearly a young man then, and you were a child?'' (unknown)

``He (Walter) was still at school, though just leaving it. He (Walter) is seven years older than I am.'' (unknown)

``He (Walter) is coming to stay with Parson John.'' (unknown)

``You don't say so, aunt Sarah? What will such a man as Captain Marrable do at Loring?'' (aunt)

Then aunt Sarah explained all that she (Marrable) knew, and perhaps suggested more than she (Marrable) knew. Walter Marrable had quarrelled with his (Marrable) father, the Colonel,--with whom, indeed, everybody of the name of Marrable had always been quarrelling, and who was believed by Miss Marrable to be the very--mischief himself. He (Marrable) was a man always in debt, who had broken his (Marrable) wife's heart, who lived with low company and disgraced the family, who had been more than once arrested, on whose behalf all the family interest had been expended, so that nobody else could get anything, and who gambled and drank and did whatever wicked things a wicked old colonel living at Portsmouth could do. And indeed, hitherto, Miss Marrable had entertained opinions hardly more charitable respecting the son than she (Marrable) had done in regard to the father. She (Marrable) had disbelieved in this branch of the Marrables altogether. Captain Marrable had lived with his (Captain) father a good deal,--at least, so she (Marrable) had understood,--and therefore could not but be bad. And, moreover, our Miss Sarah Marrable had, throughout her (Sarah) whole life, been somewhat estranged from the elder branches of the family. Her (Sarah) father, Walter, had been,--so she (Sarah) thought,--injured by his (Walter) brother Sir Gregory, and there had been some law proceedings, not quite amicable, between her (Sarah) brother the parson, and the present Sir Gregory. She (Sarah) respected Sir Gregory as the head of the family, but she (Sarah) never went now to Dunripple, and knew nothing of Sir Gregory's heir. Of the present Parson John she (Sarah) had thought very little before he (John) had come to Loring. Since he (Loring) had been living there she (Sarah) had found that blood was thicker than water,--as she (Sarah) would say,--and they two were intimate. When she (Sarah) heard that Captain Marrable was coming, because he (Captain) had quarrelled with his (Captain) father, she (Marrable) began to think that perhaps it might be as well that she (Marrable) should allow herself to meet this new cousin.

``What do you think of your cousin, Walter?'' (the clergyman)
the old clergyman said to his (clergyman) nephew, one evening, after the two ladies, who had been dining at the Rectory, had left them. It was the first occasion on which Walter Marrable had met Mary since his (Marrable) coming to Loring.

``I remember her (Marrable) as well as if it were yesterday, at Dunripple. She (Marrable) was a little girl then, and I thought her (Marrable) the most beautiful little girl in the world.'' (unknown)

``We all think her (Marrable) very beautiful still.'' (unknown)

``So she (Marrable) is; as lovely as ever she (Marrable) can stand. But she (Marrable) does not seem to have much to say for herself. I remember when she (Marrable) was a little girl she (Marrable) never would speak.'' (unknown)

``I fancy she (Marrable) can talk when she (Marrable) pleases, Walter. But you mustn't fall in love with her (Marrable).'' (unknown)

``I won't, if I can help it.'' (unknown)

``In the first place I think she (Marrable) is as good as engaged to a fellow with a very pretty property in Wiltshire, and in the next place she (Marrable) hasn't got--one shilling.'' (unknown)

``There is not much danger. I am not inclined to trouble myself about any girl in my present mood, even if she (girl) had the pretty property herself, and wasn't engaged to anybody. I suppose I shall get over it some day, but I feel just at present as though I couldn't say a kind word to a human being.'' (unknown)

``Psha! psha! that's nonsense, Walter. Take things coolly. They're more likely to come right, and they won't be so troublesome, even if they don't.'' (Parson)
Such was the philosophy of Parson John,--for the sake of digesting which the captain lit a cigar, and went out to smoke it, standing at one of the open slate-coloured gates.

It was said in the first chapter of this story that Mr. Gilmore was one of the heroes whose deeds the story undertakes to narrate, and a hint was perhaps expressed that of all the heroes he (Gilmore) was the favourite. Captain Marrable is, however, another hero, and, as such, some word or two must be said of him (hero). He (hero) was a better-looking man, certainly, than Mr. Gilmore, though perhaps his (Gilmore) personal appearance did not at first sight give to the observer so favourable an idea of his (Gilmore) character as did that of the other gentleman. Mr. Gilmore was to be read at a glance as an honest, straightforward, well-behaved country squire, whose word might be taken for anything, who might, perhaps, like to have his (Gilmore) own way, but who could hardly do a cruel or an unfair thing. He (Gilmore) was just such a man to look at as a prudent mother would select as one to whom she (mother) might entrust her (mother) daughter with safety. Now Walter Marrable's countenance was of a very different die. He (Marrable) had served in India, and the naturally dark colour of his (Marrable) face had thus become very swarthy. His (Marrable) black hair curled round his (Marrable) head, but the curls on his (Marrable) brow were becoming very thin, as though age were already telling on them, and yet he (Marrable) was four or five years younger than Mr. Gilmore. His (Gilmore) eyebrows were thick and heavy, and his (Gilmore) eyes seemed to be black. They were eyes which were used without much motion; and when they were dead set, as they were not unfrequently, it would seem as though he (Gilmore) were defying those on whom he (Gilmore) looked. Thus he (Gilmore) made many afraid of him (Gilmore), and many who were not afraid of him (Gilmore), disliked him (Gilmore) because of a certain ferocity which seemed to characterise his (Gilmore) face. He (Gilmore) wore no beard beyond a heavy black moustache, which quite covered his (Gilmore) upper lip. His (Gilmore) nose was long and straight, his (Gilmore) mouth large, and his (Gilmore) chin square. No doubt he (Gilmore) was a handsome man. And he (Gilmore) looked to be a tall man, though in truth he (Gilmore) lacked two full inches of the normal six feet. He (Gilmore) was broad across the chest, strong on his (Gilmore) legs, and was altogether such a man to look at that few would care to quarrel with him (Gilmore), and many would think that he (Gilmore) was disposed to quarrel. Of his (Gilmore) nature he (Gilmore) was not quarrelsome; but he (Gilmore) was a man who certainly had received much injury. It need not be explained at length how his (Gilmore) money affairs had gone wrong with him (Gilmore). He (Gilmore) should have inherited, and, indeed, did inherit, a fortune from his (Gilmore) mother's family, of which his (Gilmore) father had contrived absolutely to rob him (Gilmore). It was only within the last month that he (Gilmore) had discovered that his (Gilmore) father had succeeded in laying his (Gilmore) hands on certainly the bulk of his (Gilmore) money, and it might be upon all. Words between them had been very bitter. The father, with a cigar between his (father) teeth, had told his (father) son that this was the fortune of war, that if justice had been done him (father) at his (father) marriage, the money would have been his (father) own, and that by G-- he (father) was very sorry, and couldn't say anything more. The son had called the father a liar and a swindler,--as, indeed, was the truth, though the son was doubtless wrong to say so to the author of his (author) being. The father had threatened the son with his (father) horsewhip; and so they had parted, within ten days of Walter Marrable's return from India.

Walter had written to his (Walter) two uncles, asking their advice as to saving the wreck, if anything might be saved. Sir Gregory had written back to say that he (Gregory) was an old man, that he (Gregory) was greatly grieved at the misunderstanding, and that Messrs. Block and Curling were the family lawyers. Parson John invited his (John) nephew to come down to Loring Lowtown. Captain Marrable went to Block and Curling, who were by no means consolatory, and accepted his (Captain) uncle's invitation.

It was but three days after the first meeting between the two cousins, that they were to be seen one evening walking together along the banks of the Lurwell, a little river which at Loring sometimes takes the appearance of a canal, and sometimes of a natural stream. But it is commercial, having connection with the Kennet and Avon navigation; and long, slow, ponderous barges, with heavy, dirty, sleepy bargemen, and rickety, ill-used barge-horses, are common in the neighbourhood. In parts it is very pretty, as it runs under the chalky downs, and there are a multiplicity of locks, and the turf of the sheep-walks comes up to the towing path; but in the close neighbourhood of the town the canal is straight and uninteresting; the ground is level, and there is a scattered community of small, straight-built light-brick houses, which are in themselves so ugly that they are incompatible with anything that is pretty in landscape.

Parson John, always so called to distinguish him (John) from the late parson, his (John) cousin, who had been the Rev. James Marrable, had taken occasion, on behalf of his (James) nephew, to tell the story of his (James) wrong to Miss Marrable, and by Miss Marrable it had been told to Mary. To both these ladies the thing seemed to be so horrible,--the idea that a father should have robbed his (father) son,--that the stern ferocity of the slow-moving eyes was forgiven, and they took him (father) to their hearts, if not for love, at least for pity. Twenty thousand pounds ought to have become the property of Walter Marrable, when some maternal relative had died. It had seemed hard that the father should have none of it, and, on the receipt in India of representations from the Colonel, Walter had signed certain fatal papers, the effect of which was that the father had laid his (father) hands on pretty nearly the whole, if not on the whole, of the money, and had caused it to vanish. There was now a question whether some five thousand pounds might not be saved. If so, Walter would stay in England; if not, he (Walter) would exchange and go back to India;

``or,'' (he)
as he (Walter) said himself,
``to the Devil.'' (he)

``Don't speak of it in that way,'' (Mary/Mary Lowther/MARY LOWTHER)
said Mary.

``The worst of it is,'' (he)
said he (Walter)
``that I am ashamed of myself for being so absolutely cut up about money. A man should be able to bear that kind of thing; but this hits one all round.'' (he)

``I think you bear it very well.'' (unknown)

``No, I don't. I didn't bear it well when I called my father a swindler. I didn't bear it well when I swore that I would put him (father) in prison for robbing me. I don't bear it well now, when I think of it every moment. But I do so hate India, and I had so absolutely made up my mind never to return. If it hadn't been that I knew that this fortune was to be mine, I could have saved money, hand over hand.'' (unknown)

``Can't you live on your pay here?'' (unknown)

``No!'' (He)
He (Walter) answered her (Mary) almost as though he (Walter) were angry with her (Mary).
``If I had been used all my life to the strictest economies, perhaps I might do so. Some men do, no doubt; but I am too old to begin it. There is the choice of two things,--to blow my brains out, or go back.'' (unknown)

``You are not such a coward as that.'' (unknown)

``I don't know. I ain't sure that it would be cowardice. If there were anybody I could injure by doing it, it would be cowardly.'' (unknown)

``The family,'' (Mary/Mary Lowther/MARY LOWTHER)
suggested Mary.

``What does Sir Gregory care for me? I'll show you his (Gregory) letter to me some day. I don't think it would be cowardly at all to get away from such a lot.'' (unknown)

``Think what it is to know that your father is a swindler. Perhaps that is the worst of it all. Fancy talking or thinking of one's family after that. I like my uncle John. He (John) is very kind, and has offered to lend me L150, which I'm sure he (John) can't afford to lose, and which I am too honest to take. But even he (John) hardly sees it. He (John) calls it a misfortune, and I've no doubt would shake hands with his (John) brother to-morrow.'' (unknown)

``So would you, if he (John) were really sorry.'' (unknown)

``No, Mary; nothing on earth shall ever induce me to set my eyes on him (John) again willingly. He (John) has destroyed all the world for me. He (John) should have had half of it without a word. When he (John) used to whine to me in his (John) letters, and say how cruelly he (John) had been treated, I always made up my mind that he (John) should have half the income for life. It was because he (John) should not want till I came home that I enabled him (John) to do what he (John) has done. And now he (John) has robbed me of every cursed shilling! I wonder whether I shall ever get my mind free from it.'' (unknown)

``Of course you will.'' (unknown)

``It seems now that my heart is wrapped in lead.'' (she)
As they were coming home she (Mary) put her (Mary) hand upon his (Walter) arm, and asked him (Walter) to promise her (Mary) to withdraw that threat.

``Why should I withdraw it? Who cares for me?'' (unknown)

``We all care. My aunt cares. I care.'' (unknown)

``The threat means nothing, Mary. People who make such threats don't carry them out. Of course I shall go on and endure it. The worst of all is, that the whole thing makes me so unmanly,--makes such a beast of me. But I'll try to get over it.'' (Mary/Mary Lowther/MARY LOWTHER)

Mary Lowther thought that, upon the whole, he (Walter) bore his (Walter) misfortune very well.

CHAPTER XIV.

COUSINHOOD.

Mary Lowther and her (Lowther) cousin had taken their walk together on Monday evening, and on the next morning she (Lowther) received the following letter from Mrs. Fenwick. When it reached her (Fenwick) she (Fenwick) had as yet heard nothing of the Bullhampton tragedy.

Vicarage, Monday, Sept. 1, 186--.

DEAREST MARY,

I suppose you will have heard before you get this of the dreadful murder that has taken place here, and which has so startled and horrified us, that we hardly know what we are doing even yet. It is hard to say why a thing should be worse because it is close, but it certainly is so. Had it been in the next parish, or even further off in this parish, I do not think that I should feel it so much, and then we knew the old man so well; and then, again,--which makes it worst of all,--we all of us are unable to get rid of a suspicion that one whom we knew, and was liked, has been a participator in the crime.

It seems that it must have been about two o'clock on Sunday morning that Mr. Trumbull was killed. It was, at any rate, between one and three. As far as they can judge, they think that there must have been three men concerned. You remember how we used to joke about poor Mr. Trumbull's dog. Well, he (Trumbull) was poisoned first,--probably an hour before the men got into the house. It has been discovered that the foolish old man kept a large sum of money by him (man) in a box, and that he (man) always took this box into bed with him (man). The woman, who lived in the house with him (man), used to see it there. No doubt the thieves had heard of this, and both Frank and Mr. Gilmore think that the girl, Agnes Pope, whom you will remember in the choir, told about it. She (Pope) lived with Mr. Trumbull, and we all thought her (Pope) a very good girl,--though she (Pope) was too fond of that young man, Sam Brattle.

They think that the men did not mean to do the murder, but that the old man fought so hard for his (man) money that they were driven to it. His (man) body was not in the room, but on the top of the stairs, and his (man) temple had been split open with a blow of a hammer. The hammer lay beside him (man), and was one belonging to the house. Mr. Gilmore says that there was great craft in their using a weapon which they did not bring with them. Of course they cannot be traced by the hammer.

They got off with L150 in the box, and did not touch anything else. Everybody feels quite sure that they knew all about the money, and that when Mr. Gilmore saw them that night down at the churchyard corner, they were prowling about with a view of seeing how they could get into the farmer's house, and not into the Vicarage. Frank thinks that when he (Frank) afterwards found them in our place, Sam Brattle had brought them in with a kind of wild idea of taking the fruit, but that the men, of their own account, had come round to reconnoitre the house. They both say that there can be no doubt about the men having been the same. Then comes the terrible question whether Sam Brattle, the son of that dear woman at the mill, has been one of the murderers. He (Brattle) had been at home all the previous day working very hard at the works,--which are being done in obedience to your orders, my dear; but he (Brattle) certainly was out on the Saturday night.

It is very hard to get at any man's belief in such matters, but, as far as I can understand them, I don't think that either Frank or Mr. Gilmore do really believe that he (Frank) was there. Frank says that it will go very hard with him (Frank), and Mr. Gilmore has committed him (Gilmore). The magistrates are to sit to-morrow at Heytesbury, and Mr. Gilmore will be there. He (Gilmore) has, as you may be sure, behaved as well as possible, and has quite altered in his (Gilmore) manner to the old people. I was at the mill this morning. Brattle himself would not speak to me, but I sat for an hour with Mrs. Brattle and Fanny. It makes it almost the more melancholy having all the rubbish and building things about, and yet the work stopped.

Fanny Brattle has behaved so well! It was she (Brattle) who told that her (Brattle) brother had been out at night. Mr. Gilmore says that when the question was asked in his (Gilmore) presence, she (Brattle) answered it in her (Brattle) own quiet, simple way, without a moment's doubt; but since that she (Brattle) has never ceased to assert her (Brattle) conviction that her (Brattle) brother has had nothing to do either with the murder or with the robbery. If it had not been for this, Mrs. Brattle would, I think, have sunk under the load. Fanny says the same thing constantly to her (Fanny) father. He (father) scolds her (Fanny), and bids her (Fanny) hold her (Fanny) tongue; but she (Fanny) goes on, and I think it has some effect even on him (father). The whole place does look such a picture of ruin! It would break your heart to see it. And then, when one looks at the father and mother, one remembers about that other child, and is almost tempted to ask why such misery should have fallen upon parents who have been honest, sober, and industrious. Can it really be that the man is being punished here on earth because he (man) will not believe? When I hinted this to Frank, he (Frank) turned upon me, and scolded me, and told me I was measuring the Almighty God with a foot-rule. But men were punished in the Bible because they did not believe. Remember the Baptist's father. But I never dare to go on with Frank on these matters.

I am so full of this affair of poor Mr. Trumbull, and so anxious about Sam Brattle, that I cannot now write about anything else. I can only say that no man ever behaved with greater kindness and propriety than Harry Gilmore, who has had to act as magistrate. Poor Fanny Brattle has to go to Heytesbury to-morrow to give her (Brattle) evidence. At first they said that they must take the father also, but he (father) is to be spared for the present.

I should tell you that Sam himself declares that he (Sam) got to know these men at a place where he (Sam) was at work, brickmaking, near Devizes. He (Sam) had quarrelled with his (Sam) father, and had got a job there, with high wages. He (Sam) used to be out at night with them, and acknowledges that he (Sam) joined one of them, a man named Burrows, in stealing a brood of pea-fowl which some poulterers wanted to buy. He (Burrows) says he (Burrows) looked on it as a joke. Then it seems he (Burrows) had some spite against Trumbull's dog, and that this man, Burrows, came over here on purpose to take the dog away. This, according to his (man) story, is all that he (man) knows of the man; and he (man) says that on that special Saturday night he (man) had not the least idea that Burrows was at Bullhampton, till he (Burrows) heard the sound of a certain cart on the road. I tell you all this, as I am sure you will share our anxiety respecting this unfortunate young man,--because of his (man) mother and sister.

Good-bye, dearest; Frank sends ever so many loves;--and somebody else would send them too, if he (Frank) thought that I would be the bearer. Try to think so well of Bullhampton as to make you wish to live here.--Give my kindest love to your aunt Sarah.

Your most affectionate friend,

JANET FENWICK.

Mary was obliged to read the letter twice before she (Mary) completely understood it. Old Mr. Trumbull murdered! Why she (Mary) had known the old man well, had always been in the habit of speaking to him (man) when she (Mary) met him (man) either at the one gate or the other of the farmyard,--had joked with him (man) about Bone'm, and had heard him (man) assert his (man) own perfect security against robbers not a week before the night on which he (man) was murdered! As Mrs. Fenwick had said, the truth is so much more real when it comes from things that are near. And then she (Fenwick) had so often heard the character of Sam Brattle described,--the man who was now in prison as a murderer! And she (Fenwick) herself had given lessons in singing to Agnes Pope, who was now in some sort accused of aiding the thieves. And she (Pope) herself had asked Agnes whether it was not foolish for her (Agnes) to be hanging about the farmyard, outside her (Agnes) master's premises, with Sam Brattle. It was all brought very near to her (Agnes)!

Before that day was over she (Agnes) was telling the story to Captain Marrable. She (Marrable) had of course told it to her (Marrable) aunt, and they had been discussing it the whole morning. Mr. Gilmore's name had been mentioned to Captain Marrable, but very little more than the name. Aunt Sarah, however, had already begun to think whether it might not be prudent to tell cousin Walter the story of the half-formed engagement. Mary had expressed so much sympathy with her (Mary) cousin's wrongs, that aunt Sarah had begun to fear that that sympathy might lead to a tenderer feeling, and aunt Sarah was by no means anxious that her (Sarah) niece should fall in love with a gentleman whose chief attraction was the fact that he (gentleman) had been ruined by his (gentleman) own father, even though that gentleman was a Marrable himself. This danger might possibly be lessened if Captain Marrable were made acquainted with the Gilmore affair, and taught to understand how desirable such a match would be for Mary. But aunt Sarah had qualms of conscience on the subject. She (Sarah) doubted whether she (Sarah) had a right to tell the story without leave from Mary; and then there was in truth no real engagement. She (Mary) knew indeed that Mr. Gilmore had made the offer more than once; but then she (Mary) knew also that the offer had at any rate not as yet been accepted, and she (Mary) felt that on Mr. Gilmore's account as well as on Mary's she (Mary) ought to hold her (Mary) tongue. It might indeed be admissible to tell to a cousin that which she (Mary) would not tell to an indifferent young man; but, nevertheless, she (Mary) could not bring herself to do, even with so good an object, that which she (Mary) believed to be wrong.

That evening Mary was again walking on the towing-path beside the river with her (Mary) cousin Walter. She (Mary) had met him (Walter) now about five times, and there was already an intimacy between them. The idea of cousinly intimacy to girls is undoubtedly very pleasant; and I do not know whether it is not the fact that the better and the purer is the girl, the sweeter and the pleasanter is the idea. In America a girl may form a friendly intimacy with any young man she (girl) fancies, and though she (girl) may not be free from little jests and good-humoured joking, there is no injury to her (girl) from such intimacy. It is her (girl) acknowledged right to enjoy herself after that fashion, and to have what she (girl) calls a good time with young men. A dozen such intimacies do not stand in her (girl) way when there comes some real adorer who means to marry her (girl) and is able to do so. She (girl) rides with these friends, walks with them, and corresponds with them. She (girl) goes out to balls and picnics with them, and afterwards lets herself in with a latchkey, while her (girl) papa and mamma are a-bed and asleep, with perfect security. If there be much to be said against the practice, there is also something to be said for it. Girls on the other hand, on the continent of Europe, do not dream of making friendship with any man. A cousin with them is as much out of the question as the most perfect stranger. In strict families, a girl is hardly allowed to go out with her (girl) brother; and I have heard of mothers who thought it indiscreet that a father should be seen alone with his (father) daughter at a theatre. All friendships between the sexes must, under such a social code, be looked forward to as post-nuptial joys. Here in England there is a something betwixt the two. The intercourse between young men and girls is free enough to enable the latter to feel how pleasant it is to be able to forget for awhile conventional restraints, and to acknowledge how joyous a thing it is to indulge in social intercourse in which the simple delight of equal mind meeting equal mind in equal talk is just enhanced by the unconscious remembrance that boys and girls when they meet together may learn to love. There is nothing more sweet in youth than this, nothing more natural, nothing more fitting, nothing, indeed, more essentially necessary for God's purposes with his (God) creatures. Nevertheless, here with us, there is the restriction, and it is seldom that a girl can allow herself the full flow of friendship with a man who is not old enough to be her (girl) father, unless he (father) is her (girl) lover as well as her (girl) friend. But cousinhood does allow some escape from the hardship of this rule. Cousins are Tom, and Jack, and George, and Dick. Cousins probably know all or most of your little family secrets. Cousins, perhaps, have romped with you, and scolded you, and teased you, when you were young. Cousins are almost the same as brothers, and yet they may be lovers. There is certainly a great relief in cousinhood.

Mary Lowther had no brother. She (Lowther) had neither brother nor sister;--had since her (Lowther) earliest infancy hardly known any other relative save her (Lowther) aunt and old Parson John. When first she (Lowther) had heard that Walter Marrable was at Loring, the tidings gave her (Lowther) no pleasure whatever. It never occurred to her (Lowther) to say to herself:

``Now I shall have one who may become my friend, and be to me perhaps almost a brother?'' (she)
What she (Lowther) had hitherto heard of Walter Marrable had not been in his (Marrable) favour. Of his (Marrable) father she (Lowther) had heard all that was bad, and she (Lowther) had joined the father and the son together in what few ideas she (Lowther) had formed respecting them. But now, after five interviews, Walter Marrable was her (Lowther) dear cousin, with whom she (Lowther) sympathised, of whom she (Lowther) was proud, whose misfortunes were in some degree her (Lowther) misfortunes, to whom she (Lowther) thought she (Lowther) could very soon tell this great trouble of her (Lowther) life about Mr. Gilmore, as though he (Gilmore) were indeed her (Lowther) brother. And she (Lowther) had learned to like his (Gilmore) dark staring eyes, which now always seemed to be fixed on her (Lowther) with something of real regard. She (Lowther) liked them the better, perhaps, because there was in them so much of real admiration; though if it were so, Mary knew nothing of such liking herself. And now at his (Gilmore) bidding she (Mary) called him (Gilmore) Walter. He (Gilmore) had addressed her (Mary) by her (Mary) Christian name at first, as a matter of course, and she (Mary) had felt grateful to him (Gilmore) for doing so. But she (Mary) had not dared to be so bold with him (Gilmore), till he (Gilmore) had bade her (Mary) do so, and now she (Mary) felt that he (Gilmore) was a cousin indeed. Captain Marrable was at present waiting, not with much patience, for tidings from Block and Curling. Mary was not so impatient as the Captain, but she (Mary) also was intensely interested in the expected letters. On this day, however, their conversation chiefly ran on the news which Mary had that morning heard from Bullhampton.

``I suppose you feel sure,'' (the Captain)
said the Captain,
``that young Sam Brattle was one of the murderers?'' (the Captain)

``Oh no, Walter.'' (unknown)

These cousinly walks along the banks of the Lurwell were not probably favourable to Mr. Gilmore's hopes.

THE POLICE AT FAULT.

The attorney had been employed, and Sam had been remanded. There was no direct evidence against him (Sam), and nothing could be done until the other men should be taken, for whom they were seeking. The police had tracked the two men back to a cottage, about fifteen miles distant from Bullhampton, in which lived an old woman, who was the mother of the Grinder.
