But nothing more could be learned of the Grinder than that he (Sam) had been at the cottage on the Sunday morning, and had gone away, according to his (Sam) wont. The old woman swore that he (Sam) slept there the whole of Saturday night, but of course the policemen had not believed her (woman) statement. When does any policeman ever believe anything? Of the pony and cart the old woman declared she (woman) knew nothing. Her (woman) son had no pony, and no cart, to her (woman) knowing. The face of the head constable was longer on this occasion than it had been before, and his (constable) voice less confident. It had been ascertained that he (constable) had friends at Birmingham. Another remand was asked for a week, with an understanding that at the end of the week it should be renewed if necessary. For the first ten days after the murder nothing was done as to the works at the mill. The men who had been employed by Brattle ceased to come, apparently of their own account, and everything was lying there just in the state in which the men had left the place on the Saturday night. There was something inexpressibly sad in this, as the old man could not even make a pretence of going into the mill for employment, and there was absolutely nothing to which he (man) could put his (man) hands, to do it. When ten days were over, Gilmore came down to the mill, and suggested that the works should be carried on and finished by him (Gilmore). If the mill were not kept at work, the old man could not live, and no rent would be paid. During three weeks the visits made by Head Constable Toffy to the cottage in which Mrs. Burrows lived were much more frequent than were agreeable to that lady. This cottage was about four miles from Devizes, and on the edge of a common, about half a mile from the high road which leads from that town to Marlborough. There is, or was a year or two back, a considerable extent of unenclosed land thereabouts, and on a spot called Pycroft Common there was a small collection of cottages, sufficient to constitute a hamlet of the smallest class. There was no house there of greater pretensions than the very small beershop which provided for the conviviality of the Pycroftians; and of other shops there was none, save a baker's, the owner of which seldom had much bread to sell, and the establishment for brandy-balls, which was kept by Mrs. Burrows. The inhabitants were chiefly labouring men, some of whom were in summer employed in brick making; and there was an idea abroad that Pycroft generally was not sustained by regular labour and sober industry. Rents, however, were paid for the cottages, or the cottagers would have been turned adrift; and Mrs. Burrows had lived in hers for five or six years, and was noted in the neighbourhood for her (Burrows) outward neatness and attention to decency. In the summer there were always half-a-dozen large sunflowers in the patch of ground called a garden, and there was a rose-tree, and a bush of honeysuckle over the door, and an alder stump in a corner, which would still put out leaves and bear berries. When Head Constable Toffy visited her (Burrows) there would be generally a few high words, for Mrs. Burrows was by no means unwilling to let it be known that she (Burrows) objected to morning calls from Mr. Toffy.

It has been already said that at this time Mrs. Burrows did not live alone. Residing with her (Burrows) was a young woman, who was believed by Mr. Toffy to be the wife of Richard Burrows, alias the Grinder. On his (Burrows) first visit to Pycroft no doubt, Mr. Toffy was mainly anxious to ascertain whether anything was known by the old woman as to her (woman) son's whereabouts, but the second, third, and fourth visits were made rather to the younger than to the older woman. Toffy had probably learned in his (Toffy) wide experience that a man of the Grinder's nature will generally place more reliance on a young woman than on an old; and that the young woman will, nevertheless, be more likely to betray confidence than the older,--partly from indiscretion, and partly, alas! from treachery. But, if the presumed Mrs. Burrows, junior, knew aught of the Grinder's present doings, she (Burrows) was neither indiscreet nor treacherous. Mr. Toffy could get nothing from her (Burrows). She (Burrows) was sickly, weak, sullen, and silent.

He (Toffy) was convinced, at any rate, of this;--that wherever the murderers might be, the man or men who had joined Sam Brattle in the murder,--for of Sam's guilt he (Sam) was quite convinced,--neither the mother, nor the so-called wife knew of their whereabouts. He (Sam), in his (Sam) heart, condemned the constabulary of Warwickshire, of Gloucestershire, of Worcestershire, and of Somersetshire, because the Grinder was not taken. Especially he (Sam) condemned the constabulary of Warwickshire, feeling almost sure that the Grinder was in Birmingham. If the constabulary in those counties would only do their duty as they in Wiltshire did theirs, the Grinder and his (Sam) associates would soon be taken. But by him (Sam) nothing further could be learned, and Mr. Toffy left Pycroft Common with a heavy heart.

CHAPTER XVI.

MISS LOWTHER ASKS FOR ADVICE.

All these searchings for the murderers of Mr. Trumbull, and these remandings of Sam Brattle, took place in the month of September, and during that same month the energy of other men of law was very keenly at work on a widely different subject. Could Messrs. Block and Curling assure Captain Marrable that a portion of his (Captain) inheritance would be saved for him (Captain), or had that graceless father of his (father) in very truth seized upon it all? There was no shadow of doubt but that if aught was spared, it had not been spared through any delicacy on the part of the Colonel. CHAPTER XVII.

THE MARQUIS OF TROWBRIDGE.

By the end of September it had come to be pretty well understood that Sam Brattle must be allowed to go out of prison, unless something in the shape of fresh evidence should be brought up on the next Tuesday. There had arisen a very strong feeling in the county on the subject;--a Brattle feeling, and an anti-Brattle feeling. It might have been called a Bullhampton feeling and an anti-Bullhampton feeling, were it not that the biggest man concerned in Bullhampton, with certain of his (man) hangers-on and dependents, were very clearly of opinion that Sam Brattle had committed the murder, and that he (Brattle) should be kept in prison till the period for hanging him (Brattle) might come round. This very big person was the Marquis of Trowbridge, under whom poor Farmer Trumbull had held his (Trumbull) land, and who now seemed to think that a murder committed on one of his (Trumbull) tenants was almost as bad as insult to himself. He (Trumbull) felt personally angry with Bullhampton, had ideas of stopping his (Trumbull) charities to the parish, and did resolve, then and there, that he (Trumbull) would have nothing to do with a subscription for the repair of the church, at any rate for the next three years. In making up his (Trumbull) mind on which subject he (Trumbull) was, perhaps, a little influenced by the opinions and narratives of Mr. Puddleham, the Methodist minister in the village.

It was not only that Mr. Trumbull had been murdered. So great and wise a man as Lord Trowbridge would, no doubt, know very well, that in a free country, such as England, a man could not be specially protected from the hands of murderers, or others, by the fact of his (man) being the tenant, or dependent,--by his (man) being in some sort the possession of a great nobleman. The Marquis's people were all expected to vote for his (Marquis) candidates, and would soon have ceased to be the Marquis's people had they failed to do so. They were constrained, also in many respects, by the terms of their very short leases. They could not kill a head of game on their farms. They could not sell their own hay off the land, nor, indeed, any produce other than their corn or cattle. They were compelled to crop their land in certain rotation; and could take no other lands than those held under the Marquis without his (Marquis) leave. In return for all this, they became the Marquis's people. Each tenant shook hands with the Marquis perhaps once in three years; and twice a year was allowed to get drunk at the Marquis's expense--if such was his (Marquis) taste--provided that he (Marquis) had paid his (Marquis) rent. If the duties were heavy, the privileges were great. So the Marquis himself felt; and he (Marquis) knew that a mantle of security, of a certain thickness, was spread upon the shoulders of each of his (Marquis) people by reason of the tenure which bound them together. But he (Marquis) did not conceive that this mantle would be proof against the bullet of the ordinary assassin, or the hammer of the outside ruffian. But here the case was very different. The hammer had been the hammer of no outside ruffian. To the best of his (assassin) lordship's belief,--and in that belief he (assassin) was supported by the constabulary of the whole county,--the hammer had been wielded by a man of Bullhampton,--had been wielded against his (man) tenant by the son of

``a person who holds land under a gentleman who has some property in the parish.'' (the son)
It was thus the Marquis was accustomed to speak of his (Marquis) neighbour, Mr. Gilmore, who, in the Marquis's eyes, was a man not big enough to have his (Marquis) tenants called his (Marquis) people. That such a man as Sam Brattle should have murdered such a one as Mr. Trumbull, was to the Marquis an insult rather than an injury; and now it was to be enhanced by the release of the man from prison, and that by order of a bench of magistrates on which Mr. Gilmore sat!

And there was more in it even than all this. It was very well known at Turnover Park,--the seat of Lord Trowbridge, near Westbury,--that Mr. Gilmore, the gentleman who held property in his (Gilmore) lordship's parish of Bullhampton, and Mr. Fenwick, who was vicar of the same, were another Damon and Pythias. Now the ladies at Turnover, who were much devoted to the Low Church, had heard and doubtless believed, that our friend, Mr. Fenwick, was little better than an infidel. When first he (Fenwick) had come into the county, they had been very anxious to make him (Fenwick) out to be a High Churchman, and a story or two about a cross and a candlestick were fabricated for their gratification. There was at that time the remnant of a great fight going on between the Trowbridge people and another great family in the neighbourhood on this subject; and it would have suited the Ladies Stowte,--John Augustus Stowte was the Marquis of Trowbridge,--to have enlisted our parson among their enemies of this class; but the accusation fell so plump to the ground, was so impossible of support, that they were obliged to content themselves with knowing that Mr. Fenwick was--an infidel! To do the Marquis justice, we must declare that he (Marquis) would not have troubled himself on this score, if Mr. Fenwick would have submitted himself to become one of his (Fenwick) people. The Marquis was master at home, and the Ladies Sophie and Carolina would have been proud to entertain Mr. Fenwick by the week together at Turnover, had he (Fenwick) been willing, infidel or believer, to join that faction. But he (Fenwick) never joined that faction, and he (Fenwick) was not only the bosom friend of the

``gentleman who owned some land in the parish;'' (the bosom friend)
but he (Fenwick) was twice more rebellious than that gentleman himself. He (Fenwick) had contradicted the Marquis flat to his (Marquis) face,--so the Marquis said himself,--when they met once about some business in the parish; and again, when, in the Vicar's early days in Bullhampton, some gathering for school-festival purposes was made in the great home field behind Farmer Trumbull's house, Mrs. Fenwick misbehaved herself egregiously.

``Upon my word, she (Mary) patronised us,'' (Sophie/Lady Sophie)
said Lady Sophie, laughing.
``She (Mary) did, indeed! And you know what she (Mary) was. Her (Mary) father was just a common builder at Loring, who made some money by a speculation in bricks and mortar.'' (Sophie/Lady Sophie)

When Lady Sophie said this she (Sophie) was, no doubt, ignorant of the fact that Mr. Balfour had been the younger son of a family much more ancient than her (Sophie) own, that he (Balfour) had taken a double-first at Oxford, had been a member of half the learned societies in Europe, and had belonged to two or three of the best clubs in London.

From all this it will be seen that the Marquis of Trowbridge would be disposed to think ill of whatever might be done in regard to the murder by the Gilmore-Fenwick party in the parish. And then there were tales about for which there was perhaps some foundation, that the Vicar and the murderer had been very dear friends. It was certainly believed at Turnover that the Vicar and Sam Brattle had for years past spent the best part of their Sundays fishing together. There were tales of rat-killing matches in which they had been engaged,--originating in the undeniable fact of a certain campaign against rats at the mill, in which the Vicar had taken an ardent part. Undoubtedly the destruction of vermin, and, in regard to one species, its preservation for the sake of destruction,--and the catching of fish,--and the shooting of birds,--were things lovely in the Vicar's eyes. He (Vicar), perhaps, did let his (Vicar) pastoral dignity go a little by the board, when he (Vicar) and Sam stooped together, each with a ferret in his (Vicar) hand, grovelling in the dust to get at certain rat-advantages in the mill. Gilmore, who had seen it, had told him (Gilmore) of this.

``I understand it all, old fellow,'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)
Fenwick had said to his (Fenwick) friend,
``and know very well I have got to choose between two things. I must be called a hypocrite, or else I must be one. I have no doubt that as years go on with me I shall see the advantage of choosing the latter.'' (friend)
There were at that time frequent discussions between them on the same subject, for they were friends who could dare to discuss each other's modes of life; but the reader need not be troubled further now with this digression. The position which the Vicar held in the estimation of the Marquis of Trowbridge will probably be sufficiently well understood.

The family at Turnover Park would have thought it a great blessing to have had a clergyman at Bullhampton with whom they could have cordially co-operated; but, failing this, they had taken Mr. Puddleham, the Methodist minister, to their arms. From Mr. Puddleham they learned parish facts and parish fables, which would never have reached them but for his (Puddleham) assistance. Mr. Fenwick was well aware of this, and used to declare that he (Fenwick) had no objection to it. He (Fenwick) would protest that he (Fenwick) could not see why Mr. Puddleham should not get along in the parish just as well as himself, he (Puddleham) having, and meaning to keep to himself, the slight advantages of the parish church, the vicarage-house, and the small tithes. Of this he (Puddleham) was quite sure, that Mr. Puddleham's religious teaching was better than none at all; and he (Puddleham) was by no means convinced,--so he (Puddleham) said,--that, for some of his (Puddleham) parishioners, Mr. Puddleham was not a better teacher than he (Puddleham) himself. He (Puddleham) always shook hands with Mr. Puddleham, though Mr. Puddleham would never look him (Puddleham) in the face, and was quite determined that Mr. Puddleham should not be a thorn in his (Puddleham) side.

In this matter of Sam Brattle's imprisonment and now intended liberation, tidings from the parish were doubtless conveyed by Mr. Puddleham to Turnover,--probably not direct, but still in such a manner that the great people at Turnover knew to whom they were indebted. Now Mr. Gilmore had certainly, from the first, been by no means disposed to view favourably the circumstances attaching to Sam Brattle on that Saturday night. When the great blow fell on the Brattle family, his (Brattle) demeanour to them was changed, and he (Brattle) forgave the miller's contumacy; but he (Brattle) had always thought that Sam had been guilty. CHAPTER XVIII.

BLANK PAPER.

Early in October Captain Marrable was called up to town by letters from Messrs. Block and Curling, and according to promise wrote various letters to Mary Lowther, telling her (Lowther) of the manner in which his (Captain) business progressed. All of these letters were shown to Aunt Sarah,--and would have been shown to Parson John were it not that Parson John declined to read them. But though the letters were purely cousinly,--just such letters as a brother might write,--yet Miss Marrable thought that they were dangerous. She (Marrable) did not say so; but she (Marrable) thought that they were dangerous. Of late Mary had spoken no word of Mr. Gilmore; and Aunt Sarah, through all this silence, was able to discover that Mr. Gilmore's prospects were not becoming brighter. Mary herself, having quite made up her (Mary) mind that Mr. Gilmore's prospects, so far as she (Mary) was concerned, were all over, could not decide how and when she (Mary) should communicate the resolve to her (Mary) lover. According to her (Mary) present agreement with him (lover), she (Mary) was to write to him (lover) at once should she (Mary) accept any other offer; and was to wait for six months if this should not be the case. Certainly, there was no rival in the field, and therefore she (Mary) did not quite know whether she (Mary) ought or ought not to write at once in her (Mary) present circumstances of assured determination. She (Mary) soon told herself that in this respect also she (Mary) would go to her (Mary) new-found brother for advice. She (Mary) would ask him (brother), and do just as he (brother) might bid her (Mary). Had he (brother) not already proved how fit a person he (brother) was to give advice on such a subject?

After an absence of ten days he (brother) came home, and nothing could exceed Mary's anxiety as to the tidings which he (brother) should bring with him (brother). She (Mary) endeavoured not to be selfish about the matter; but she (Mary) could not but acknowledge that, even as regarded herself, the difference between his (brother) going to India or staying at home was so great as to affect the whole colour of her (Mary) life. There was, perhaps, something of the feeling of being subject to desertion about her (Mary), as she (Mary) remembered that in giving up Mr. Gilmore she (Mary) must also give up the Fenwicks. She (Mary) could not hope to go to Bullhampton again, at least for many a long day. She (Mary) would be very much alone if her (Mary) new brother were to leave her (Mary) now. On the morning after his (brother) arrival he (brother) came up to them at Uphill, and told them that the matter was almost settled. Messrs. Block and Curling had declared that it was as good as settled; the money would be saved, and there would be, out of the L20,000 which he (brother) had inherited, something over L4000 for him (brother); so that he (brother) need not return to India. CHAPTER XIX.

SAM BRATTLE RETURNS HOME.

The Tuesday's magistrates' meeting had come off at Heytesbury, and Sam Brattle had been discharged. Mr. Jones had on this occasion indignantly demanded that his (Jones) client should be set free without bail; but to this the magistrates would not assent. The attorney attempted to demonstrate to them that they could not require bail for the reappearance of an accused person, when that accused person was discharged simply because there was no evidence against him (attorney). But to this exposition of the law Sir Thomas and his (Thomas) brother magistrates would not listen.

``If the other persons should at last be taken, and Brattle should not then be forthcoming, justice would suffer,'' (Thomas/Thomas Charleys)
said Sir Thomas. County magistrates, as a rule, are more conspicuous for common sense and good instincts than for sound law; and Mr. Jones may, perhaps, have been right in his (Jones) view of the case. CHAPTER XX.

I HAVE A JUPITER OF MY OWN NOW.

When Mary Lowther returned home from the last walk with her (Lowther) cousin that has been mentioned, she (Lowther) was quite determined that she (Lowther) would not disturb her (Lowther) happiness on that night by the task of telling her (Lowther) engagement to her (Lowther) aunt. MY DEAR MR. GILMORE,

When last you came down to the Vicarage to see me I promised you, as you may perhaps remember, that if it should come to pass that I should engage myself to any other man, I would at once let you know that it was so. I little thought then that I should so soon be called upon to keep my promise. I will not pretend that the writing of this letter is not very painful to me; but I know that it is my duty to write it, and to put an end to a suspense which you have been good enough to feel on my account. You have, I think, heard the name of my cousin, Captain Walter Marrable, who returned from India two or three months ago. I found him (Marrable) staying here with his (Marrable) uncle, the clergyman, and now I am engaged to be his (Marrable) wife.

Perhaps it would be better that I should say nothing more than this, and that I should leave myself and my character and name to your future kindness,--or unkindness,--without any attempt to win the former or to decry the latter; but you have been to me ever so good and noble that I cannot bring myself to be so cold and short. I have always felt that your preference for me has been a great honour to me. I have appreciated your esteem most highly, and have valued your approbation more than I have been able to say. If it could be possible that I should in future have your friendship, I should value it more than that of any other person. God bless you, Mr. Gilmore. I shall always hope that you may be happy, and I shall hear with delight any tidings which may seem to show that you are so.

Pray believe that I am Your most sincere friend,

MARY LOWTHER.

I have thought it best to tell Janet Fenwick what I have done.

Loring, Thursday.

DEAREST JANET,

I wonder what you will say to my news? But you must not scold me. Pray do not scold me. It could never, never have been as you wanted. I have engaged myself to marry my cousin, Captain Walter Marrable, who is a nephew of Sir Gregory Marrable, and a son of Colonel Marrable. We shall be very poor, having not more than L300 a-year above his (Colonel) pay as a captain; but if he (Colonel) had nothing, I think I should do the same. Do you remember how I used to doubt whether I should ever have that sort of love for a man for which I used to envy you? I don't envy you any longer, and I don't regard Mr. Fenwick as being nearly so divine as I used to do. I have a Jupiter of my own now, and need envy no woman the reality of her (woman) love.

I have written to Mr. Gilmore by the same post as will take this, and have just told him (Gilmore) the bare truth. What else could I tell him (Gilmore)? I have said something horribly stilted about esteem and friendship, which I would have left out, only that my letter seemed to be heartless without it. He (Gilmore) has been to me as good as a man could be; but was it my fault that I could not love him (man)? If you knew how I tried,--how I tried to make believe to myself that I loved him (man); how I tried to teach myself that that sort of very chill approbation was the nearest approach to love that I could ever reach; and how I did this because you bade me;--if you could understand all this, then you would not scold me. And I did almost believe that it was so. But now--! Oh, dear! how would it have been if I had engaged myself to Mr. Gilmore, and that then Walter Marrable had come to me! I get sick when I think how near I was to saying that I would love a man whom I never could have loved.

Of course I used to ask myself what I should do with myself. I suppose every woman living has to ask and to answer that question. I used to try to think that it would be well not to think of the outer crust of myself. What did it matter whether things were soft to me or not? I could do my duty. And as this man was good, and a gentleman, and endowed with high qualities and appropriate tastes, why should he (man) not have the wife he (man) wanted? I thought that I could pretend to love him (man), till, after some fashion, I should love him (man); but as I think of it now, all this seems to be so horrid! I know now what to do with myself. To be his (man) from head to foot! To feel that nothing done for him (man) would be mean or distasteful! To stand at a washtub and wash his (man) clothes, if it were wanted. Oh, Janet, I used to dread the time in which he (man) would have to put his (man) arm round me and kiss me! I cannot tell you what I feel now about that other he (man).

I know well how provoked you will be,--and it will all come of love for me; but you cannot but own that I am right. If you have any justice in you, write to me and tell me that I am right.

Only that Mr. Gilmore is your great friend, and that, therefore, just at first, Walter will not be your friend, I would tell you more about him (Walter),--how handsome he (Walter) is, how manly, and how clever. And then his (Walter) voice is like the music of the spheres. You won't feel like being his (Walter) friend at first, but you must look forward to his (Walter) being your friend; you must love him (Walter)--as I do Mr. Fenwick; and you must tell Mr. Fenwick that he (Fenwick) must open his (Fenwick) heart for the man who is to be my husband. Alas, alas! I fear it will be long before I can go to Bullhampton. How I do wish that he (Fenwick) would find some nice wife to suit him (Fenwick)!

Good bye, dearest Janet. If you are really good, you will write me a sweet, kind, loving letter, wishing me joy. You must know all. Aunt Sarah has refused to congratulate me, because the income is so small. Nevertheless, we have not quarrelled. But the income will be nothing to you, and I do look forward to a kind word. When everything is settled, of course I will tell you.

Your most affectionate friend,

MARY LOWTHER.

The former letter of the two was shown to Miss Marrable. That lady was of opinion that it should not be sent; but would not say that, if to be sent, it could be altered for the better.

Of course it was a very nice thing to be in love. Verses and pretty speeches and easy-spoken romance were pleasant enough in their way. Parson John had no doubt tried them himself in early life, and had found how far they were efficacious for his (John) own happiness. But young women were so apt to want too much of the excitement! CHAPTER XXII.

WHAT THE FENWICKS THOUGHT ABOUT IT.

Bullhampton unfortunately was at the end of the postman's walk, and as the man came all the way from Lavington, letters were seldom received much before eleven o'clock. Now this was a most pernicious arrangement, in respect to which Mr. Fenwick carried on a perpetual feud with the Post-office authorities, having put forward a great postal doctrine that letters ought to be rained from heaven on to everybody's breakfast-table exactly as the hot water is brought in for tea. He (Fenwick), being an energetic man, carried on a long and angry correspondence with the authorities aforesaid; but the old man from Lavington continued to toddle into the village just at eleven o'clock. It was acknowledged that ten was his (man) time; but, as he (man) argued with himself, ten and eleven were pretty much of a muchness. The consequence of this was, that Mary Lowther's letters to Mrs. Fenwick had been read by her (Fenwick) two or three hours before she (Fenwick) had an opportunity of speaking on the subject to her (Fenwick) husband. At last, however, he (husband) returned, and she (Fenwick) flew at him (husband) with the letter in her (Fenwick) hand.

``Frank,'' (she)
she (Fenwick) said,
``Frank, what do you think has happened?'' (she)

``The Bank of England must have stopped, from the look of your face.'' (unknown)

``I wish it had, with all my heart, sooner than this. Mary has gone and engaged herself to her (Mary) cousin, Walter Marrable.'' (unknown)

``Oh, yes; she (wife) has been half ashamed of herself every word she (wife) has written. I know her (wife) so well. To think that Mary Lowther should have engaged herself to any man after two days' acquaintance!'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)

Mr. Fenwick read the letter through attentively, and then handed it back.

``It's a good letter,'' (he)

``You mean that it's well written?'' (unknown)

``I mean that it's true. There are no touches put in to make effect. She (Lowther) does love the one man, and she (Lowther) doesn't love the other. All I can say is, that I'm very sorry for it. It will drive Gilmore out of the place.'' (unknown)

The Vicar had another matter of moment to discuss with his (Fenwick) wife. Sam Brattle, after having remained hard at work at the mill for nearly a fortnight,--so hard at work as to induce his (Fenwick) father to declare that he (Fenwick)'d bet a guinea there wasn't a man in the three parishes who could come nigh his (man) Sam for a right down day's work;--after all this, Sam had disappeared, had been gone for two days, and was said by the constable to have been seen at night on the Devizes side, from whence was supposed to come the Grinder, and all manner of Grinder's iniquities. Up to this time no further arrest had been made on account of Mr. Trumbull's murder, nor had any trace been found of the Grinder, or of that other man who had been his (man) companion. In spite, however, of this interruption, Mary Lowther and her (Lowther) engagement to Captain Marrable was the subject of greatest interest at the Vicarage that day and through the night. The Vicarage, Friday.

DEAREST MARY,

I do not know how to answer your letter. You tell me to write pleasantly, and to congratulate you; but how is one to do that so utterly in opposition to one's own interests and wishes? Oh dear, oh dear! how I do so wish you had stayed at Bullhampton! I know you will be angry with me for saying so, but how can I say anything else? I cannot picture you to myself going about from town to town and living in country-quarters. And as I never saw Captain Marrable, to the best of my belief, I cannot interest myself about him (Captain) as I do about one whom I know and love and esteem. I feel that this is not a nice way of writing to you, and indeed I would be nice if I could. Of course I wish you to be full of joy;--of course I wish with all my heart that you may be happy if you marry your cousin; but the thing has come so suddenly that we cannot bring ourselves to look upon it as a reality.

``You should speak for yourself, Janet,'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)
said Mr. Fenwick, when he (Fenwick) came to this part of the letter. He (Fenwick) did not, however, require that the sentence should be altered.

You talk so much of doing what is right! Nobody has ever doubted that you were right both in morals and sentiment. The only regret has been that such a course should be right, and that the other thing should be wrong. Poor man! we have not seen him (man) yet, nor heard from him (man). Frank says that he (Frank) will take it very badly. I suppose that men do always get over that kind of thing much quicker than women do. Many women never can get over it at all; and Harry Gilmore, though there is so little about him (Gilmore) that seems to be soft, is in this respect more like a woman than a man. Had he (man) been otherwise, and had only half cared for you, and asked you to be his (man) wife as though your taking him (man) were a thing he (man) didn't much care about, and were quite a matter of course, I believe you would have been up at Hampton Privets this moment, instead of going soldiering with a captain.

Frank bids me send you his (Frank) kindest love and his (Frank) best wishes for your happiness. Those are his (Frank) very words, and they seem to be kinder than mine. Of course you have my love and my best wishes; but I do not know how to write as though I could rejoice with you. Your husband will always be dear to us, whoever he (husband) may be, if he (husband) be good to you. At present I feel very, very angry with Captain Marrable; as though I wish he (Marrable) had had his (Marrable) head blown off in battle. However, if he (Marrable) is to be the happy man, I will open my heart to him (Marrable);--that is, if he (Marrable) be good.

I know this is not nice, but I cannot make it nicer now. God bless you, dearest Mary.

Ever your most affectionate friend,

JANET FENWICK.

The letter was not posted till the hour for despatch on the following day; but, up to that hour, nothing had been seen at the Vicarage of Mr. Gilmore.

CHAPTER XXIII.

WHAT MR. GILMORE THOUGHT ABOUT IT.

Mr. Gilmore was standing on the doorsteps of his (Gilmore) own house when Mary's letter was brought to him (Gilmore). It was a modest-sized country gentleman's residence, built of variegated uneven stones, black and grey and white, which seemed to be chiefly flint; but the corners and settings of the windows and of the door-ways, and the chimneys, were of brick. There was something sombre about it, and many perhaps might call it dull of aspect; but it was substantial, comfortable, and unassuming. It was entered by broad stone steps, with iron balustrades curving outwards as they descended, and there was an open area round the house, showing that the offices were in the basement. In these days it was a quiet house enough, as Mr. Gilmore was a man not much given to the loudness of bachelor parties. He (man) entertained his (man) neighbours at dinner perhaps once a month, and occasionally had a few guests staying with him (man). His (man) uncle, the prebendary from Salisbury, was often with him (man), and occasionally a brother who was in the army. For the present, however, he (man) was much more inclined, when in want of society, to walk off to the Vicarage than to provide it for himself at home. When Mary's letter was handed to him (man) with his (man)

``Times'' (him)
and other correspondence, he (man) looked, as everybody does, at the address, and at once knew that it came from Mary Lowther. He (man) had never hitherto received a letter from her (Lowther), but yet he (man) knew her (Lowther) handwriting well. Without waiting a moment, he (man) turned upon his (man) heel, and went back into his (man) house, and through the hall to the library. When there, he (man) first opened three other letters, two from tradesmen in London, and one from his (man) uncle, offering to come to him (man) on the next Monday. Then he (man) opened the
``Times,'' (he)
and cut it, and put it down on the table. Mary's letter meanwhile was in his (man) hand, and anyone standing by might have thought that he (man) had forgotten it. But he (man) had not forgotten it, nor was it out of his (man) mind for a moment. While looking at the other letters, while cutting the paper, while attempting, as he (man) did, to read the news, he (man) was suffering under the dread of the blow that was coming. He (man) was there for twenty minutes before he (man) dared to break the envelope; and though during the whole of that time he (man) pretended to deceive himself by some employment, he (man) knew that he (man) was simply postponing an evil thing that was coming to him (man). At last he (man) cut the letter open, and stood for some moments looking for courage to read it. He (man) did read it, and then sat himself down in his (man) chair, telling himself that the thing was over, and that he (man) would bear it as a man. He (man) took up his (man) newspaper, and began to study it. It was the time of the year when newspapers are not very interesting, but he (man) made a rush at the leading articles, and went through two of them. Then he (man) turned over to the police reports. He (man) sat there for an hour, and read hard during the whole time. Then he (man) got up and shook himself, and knew that he (man) was a crippled man, with every function out of order, disabled in every limb. He (man) walked from the library into the hall, and thence to the dining-room, and so, backwards and forwards, for a quarter of an hour. At last he (man) could walk no longer, and, closing the door of the library behind him (man), he (man) threw himself on a sofa and cried like a woman.

What was it that he (man) wanted, and why did he (man) want it? Were there not other women whom the world would say were as good? Was it ever known that a man had died, or become irretrievably broken and destroyed by disappointed love? Was it not one of those things that a man should shake off from him (man), and have done with it? He (man) asked himself these, and many such-like questions, and tried to philosophise with himself on the matter. Had he (man) no will of his (man) own, by which he (man) might conquer this enemy? No; he (man) had no will of his (man) own, and the enemy would not be conquered. He (man) had to tell himself that he (man) was so poor a thing that he (man) could not stand up against the evil that had fallen on him (man).

He (man) walked out round his (man) shrubberies and paddocks, and tried to take an interest in the bullocks and the horses. He (man) knew that if every bullock and horse about the place had been struck dead it would not enhance his (man) misery. He (man) had not had much hope before, but now he (man) would have seen the house of Hampton Privets in flames, just for the chance that had been his (Hampton) yesterday. It was not only that he (Hampton) wanted her (Hampton), or that he (Hampton) regretted the absence of some recognised joys which she (Hampton) would have brought to him (Hampton); but that the final decision on her (Hampton) part seemed to take from him (Hampton) all vitality, all power of enjoyment, all that inward elasticity which is necessary for an interest in worldly affairs.

He (Hampton) had as yet hardly thought of anything but himself;--had hardly observed the name of his (Hampton) successful rival, or paid any attention to aught but the fact that she (Hampton) had told him (Hampton) that it was all over. He (Hampton) had not attempted to make up his (Hampton) mind whether anything could still be done, whether he (Hampton) might yet have a chance, whether it would be well for him (Hampton) to quarrel with the man; whether he (Hampton) should be indignant with her (Hampton), or remonstrate once again in regard to her (Hampton) cruelty. He (Hampton) had thought only of the blow, and of his (Hampton) inability to support it. Would it not be best that he (Hampton) should go forth, and blow out his (Hampton) brains, and have done with it?

He (Hampton) did not look at the letter again till he (Hampton) had returned to the library. Then he (Hampton) took it from his (Hampton) pocket, and read it very carefully. Yes, she (Hampton) had been quick about it. Why; how long had it been since she (Hampton) had left their parish? It was still October, and she (Hampton) had been there just before the murder--only the other day! Captain Walter Marrable! No; he (Marrable) didn't think he (Marrable) had ever heard of him (Marrable). Some fellow with a moustache and a military strut--just the man that he (man) had always hated; one of a class which, with nothing real to recommend it, is always interfering with the happiness of everybody. It was in some such light as this that Mr. Gilmore at present regarded Captain Marrable. How could such a man make a woman happy,--a fellow who probably had no house nor home in which to make her (woman) comfortable? Staying with his (man) uncle the clergyman! Poor Gilmore expressed a wish that the uncle the clergyman had been choked before he (clergyman) had entertained such a guest. Then he (clergyman) read the concluding sentence of poor Mary's letter, in which she (Mary) expressed a hope that they might be friends. Was there ever such cold-blooded trash? Friends indeed! What sort of friendship could there be between two persons, one of whom had made the other so wretched,--so dead as was he (clergyman) at present!

For some half-hour he (clergyman) tried to comfort himself with an idea that he (clergyman) could get hold of Captain Marrable and maul him (Marrable); that it would be a thing permissible for him (Marrable), a magistrate, to go forth with a whip and flog the man, and then perhaps shoot him (man), because the man had been fortunate in love where he (man) had been unfortunate. But he (man) knew the world in which he (man) lived too well to allow himself long to think that this could really be done. It might be that it would be a better world were such revenge practicable in it; but, as he (man) well knew, it was not practicable now, and if Mary Lowther chose to give herself to this accursed Captain, he (Captain) could not help it. There was nothing that he (Captain) could do but to go away and chafe at his (Captain) suffering in some part of the world in which nobody would know that he (Captain) was chafing.

When the evening came, and he (Captain) found that his (Captain) solitude was terribly oppressive to him (Captain), he (Captain) thought that he (Captain) would go down to the Vicarage. He (Captain) had been told by that false one that her (Lowther) tidings had been sent to her (Lowther) friend. There is something mean to a man in the want of success in love. If a man lose a venture of money he (man) can tell his (man) friend; or if he (man) be unsuccessful in trying for a seat in parliament; or be thrown out of a run in the hunting-field; or even if he (man) be blackballed for a club; but a man can hardly bring himself to tell his (man) dearest comrade that his (man) Mary has preferred another man to himself. He (Gilmore) went back all alone, and tumbled and tossed and fretted through the miserable night.

CHAPTER XXIV.

THE REV. HENRY FITZACKERLEY CHAMBERLAINE.

It was decided that evening at the Vicarage that it would be better for all parties that the reverend uncle from Salisbury should be told to make his (uncle) visit, and spend the next week at Hampton Privets; that is, that he (uncle) should come on the Monday and stay till the Saturday. The letter was written down at the Vicarage, as Fenwick feared that it would never be written if the writing of it were left to the unassisted energy of the Squire. The letter was written, and the Vicar, who walked back to Hampton Privets with his (Vicar) friend, took care that it was given to a servant on that night.

On the Sunday nothing was seen of Mr. Gilmore. He (Gilmore) did not come to church, nor would he (Gilmore) dine at the Vicarage. He (Gilmore) remained the whole day in his (Gilmore) own house, pretending to write, trying to read, with accounts before him (Gilmore), with a magazine in his (Gilmore) hand, even with a volume of sermons open on the table before him (Gilmore). But neither the accounts, nor the magazines, nor the sermons, could arrest his (Gilmore) attention for a moment. He (Gilmore) had staked everything on obtaining a certain object, and that object was now beyond his (Gilmore) reach. Men fail often in other things, in the pursuit of honour, fortune, or power, and when they fail they can begin again. There was no beginning again for him (Gilmore). When Mary Lowther should have married this captain, she (Lowther) would be a thing lost to him (captain) for ever;--and was she (Lowther) not as bad as married to this man already? He (man) could do nothing to stop her (Lowther) marriage.

Early in the afternoon of Monday the Rev. Henry Fitzackerley Chamberlaine reached Hampton Privets. He (Chamberlaine) came with his (Chamberlaine) own carriage and a pair of post-horses, as befitted a prebendary of the good old times. Not that Mr. Chamberlaine was a very old man, but that it suited his (Chamberlaine) tastes and tone of mind to adhere to the well-bred ceremonies of life, so many of which went out of fashion when railroads came in. Mr. Chamberlaine was a gentleman of about fifty-five years of age, unmarried, possessed of a comfortable private independence, the incumbent of a living in the fens of Cambridgeshire, which he (Chamberlaine) never visited,--his (Chamberlaine) health forbidding him (Chamberlaine) to do so,--on which subject there had been a considerable amount of correspondence between him (Chamberlaine) and a certain right rev. prelate, in which the prebendary had so far got the better in the argument as not to be disturbed in his (Chamberlaine) manner of life; and he (Chamberlaine) was, as has been before said, the owner of a stall in Salisbury Cathedral. His (owner) lines had certainly fallen to him (owner) in very pleasant places. As to that living in the fens, there was not much to prick his (owner) conscience, as he (owner) gave up the parsonage house and two-thirds of the income to his (owner) curate, expending the other third on local charities. Perhaps the argument which had most weight in silencing the bishop was contained in a short postscript to one of his (bishop) letters.

He (Chamberlaine) was a very handsome man, about six feet high, with large light grey eyes, a straight nose, and a well cut chin. His (Chamberlaine) lips were thin, but his (Chamberlaine) teeth were perfect,--only that they had been supplied by a dentist. It was whispered, indeed, that married ladies would sometimes succumb, and rave about the beauty, and the dignity, and the white hands, and the deep rolling voice of the Rev. Henry Fitzackerley Chamberlaine. Indeed, his (Chamberlaine) voice was very fine when it would be heard from the far-off end of the choir during the communion service, altogether trumping the exertion of the other second-rate clergyman who would be associated with him (clergyman) at the altar. And he (clergyman) had, too, great gifts of preaching, which he (clergyman) would exercise once a week during thirteen weeks of the year. He (clergyman) never exceeded twenty-five minutes; every word was audible throughout the whole choir, and there was a grace about it that was better than any doctrine. When he (clergyman) was to be heard the cathedral was always full, and he (clergyman) was perhaps justified in regarding himself as one of the ecclesiastical stars of the day. Many applications were made to him (clergyman) to preach here and there, but he (clergyman) always refused. Stories were told of how he (clergyman) had declined to preach before the Queen at St. James's, averring that if Her (Queen) Majesty would please to visit Salisbury, every accommodation should be provided for her (Queen). As to preaching at Whitehall, Westminster, and St. Paul's, it was not doubted that he (Paul) had over and over again declared that his (Paul) appointed place was in his (Paul) own stall, and that he (Paul) did not consider that he (Paul) was called to holding forth in the market-place. He (Paul) was usually abroad during the early autumn months, and would make sundry prolonged visits to friends; but his (Paul) only home was his (Paul) prebendal residence in the Close. It was not much of a house to look at from the outside, being built with the plainest possible construction of brick; but within it was very pleasant. All that curtains, and carpets, and armchairs, and books, and ornaments could do, had been done lavishly, and the cellar was known to be the best in the city. He (Paul) always used post-horses, but he (Paul) had his (Paul) own carriage. He (Paul) never talked very much, but when he (Paul) did speak people listened to him (Paul). His (Paul) appetite was excellent, but he (Paul) was a feeder not very easy to please; it was understood well by the ladies of Salisbury that if Mr. Chamberlaine was expected to dinner, something special must be done in the way of entertainment. He (Chamberlaine) was always exceedingly well dressed. What he (Chamberlaine) did with his (Chamberlaine) hours nobody knew, but he (Chamberlaine) was supposed to be a man well educated at all points. That he (Chamberlaine) was such a judge of all works of art, that not another like him (Chamberlaine) was to be found in Wiltshire, nobody doubted. It was considered that he (Chamberlaine) was almost as big as the bishop, and not a soul in Salisbury would have thought of comparing the dean to him (dean). A good dinner, a pretty ring, an easy chair, a china tea-cup, might all be procured with certainty, as long as money lasted. CHAPTER XXV.

CARRY BRATTLE.

``Wheresoever I may send for you? Do you think that I would have you harmed?'' (unknown)

``Perhaps it'd be--for a prison; or to live along with a lot of others. Oh, Mr. Fenwick, I could not stand that.'' (He)

He (Sam) did not dare to proceed any further lest he (Sam) should be tempted to make promises which he (Sam) himself could not perform; but she (sister) did give him (Sam) an assurance before he (Sam) went that if she (sister) left her (sister) present abode within a month, she (sister) would let him (Sam) know whither she (sister) was going.

He (Sam) went to the Bald-faced Stag and got his (Sam) gig; and on his (Sam) way home, just as he (Sam) was leaving the village of Lavington, he (Sam) overtook Sam Brattle. He (Sam) stopped and spoke to the lad, asking him (Sam) whether he (Sam) was returning home, and offering him (Sam) a seat in the gig. Sam declined the seat, but said that he (Sam) was going straight to the mill.

``It is very hard to make crooked things straight,'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)
said Mr. Fenwick to himself as he (Fenwick) drove up to his (Fenwick) own hall-door.

CHAPTER XXVI.

THE TURNOVER CORRESPONDENCE.

It is hoped that the reader will remember that the Marquis of Trowbridge was subjected to very great insolence from Mr. Fenwick during the discussion which took place in poor old farmer Trumbull's parlour respecting the murder. Our friend, the Vicar, did not content himself with personal invective, but made allusion to the Marquis's daughters. The Marquis, as he (Marquis) was driven home in his (Marquis) carriage, came to sundry conclusions about Mr. Fenwick. That the man was an infidel he (Fenwick) had now no matter of doubt whatever; and if an infidel, then also a hypocrite, and a liar, and a traitor, and a thief. Was he (thief) not robbing the parish of the tithes, and all the while entrapping the souls of men and women? Was it not to be expected that with such a pastor there should be such as Sam Brattle and Carry Brattle in the parish? It was true that as yet this full blown iniquity had spread itself only among the comparatively small number of tenants belonging to the objectionable

``person,'' (tenants)
who unfortunately owned a small number of acres in his (Brattle) lordship's parish;--but his (Brattle) lordship's tenant had been murdered! And with such a pastor in the parish, and such an objectionable person, owning acres, to back the pastor, might it not be expected that all his (pastor) tenants would be murdered? Many applications had already been made to the Marquis for the Church Farm; but as it happened that the applicant whom the Marquis intended to favour, had declared that he (Marquis) did not wish to live in the house because of the murder, the Marquis felt himself justified in concluding that if everything about the parish were not changed very shortly, no decent person would be found willing to live in any of his (Marquis) houses. And now, when they had been talking of murderers, and worse than murderers, as the Marquis said to himself, shaking his (Marquis) head with horror in the carriage as he (Marquis) thought of such iniquity, this infidel clergyman had dared to allude to his (clergyman) lordship's daughters! Such a man had no right even to think of women so exalted. The existence of the Ladies Stowte must no doubt be known to such men, and among themselves probably some allusion in the way of faint guesses might be made as to their modes of life, as men guess at kings and queens, and even at gods and goddesses. But to have an illustration, and a very base illustration, drawn from his (man) own daughters in his (man) own presence, made with the object of confuting himself,--this was more than the Marquis could endure. He (Marquis) could not horsewhip Mr. Fenwick; nor could he (Fenwick) send out his (Fenwick) retainers to do so; but, thank God, there was a bishop! He (bishop) did not quite see his (bishop) way, but he (bishop) thought that Mr. Fenwick might be made at least to leave that parish.
``Turn my daughters out of my house, because--oh, oh!'' (He)
He (Fenwick) almost put his (Fenwick) fist through the carriage window in the energy of his (Fenwick) action as he (Fenwick) thought of it.

As it happened, the Marquis of Trowbridge had never sat in the House of Commons, but he (Marquis) had a son who sat there now. Lord St. George was member for another county in which Lord Trowbridge had an estate, and was a man of the world. His (Trowbridge) father admired him (Trowbridge) much, and trusted him (Trowbridge) a good deal, but still had an idea that his (Trowbridge) son hardly estimated in the proper light the position in the world which he (Trowbridge) was called to fill. Lord St. George was now at home at the Castle, and in the course of that evening the father, as a matter of course, consulted the son. He (son) considered that it would be his (son) duty to write to the bishop, but he (son) would like to hear St. George's idea on the subject. He (son) began, of course, by saying that he (son) did not doubt but that St. George would agree with him (son).

``I shouldn't make any fuss about it,'' (the son)
said the son.

``What! pass it over?'' (unknown)

``Yes; I think so.'' (unknown)

``Do you understand the kind of allusion that was made to your sisters?'' (unknown)

``It won't hurt them, my lord; and people make allusion to everything now-a-days. The bishop can't do anything. For aught you know he (bishop) and Fenwick may be bosom friends.'' (unknown)

``The bishop, St. George, is a most right-thinking man.'' (unknown)

``No doubt. The bishops, I believe, are all right-thinking men, and it is well for them that they are so very seldom called on to go beyond thinking. No doubt he (George)'ll think that this fellow was indiscreet; but he (George) can't go beyond thinking. You'll only be raising a blister for yourself.'' (unknown)

``Raising a what?'' (unknown)

``A blister, my lord. The longer I live the more convinced I become that a man shouldn't keep his (man) own sores open.'' (son)

There was something in the tone of his (son) son's conversation which pained the Marquis much; but his (Marquis) son was known to be a wise and prudent man, and one who was rising in the political world. The Marquis sighed, and shook his (Marquis) head, and murmured something as to the duty which lay upon the great to bear the troubles incident to their greatness;--by which he (Marquis) meant that sores and blisters should be kept open, if the exigencies of rank so required. But he (Marquis) ended the discussion at last by declaring that he (Marquis) would rest upon the matter for forty-eight hours. Unfortunately before those forty-eight hours were over Lord St. George had gone from Turnover Castle, and the Marquis was left to his (Marquis) own lights. In the meantime, the father and son and one or two friends, had been shooting over at Bullhampton; so that no further steps of warfare had been taken when Mr. and Mrs. Fenwick met the Marquis on the pathway.

On the following day his (Marquis) lordship sat in his (lordship) own private room thinking of his (lordship) grievance. He (lordship) had thought of it and of little else for now nearly sixty hours.

``Suggest to me to turn out my daughters! Heaven and earth! My daughters!'' (He)
He (lordship) was well aware that, though he (lordship) and his (lordship) son often differed, he (lordship) could never so safely keep himself out of trouble as by following his (lordship) son's advice. But surely this was a matter per se, standing altogether on its own bottom, very different from those ordinary details of life on which he (lordship) and his (lordship) son were wont to disagree. His (lordship) daughters! The Ladies Sophie and Carolina Stowte! It had been suggested to him (lordship) to turn them out of his (lordship) house because-- Oh! oh! The insult was so great that no human marquis could stand it. He (marquis) longed to be writing a letter to the bishop. He (marquis) was proud of his (marquis) letters. Pen and paper were at hand, and he (marquis) did write.

RIGHT REV. AND DEAR LORD BISHOP,

I think it right to represent to your lordship the conduct,--I believe I may be justified in saying the misconduct,--of the Reverend -- Fenwick, the vicar of Bullhampton.

He (Fenwick) knew our friend's Christian name very well, but he (Fenwick) did not choose to have it appear that his (Fenwick) august memory had been laden with a thing so trifling.

You may have heard that there has been a most horrid murder committed in the parish on one of my tenants; and that suspicion is rife that the murder was committed in part by a young man, the son of a miller who lives under a person who owns some land in the parish. The family is very bad, one of the daughters being, as I understand, a prostitute. The other day I thought it right to visit the parish with the view of preventing, if possible, the sojourn there among my people of these objectionable characters. When there I was encountered by Mr. Fenwick, not only in a most unchristian spirit, but in a bearing so little gentlemanlike, that I cannot describe it to you. He (Fenwick) had obtruded himself into my presence, into one of my own houses, the very house of the murdered man, and there, when I was consulting with the person to whom I have alluded as to the expediency of ridding ourselves of these objectionable characters, he (man) met me with ribaldry and personal insolence. When I tell your lordship that he (lordship) made insinuations about my own daughters, so gross that I cannot repeat them to you, I am sure that I need go no further. There were present at this meeting Mr. Puddleham, the Methodist minister, and Mr. Henry Gilmore, the landlord of the persons in question.

Your lordship has probably heard the character, in a religious point of view, of this gentleman. It is not for me to express an opinion of the motives which can induce such a one to retain his (gentleman) position as an incumbent of a parish. But I do believe that I have a right to ask from your lordship for some inquiry into the scene which I have attempted to describe, and to expect some protection for the future. I do not for a moment doubt that your lordship will do what is right in the matter.

I have the honour to be, Right Reverend and dear Lord Bishop, Your most obedient and faithful Servant,

TROWBRIDGE.

He (TROWBRIDGE) read this over thrice, and became so much in love with the composition, that on the third reading he (TROWBRIDGE) had not the slightest doubt as to the expediency of sending it. Nor had he (TROWBRIDGE) much doubt but that the bishop would do something to Mr. Fenwick, which would make the parish too hot to hold that disgrace to the Church of England.

When Fenwick came home from Pycroft Common he (Fenwick) found a letter from the bishop awaiting him (Fenwick). He (Fenwick) had driven forty miles on that day, and was rather late for dinner. His (Fenwick) wife, however, came upstairs with him (Fenwick) in order that she (wife) might hear something of his (Fenwick) story, and brought his (Fenwick) letters with her (wife). He (Fenwick) did not open that from the bishop till he (Fenwick) was half dressed, and then burst out into loud laughter as he (Fenwick) read it.

``What is it, Frank?'' (wife)
asked his (Fenwick) wife, through the open door of her (wife) own room.

``Here's such a game,'' (he)
said he (Fenwick).
``Never mind; let's have dinner, and then you shall see it.'' (The reader)
The reader, however, may be quite sure that Mrs. Fenwick did not wait till dinner was served before she (Fenwick) knew the nature of the game.

The bishop's letter to the Vicar was very short and very rational, and it was not that which made the Vicar laugh; but inside the bishop's letter was that from the Marquis.

``My dear Mr. Fenwick,'' (the bishop)
said the bishop,

after a good deal of consideration, I have determined to send you the enclosed. I do so because I have made it a rule never to receive an accusation against one of my clergy without sending it to the person accused. You will, of course, perceive that it alludes to some matter which lies outside of my control and right of inquiry; but perhaps you will allow me, as a friend, to suggest to you that it is always well for a parish clergyman to avoid controversy and quarrel with his (clergyman) neighbours; and that it is especially expedient that he (clergyman) should be on good terms with those who have influence in his (clergyman) parish. Perhaps you will forgive me if I add that a spirit of pugnacity, though no doubt it may lead to much that is good, has its bad tendencies if not watched closely.

Pray remember that Lord Trowbridge is a worthy man, doing his (Trowbridge) duty on the whole well; and that his (Trowbridge) position, though it be entitled to no veneration, is entitled to much respect. If you can tell me that you will feel no grudge against him (Trowbridge) for what has taken place, I shall be very happy.

You will observe that I have been careful that this letter shall have no official character.

Yours very faithfully,

&c., &c., &c.

The letter was answered that evening, but before the answer was written, the Marquis of Trowbridge was discussed between the husband and wife, not in complimentary terms. Mrs. Fenwick on the occasion was more pugnacious than her (Fenwick) husband. She (Fenwick) could not forgive the man who had hinted to the bishop that her (Fenwick) husband held his (husband) living from unworthy motives, and that he (husband) was a bad clergyman.

``My dear girl,'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)

MY DEAR LORD BISHOP,

I return the Marquis's letter with many thanks. I can assure you that I take in proper spirit your little hints as to my pugnacity of disposition, and will endeavour to profit by them. My wife tells me that I am given to combativeness, and I have no doubt that she (wife) is right.

As to Lord Trowbridge, I can assure your lordship that I will not bear any malice against him (Trowbridge), or even think ill of him (Trowbridge) because of his (Trowbridge) complaint. He (Trowbridge) and I probably differ in opinion about almost everything, and he (Trowbridge) is one of those who pity the condition of all who are so blinded as to differ from him (Trowbridge). I hope I may be allowed to assure your lordship, without any reference to my motives for keeping it, that I shall be very slow to give up a living in your lordship's diocese. As your letter to me is unofficial,--and I thank you heartily for sending it in such form,--I have ventured to reply in the same strain.

I am, my dear Lord Bishop, Your very faithful servant,

``There,'' (he)

``I shall never see the remainder of the series. I would give a shilling to know how the bishop gets out of it in writing to the Marquis, and half-a-crown to see the Marquis's rejoinder.'' (wife)
The reader shall be troubled with neither, as he (FENWICK) would hardly price them so high as did the Vicar. The bishop's letter really contained little beyond an assurance on his (bishop) part that Mr. Fenwick had not meant anything wrong, and that the matter was one with which he (Fenwick), the bishop, had no concern; all which was worded with most complete episcopal courtesy. The rejoinder of the Marquis was long, elaborate, and very pompous. He (Marquis) did not exactly scold the bishop, but he (Marquis) expressed very plainly his (Marquis) opinion that the Church of England was going to the dogs, because a bishop had not the power of utterly abolishing any clergyman who might be guilty of an offence against so distinguished a person as the Marquis of Trowbridge.

``Why would the other servants mind it?'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)
asked Fenwick. But his (Fenwick) wife on such a matter could have a way of her (wife) own, and that project was soon knocked on the head. No doubt her (wife) father's house was the proper place for her (wife), but then her (wife) father was so dour a man.

``Upon my word,'' (the Vicar)
said the Vicar,

CHAPTER XXVII.

``I NEVER SHAMED NONE OF THEM.'' (unknown)

``Something must be done about Carry Brattle at once.'' (The Vicar)
The Vicar felt that he (Vicar) had pledged himself to take some steps for her (wife) welfare, and it seemed to him (Vicar), as he (Vicar) thought of the matter, that there were only two steps possible. He (Vicar) might intercede with her (wife) father, or he (Vicar) might use his (Vicar) influence to have her (wife) received into some house of correction, some retreat, in which she (wife) might be kept from evil and disciplined for good. He (Vicar) knew that the latter would be the safer plan, if it could be brought to bear; and it would certainly be the easier for himself. But he (Vicar) thought that he (Vicar) had almost pledged himself to the girl not to attempt it, and he (Vicar) felt sure that she (girl) would not accede to it. He (Vicar) found the Squire and the Prebendary together, and at once started his (Vicar) subject.

Gilmore and Fenwick walked down to the mill together, it being understood that the Squire was not to show himself there. Fenwick's difficult task, if it were to be done at all, must be done by himself alone. He (Fenwick) must beard the lion in his (Fenwick) den, and make the attack without any assistant. ``He (Henry) can't eat me,'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)

``I shall break up the house and get away,'' (he)
said he (Gilmore).

``Don't do that rashly, Harry. There can be no spot in the world in which you can be so useful as you are here.'' (unknown)

``All my usefulness has been dragged out of me. I don't care about the place or about the people. I am ill already, and shall become worse. I think I will go abroad for four or five years. I've an idea I shall go to the States.'' (unknown)

``Atra Cura sits behind the horseman,'' (the Vicar)

I'm sure that the same prescription holds good for all maladies of the mind. You can't earn the half-crown a day, but you may work as hard as though you did.'' (unknown)

Fenwick was about half a mile from the mill when Gilmore left him (Gilmore), and he (Gilmore) wished that it were a mile and a half. He (Gilmore) knew well that an edict had gone forth at the mill that no one should speak to the old man about his (man) daughter. With the mother the Vicar had often spoken of her (mother) lost child, and had learned from her (mother) how sad it was to her (mother) that she (mother) could never dare to mention Carry's name to her (mother) husband. He (husband) had cursed his (husband) child, and had sworn that she (mother) should never more have part in him (husband) or his (husband). She (mother) had brought sorrow and shame upon him (husband), and he (husband) had cut her (mother) off with a steady resolve that there should be no weak backsliding on his (husband) part. Those who knew him (husband) best declared that the miller would certainly keep his (miller) word, and hitherto no one had dared to speak of the lost one in her (mother) father's hearing. All this Mr. Fenwick knew, and he (Fenwick) knew also that the man was one who could be very fierce in his (man) anger. He (man) had told his (man) wife that old Brattle was the only man in the world before whom he (Brattle) would be afraid to speak his (Brattle) mind openly, and in so saying he (Brattle) had expressed a feeling that was very general throughout all Bullhampton. Mr. Puddleham was a very meddlesome man, and he (Puddleham) had once ventured out to the mill to say a word, not indeed about Carry, but touching some youthful iniquity of which Sam was supposed to have been guilty. He (Sam) never went near the mill again, but would shudder and lift up his (Sam) hands and his (Sam) eyes when the miller's name was mentioned. It was not that Brattle used rough language, or became violently angry when accosted; but there was a sullen sternness about the man, and a capability of asserting his (man) own mastery and personal authority, which reduced those who attacked him (man) to the condition of vanquished combatants, and repulsed them, so that they would retreat as beaten dogs. Mr. Fenwick, indeed, had always been well received at the mill. The women of the family loved him (Fenwick) dearly, and took great comfort in his (Fenwick) visits. From his (Fenwick) first arrival in the parish he (Fenwick) had been on intimate terms with them, though the old man had never once entered his (man) church. But even Fenwick had been so answered more than once as to have been forced to retreat with that feeling of having his (Fenwick) tail, like a cur, between his (Fenwick) legs.

``He (Harry) can't eat me,'' (he)
he (Fenwick) said to himself, as the low willows round the mill came in sight. When a man is reduced to that consolation, as many a man often is, he (man) may be nearly sure that he (man) will be eaten.

When he (man) got over the stile into the lane close to the mill-door, he (man) found that the mill was going. Gilmore had told him (Gilmore) that it might probably be so, as he (Gilmore) had heard that the repairs were nearly finished. Fenwick was sure that after so long a period of enforced idleness Brattle would be in the mill, but he (Fenwick) went at first into the house and there found Mrs. Brattle and Fanny. Even with them he (Fenwick) hardly felt himself to be at home, but after a while managed to ask a few questions about Sam. Sam had come back, and was now at work, but he (Sam) had had some terribly hard words with his (Sam) father. The old man had desired to know where his (man) son had been. Sam had declined to tell, and had declared that if he (Sam) was to be cross-questioned about his (Sam) comings and goings he (Sam) would leave the mill altogether. His (Sam) father had told him (Sam) that he (Sam) had better go. Sam had not gone, but the two had been working on together since without interchanging a word.

London, Sunday.

HONOURED SIR,

I told you that I would write if it came as I was going away, but I've been forced to go without writing. There was nothing to write with at the cottage. Mrs. Burrows and me had words, and I thought as she (Burrows) would rob me, and perhaps worse. Yours humbly, and most unfortunate,

If it's any good to be sorry, nobody can be more sorry than me, and nobody more unhappy. I did try to pray when you was gone, but it only made me more ashamed. If there was only anywhere to go to, I'd go.

CHAPTER XXIX.

THE BULL AT LORING.

Gilmore had told his (Gilmore) friend that he (Gilmore) would do two things,--that he (Gilmore) would start off and travel for four or five years, and that he (Gilmore) would pay a visit to Loring. Fenwick had advised him (Fenwick) to do neither, but to stay at home and dig and say his (Fenwick) prayers. But in such emergencies no man takes his (man) friend's advice; and when Mr. Chamberlaine had left him (Chamberlaine), Gilmore had made up his (Gilmore) mind that he (Gilmore) would at any rate go to Loring. He (Gilmore) went to church on the Sunday morning, and was half resolved to tell Mrs. Fenwick of his (Gilmore) purpose; but chance delayed her (Fenwick) in the church, and he (Gilmore) sauntered away home without having mentioned it. He (Gilmore) let half the next week pass by without stirring beyond his (Gilmore) own ground. During those three days he (Gilmore) changed his (Gilmore) mind half a dozen times; but at last, on the Thursday, he (Gilmore) had his (Gilmore) portmanteau packed and started on his (Gilmore) journey. As he (Gilmore) was preparing to leave the house he (Gilmore) wrote one line to Fenwick in pencil.

``I am this moment off to Loring.--H. G.'' (he)
This he (Fenwick) left in the village as he (Fenwick) drove through to the Westbury station.

He (Fenwick) had formed no idea in his (Fenwick) own mind of any definite purpose in going. He (Fenwick) did not know what he (Fenwick) should do or what say when he (Fenwick) got to Loring. He (Loring) had told himself a hundred times that any persecution of the girl on his (Loring) part would be mean and unworthy of him (Loring). And he (Loring) was also aware that no condition in which a man could place himself was more open to contempt than that of a whining, pining, unsuccessful lover. A man is bound to take a woman's decision against him (man), bear it as he (man) may, and say as little against it as possible. He (man) is bound to do so when he (man) is convinced that a woman's decision is final; and there can be no stronger proof of such finality than the fact that she (woman) has declared a preference for some other man. All this Gilmore knew, but he (Gilmore) would not divest himself of the idea that there might still be some turn in the wheel of fortune. He (Gilmore) had heard a vague rumour that Captain Marrable, his (Marrable) rival, was a very dangerous man. His (Marrable) uncle was quite sure that the Captain's father was thoroughly bad, and had thrown out hints against the son, which Gilmore in his (Gilmore) anxiety magnified till he (Gilmore) felt convinced that the girl whom he (Gilmore) loved with all his (Gilmore) heart was going to throw herself into the arms of a thorough scamp. Could he (Gilmore) not do something, if not for his (Gilmore) own sake, then for hers? Might it not be possible for him (Gilmore) to deliver her (girl) from her (girl) danger? What, if he (Gilmore) should discover some great iniquity;--would she (girl) not then in her (girl) gratitude be softened towards him (Gilmore)? It was on the cards that this reprobate was married already, and was about to commit bigamy. It was quite probable that such a man should be deeply in debt. As for the fortune that had been left to him (man), Mr. Chamberlaine had already ascertained that that amounted to nothing. It had been consumed to the last shilling in paying the joint debts of the father and son. Men such as Mr. Chamberlaine have sources of information which are marvellous to the minds of those who are more secluded, and not the less marvellous because the information is invariably false. Gilmore in this way almost came to a conviction that Mary Lowther was about to sacrifice herself to a man utterly unworthy of her (Lowther), and he (man) taught himself, not to think,--but to believe it to be possible that he (man) might save her (Lowther). Those who knew him (man) would have said that he (man) was the last man in the world to be carried away by a romantic notion;--but he (man) had his (man) own idea of romance as plainly developed in his (man) mind as was ever the case with a knight of old, who went forth for the relief of a distressed damsel. If he (man) could do anything towards saving her (damsel), he (man) would do it, or try to do it, though he (man) should be brought to ruin in the attempt. Might it not be that at last he (man) would have the reward which other knights always attained? The chance in his (man) favour was doubtless small, but the world was nothing to him (man) without this chance.

He (man) had never been at Loring before, but he (man) had learned the way. He (man) went to Chippenham and Swindon, and then by the train to Loring. He (Loring) had no very definite plan formed for himself. He (Loring) rather thought that he (Loring) would call at Miss Marrable's house,--call if possible when Mary Lowther was not there,--and learn from the elder lady something of the facts of the case. He (Loring) had been well aware for many weeks past, from early days in the summer, that old Miss Marrable had been in favour of his (Loring) claim. He (Loring) had heard too that there had been family quarrels among the Marrables, and a word had been dropped in his (Loring) hearing by Mrs. Fenwick, which had implied that Miss Marrable was by no means pleased with the match which her (Marrable) niece Mary Lowther was proposing to herself. Everything seemed to show that Captain Marrable was a most undesirable person.

He (knight) was shown up to a bedroom, and then ushered into the commercial room of the house. Loring, though it does a very pretty trade as a small town, and now has for some years been regarded as a thriving place in its degree, is not of such importance in the way of business as to support a commercial inn of the first class. At such houses the commercial room is as much closed against the uninitiated as is a first-class club in London. In such rooms a non-commercial man would be almost as much astray as is a non-broker in Capel Court, or an attorney in a bar mess-room. At the Bull things were a little mixed. There is not, as a rule, a regular daily commercial repast; but when three or more gentlemen dine together at five o'clock, the dinner becomes a commercial dinner, and the commercial laws as to wine, &c., are enforced, with more or less restriction as circumstances may seem to demand. CHAPTER XXXII.

MR. GILMORE``S SUCCESS.

Harry Gilmore, the prosperous country gentleman, the county magistrate, the man of acres, the nephew of Mr. Chamberlaine, respected by all who knew him (Chamberlaine),--with the single exception of the Marquis of Trowbridge,--was now so much reduced that he (Trowbridge) felt himself to be an inferior being to Mr. Cockey, with whom he (Cockey) breakfasted. He (Cockey) had come to Loring, and now he (Cockey) was there he (Cockey) did not know what to do with himself. He (Loring) was his (Loring) own master. No one would be injured by anything that he (Loring) might do. He (Loring) had a right to spend his (Loring) income as he (Loring) pleased. He (Loring) had duties to perform, and he (Loring) must perform them, let them be ever so distasteful. It was only an idea, made to be rejected; but, nevertheless, he (Loring) thought of it.

To do something, however, was incumbent on him (Loring). After breakfast he (Loring) sauntered up the hill and saw Captain Marrable enter the house in which Mary Lowther lived. He (Marrable) felt thoroughly ashamed of himself in thus creeping about, and spying things out,--and, in truth, he (Marrable) had not intended thus to watch his (Marrable) rival.
