He (man) had almost brought himself to think that even yet he (man) would succeed at last.

CHAPTER XXXIII.

FAREWELL.

Christmas came, and a month beyond Christmas, and by the end of January Captain Marrable and Miss Lowther had agreed to regard all their autumn work as null and void,--to look back upon the love-making as a thing that had not been, and to part as friends. Both of them suffered much in this arrangement,--the man being the louder in the objurgations which he (man) made against his (man) ill-fortune, and in his (man) assurances to himself and others that he (man) was ruined for life. And, indeed, no man could have been much more unhappy than was Walter Marrable in these days. To him (Marrable) was added the trouble, which he (Marrable) did not endeavour to hide from himself or Mary, that all this misery came to him (Marrable) from his (Marrable) own father. Before the end of November, sundry renewed efforts were made to save a portion of the money, and the lawyers descended so low as to make an offer to take L2000. They might have saved themselves the humiliation, for neither L2000 nor L200 could have been made to be forthcoming. Walter Marrable, when the time came, was painfully anxious to fight somebody; but he (Marrable) was told very clearly by Messrs. Block and Curling, that there was nobody whom he (Marrable) could fight but his (Marrable) father, and that even by fighting his (Marrable) father, he (Marrable) would never obtain a penny.

``My belief,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Curling,
``is, that you could put your father in prison, but that probably is not your object.'' (Mr.)
Marrable was forced to own that that was not his (Marrable) object; but he (Marrable) did so in a tone which seemed to imply that a prison, were it even for life, would be the best place for his (Marrable) father. Block and Curling had been solicitors to the Marrables for ever so many years; and though they did not personally love the Colonel, they had a professional feeling that the blackness of a black sheep of a family should not be made public, at any rate by the family itself or by the family solicitors. Almost every family has a black sheep, and it is the especial duty of a family solicitor to keep the family black sheep from being dragged into the front and visible ranks of the family. The Captain had been fatally wrong in signing the paper which he (Captain) had signed, and must take the consequences.
``I don't think, Captain Marrable, that you would save yourself in any way by proceeding against the Colonel,'' (Mr.)
said Mr. Curling.
``I have not the slightest intention of proceeding against him (Colonel),'' (the Captain)
said the Captain, in great dudgeon,--and then he (Captain) left the office and shook the dust off his (Captain) feet, as against Block and Curling as well as against his (Captain) father.

After this,--immediately after it,--he (Captain) had one other interview with his (Captain) father. As he (Captain) told his (Captain) uncle, the devil prompted him (devil) to go down to Portsmouth to see the man to whom his (devil) interests should have been dearer than to all the world beside, and who had robbed him (devil) so ruthlessly. There was nothing to be gained by such a visit. Neither money nor counsel, nor even consolation would be forthcoming from Colonel Marrable. Probably Walter Marrable felt in his (Marrable) anger that it would be unjust that his (Marrable) father should escape without a word to remind him (father) from his (father) son's mouth of all that he (father) had done for his (father) son. He (Colonel) was a thin old man, who wore padded coats, and painted his (Colonel) beard and his (Colonel) eyebrows, and had false teeth, and who, in spite of chronic absence of means, always was possessed of clothes apparently just new from the hands of a West-end tailor. He (tailor) was one of those men who, through their long, useless, ill-flavoured lives, always contrive to live well, to eat and drink of the best, to lie softly, and to go about in purple and fine linen,--and yet, never have any money. Among a certain set Colonel Marrable, though well known, was still popular. He (Colonel) was good-tempered, well-mannered, sprightly in conversation, and had not a scruple in the world. He (Colonel) was over seventy, had lived hard, and must have known that there was not much more of it for him (Colonel). But yet he (Colonel) had no qualms, and no fears. It may be doubted whether he (Colonel) knew that he (Colonel) was a bad man,--he (Colonel), than whom you could find none worse though you were to search the country from one end to another. To lie, to steal,--not out of tills or pockets, because he (Colonel) knew the danger; to cheat--not at the card-table, because he (Colonel) had never come in the way of learning the lesson; to indulge every passion, though the cost to others might be ruin for life; to know no gods but his (Colonel) own bodily senses, and no duty but that which he (Colonel) owed to those gods; to eat all, and produce nothing; to love no one but himself; to have learned nothing but how to sit at table like a gentleman; to care not at all for his (gentleman) country, or even for his (gentleman) profession; to have no creed, no party, no friend, no conscience, to be troubled with nothing that touched his (gentleman) heart;--such had been, was, and was to be the life of Colonel Marrable. Perhaps it was accounted to him (Marrable) as a merit by some that he (Marrable) did not quail at any coming fate. When his (Marrable) doctor warned him (Marrable) that he (Marrable) must go soon, unless he (Marrable) would refrain from this and that and the other,--so wording his (Marrable) caution that the Colonel could not but know and did know, that let him (Colonel) refrain as he (Colonel) would he (Colonel) must go soon,--he (Colonel) resolved that he (Colonel) would refrain, thinking that the charms of his (Colonel) wretched life were sweet enough to be worth such sacrifice; but in no other respect did the caution affect him (Colonel). He (Colonel) never asked himself whether he (Colonel) had aught even to regret before he (Colonel) died, or to fear afterwards.

There are many Colonel Marrables about in the world, known well to be so at clubs, in drawing-rooms, and by the tradesmen who supply them. Men give them dinners and women smile upon them. The best of coats and boots are supplied to them. They never lack cigars nor champagne. They have horses to ride, and servants to wait upon them more obsequious than the servants of other people. And men will lend them money too,--well knowing that there is no chance of repayment. Now and then one hears a horrid tale of some young girl who surrenders herself to such a one, absolutely for love! Upon the whole the Colonel Marrables are popular. It is hard to follow such a man quite to the end and to ascertain whether or no he (man) does go out softly at last, like the snuff of a candle,--just with a little stink.

-LSB-Illustration: Mary Lowther writes to Walter Marrable.-RSB-

Captain Marrable when he (Marrable) received it, though he (Marrable) acknowledged the truth of all the arguments, loved the girl far too well to feel that this release gave him (Marrable) any comfort. He (Marrable) had doubtless felt that the engagement was a burthen on him (Marrable),--that he (Marrable) would not have entered into it had he (Marrable) not felt sure of his (Marrable) diminished fortune, and that there was a fearful probability that it might never result in their being married; but not the less did the breaking up of it make him (Marrable) very wretched. An engagement for marriage can never be so much to a man as it is to a woman,--marriage itself can never be so much, can never be so great a change, produce such utter misery, or of itself be efficient for such perfect happiness,--but his (man) love was true and steadfast, and when he (man) learned that she (woman) was not to be his (man), he (man) was as a man who had been robbed of his (man) treasure. Her (woman) letter was long and argumentative. His (man) reply was short and passionate;--and the reader shall see it.

Duke Street, January, 186--.

DEAREST MARY,

I suppose you are right. Everybody tells me so, and no doubt everybody tells you the same. The chances are that I shall get bowled over; and as for getting back again, I don't know when I can hope for it. In such a condition it would I believe be very wrong and selfish were I to go and leave you to think of me as your future husband. You would be waiting for that which would never come.

As for me, I shall never care for any other woman. A soldier can get on very well without a wife, and I shall always regard myself now as one of those useless but common animals who are called

``not marrying men.'' (I)
I shall never marry. I shall always carry your picture in my heart, and shall not think that I am sinning against you or any one else when I do so after hearing that you are married.

I need not tell you that I am very wretched. It is not only that I am separated from you, my own dear, dearest girl, but that I cannot refrain from thinking how it has come to pass that it is so. I went down to see my father yesterday. I did see him (father), and you may imagine of what nature was the interview. I sometimes think, when I lie in bed, that no man was ever so ill-treated as I have been.

Dearest love, good-bye. I could not have brought myself to say what you have said, but I know that you are right. It has not been my fault, dear. I did love you, and do love you as truly as any man ever loved a woman.

Yours with all my heart,

WALTER MARRABLE.

I should like to see you once more before I start. Is there any harm in this? I must run down to my uncle's, but I will not go up to you if you think it better not. If you can bring yourself to see me, pray, pray do.

CHAPTER XXXIV.

BULLHAMPTON NEWS.

When the matter was quite settled at Loring,--when Miss Marrable not only knew that the engagement had been surrendered on both sides, but that it had been so surrendered as to be incapable of being again patched up, she (Marrable) bethought herself of her (Marrable) promise to Mr. Gilmore. Miss Marrable had undertaken that Mr. Gilmore should be informed as soon as the engagement was brought to an end, and had been told that this information should reach him (Gilmore) through Mrs. Fenwick. When a fortnight had passed, Miss Marrable was aware that Mary had not herself written to her (Mary) friend at Bullhampton; and though she (Mary) felt herself to be shy of the subject, though she (Mary) entertained a repugnance to make any communication based on a hope that Mary might after a while receive her (Mary) old lover graciously,--for time must of course be needed before such grace could be accorded,--she (Mary) did write a few lines to Mrs. Fenwick. She (Fenwick) explained that Captain Marrable was to return to India, and that he (Marrable) was to go as a free man. Mary, she (Mary) said, bore her (Mary) burden well. Of course, it must be some time before the remembrance of her (Mary) cousin would cease to be a burden to her (Mary); but she (Mary) went about her (Mary) heavy task with a good will,--so said Miss Marrable,--and would no doubt conquer her (Marrable) own unhappiness after a time by the strength of her (Marrable) personal character. ``And it will be a comfort to him (governor),'' (husband)

``It is the man's nature,'' (the parson)
said the parson.

Everything had been very quiet at Bullhampton during the last three months. The mill was again in regular work, and Sam had remained at home with fair average regularity. The Vicar had heard nothing more of Carry Brattle, and had been unable to trace her (Fenwick) or to learn where she (Fenwick) was living. The strangest and most important piece of business going on at this time in Bullhampton was the building of a new chapel or tabernacle,--the people called it a Salem,--for Mr. Puddleham. The first word as to the erection reached Mr. Fenwick's ears from Grimes, the builder and carpenter, who, meeting him (Grimes) in Bullhampton Street, pointed out to him (Grimes) a bit of spare ground just opposite the vicarage gates,--a morsel of a green on which no building had ever yet stood, and told him (Grimes) that the Marquis had given it for a chapel.

This he (Fenwick) said in a cheery tone, showing thereby considerable presence of mind. A cottage built there would have been offensive; but a staring brick Methodist chapel, with the word Salem inserted in large letters over the door, would, as he (Marquis) was aware, flout him (Marquis) every time he (Marquis) left or entered his (Marquis) garden. He (Marquis) had always been specially careful to avoid any semblance of a quarrel with the Methodist minister, and had in every way shown his (minister) willingness to regard Mr. Puddleham's flock as being equal to his (minister) own in the general gifts of civilisation. To Mr. Puddleham himself, he (Puddleham) had been very civil, sending him (Puddleham) fruit and vegetables out of the Vicarage garden, and lending him (Puddleham) newspapers. When the little Puddlehams were born, Mrs. Fenwick always inquired after the mother and infant. The greatest possible care had been exercised at the Vicarage since Mr. Fenwick's coming to show that the Established Church did not despise the dissenting congregation. A large and commodious spot of ground, remote from the vicarage, had, as he (Puddleham) believed, been chosen. When he (Puddleham) heard those tidings, and saw what would be the effect of the building, it seemed to him (Puddleham) almost impossible that a Marquis could condescend to such revenge. MR. PUDDLEHAM``S NEW CHAPEL.

The Vicar devoted a week to the consideration of his (Vicar) grievance about the chapel, and then did write to the Marquis. Mr. Puddleham had been much elated by the prospect of his (Puddleham) new Bethel, and had, it must be confessed, received into his (Puddleham) mind an idea that it would be a good thing to quarrel with the Vicar under the auspices of the landlord. Fenwick's character had hitherto been too strong for him (character), and he (character) had been forced into parochial quiescence and religious amity almost in spite of his (character) conscience. He (character) was a much older man than Mr. Fenwick, having been for thirty years in the ministry, and he (Fenwick) had always previously enjoyed the privilege of being on bad terms with the clergyman of the Establishment. It had been his (clergyman) glory to be a poacher on another man's manor, to filch souls, as it were, out of the keeping of a pastor of a higher grade than himself, to say severe things of the short comings of an endowed clergyman, and to obtain recognition of his (clergyman) position by the activity of his (clergyman) operations in the guise of a blister. Our Vicar, understanding something of this, had, with some malice towards the gentleman himself, determined to rob Mr. Puddleham of his (Puddleham) blistering powers. There is no doubt a certain pleasure in poaching which does not belong to the licit following of game; but a man can't poach if the right of shooting be accorded to him (man). Mr. Puddleham had not been quite happy in his (Puddleham) mind amidst the ease and amiable relations which Mr. Fenwick enforced upon him (Fenwick), and had long since begun to feel that a few cabbages and peaches did not repay him (Fenwick) for the loss of those pleasant and bitter things, which it would have been his (Fenwick) to say in his (Fenwick) daily walks and from the pulpit of his (Fenwick) Salem, had he (Fenwick) not been thus hampered, confined, and dominated. He (Fenwick) told himself that though he (Fenwick) had not hankered after these flesh-pots, that though he (Fenwick) would have preferred to be without the flesh-pots, he (Fenwick) had submitted to them. He (Fenwick) was painfully conscious of the guile of this young man, who had, as it were, cheated him (man) out of that appropriate acerbity of religion, without which a proselyting sect can hardly maintain its ground beneath the shadow of an endowed and domineering Church. War was necessary to Mr. Puddleham. He (Puddleham) had come to be hardly anybody at all, because he (Puddleham) was at peace with the vicar of the parish in which he (Puddleham) was established. Mr. Puddleham had his (Puddleham) eye keenly set on the scene of his (Puddleham) future ministration, and was aware of Grimes's default almost as soon as that man with his (man) myrmidons had left the ground. If he (Vicar) couldn't be allowed to do as much as that for the Vicar of the parish, Bullhampton wouldn't be, in Mr. Grimes's opinion, any place for anybody to live in. Mr. Puddleham argued the matter out, but he (Puddleham) argued in vain. ``The Marquis doesn't change his (Marquis) mind, Mr. Grimes,'' (he)

By this time all Bullhampton knew of the quarrel,--knew of it, although Mr. Fenwick had been so very careful to guard himself from any quarrelling at all. He (Fenwick) had not spoken a word in anger on the subject to anyone but his (Fenwick) wife; and in making his (Fenwick) request to Grimes had done so with hypocritical good humour. But, nevertheless, he (Grimes) was aware that the parish was becoming hot about it; and when he (Grimes) sat down to write his (Grimes) letter to the Marquis he (Marquis) was almost minded to give up the idea of writing, to return to Grimes, and to allow the measuring and sod-turning to be continued. Why should a place of worship opposite to his (Grimes) gate be considered by him (Grimes) as an injury? Why should the psalm-singing of Christian brethren hurt his (Christian) ears as he (Christian) walked about his (Christian) garden? And if, through the infirmity of his (Christian) nature, his (Christian) eyes and his (Christian) ears were hurt, what was that to the great purport for which he (Christian) had been sent into the parish? Was he (Christian) not about to create enmity by his (Christian) opposition; and was it not his (Christian) special duty to foster love and goodwill among his (Christian) people? After all he (Christian), within his (Christian) own Vicarage grounds, had all that it was intended that he (Christian) should possess; and that he (Christian) held very firmly. Poor Mr. Puddleham had no such firm holding; and why should he (Puddleham) quarrel with Mr. Puddleham because that ill-paid preacher sought to strengthen the ground on which his (Puddleham) Salem stood?

As he (Puddleham) paused, however, to think of all this, there came upon him (Puddleham) the conviction that in this thing that was to be done the Marquis was determined to punish him (Marquis) personally, and he (Marquis) could not resist the temptation of fighting the Marquis. And then, if he (Marquis) succumbed easily in this matter, would it not follow almost as a matter of course that the battle against him (Marquis) would be carried on elsewhere? If he (Marquis) yielded now, resolving to ignore altogether any idea of his (Marquis) own comfort or his (Marquis) own taste, would he (Marquis) thereby maintain that tranquillity in his (Marquis) parish which he (Marquis) thought so desirable? He (Marquis) had already seen that in Mr. Puddleham's manner to himself which made him (Puddleham) sure that Mr. Puddleham was ambitious to be a sword in the right hand of the Marquis. Personally the Vicar was himself pugnacious. Few men, perhaps, were more so. If there must be a fight let them come on, and he (Vicar) would do his (Vicar) best. Turning the matter thus backwards and forwards in his (Vicar) mind, he (Vicar) came at last to the conclusion that there must be a fight, and consequently he (Vicar) wrote the following letter to the Marquis;--

Bullhampton Vicarage, January 3, 186--.

MY LORD MARQUIS,

I learned by chance the other day in the village that a new chapel for the use of the Methodist congregation of the parish was to be built on the little open green immediately opposite the Vicarage gate, and that this special spot of ground had been selected and given by your lordship for this purpose. I do not at all know what truth there may be in this,--except that Mr. Grimes, the carpenter here, has received orders from your agent about the work. It may probably be the case that the site has been chosen by Mr. Packer, and not by your lordship. As no real delay to the building can at this time of the year arise from a short postponement of the beginning, I have asked Mr. Grimes to desist till I shall have written to you on the subject.

I can assure your lordship, in the first place, that no clergyman of the Established Church in the kingdom can be less unwilling than I am that they who dissent from my teaching in the parish should have a commodious place of worship. If land belonged to me in the place I would give it myself for such a purpose; and were there no other available site than that chosen, I would not for a moment remonstrate against it. I had heard, with satisfaction, from Mr. Puddleham himself that another spot was chosen near the cross roads in the village, on which there is more space, to which as I believe there is no objection, and which would certainly be nearer than that now selected to the majority of the congregation.

But of course it would not be for me to trouble your lordship as to the ground on which a Methodist chapel should be built, unless I had reason to show why the site now chosen is objectionable. I do not for a moment question your lordship's right to give the site. There is something less than a quarter of an acre in the patch in question; and though hitherto I have always regarded it as belonging in some sort to the Vicarage,--as being a part, as it were, of the entrance,--I feel convinced that you, as landlord of the ground, would not entertain the idea of bestowing it for any purpose without being sure of your right to do so. I raise no question on this point, believing that there is none to be raised; but I respectfully submit to your lordship, whether such an erection as that contemplated by you will not be a lasting injury to the Vicarage of Bullhampton, and whether you would wish to inflict a lasting and gratuitous injury on the vicar of a parish, the greatest portion of which belongs to yourself.

No doubt life will be very possible to me and my wife, and to succeeding vicars and their wives, with a red-brick chapel built as a kind of watch-tower over the Vicarage gate. So would life be possible at Turnover Park with a similar edifice immediately before your lordship's hall-door. Knowing very well that the reasonable wants of the Methodists cannot make such a building on such a spot necessary, you no doubt would not consent to it; and I now venture to ask you to put a stop to this building here for the same reason. Were there no other site in the parish equally commodious I would not say a word.

I have the honour to be, Your lordship's most obedient servant,

FRANCIS FENWICK.

Lord Trowbridge, when he (Trowbridge) received this letter,--when he (Trowbridge) had only partially read it, and had not at all digested it, was disposed to yield the point. He (Trowbridge) was a silly man, thinking much too highly of his (Trowbridge) own position, believing himself entitled to unlimited deference from all those who in any way came within the rays of his (Trowbridge) magnificence, and easily made angry by opposition; but he (Trowbridge) was not naturally prone to inflict evil, and did in some degree recognise it as a duty attached to his (Trowbridge) splendour that he (Trowbridge) should be beneficent to the inferiors with whom he (Trowbridge) was connected. Great as was his (Trowbridge) wrath against the present Vicar of Bullhampton, and thoroughly as he (Trowbridge) conceived it to be expedient that so evil-minded a pastor should be driven out of the parish, nevertheless he (pastor) felt some scruple at taking a step which would be injurious to the parish vicar, let the parish vicar be who he (vicar) might. Packer was the sinner who had originated the new plan for punishing Mr. Fenwick,--Packer, with the assistance of Mr. Puddleham; and the Marquis, though he (Marquis) had in some sort authorised the plan, had in truth thought very little about it. When the Vicar spoke of the lasting injury to the Vicarage, and when Lord Trowbridge remembered that he (Trowbridge) owned two thousand and two acres within the parish,--as Mr. Puddleham had told him (Puddleham),--he (Puddleham) began to think that the chapel had better be built elsewhere. The Vicar was a pestilent man to whom punishment was due, but the punishment should be made to attach itself to the man, rather than to the man's office. So was working the Marquis's mind, till the Marquis came upon that horrid passage in the Vicar's letter, in which it was suggested that the building of a Methodist chapel in his (Vicar) own park, immediately in front of his (Vicar) own august hall-door might under certain circumstances be expedient. The remark was almost as pernicious and unpardonable as that which had been made about his (Vicar) lordship's daughters. It was manifest to him (Vicar) that the Vicar intended to declare that marquises were no more than other people,--and that the declaration was made and insisted on with the determination of insulting him (Vicar). Had this apostate priest been capable of feeling any proper appreciation of his (priest) own position and that of the Marquis, he (Marquis) would have said nothing of Turnover Park. When the Marquis had read the letter a second time and had digested it he (Marquis) perceived that its whole tenour was bad, that the writer was evil-minded, and that no request made by him (writer) should be granted. Even though the obnoxious chapel should have to be pulled down for the benefit of another vicar, it should be put up for the punishment of this vicar. A man who wants to have a favour done for him (man), can hardly hope to be successful if he (man) asks for the favour with insolence. So the heart of the Marquis was hardened, and he (Marquis) was strengthened to do that which misbecame him (Marquis) both as a gentleman and a landlord.

He (Marquis) did not answer the letter for some time; but he (Marquis) saw Packer, saw his (Marquis) head agent, and got out the map of the property. The map of the property was not very clear in the matter, but he (Marquis) remembered the space well, and convinced himself that no other place in all Bullhampton could be so appropriate for a Methodist chapel. At the end of a week he (Marquis) caused a reply to be written to Mr. Fenwick. He (Fenwick) would not demean himself by writing with his (Fenwick) own hand, but he (Fenwick) gave his (Fenwick) orders to the head agent. The head agent merely informed the Vicar that it was considered that the spot of ground in question was the most appropriate in the village for the purpose in hand.

Mrs. Fenwick when she (Fenwick) heard the reply burst out into tears. She (Fenwick) was a woman by no means over devoted to things of this world, who thought much of her (Fenwick) duties and did them, who would have sacrificed anything for her (Fenwick) husband and children, who had learned the fact that both little troubles and great, if borne with patience, may be borne with ease; but she (Fenwick) did think much of her (Fenwick) house, was proud of her (Fenwick) garden, and rejoiced in the external prettiness of her (Fenwick) surroundings. It was gall to her (Fenwick) that this hideous building should be so placed as to destroy the comeliness of that side of her (Fenwick) abode.

``We shall hear their singing and ranting whenever we open our front windows,'' (she)
she (Fenwick) said.

``Then we won't open them,'' (the Vicar)
said the Vicar.

``We can't help ourselves. Just see what it will be whenever we go in and out. We might just as well have it inside the house at once.'' (unknown)

``You speak as though Mr. Puddleham were always in his (Puddleham) pulpit.'' (unknown)

``They're always doing something,--and then the building will be there whether it's open or shut. It will alter the parish altogether, and I really think it will be better that you should get an exchange.'' (unknown)

``And run away from my enemy?'' (unknown)

``It would be running away from an intolerable nuisance.'' (unknown)

``I won't do that,'' (the Vicar)
said the Vicar.
``If there were no other reason for staying, I won't put it in the power of the Marquis of Trowbridge to say that he (Trowbridge) has turned me out of my parish, and so punished me because I have not submitted myself to him (Trowbridge). I have not sought the quarrel. He (Trowbridge) has been overbearing and insolent, and now is meanly desirous to injure me because I will not suffer his (Trowbridge) insolence. No doubt, placed as he (Trowbridge) is, he (Trowbridge) can do much; but he (Trowbridge) cannot turn me out of Bullhampton.'' (unknown)

``What is the good of staying, Frank, if we are to be made wretched?'' (unknown)

``We won't be made wretched. What! be wretched because there is an ugly building opposite to your outside gate? It is almost wicked to say so. I don't like it. I like the doing of the thing less even than the thing itself. If it can be stopped, I will stop it. If it could be prevented by any amount of fighting, I should think myself right to fight in such a cause. If I can see my way to doing anything to oppose the Marquis, it shall be done. But I won't run away.'' (Mrs. Fenwick)
Mrs. Fenwick said nothing more on the subject at that moment, but she (Fenwick) felt that the glory and joy of the Vicarage were gone from it.

CHAPTER XXXVI.

SAM BRATTLE GOES OFF AGAIN.

Mr. Grimes had suggested to the Vicar in a very low whisper that the new chapel might perhaps be put down as a nuisance.

``It ain't for me to say, of course,'' (Mr. Grimes/Grimes)
said Mr. Grimes,
``and in the way of business one building is as good as another as long as you see your money. But buildings is stopped because they're nuisances.'' (Mr. Grimes/Grimes)
This occurred a day or two after the receipt of the agent's letter from Turnover, and the communication was occasioned by orders given to Mr. Grimes to go on with the building instantly, unless he (Grimes) intended to withdraw from the job.
``I don't think, Grimes, that I can call a place of Christian worship a nuisance,'' (the Vicar)
said the Vicar. To this Grimes rejoined that he (Grimes) had known a nunnery bell to be stopped because it was a nuisance, and that he (Grimes) didn't see why a Methodist chapel bell was not as bad as a nunnery bell. Fenwick had declared that he (Fenwick) would fight if he (Fenwick) could find a leg to stand upon, and he (Fenwick) thanked Grimes, saying that he (Grimes) would think of the suggestion. But when he (Grimes) thought of it, he (Grimes) did not see that any remedy was open to him (Grimes) on that side. In the meantime Mr. Puddleham attacked Grimes with great severity because the work was not continued. Mr. Puddleham, feeling that he (Puddleham) had the Marquis at his (Puddleham) back, was eager for the fight. He (Puddleham) had already received in the street a salutation from the Vicar, cordial as usual, with the very slightest bend of his (Vicar) neck, and the sourest expression of his (Vicar) mouth. Mrs. Puddleham had already taught the little Puddlehams that the Vicarage cabbages were bitter with the wormwood of an endowed Establishment, and ought no longer to be eaten by the free children of an open Church. Mr. Puddleham had already raised up his (Puddleham) voice in his (Puddleham) existing tabernacle, as to the injury which was being done to his (Puddleham) flock, and had been very touching on the subject of the little vineyard which the wicked king coveted. When he (king) described himself as Naboth, it could not but be supposed that Ahab and Jezebel were both in Bullhampton. It went forth through the village that Mr. Puddleham had described Mrs. Fenwick as Jezebel, and the torch of discord had been thrown down, and war was raging through the parish.

There had come to be very high words indeed between Mr. Grimes and Mr. Puddleham, and some went so far as to declare that they had heard the builder threaten to punch the minister's head. This Mr. Grimes denied stoutly, as the Methodist party were making much of it in consequence of Mr. Puddleham's cloth and advanced years.

``There's no lies is too hot for them,'' (Mr. Grimes/Grimes)
said Mr. Grimes, in his (Grimes) energy, and
``no lawlessness too heavy.'' (Mr. Grimes/Grimes)
Then he (Grimes) absolutely refused to put his (Grimes) hand to a spade or a trowel. He (Grimes) had his (Grimes) time named in his (Grimes) contract, he (Grimes) said, and nobody had a right to drive him (Grimes). This was ended by the appearance on a certain Monday morning of a Baptist builder from Salisbury, with all the appurtenances of his (builder) trade, and with a declaration on Mr. Grimes' part, that he (Grimes) would have the law on the two leading members of the Puddleham congregation, from whom he (Grimes) had received his (Grimes) original order. In truth, however, there had been no contract, and Mr. Grimes had gone to work upon a verbal order which, according to the Puddleham theory, he (Grimes) had already vitiated by refusing compliance with its terms. He (Grimes), however, was hot upon his (Grimes) lawsuit, and thus the whole parish was by the ears.

It may be easily understood how much Mr. Fenwick would suffer from all this. It had been specially his (Fenwick) pride that his (Fenwick) parish had been at peace, and he (Fenwick) had plumed himself on the way in which he (Fenwick) had continued to clip the claws with which nature had provided the Methodist minister. Though he (minister) was fond of a fight himself, he (minister) had taught himself to know that in no way could he (minister) do the business of his (minister) life more highly or more usefully than as a peacemaker; and as a peacemaker he (peacemaker) had done it. He (peacemaker) had never put his (peacemaker) hand within Mr. Puddleham's arm, and whispered a little parochial nothing into his (Puddleham) neighbour's ear, without taking some credit to himself for his (Puddleham) cleverness. He (Puddleham) had called his (Puddleham) peaches angels of peace, and had spoken of his (Puddleham) cabbages as being dove-winged. All this was now over, and there was hardly one in Bullhampton who was not busy hating and abusing somebody else.

And then there came another trouble on the Vicar. Just at the end of January, Sam Brattle came up to the Vicarage and told Mr. Fenwick that he (Fenwick) was going to leave the mill. Sam was dressed very decently; but he (Sam) was attired in an un-Bullhampton fashion, which was not pleasant to Mr. Fenwick's eyes; and there was about him (Fenwick) an air which seemed to tell of filial disobedience and personal independence.

``But you mean to come back again, Sam?'' (the Vicar)
said the Vicar.

``Well, sir; I don't know as I do. Father and I has had words.'' (unknown)

``And that is to be a reason why you should leave him (Father)? You speak of your father as though he (father) were no more to you than another man.'' (unknown)

``You do, sir.'' (unknown)

``He (Sam) is a very just man, and he (Sam) is very fond of you. You are the apple of his (Sam) eye, and now you would bring his (Sam) gray hairs with sorrow to the grave.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean that he (Sam) has banished you from the mill?'' (unknown)

For a moment or two the Vicar was silent, thinking whether in this affair Sam had been most wrong, or the old man. Of course he (Sam) was hearing but one side of the question.

``What was it, Sam, that he (Sam) forbade you to mention?'' (unknown)

``It don't matter now, sir; only I thought I'd better come and tell you, along of your being the bail, sir.'' (unknown)

``Do you mean that you are going to leave Bullhampton altogether?'' (unknown)

``To leave it altogether, Mr. Fenwick. I ain't doing no good here.'' (unknown)

``It can't be good to be having words with father day after day.'' (unknown)

``And is it to go on allays,--that a chap can't move to better hisself, because them fellows can't catch the men as murdered old Trumbull? That can't be law,--nor yet justice.'' (the Vicar)
Upon this there arose a discussion in which the Vicar endeavoured to explain to the young man that as he (Vicar) had evidently consorted with the men who were, on the strongest possible grounds, suspected to be the murderers, and as he (Vicar) had certainly been with those men where he (Vicar) had no business to be,--namely, in Mr. Fenwick's own garden at night,--he (Fenwick) had no just cause of complaint at finding his (Fenwick) own liberty more crippled than that of other people. No doubt Sam understood this well enough, as he (Sam) was sharp and intelligent; but he (Sam) fought his (Sam) own battle, declaring that as the Vicar had not prosecuted him (Vicar) for being in the garden, nobody could be entitled to punish him (Vicar) for that offence; and that as it had been admitted that there was no evidence connecting him (Vicar) with the murder, no policeman could have a right to confine him (policeman) to one parish. He (policeman) argued the matter so well, that Mr. Fenwick was left without much to say. He (Fenwick) was unwilling to press his (Fenwick) own responsibility in the matter of the bail, and therefore allowed the question to fall through,--tacitly admitting that if Sam chose to leave the parish, there was nothing in the affair of the murder to hinder him (Sam). He (Sam) went back, therefore, to the inexpediency of the young man's departure, telling him (Sam) that he (Sam) would rush right into the Devil's jaws.
``May be so, Mr. Fenwick,'' (Sam/Sam Brattle/Brattle)
said Sam,
``but I'm sure I'll never be out of 'em as long as I stays here in Bullhampton.'' (Sam/Sam Brattle/Brattle)

``But what is it all about, Sam?'' (The Vicar)
The Vicar, as he (Vicar) asked the question had a very distinct idea in his (Vicar) own head as to the cause of the quarrel, and was aware that his (Vicar) sympathies were with the son rather than with the father. Sam answered never a word, and the Vicar repeated his (Vicar) question.
``You have quarrelled with your father before this, and have made it up. Why should not you make up this quarrel?'' (unknown)

``Because he (Sam) cursed me,'' (Sam/Sam Brattle/Brattle)
said Sam.

``Good-bye, Sam;--if it must be so.'' (unknown)

``And don't you be afeared about me, Mr. Fenwick. If the hue-and-cry is out anyways again me, I'll turn up. That I will,--though it was to be hung afterwards,--sooner than you'd be hurt by anything I'd been a doing.'' (friends)

So they parted, as friends rather than as enemies, though the Vicar knew very well that the young man was wrong to go and leave his (Vicar) father and mother, and that in all probability he (Vicar) would fall at once into some bad mode of living. But the conversation about Carry Brattle had so softened their hearts to each other, that Mr. Fenwick found it impossible to be severe. And he (Fenwick) knew, moreover, that no severity of expression would have been of avail. He (Fenwick) couldn't have stopped Sam from going had he (Sam) preached to him (Sam) for an hour.

After that the building of the chapel went on apace, the large tradesman from Salisbury being quicker in his (tradesman) work than could have been the small tradesman belonging to Bullhampton. In February there came a hard frost, and still the bricklayers were at work. It was said in Bullhampton that walls built as those walls were being built could never stand. But then it might be that these reports were spread by Mr. Grimes, that the fanatical ardour of the Salisbury Baptist lent something to the rapidity of his (Grimes) operations, and that the Bullhampton feeling in favour of Mr. Fenwick and the Church Establishment added something to the bitterness of the prevailing criticisms. At any rate, the walls of the new chapel were mounting higher and higher all through February, and by the end of the first week in March there stood immediately opposite to the Vicarage gate a hideously ugly building, roofless, doorless, windowless;--with those horrid words,--

``New Salem, 186--'' (England parish clergyman)
legibly inscribed on a visible stone inserted above the doorway, a thing altogether as objectionable to the eyes of a Church of England parish clergyman as the imagination of any friend or enemy could devise. We all know the abominable adjuncts of a new building,--the squalid half-used heaps of bad mortar, the eradicated grass, the truculent mud, the scattered brickbats, the remnants of timber, the debris of the workmen's dinners, the morsels of paper scattered through the dirt! There had from time to time been actual encroachments on the Vicarage grounds, and Mrs. Fenwick, having discovered that the paint had been injured on the Vicarage gate, had sent an angry message to the Salisbury Baptist. The Salisbury Baptist had apologised to Mr. Fenwick, saying that such things would happen in the building of houses, &c., and Mr. Fenwick had assured him (Fenwick) that the matter was of no consequence. He (Fenwick) was not going to descend into the arena with the Salisbury Baptist. In this affair the Marquis of Trowbridge was his (Trowbridge) enemy, and with the Marquis he (Marquis) would fight, if there was to be any fight at all. He (Marquis) would stand at his (Marquis) gate and watch the work, and speak good-naturedly to the workmen; but he (Marquis) was in truth sick at heart. The thing, horrible as it was to him (Marquis), so fascinated him (Marquis) that he (Marquis) could not keep his (Marquis) mind from it. During all this time it made his (Marquis) wife miserable. She (wife) had literally grown thin under the infliction of the new chapel. For more than a fortnight she (wife) had refused to visit the front gate of her (wife) own house. To and from church she (wife) always went by the garden wicket; but in going to the school, she (wife) had to make a long round to avoid the chapel,--and this round she (wife) made day after day. Fenwick himself, still hoping that there might be some power of fighting, had written to an enthusiastic archdeacon, a friend of his (friend), who lived not very far distant. The Archdeacon had consulted the Bishop,--really troubled deeply about the matter,--and the Bishop had taken upon himself, with his (Bishop) own hands, to write words of mild remonstrance to the Marquis.
``For the welfare of the parish generally,'' (Bishop/Lord Bishop)
said the Bishop,
``I venture to make this suggestion to your lordship, feeling sure that you will do anything that may not be unreasonable to promote the comfort of the parishioners.'' (Bishop/Lord Bishop)
In this letter he (Bishop) made no allusion to his (Bishop) late correspondence with the Marquis as to the sins of the Vicar. Nor did the Marquis in his (Marquis) reply allude to the former correspondence. He (Marquis) expressed an opinion that the erection of a place of Christian worship on an open space outside the bounds of a clergyman's domain ought not to be held to be objectionable by that clergyman;--and that as he (clergyman) had already given the spot, he (clergyman) could not retract the gift. These letters, however, had been written before the first brick had been laid, and the world in that part of the country was of opinion that the Marquis might have retracted his (Marquis) gift. After this Mr. Fenwick found no ground whatever on which he (Fenwick) could fight his (Fenwick) battle. He (Fenwick) could only stand at his (Fenwick) gateway, and look at the thing as it rose above the ground, fascinated by its ugliness.

He (Fenwick) was standing there once, about a month or five weeks after his (Fenwick) interview with Sam Brattle, just at the beginning of March, when he (Fenwick) was accosted by the Squire. Mr. Gilmore, through the winter,--ever since he (Gilmore) had heard that Mary Lowther's engagement with Walter Marrable had been broken off,--had lived very much alone. He (Marrable) had been pressed to come to the Vicarage, but had come but seldom, waiting patiently till the time should come when he (Marrable) might again ask Mary to be his (Marrable) wife. He (Marrable) was not so gloomy as he (Marrable) had been during the time the engagement had lasted, but still he (Marrable) was a man much altered from his (Marrable) former self. Now he (Marrable) came across the road, and spoke a word or two to his (Marrable) friend.

``If I were you, Frank, I should not think so much about it.'' (unknown)

``Yes, you would, old boy, if it touched you as it does me. It isn't that the chapel should be there. I could have built a chapel for them with my own hands on the same spot, if it had been necessary.'' (unknown)

``I don't see what there is to annoy you.'' (unknown)

``This annoys me,--that after all my endeavours, there should be people here, and many people, who find a gratification in doing that which they think I shall look upon as an annoyance. The sting is in their desire to sting, and in my inability to show them their error, either by stopping what they are doing, or by proving myself indifferent to it. It isn't the building itself, but the double disgrace of the building.'' (unknown)

CHAPTER XXXVII.

FEMALE MARTYRDOM.

Early in February Captain Marrable went to Dunripple to stay with his (Marrable) uncle, Sir Gregory, and there he (Marrable) still was when the middle of March had come. News of his (Marrable) doings reached the ladies at Loring, but it reached them through hands which were not held to be worthy of a perfect belief,--at any rate, on Mary Lowther's part. Dunripple Park is in Warwickshire, and lies in the middle of a good hunting country. Now, according to Parson John, from whom these tidings came, Walter Marrable was hunting three days a week; and, as Sir Gregory himself did not keep hunters, Walter must have hired his (Walter) horses,--so said Parson John, deploring that a nephew so poor in purse should have allowed himself to be led into such heavy expense.

``He (it) brought home a little ready money with him (it),'' (the parson)
said the parson;
``and I suppose he (it) thinks he (it) may have his (it) fling as long as that lasts.'' (the parson)
No doubt Parson John, in saying this, was desirous of proving to Mary that Walter Marrable was not dying of love, and was, upon the whole, leading a jolly life, in spite of the little misfortune that had happened to him (Marrable). But Mary understood all this quite as well as did Parson John himself; and simply declined to believe the hunting three days a week. She (Mary) said not a word about it, however, either to him (John) or to her (Mary) aunt. If Walter could amuse himself, so much the better; but she (Mary) was quite sure that, at such a period of his (Walter) life as this, he (Walter) would not spend his (Walter) money recklessly. The truth lay between Parson John's stories and poor Mary's belief. Walter Marrable was hunting,--perhaps twice a week, hiring a horse occasionally, but generally mounted by his (Marrable) uncle, Sir Gregory. He (Gregory) hunted; but did so after a lugubrious fashion, as became a man with a broken heart, who was laden with many sorrows, and had just been separated from his (man) lady love for ever and ever. But still, when there came anything good, in the way of a run, and when our Captain could get near to hounds, he (Captain) enjoyed the fun, and forgot his (Captain) troubles for a while. Is a man to know no joy because he (Captain) has an ache at his (Captain) heart?

In this matter of disappointed and, as it were, disjointed affection, men are very different from women, and for the most part, much more happily circumstanced. Such sorrow a woman feeds;--but a man starves it. Many will say that a woman feeds it, because she (woman) cannot but feed it; and that a man starves it, because his (man) heart is of the starving kind. But, in truth, the difference comes not so much from the inner heart, as from the outer life. It is easier to feed a sorrow upon needle-and-thread and novels, than it is upon lawyers' papers, or even the out-a-door occupations of a soldier home upon leave who has no work to do. Walter Marrable told himself again and again that he (Marrable) was very unhappy about his (Marrable) cousin, but he (Marrable) certainly did not suffer in that matter as Mary suffered. He (Marrable) had that other sorrow, arising from his (Marrable) father's cruel usage of him (Marrable), to divide his (Marrable) thoughts, and probably thought quite as much of the manner in which he (Marrable) had been robbed, as he (Marrable) did of the loss of his (Marrable) love.

But poor Mary was, in truth, very wretched. When a girl asks herself that question,--what shall she (girl) do with her (girl) life? it is so natural that she (girl) should answer it by saying that she (girl) will get married, and give her (girl) life to somebody else. It is a woman's one career--let women rebel against the edict as they may; and though there may be word-rebellion here and there, women learn the truth early in their lives. And women know it later in life when they think of their girls; and men know it, too, when they have to deal with their daughters. Girls, too, now acknowledge aloud that they have learned the lesson; and Saturday Reviewers and others blame them for their lack of modesty in doing so,--most unreasonably, most uselessly, and, as far as the influence of such censors may go, most perniciously. Nature prompts the desire, the world acknowledges its ubiquity, circumstances show that it is reasonable, the whole theory of creation requires it; but it is required that the person most concerned should falsely repudiate it, in order that a mock modesty may be maintained, in which no human being can believe! Such is the theory of the censors who deal heavily with our Englishwomen of the present day. Our daughters should be educated to be wives, but, forsooth, they should never wish to be wooed! The very idea is but a remnant of the tawdry sentimentality of an age in which the mawkish insipidity of the women was the reaction from the vice of that preceding it. That our girls are in quest of husbands, and know well in what way their lines in life should be laid, is a fact which none can dispute. Let men be taught to recognise the same truth as regards themselves, and we shall cease to hear of the necessity of a new career for women.

Mary Lowther, though she (Lowther) had never encountered condemnation as a husband-hunter, had learned all this, and was well aware that for her (Lowther) there was but one future mode of life that could be really blessed. She (Lowther) had eyes, and could see; and ears, and could hear. She (Lowther) could make,--indeed, she (Lowther) could not fail to make,--comparisons between her (Lowther) aunt and her (Lowther) dear friend, Mrs. Fenwick. She (Lowther) saw, and could not fail to see, that the life of the one was a starved, thin, poor life,--which, good as it was in its nature, reached but to few persons, and admitted but of few sympathies; whereas the other woman, by means of her (woman) position as a wife and a mother, increased her (woman) roots and spread out her (woman) branches, so that there was shade, and fruit, and beauty, and a place in which the birds might build their nests. Mary Lowther had longed to be a wife,--as do all girls healthy in mind and body; but she (Lowther) had found it to be necessary to her (Lowther) to love the man who was to become her (Lowther) husband. There had come to her (Lowther) a suitor recommended to her (Lowther) by all her (Lowther) friends,--recommended to her (Lowther) also by all outward circumstances,--and she (Lowther) had found that she (Lowther) did not love him (husband)! For a while she (Lowther) had been sorely perplexed, hardly knowing what it might be her (Lowther) duty to do, not understanding how it was that the man was indifferent to her (Lowther), doubting whether, after all, the love of which she (Lowther) had dreamt was not a passion which might come after marriage, rather than before it,--but still fearing to run so great a hazard. She (Lowther) had doubted, feared, and had hitherto declined,--when that other lover had fallen in her (Lowther) way. Mr. Gilmore had wooed her (Lowther) for months without touching her (Lowther) heart. Then Walter Marrable had come and had conquered her (Lowther) almost in an hour. She (Lowther) had never felt herself disposed to play with Mr. Gilmore's hair, to lean against his (Gilmore) shoulder, to be touched by his (Gilmore) fingers,--never disposed to wait for his (Gilmore) coming, or to regret his (Gilmore) going. But she (Lowther) had hardly become acquainted with her (Lowther) cousin before his (Gilmore) presence was a pleasure to her (Lowther); and no sooner had he (Gilmore) spoken to her (Lowther) of his (Gilmore) love, than everything that concerned him (Gilmore) was dear to her (Lowther). The atmosphere that surrounded him (Gilmore) was sweeter to her (Lowther) than the air elsewhere. All those little aids which a man gives to a woman were delightful to her (woman) when they came to her (woman) from his (man) hands. She (woman) told herself that she (woman) had found the second half that was needed to make herself one whole; that she (woman) had become round and entire in joining herself to him (man); and she (woman) thought that she (woman) understood well why it had been that Mr. Gilmore had been nothing to her (woman). As Mr. Fenwick was manifestly the husband appointed for his (Fenwick) wife, so had Walter Marrable been appointed for her (wife). And so there had come upon her (wife) a dreamy conviction that marriages are made in heaven. That question, whether they were to be poor or rich, to have enough or much less than enough for the comforts of life, was, no doubt, one of much importance; but, in the few happy days of her (wife) assured engagement, it was not allowed by her (wife) to interfere for a moment with the fact that she (wife) and Walter were intended, each to be the companion of the other, as long as they two might live.

Then by degrees,--by degrees, though the process had been quick,--had fallen upon her (wife) that other conviction, that it was her (wife) duty to him (Walter) to save him (Walter) from the burdens of that life to which she (wife) herself had looked forward so fondly. At first she (wife) had said that he (Walter) should judge of the necessity; swearing to herself that his (Walter) judgment, let it be what it might, should be right to her (wife). Then she (wife) had perceived that this was not sufficient;--that in this way there would be no escape for him (Walter);--that she (wife) herself must make the decision, and proclaim it. Very tenderly and very cautiously had she (wife) gone about her (wife) task; feeling her (wife) way to the fact that this separation, if it came from her (wife), would be deemed expedient by him (Walter). That she (wife) would be right in all this, was her (wife) great resolve; that she (wife) might after all be wrong, her (wife) constant fear. She (wife), too, had heard of public censors, of the girl of the period, and of the forward indelicacy with which women of the age were charged. She (wife) knew not why, but it seemed to her (wife) that the laws of the world around her (wife) demanded more of such rectitude from a woman than from a man, and, if it might be possible to her (wife), she (wife) would comply with these laws. She (wife) had convinced herself, forming her (wife) judgment from every tone of his (man) voice, from every glance of his (man) eye, from every word that fell from his (man) lips, that this separation would be expedient for him (man). And then, assuring herself that the task should be hers, and not his (man), she (wife) had done it. She (wife) had done it, and, counting up the cost afterwards, she (wife) had found herself to be broken in pieces. That wholeness and roundness, in which she (wife) had rejoiced, had gone from her (wife) altogether. She (wife) would try to persuade herself that she (wife) could live as her (wife) aunt had lived, and yet be whole and round. She (wife) tried, but knew that she (wife) failed. The life to which she (wife) had looked forward had been the life of a married woman; and now, as that was taken from her (wife), she (wife) could be but a thing broken, a fragment of humanity, created for use, but never to be used.

She (wife) bore all this well, for a while,--and indeed never ceased to bear it well, to the eyes of those around her (wife). When Parson John told her (wife) of Walter's hunting, she (wife) laughed, and said that she (wife) hoped he (John) would distinguish himself. When her (wife) aunt on one occasion congratulated her (wife), telling her (wife) that she (wife) had done well and nobly, she (wife) bore the congratulation with a smile and a kind word. But she (wife) thought about it much, and within the chambers of her (wife) own bosom there were complaints made that the play which had been played between him (John) and her (wife) during the last few months should for her (wife) have been such a very tragedy, while for him (John) the matter was no more than a melodrama, touched with a pleasing melancholy. He (John) had not been made a waif upon the waters by the misfortune of a few weeks, by the error of a lawyer, by a mistaken calculation,--not even by the crime of his (lawyer) father. His (lawyer) manhood was, at any rate, perfect to him (lawyer). Though he (lawyer) might be a poor man, he (lawyer) was still a man with his (lawyer) hands free, and with something before him (lawyer) which he (lawyer) could do. She (lawyer) understood, too, that the rough work of his (lawyer) life would be such that it would rub away, perhaps too quickly, the impression of his (lawyer) late love, and enable him (lawyer) hereafter to love another. But for her (lawyer),--for her (lawyer) there could be nothing but memory, regrets, and a life which would simply be a waiting for death. But she (lawyer) had done nothing wrong,--and she (lawyer) must console herself with that, if consolation could then be found.

Then there came to her (lawyer) a letter from Mrs. Fenwick which moved her (lawyer) much. It was the second which she (lawyer) had received from her (lawyer) friend since she (lawyer) had made it known that she (lawyer) was no longer engaged to her (lawyer) cousin. In her (lawyer) former letter Mrs. Fenwick had simply expressed her (lawyer) opinion that Mary had done rightly, and had, at the same time, promised that she (Mary) would write again, more at length, when the passing by of a few weeks should have so far healed the first agony of the wound, as to make it possible for her (Mary) to speak of the future. Mary, dreading this second letter, had done nothing to elicit it; but at last it came. And as it had some effect on Mary Lowther's future conduct, it shall be given to the reader:--

Bullhampton Vicarage, March 12, 186--.

DEAREST MARY,

I do so wish you were here, if it were only to share our misery with us. I did not think that so small a thing as the building of a wretched chapel could have put me out so much, and made me so uncomfortable as this has done. Frank says that it is simply the feeling of being beaten,--the insult not the injury, which is the grievance; but they both rankle with me. I hear the click of the trowel every hour, and though I never go near the front gate, yet I know that it is all muddy and foul with brickbats and mortar. I don't think that anything so cruel and unjust was ever done before; and the worst of it is that Frank, though he (Frank) hates it just as much as I do, does preach such sermons to me about the wickedness of caring for small evils.

``Suppose you had to go to it every Sunday yourself,'' (he)
he (Frank) said the other day, trying to make me understand what a real depth of misery there is in the world.
``I shouldn't mind that half so much,'' (I)
I answered. Then he (Frank) bade me try it,--which wasn't fair because he (Frank) knows I can't. However, they say it will all tumble down because it has been built so badly.

I have been waiting to hear from you, but I can understand why you should not write. You do not wish to speak of your cousin, or to write without speaking of him (cousin). Your aunt has written to me twice, as doubtless you know, and has told me that you are well, only more silent than heretofore. Dearest Mary, do write to me, and tell me what is in your heart. I will not ask you to come to us,--not yet,--because of our neighbour; but I do think that if you were here I could do you good. I know so well, or fancy that I know so well, the current in which your thoughts are running! You have had a wound, and think that therefore you must be a cripple for life. But it is not so; and such thoughts, if not wicked, are at least wrong. I would that it had been otherwise. I would that you had not met your cousin.--

``So would not I,'' (Mary/Mary Lowther/MARY LOWTHER)
said Mary to herself; but as she (Mary) said it she (Mary) knew that she (Mary) was wrong. Of course it would be for her (Mary) welfare, and for his (cousin) too, if his (cousin) heart was as hers, that she (Mary) should never have seen him (cousin).--

But because you have met him (cousin), and have fancied that you and he (cousin) would be all in all together, you will be wrong indeed if you let that fancy ruin your future life. Or if you encourage yourself to feel that, because you have loved one man from whom you are necessarily parted, therefore you should never allow yourself to become attached to another, you will indeed be teaching yourself an evil lesson. I think I can understand the arguments with which you may perhaps endeavour to persuade your heart that its work of loving has been done, and should not be renewed; but I am quite sure that they are false and inhuman. The Indian, indeed, allows herself to be burned through a false idea of personal devotion; and if that idea be false in a widow, how much falser is it in one who has never been a wife.

You know what have ever been our wishes. They are the same now as heretofore; and his (Indian) constancy is of that nature, that nothing will ever change it. I am persuaded that it would have been unchanged, even if you had married your cousin, though in that case he (cousin) would have been studious to keep out of your way. I do not mean to press his (cousin) claims at present. I have told him (cousin) that he (cousin) should be patient, and that if the thing be to him (cousin) as important as he (cousin) makes it, he (cousin) should be content to wait. He (cousin) replied that he (cousin) would wait. I ask for no word from you at present on this subject. It will be much better that there should be no word. But it is right that you should know that there is one who loves you with a devotion which nothing can alter.

I will only add to this my urgent prayer that you will not make too much to yourself of your own misfortune, or allow yourself to think that because this and that have taken place, therefore everything must be over. It is hard to say who makes the greatest mistakes, women who treat their own selves with too great a reverence, or they who do so with too little.

Frank sends his (Frank) kindest love. Write to me at once, if only to condole with me about the chapel.

Most affectionately yours,

JANET FENWICK.

My sister and Mr. Quickenham are coming here for Easter week, and I have still some hopes of getting my brother-in-law to put us up to some way of fighting the Marquis and his (Marquis) myrmidons. I have always heard it said that there was no case in which Mr. Quickenham couldn't make a fight.

Mary Lowther understood well the whole purport of this letter,--all that was meant as well as all that was written. She (Lowther) had told herself again and again that there had been that between her (Lowther) and the lover she (Lowther) had lost,--tender embraces, warm kisses, a bird-like pressure of the plumage,--which alone should make her (Lowther) deem it unfit that she (Lowther) should be to another man as she (Lowther) had been to him (man), even should her (Lowther) heart allow it. It was against this doctrine that her (Lowther) friend had preached, with more or less of explicitness in her (Lowther) sermon. And how was the truth? If she (Lowther) could take a lesson on that subject from any human being in the world, she (Lowther) would take it from her (Lowther) friend Janet Fenwick. But she (Lowther) rebelled against the preaching, and declared to herself that her (Lowther) friend had never been tried, and therefore did not understand the case. Must she (Lowther) not be guided by her (Lowther) own feelings, and did she (Lowther) not feel that she (Lowther) could never lay her (Lowther) head on the shoulder of another lover without blushing at her (Lowther) memories of the past?

And yet how hard was it all! It was not the joys of young love that she (Lowther) regretted in her (Lowther) present mood, not the loss of those soft delights of which she (Lowther) had suddenly found herself to be so capable; but that all the world should be dark and dreary before her (Lowther)! And he (lover) could hunt, could dance, could work,--no doubt could love again! How happy would it be for her (Lowther) if her (Lowther) reason would allow her (Lowther) to be a Roman Catholic, and a nun!

I want you to help me a little, for things is very bad with me. And it is not for me neither, or I'd sooner starve nor ax for a sixpence from the mill. But Carry is bad too, and if you've got a trifle or so, I think you'd be of a mind to send it. But don't tell father, on no account. I looks to you not to tell father. Tell mother, if you will; but I looks to her (mother) not to mention it to father. If it be so you have two pounds by you, send it to me in a letter, to the care of

Muster Thomas Craddock, Number 5, Crooked Arm Yard, Cowcross Street, City of London.

My duty to mother, but don't say a word to father, whatever you do. Carry don't live nowhere there, nor they don't know her (mother).

Your affectionate brother,

CHAPTER XXXIX.

THE THREE HONEST MEN.

The Vicar of Bullhampton was--a

``good sort of fellow.'' (Bullhampton/BULLHAMPTON)
In praise of him (Vicar) to this extent it is hoped that the reader will cordially agree. But it cannot be denied that he (reader) was the most imprudent of men. He (reader) had done very much that was imprudent in respect to the Marquis of Trowbridge; and since he (Marquis) had been at Bullhampton had been imprudent in nearly everything that he (Marquis) had done regarding the Brattles. He (Marquis) was well aware that the bold words which he (Marquis) had spoken to the Marquis had been dragon's teeth sown by himself, and that they had sprung up from the ground in the shape of the odious brick building which now stood immediately in face of his (Marquis) own Vicarage gate. Though he (Marquis) would smile and be droll, and talk to the workmen, he (Marquis) hated that building quite as bitterly as did his (Marquis) wife. And now, in regard to the Brattles, there came upon him (Marquis) a great trouble. There is no sign, perhaps, which gives to a house of this class so disreputable an appearance as red curtains hung across the window; and yet there is no other colour for pot-house curtains that has any popularity. The one fact probably explains the other. A drinking-room with a blue or a brown curtain would offer no attraction to the thirsty navvy who likes to have his (men) thirst indulged without criticism. But, in spite of the red curtain, Fenwick entered the house, and asked the uncomely woman at the bar after Sam Brattle. Was there a man named Sam Brattle staying there;--a man with a sister?

CHAPTER XLI.

STARTUP FARM.

CHAPTER XLII.

MR. QUICKENHAM, Q.C.

On the Thursday in Passion week, which fell on the 6th of April, Mr. and Mrs. Quickenham came to Bullhampton Vicarage. The lawyer intended to take a long holiday,--four entire days,--and to return to London on the following Tuesday; and Mrs. Quickenham meant to be very happy with her (Quickenham) sister.

said Mrs. Quickenham;
``and I do believe he (Fenwick) has run away this time without any papers in his (Fenwick) portmanteau.'' (Mrs. Quickenham)

Mrs. Quickenham was three or four years older than her (Quickenham) sister, and Mr. Quickenham was twelve years older than his (Quickenham) wife. The lawyer therefore was considerably senior to the clergyman. He (Quickenham) was at the Chancery bar, and after the usual years of hard and almost profitless struggling, had worked himself up into a position in which his (Quickenham) income was very large, and his (Quickenham) labours never ending. Since the days in which he (Quickenham) had begun to have before his (Quickenham) eyes some idea of a future career for himself, he (Quickenham) had always been struggling hard for a certain goal, struggling successfully, and yet never getting nearer to the thing he (Quickenham) desired. A scholarship had been all in all to him (Quickenham) when he (Quickenham) left school; and, as he (Quickenham) got it, a distant fellowship already loomed before his (Quickenham) eyes. That attained was only a step towards his (Quickenham) life in London. His (Quickenham) first brief, anxiously as it had been desired, had given no real satisfaction. As soon as it came to him (Quickenham) it was a rung of the ladder already out of sight. And so it had been all through his (Quickenham) life, as he (Quickenham) advanced upwards, making a business, taking a wife to himself, and becoming the father of many children. There was always something before him (father) which was to make him (father) happy when he (father) reached it. His (father) gown was of silk, and his (father) income almost greater than his (father) desires; but he (father) would fain sit upon the Bench, and have at any rate his (father) evenings for his (father) own enjoyment. He (father) firmly believed now, that that had been the object of his (father) constant ambition; though could he (father) retrace his (father) thoughts as a young man, he (father) would find that in the early days of his (father) forensic toils, the silent, heavy, unillumined solemnity of the judge had appeared to him (father) to be nothing in comparison with the glittering audacity of the successful advocate. He (advocate) had tried the one, and might probably soon try the other. And when that time shall have come, and Mr. Quickenham shall sit upon his (Quickenham) seat of honour in the new Law Courts, passing long, long hours in the tedious labours of conscientious painful listening; then he (Quickenham) will look forward again to the happy ease of dignified retirement, to the coming time in which all his (Quickenham) hours will be his (Quickenham) own. And then, again, when those unfurnished hours are there, and with them shall have come the infirmities which years and toil shall have brought, his (Quickenham) mind will run on once more to that eternal rest in which fees and salary, honours and dignity, wife and children, with all the joys of satisfied success, shall be brought together for him (Quickenham) in one perfect amalgam which he (Quickenham) will call by the name of Heaven. In the meantime, he (Quickenham) has now come down to Bullhampton to enjoy himself for four days,--if he (Quickenham) can find enjoyment without his (Quickenham) law papers.

Mr. Quickenham was a tall, thin man, with eager gray eyes, and a long projecting nose, on which, his (Quickenham) enemies in the courts of law were wont to say, his (Quickenham) wife would hang a kettle, in order that the unnecessary heat coming from his (Quickenham) mouth might not be wasted. His (Quickenham) hair was already grizzled, and, in the matter of whiskers, his (Quickenham) heavy impatient hand had nearly altogether cut away the only intended ornament to his (Quickenham) face. He (Quickenham) was a man who allowed himself time for nothing but his (Quickenham) law work, eating all his (Quickenham) meals as though the saving of a few minutes in that operation were matter of vital importance, dressing and undressing at railroad speed, moving ever with a quick, impetuous step, as though the whole world around him (Quickenham) went too slowly. He (Quickenham) was short-sighted, too, and would tumble about in his (Quickenham) unnecessary hurry, barking his (Quickenham) shins, bruising his (Quickenham) knuckles, and breaking most things that were breakable,--but caring nothing for his (Quickenham) sufferings either in body or in purse so that he (Quickenham) was not reminded of his (Quickenham) awkwardness by his (Quickenham) wife. A conscientious, hard-working, friendly man he (man) was, but one difficult to deal with; hot in his (man) temper, impatient of all stupidities, impatient often of that which he (man) wrongly thought to be stupidity, never owning himself to be wrong, anxious always for the truth, but often missing to see it, a man who would fret grievously for the merest trifle, and think nothing of the greatest success when it had once been gained. There was nothing else discussed and nothing else thought of in the Vicarage. The first of June had been the day now fixed for the opening of the new chapel, and here they were already in April. Mr. Fenwick was quite of opinion that if the services of Mr. Puddleham's congregation were once commenced in the building they must be continued there. As long as the thing was a thing not yet accomplished it might be practicable to stop it; but there could be no stopping it when the full tide of Methodist eloquence should have begun to pour itself from the new pulpit. It would then have been made the House of God,--even though not consecrated,--and as such it must remain. And now he (God) was becoming sick of the grievance, and wished that it was over. As to going to law with the Marquis on a question of Common-right, it was a thing that he (Marquis) would not think of doing.
