CHAPTER XLIII.

EASTER AT TURNOVER CASTLE.

It was not only at Bullhampton that this affair of the Methodist chapel demanded and received attention. At Turnover also a good deal was being said about it, and the mind of the Marquis was not easy. As has been already told, the bishop had written to him (bishop) on the subject, remonstrating with him (bishop) as to the injury he (bishop) was doing to the present vicar, and to future vicars, of the parish which he (bishop), as landlord, was bound to treat with beneficent consideration. The Marquis had replied to the bishop with a tone of stern resolve. The Vicar of Bullhampton had treated him (Vicar) with scorn, nay, as he (Vicar) thought, with most unpardonable insolence, and he (Vicar) would not spare the Vicar. It was proper that the dissenters at Bullhampton should have a chapel, and he (Vicar) had a right to do what he (Vicar) liked with his (Vicar) own. So arguing with himself, he (Vicar) had written to the bishop very firmly; but his (Vicar) own mind had not been firm within him (Vicar) as he (Vicar) did so. There were misgivings at his (Vicar) heart. He (Vicar) was a Churchman himself, and he (Vicar) was pricked with remorse as he (Vicar) remembered that he (Vicar) was spiting the Church which was connected with the state, of which he (Vicar) was so eminent a supporter. His (Vicar) own chief agent, too, had hesitated, and had suggested that perhaps the matter might be postponed. His (Vicar) august daughters, though they had learned to hold the name of Fenwick in proper abhorrence, nevertheless were grieved about the chapel. Men and women were talking about it, and the words of the common people found their way to the august daughters of the house of Stowte.

``Papa,'' (Lady)
said Lady Carolina;
``wouldn't it, perhaps, be better to build the Bullhampton chapel a little farther off from the Vicarage?'' (Lady)

``The next vicar might be a different sort of person,'' (Sophie/Lady Sophie)
said the Lady Sophie.

``No; it wouldn't,'' (the Earl)
said the Earl, who was apt to be very imperious with his (Earl) own daughters, although he (Earl) was of opinion that they should be held in great awe by all the world--excepting only himself and their eldest brother.

That eldest brother, Lord Saint George, was in truth regarded at Turnover as being, of all persons in the world, the most august. The Marquis himself was afraid of his (Marquis) son, and held him (Marquis) in extreme veneration. To the mind of the Marquis the heir expectant of all the dignities of the House of Stowte was almost a greater man than the owner of them; and this feeling came not only from a consciousness on the part of the father that his (father) son was a bigger man than himself, cleverer, better versed in the affairs of the world, and more thought of by those around them, but also to a certain extent from an idea that he (father) who would have all these grand things thirty or perhaps even fifty years hence, must be more powerful than one with whom their possession would come to an end probably after the lapse of eight or ten years. His (father) heir was to him (father) almost divine. When things at the castle were in any way uncomfortable, he (father) could put up with the discomfort for himself and his (father) daughters; but it was not to be endured that Saint George should be incommoded. Old carriage-horses must be changed if he (Saint) were coming; the glazing of the new greenhouse must be got out of the way, lest he (Saint) should smell the paint; the game must not be touched till he (Saint) should come to shoot it. And yet Lord Saint George himself was a man who never gave himself any airs; and who in his (Saint) personal intercourse with the world around him (Saint) demanded much less acknowledgment of his (Saint) magnificence than did his (Saint) father.

And now, during this Easter week, Lord Saint George came down to the castle, intending to kill two birds with one stone, to take his (Saint) parliamentary holiday, and to do a little business with his (Saint) father. It not unfrequently came to pass that he (Saint) found it necessary to repress the energy of his (Saint) father's august magnificence. He (Saint) would go so far as to remind his (Saint) father that in these days marquises were not very different from other people, except in this, that they perhaps might have more money. The Marquis would fret in silence, not daring to commit himself to an argument with his (Marquis) son, and would in secret lament over the altered ideas of the age. It was his (Marquis) theory of politics that the old distances should be maintained, and that the head of a great family should be a patriarch, entitled to obedience from those around him (patriarch). It was his (patriarch) son's idea that every man was entitled to as much obedience as his (man) money would buy, and to no more. This was very lamentable to the Marquis; but nevertheless, his (Marquis) son was the coming man, and even this must be borne.

``I'm sorry about this chapel at Bullhampton,'' (the son)
said the son to the father after dinner.

``Why sorry, Saint George? I thought you would have been of opinion that the dissenters should have a chapel.'' (unknown)

``Certainly they should, if they're fools enough to want to build a place to pray in, when they have got one already built for them. There's no reason on earth why they shouldn't have a chapel, seeing that nothing that we can do will save them from schism.'' (unknown)

``We can't prevent dissent, Saint George.'' (unknown)

``We can't prevent it, because, in religion as in everything else, men like to manage themselves. This farmer or that tradesman becomes a dissenter because he (tradesman) can be somebody in the management of his (tradesman) chapel, and would be nobody in regard to the parish church.'' (unknown)

``That is very dreadful.'' (unknown)

``Not worse than our own people, who remain with us because it sounds the most respectable. Not one in fifty really believes that this or that form of worship is more likely to send him (tradesman) to heaven than any other.'' (unknown)

``I certainly claim to myself to be one of the few,'' (the Marquis)
said the Marquis.

``No doubt; and so you ought, my lord, as every advantage has been given you. But, to come back to the Bullhampton chapel,--don't you think we could move it away from the parson's gate?'' (unknown)

``They have built it now, Saint George.'' (unknown)

``They can't have finished it yet.'' (unknown)

Lord Saint George returned to town two days afterwards, and the Marquis was left with the dilemma on his (Marquis) mind. Lord Saint George, though he (Saint) would frequently interfere in matters connected with the property in the manner described, would never dictate and seldom insist. He (Saint) had said what he (Saint) had got to say, and the Marquis was left to act for himself. But the old lord had learned to feel that he (lord) was sure to fall into some pit whenever he (lord) declined to follow his (lord) son's advice. His (lord) son had a painful way of being right that was a great trouble to him (lord). And this was a question which touched him (lord) very nearly. It was not only that he (lord) must yield to Mr. Fenwick before the eyes of Mr. Puddleham and all the people of Bullhampton; but that he (Puddleham) must confess his (Puddleham) own ignorance as to the borders of his (Puddleham) own property, and must abandon a bit of land which he (Puddleham) believed to belong to the Stowte estate. Now, if there was a point in his (Puddleham) religion as to which Lord Trowbridge was more staunch than another, it was as to the removal of landmarks. He (Trowbridge) did not covet his (Trowbridge) neighbour's land; but he (Trowbridge) was most resolute that no stranger should, during his (Trowbridge) reign, ever possess a rood of his (Trowbridge) own.

CHAPTER XLIV.

THE MARRABLES OF DUNRIPPLE.

``If I were to go, there would be nobody left but you. You should remember that, Walter, when you talk of going to India.'' (Walter/Walter Marrable/Marrable)
This was said to Walter Marrable at Dunripple, by his (Marrable) cousin Gregory, Sir Gregory's only son.

``And if I were to die in India, as I probably shall, who will come next?'' (unknown)

``There is nobody to come next for the title.'' (unknown)

``But for the property?'' (unknown)

``As it stands at present, if you and I were to die before your father and uncle John, the survivor of them would be the last in the entail. This conversation took place between the two cousins when Walter had been already two or three weeks at Dunripple. He (Walter) had come there intending to stay over two or three days, and he (Walter) had already accepted an invitation to make the house his (Walter) home as long as he (Walter) should remain in England. He (Walter) had known but little of his (Walter) uncle and nothing of his (Walter) cousin, before this visit was made. He (Walter) had conceived them to be unfriendly to him (Walter), having known them to be always unfriendly to his (Walter) father. He (Walter) was, of course, aware,--very well aware now, since he (Walter) had himself suffered so grievously from his (Walter) father's dishonesty,--that the enmity which had reached them from Dunripple had been well deserved. Colonel Marrable had, as a younger brother, never been content with what he (Marrable) was able to extract from the head of the family, who was, in his (Marrable) eyes, a milch cow that never ought to run dry. He (Marrable) had believed that the Dunripple people were stupid, and prejudiced, and selfish; and it had only been at the instance of his (Marrable) uncle, the parson, that he (Marrable) had consented to make the visit. He (Marrable) had gone there, and had been treated, at any rate, with affectionate consideration. And he (Marrable) had found the house to be not unpleasant, though very quiet. Living at Dunripple there was a Mrs. Brownlow, a widowed sister of the late Lady Marrable, with her (Lady) daughter, Edith Brownlow. Previous to this time Walter Marrable had never even heard of the Brownlows, so little had he (Marrable) known about Dunripple; and when he (Marrable) arrived there it had been necessary to explain to him (Marrable) who these people were.

He (Marrable) had found his (Marrable) uncle, Sir Gregory, to be much such a man as he (Marrable) had expected in outward appearance and mode of life. The baronet was old and disposed to regard himself as entitled to all the indulgences of infirmity. He (Marrable) rose late, took but little exercise, was very particular about what he (Marrable) ate, and got through his (Marrable) day with the assistance of his (Marrable) steward, his (Marrable) novel, and occasionally of his (Marrable) doctor. He (Marrable) slept a great deal, and was never tired of talking of himself. Occupation in life he (Marrable) had none, but he (Marrable) was a charitable, honourable man, who had high ideas of what was due to others. His (Marrable) son, however, had astonished Walter considerably. Gregory Marrable the younger was a man somewhat over forty, but he (Marrable) looked as though he (Marrable) were sixty. He (Marrable) was very tall and thin, narrow in the chest, and so round in the shoulders as to appear to be almost humpbacked. He (Marrable) was so short-sighted as to be nearly blind, and was quite bald. He (Marrable) carried his (Marrable) head so forward that it looked as though it were going to fall off. Chaucer was his (Andrew) favourite poet, and he (Andrew) was supposed to have read the works of Gower in English, French, and Latin. Walter could hardly regard him (Walter) as a cousin, declaring to himself that his (Walter) uncle the parson, and his (Walter) own father were, in effect, younger men than the younger Gregory Marrable. He (Marrable) was never without a cough, never well, never without various ailments and troubles of the flesh,--of which, however, he (Marrable) himself made but slight account, taking them quite as a matter of course. With such inmates the house no doubt would have been dull, had there not been women there to enliven it.

Between him (Marrable) and the title and the estate there were but the lives of four old men. CHAPTER XLV.

WHAT SHALL I DO WITH MYSELF?

Parson John Marrable, though he (John) said nothing in his (John) letters to Dunripple about the doings of his (John) nephew at Loring, was by no means equally reticent in his (John) speech at Loring as to the doings at Dunripple. He (John), too, had heard of Edith Brownlow, and had heard that if a marriage could be arranged between Walter and Edith, the family troubles would be in a fair way of settlement. No good could come to anybody from that other marriage. As for Mary Lowther, it was manifestly her (Lowther) duty to become Mrs. Gilmore. He (Walter) therefore took some trouble to let the ladies at Uphill know that Captain Marrable had been received very graciously at Dunripple; that he (Marrable) was making himself very happy there, hunting, shooting, and forgetting his (Marrable) old troubles; that it was understood that he (Marrable) was to be recognised as the heir;--and that there was a young lady in the case, the favourite of Sir Gregory.

He (Gregory) understood the world too well to say a word to Mary Lowther herself about her (Lowther) rival. Mary would have perceived his (Gregory) drift. She (Brownlow) would not stand in the way of it; and, indeed, how could she (Brownlow) stand in the way of it? Let him (Marrable) marry whom he (Marrable) might, she (Brownlow) could have no ground of complaint on that score.

She (Brownlow) was in this state of mind when she (Brownlow) received Captain Marrable's letter from Dunripple. When she (Brownlow) opened it, for a moment she (Brownlow) thought that it would convey to her (Brownlow) tidings respecting Miss Brownlow. When she (Brownlow) had read it, she (Brownlow) told herself how impossible it was that he (Marrable) should have told her (Brownlow) of his (Marrable) new matrimonial intentions, even if he (Marrable) entertained them. When at Loring he (John) had determined that he (John) must go to India. He (John) had found it to be impossible that he (John) should live without going to India. He (John) had now been staying a few weeks at Dunripple with his (John) uncle, and with Edith Brownlow, and it turned out that he (John) need not go to India at all. Then she (Brownlow) sat down, and wrote to him (John) that guarded, civil, but unenthusiastic letter, of which the reader has already heard. She (Brownlow) had allowed herself to be wounded and made sore by what they had told her (Brownlow) of Edith Brownlow.

It was still early in the spring, just in the middle of April, when Mary received another letter from her (Mary) friend at Bullhampton, a letter which made her (Mary) turn all these things in her (Mary) mind very seriously. If Walter Marrable were to marry Edith Brownlow, what sort of future life should she (Brownlow), Mary Lowther, propose to herself? She (Lowther) was firmly resolved upon one thing, that it behoved her (Lowther) to look rather to what was right than to what might simply be pleasant. But would it be right that she (Lowther) should consider herself to be, as it were, widowed by the frustration of an unfortunate passion? Life would still be left to her (Lowther),--such a life as that which her (Lowther) aunt lived,--such a life, with this exception, that whereas her (Lowther) aunt was a single lady with moderate means, she (Lowther) would be a single lady with very small means indeed. But that question of means did not go far with her (Lowther); there was something so much more important that she (Lowther) could put that out of sight. She (Lowther) had told herself very plainly that it was a good thing for a woman to be married; that she (woman) would live and die unsuccessfully if she (woman) lived and died a single woman; that she (woman) had desired to do better with herself than that. Was it proper that she (woman) should now give up all such ambition because she (woman) had made a mistake? If it were proper, she (woman) would do so; and then the question resolved itself into this;--Could she (woman) be right if she (woman) married a man without loving him (man)? To marry a man without esteeming him (man), without the possibility of loving him (man) hereafter, she (woman) knew would be wrong.

Mrs. Fenwick's letter was as follows;--

Vicarage, Tuesday.

MY DEAR MARY,

My brother-in-law left us yesterday, and has put us all into a twitter. He (brother-in-law) said, just as he (brother-in-law) was going away, that he (brother-in-law) didn't believe that Lord Trowbridge had any right to give away the ground, because it had not been in his (Trowbridge) possession or his (Trowbridge) family's for a great many years, or something of that sort. We don't clearly understand all about it, nor does he (Trowbridge); but he (Trowbridge) is to find out something which he (Trowbridge) says he (Trowbridge) can find out, and then let us know. But in the middle of all this, Frank declares that he (Frank) won't stir in the matter, and that if he (Frank) could put the abominable thing down by holding up his (Frank) finger, he (Frank) would not do it. And he (Frank) has made me promise not to talk about it, and, therefore, all I can do is to be in a twitter. If that spiteful old man has really given away land that doesn't belong to him (man), simply to annoy us,--and it certainly has been done with no other object,--I think that he (man) ought to be told of it. Frank, however, has got to be quite serious about it, and you know how very serious he (Frank) can be when he (Frank) is serious.

But I did not sit down to write specially about that horrid chapel. I want to know what you mean to do in the summer. It is always better to make these little arrangements beforehand; and when I speak of the summer, I mean the early summer. The long and the short of it is, will you come to us about the end of May?

Of course, I know which way your thoughts will go when you get this, and, of course, you will know what I am thinking of when I write it; but I will promise that not a word shall be said to you to urge you in any way. I do not suppose you will think it right that you should stay away from friends whom you love, and who love you dearly, for fear of a man who wants you to marry him (man). You are not afraid of Mr. Gilmore, and I don't suppose that you are going to shut yourself up all your life because Captain Marrable has not a fortune of his (Marrable) own. Come at any rate. If you find it unpleasant you shall go back just when you please, and I will pledge myself that you shall not be harassed by persuasions.

Yours most affectionately,

JANET FENWICK.

Frank has read this. He (Frank) says that all I have said about his (Frank) being serious is a tarradiddle; but that nothing can be more true than what I have said about your friends loving you, and wishing to have you here again. If you were here we might talk him (Frank) over yet about the chapel.

To which, in the Vicar's handwriting, was added the word,

``Never!'' (the Vicar)

It was two days before she (FENWICK) showed this letter to her (FENWICK) aunt--two days in which she (FENWICK) had thought much upon the subject. She (FENWICK) knew well that her (FENWICK) aunt would counsel her (FENWICK) to go to Bullhampton, and, therefore, she (FENWICK) would not mention the letter till she (FENWICK) had made up her (FENWICK) own mind.

``What will you do?'' (aunt)
said her (FENWICK) aunt.

``I will go, if you do not object.'' (unknown)

``I certainly shall not object,'' (Miss Marrable/Marrable/MISS MARRABLE)
said Miss Marrable.

Then Mary wrote a very short letter to her (Mary) friend, which may as well, also, be communicated to the reader:--

Loring, Thursday.

DEAR JANET,

I will go to you about the end of May; and yet, though I have made up my mind to do so, I almost doubt that I am not wise. If one could only ordain that things should be as though they had never been! That, however, is impossible, and one can only endeavour to live so as to come as nearly as possible to such a state. I know that I am confused; but I think you will understand what I mean.

I intend to be very full of energy about the chapel, and I do hope that your brother-in-law will be able to prove that Lord Trowbridge has been misbehaving himself. I never loved Mr. Puddleham, who always seemed to look upon me with wrath because I belonged to the Vicarage; and I certainly should take delight in seeing him (Puddleham) banished from the Vicarage gate.

Always affectionately yours,

MARY LOWTHER.

CHAPTER XLVII.

SAM BRATTLE IS WANTED.

The next week was one of considerable perturbation, trouble, and excitement at Bullhampton, and in the neighbourhood of Warminster and Heytesbury. It soon became known generally that Jack the Grinder and Lawrence Acorn were in Salisbury gaol, and that Sam Brattle--was wanted. The perturbation and excitement at Bullhampton were, of course, greater than elsewhere. It was necessary that the old miller should be told,--necessary also that the people at the mill should be asked as to Sam's present whereabouts. If they did not know it, they might assist the Vicar in discovering it. Fenwick went to the mill, taking the Squire with him (Fenwick); but they could obtain no information. he (miller) said.

On that same day there was a meeting of the magistrates at Heytesbury, and the two men who had been so cruelly fetched back from San Francisco were brought before it. Mr. Gilmore was on the bench, along with Sir Thomas Charleys, who was the chairman, and three other gentlemen. Lord Trowbridge was in the court house, and sat upon the bench, but gave it out that he (Trowbridge) was not sitting there as a magistrate. Samuel Brattle was called upon to answer to his (Samuel) bail, and Jones, the attorney appearing for him (Jones), explained that he (Jones) had gone from home to seek work elsewhere, alluded to the length of time that had elapsed, and to the injustice of presuming that a man against whom no evidence had been adduced, should be bound to remain always in one parish,--and expressed himself without any doubt that Mr. Fenwick and Mr. George Brattle, who were his (Fenwick) bailsmen, would cause him (Fenwick) to be found and brought forward. As neither the clergyman nor the farmer were in court, nothing further could be done at once; and the magistrates were quite ready to admit that time must be allowed. Nor was the case at all ready against the two men who were in custody. Indeed, against them the evidence was so little substantial that a lawyer from Devizes, who attended on their behalf, expressed his (lawyer) amazement that the American authorities should have given them up, and suggested that it must have been done with some view to a settlement of the Alabama claims. Evidence, however, was brought up to show that the two men had been convicted before, the one for burglary, and the other for horse-stealing; that the former, John Burrows, known as the Grinder, was a man from Devizes with whom the police about that town, and at Chippenham, Bath, and Wells, were well acquainted; that the other, Acorn, was a young man who had been respectable, as a partner in a livery stable at Birmingham, but who had taken to betting, and had for a year past been living by evil courses, having previously undergone two years of imprisonment with hard labour. It was proved that they had been seen in the neighbourhood both before and after the murder; that boots found in the cottage at Pycroft Common fitted certain footmarks in the mud of the farmer's yard; that Burrows had been supplied with a certain poison at a county chemist's at Lavington, and that the dog Bone'm had been poisoned with the like. Many other matters were proved, all of which were declared by the lawyer from Devizes to amount to nothing, and by the police authorities, who were prosecutors, to be very much. The magistrates of course ordered a remand, and ordered also that on the day named Sam Brattle should appear. It was understood that that day week was only named pro forma, the constables having explained that at least a fortnight would be required for the collection of further evidence. This took place on Tuesday, the 25th of April, and it was understood that time up to the 8th of May would be given to the police to complete their case.

So far all went on quietly at Heytesbury; but before the magistrates left the little town there was a row. Sir Thomas Charleys, in speaking to his (Charleys) brother magistrate, Mr. Gilmore, about the whole affair and about the Brattles in particular, had alluded to

CHAPTER XLVIII.

MARY LOWTHER RETURNS TO BULLHAMPTON.

A month went by after the scenes described in the last chapter, and summer had come at Bullhampton. It was now the end of May, and, with the summer, Mary Lowther had arrived. During the month very little progress had been made with the case at Heytesbury. There had been two or three remands, and now there was yet another. The police declared that this was rendered necessary by the absence of Sam Brattle,--that the magistrates were anxious to give all reasonable time for the production of the man who was out upon bail,--and that, as he (man) was undoubtedly concerned in the murder, they were determined to have him (man). But they who professed to understand the case, among whom were the lawyer from Devizes and Mr. Jones of Heytesbury, declared that no real search had been made for Brattle because the evidence in regard to the other men was hitherto inefficient. The remand now stood again till Tuesday, June the 5th, and it was understood that if Brattle did not then appear the bail would be declared to have been forfeited.

Fenwick had written a very angry letter to Lord Trowbridge, to which he (Trowbridge) had got no answer, and Lord Trowbridge had written a very silly letter to the bishop, in replying to which the bishop had snubbed him (bishop).

``I am informed by my friend, Mr. Gilmore,'' (the Vicar)
said the Vicar to the Marquis,
``that your lordship has stated openly that I have made visits to a young woman in Salisbury which are disgraceful to me, to my cloth, and to the parish of which I am the incumbent. I do not believe that your lordship will deny that you have done so, and I, therefore, call upon you at once to apologise to me for the calumny, which, in its nature, is as injurious and wicked as calumny can be, and to promise that you will not repeat the offence.'' (Marquis/Trowbridge/Marquis of Trowbridge)
The Marquis, when he (Marquis) received this, had not as yet written that letter to the bishop on which he (bishop) had resolved after his (bishop) interview with Gilmore,--feeling, perhaps, some qualms of conscience, thinking that it might be well that he (Gilmore) should consult his (Gilmore) son,--though with a full conviction that, if he (Gilmore) did so, his (Gilmore) son would not allow him (Gilmore) to write to the bishop at all,--possibly with some feeling that he (Gilmore) had been too hard upon his (Gilmore) enemy, the Vicar. But, when the letter from Bullhampton reached him (Vicar), all feelings of doubt, caution, and mercy, were thrown to the winds. The tone of the letter was essentially aggressive and impudent. It was the word calumny that offended him (Vicar) most, that, and the idea that he (Vicar), the Marquis of Trowbridge, should be called upon to promise not to commit an offence! The pestilent infidel at Bullhampton, as he (infidel) called our friend, had not attempted to deny the visits to the young woman at Salisbury. And the Marquis had made fresh inquiry which had completely corroborated his (Marquis) previous information. He (Marquis) had learned Mrs. Stiggs's address, and the name of Trotter's Buildings, which details were to his (Trotter) mind circumstantial, corroborative, and damnatory. Some dim account of the battle at the Three Honest Men had reached him (Trotter), and the undoubted fact that Carry Brattle was maintained by the Vicar. Then he (Vicar) remembered all Fenwick's old anxiety on behalf of the brother, whom the Marquis had taught himself to regard as the very man who had murdered his (Marquis) tenant. He (Marquis) reminded himself, too, of the murderer's present escape from justice by aid of this pestilent clergyman; and thus became convinced that in dealing with Mr. Fenwick, as it was his (Fenwick) undoubted duty to do, he (Fenwick) had to deal with one of the very worst of the human race. His (Fenwick) lordship's mind was one utterly incapable of sifting evidence,--unable even to understand evidence when it came to him (Fenwick). He (Fenwick) was not a bad man. He (Fenwick) desired nothing that was not his (Fenwick) own, and remitted much that was. He (Fenwick) feared God, honoured the Queen, and loved his (God) country. He (God) was not self-indulgent. He (God) did his (God) duties as he (God) knew them. But he (God) was an arrogant old fool, who could not keep himself from mischief,--who could only be kept from mischief by the aid of some such master as his (master) son. As soon as he (master) received the Vicar's letter he (master) at once sat down and wrote to the bishop. He (master) was so sure that he (master) was right, that he (master) sent Fenwick's letter to the bishop, acknowledging what he (master) himself had said at Heytesbury, and justifying it altogether by an elaborate account of the Vicar's wickedness.
``And now, my lord, let me ask you,'' (he)
said he (Vicar), in conclusion,
``whether you deem this a proper man to have the care of souls in the large and important parish of Bullhampton.'' (he)

The bishop felt himself to be very much bullied. He (bishop) had no doubt whatsoever about his (bishop) parson. He (bishop) knew that Fenwick was too strong a man to be acted upon beneficially by such advice as to his (Fenwick) private conduct as a bishop might give, and too good a man to need any caution as to his (man) conduct.

``My Lord Marquis,'' (he)
he (man) said, in reply,
``in returning the endorsed letter from Mr. Fenwick to your lordship, I can only say that nothing has been brought before me by your lordship which seems to me to require my interference. I should be wrong if I did not add to this the expression of my opinion that Mr. Fenwick is a moral man, doing his (Fenwick) duty in his (Fenwick) parish well, and an example in my diocese to be followed, rather than a stumbling block.'' When this letter reached the Castle Lord St. George was there. The poor old Marquis was cut to the quick. He (Marquis) immediately perceived,--so he (Marquis) told himself,--that the bishop was an old woman, who understood nothing; but he (bishop) was sure that St. George would not look at the matter in the same light. And yet it was impossible not to tell St. George. Much as he (bishop) dreaded his (bishop) son, he (bishop) did honestly tell everything to his (bishop) Mentor. He (bishop) had already told St. George of Fenwick's letter to him (bishop) and of his (bishop) letter to the bishop, and St. George had whistled. Now he (George) showed the bishop's letter to his (George) son. St. George read the letter, refolded it slowly, shrugged his (George) shoulders, and said, as he (George) returned it to his (George) father,--

``Well, my lord, I suppose you like a hornet's nest.'' (father)

This was the uncomfortable position of things at Bullhampton about the beginning of June, at which time Mary Lowther was again staying with her (Lowther) friend Mrs. Fenwick. Carry Brattle was still at Salisbury, but had not been seen by the Vicar for more than a fortnight. The Marquis's letter, backed as it was in part by his (Marquis) wife's counsel, had, much to his (Marquis) own disgust, deterred him (Marquis) from seeing the girl. His (Marquis) wife, however, had herself visited Trotter's Buildings, and had seen Carry, taking to her (wife) a little present from her (wife) mother, who did not dare to go over to Salisbury to see her (wife) child, because of words that had passed between her (wife) and her (wife) husband.

Mrs. Fenwick, on her (Fenwick) return home, had reported that Carry was silent, sullen, and idle; that her (Fenwick) only speech was an expression of a wish that she (Fenwick) was dead, and that Mrs. Stiggs had said that she (Stiggs) could get no good of her (Stiggs). In the meantime Sam Brattle had not yet turned up, and the 5th of June was at hand.

Mary Lowther was again at the vicarage, and of course it was necessary that she (Lowther) and Mr. Gilmore should meet each other. A promise had been made to her (Lowther) that no advice should be pressed upon her (Lowther),--the meaning of which, of course, was that nothing should be said to her (Lowther) urging her (Lowther) to marry Mr. Gilmore. But it was of course understood by all the parties concerned that Mr. Gilmore was to be allowed to come to the house; and, indeed, this was understood by the Fenwicks to mean almost as plainly that she (Lowther) would at least endeavour to bring herself to accept him (Gilmore) when he (Gilmore) did come. To Mary herself, as she (Mary) made the journey, the same meaning seemed to be almost inevitable; and as she (Mary) perceived this, she (Mary) told herself that she (Mary) had been wrong to leave home. She (Mary) knew,--she (Mary) thought she (Mary) knew,--that she (Mary) must refuse him (Gilmore), and in doing so would simply be making fresh trouble. Would it not have been better for her (Mary) to have remained at Loring,--to have put herself at once on a par with her (Mary) aunt, and have commenced her (Mary) life of solitary spinsterhood and dull routine? But, then, why should she (Mary) refuse him (Gilmore)? She (Mary) endeavoured to argue it out with herself in the railway carriage. She (Mary) had been told that Walter Marrable would certainly marry Edith Brownlow, and she (Brownlow) believed it. No doubt it was much better that he (Marrable) should do so. At any rate, she (Brownlow) and Walter were separated for ever. When he (Walter) wrote to her (Brownlow), declaring his (Walter) purpose of remaining in England, he (Walter) had said not a word of renewing his (Walter) engagement with her (Brownlow). No doubt she (Brownlow) loved him (Walter). About that she (Brownlow) did not for a moment endeavour to deceive herself. No doubt, if that fate in life which she (Brownlow) most desired might be hers, she (Brownlow) would become the wife of Walter Marrable. But that fate would not be hers, and then there arose the question whether, on that account, she (Brownlow) was unfit to be the wife of any other man. Of this she (Brownlow) was quite certain, that should it ever seem to her (Brownlow) to be her (Brownlow) duty to accept the other man, she (Brownlow) would first explain to him (man) clearly the position in which she (Brownlow) found herself. At last the whole matter resolved itself to this;--was it possible for her (Brownlow) to divest her (Brownlow) idea of life of all romance, and to look for contentment and satisfaction in the performance of duties to others? The prospect of an old maid's life at Loring was not pleasant to her (maid) eyes; but she (maid) would bear that, and worse than that, rather than do wrong. CHAPTER XLIX.

MARY LOWTHER``S DOOM.

The police were so very tedious in managing their business, and the whole affair of the second magisterial investigation was so protracted, that people in the neighbourhood became almost tired of it, in spite of that appetite for excitement which the ordinary quiet life of a rural district produces. On the first Tuesday in June Sam had surrendered himself at Heytesbury, and on the second Tuesday it was understood that the production of the prisoners was only formal. The final examination, and committal, if the evidence should be sufficient, was to take place on the third Tuesday in the month. Against this Mr. Jones had remonstrated very loudly on Sam's behalf, protesting that the magistrates were going beyond their power in locking up a man against whom there was no more evidence now than there had been when before they had found themselves compelled to release him (man) on bail. But this was of no avail. Sam had been released before because the men who were supposed to have been his (Sam) accomplices were not in custody; and now that they were in custody the police declared it to be out of the question that he (Sam) should be left at large. The magistrates of course agreed with the police, in spite of the indignation of Mr. Jones. In the meantime a subpoena was served upon Carry Brattle to appear on that final Tuesday,--Tuesday the nineteenth of June. The policeman, when he (policeman) served her (Sam) with the paper, told her (Sam) that on the morning in question he (policeman) would come and fetch her (Sam). But it was well known in Trotter's Buildings, and round about the Three Honest Men, that Sam Brattle was to be tried for the murder of Mr. Trumbull, and public opinion in that part of Salisbury was adverse to Sam. Public opinion was averse, also, to poor Carry; and Mrs. Stiggs was becoming almost tired of her (Stiggs) lodger, although the payment made for her (Stiggs) was not ungenerous and was as punctual as the sun. In truth, the tongue of the landlady of the Three Honest Men was potential in those parts, and was very bitter against Sam and his (Sam) sister.

CHAPTER L.

MARY LOWTHER INSPECTS HER FUTURE HOME.

Of course it was soon known in the vicarage that Mary Lowther had accepted the Squire's hand. CHAPTER LI.

THE GRINDER AND HIS (man) COMRADE.

CHAPTER LII.

CARRY BRATTLE``S JOURNEY.

Mrs. Stiggs had been right in her (Stiggs) surmise about Carry Brattle. The confinement in Trotter's Buildings and want of interest in her (Stiggs) life was more than the girl could bear, and she (Stiggs) had been thinking of escape almost from the first day that she (Stiggs) had been there. Had it not been for the mingled fear and love with which she (Stiggs) regarded Mr. Fenwick, had she (Stiggs) not dreaded that he (Fenwick) should think her (Stiggs) ungrateful, she (Stiggs) would have flown even before the summons came to her (Stiggs) which told her (Stiggs) that she (Stiggs) must appear before the magistrates and lawyers, and among a crowd of people, in the neighbourhood of her (Stiggs) old home. That she (Stiggs) could not endure, and therefore she (Stiggs) had flown. When it had been suggested to her (Stiggs) that she (Stiggs) should go and live with her (Stiggs) brother's wife as her (Stiggs) servant, that idea had been hard to bear. But there had been uncertainty, and an opinion of her (Stiggs) own which proved to be right, that her (Stiggs) sister-in-law would not receive her (Stiggs). Now about this paper that the policeman had handed to her (Stiggs), and the threatened journey to Heytesbury, there was no uncertainty,--unless she (Stiggs) might possibly escape the evil by running away. Therefore she (Stiggs) ran away.

The straight-going people of the world, in dealing with those who go crooked, are almost always unreasonable.

``Because you have been bad,'' (unknown)
say they who are not bad to those who are bad,
``because you have hitherto indulged yourself with all pleasures within your reach, because you have never worked steadily or submitted yourself to restraint, because you have been a drunkard, and a gambler, and have lived in foul company, therefore now,--now that I have got a hold of you and can manipulate you in reference to your repentance and future conduct,--I will require from you a mode of life that, in its general attractions, shall be about equal to that of a hermit in the desert. If you flinch you are not only a monster of ingratitude towards me, who am taking all this trouble to save you, but you are also a poor wretch for whom no possible hope of grace can remain.'' (a man)
When it is found that a young man is neglecting his (man) duties, doing nothing, spending his (man) nights in billiard rooms and worse places, and getting up at two o'clock in the day, the usual prescription of his (man) friends is that he (man) should lock himself up in his (man) own dingy room, drink tea, and spend his (man) hours in reading good books. It is hardly recognised that a sudden change from billiards to good books requires a strength of character which, if possessed, would probably have kept the young man altogether from falling into bad habits. If we left the doors of our prisons open, and then expressed disgust because the prisoners walked out, we should hardly be less rational. The hours at Mrs. Stiggs's house had been frightfully heavy to poor Carry Brattle, and at last she (Stiggs) escaped.

It was half-past ten on the Monday morning when she (Stiggs) went out. It was her (Stiggs) custom to go out at that hour. Mr. Fenwick had desired her (Stiggs) to attend the morning services at the Cathedral. She (Stiggs) had done so for a day or two, and had then neglected them. But she (Stiggs) had still left the house always at that time; and once, when Mrs. Stiggs had asked some question on the subject, she (Stiggs) had replied almost in anger that she (Stiggs) was not a prisoner. On this occasion she (Stiggs) made changes in her (Stiggs) dress which were not usual, and therefore she (Stiggs) was careful to avoid being seen as she (Stiggs) went; but had she (Stiggs) been interrogated she (Stiggs) would have persevered. Who had a right to stop her (Stiggs)?

But where should she (Stiggs) go? The reader may perhaps remember that once when Mr. Fenwick first found this poor girl, after her (girl) flight from home and her (girl) great disgrace, she (girl) had expressed a desire to go to the mill and just look at it,--even if she (girl) might do no more than that. The same idea was now in her (girl) mind, but as she (girl) left the city she (girl) had no concerted plan. There were two things between which she (girl) must choose at once,--either to go to London, or not to go to London. She (girl) had money enough for her (girl) fare, and perhaps a few shillings over. In a dim way she (girl) did understand that the choice was between going to the devil at once,--and not going quite at once; and then, weakly, wistfully, with uncertain step, almost without an operation of her (girl) mind, she (girl) did not take the turn which, from the end of Trotter's Buildings, would have brought her (girl) to the Railway Station, but did take that which led her (girl) by the Three Honest Men out on to the Devizes road,--the road which passes across Salisbury Plain, and leads from the city to many Wiltshire villages,--of which Bullhampton is one.

She (girl) walked slowly, but she (girl) walked nearly the whole day. Nothing could be more truly tragical than the utterly purposeless tenour of her (girl) day,--and of her (girl) whole life. She (girl) had no plan,--nothing before her (girl); no object even for the evening and night of that very day in which she (girl) was wasting her (girl) strength on the Devizes road. It is the lack of object, of all aim, in the lives of the houseless wanderers that gives to them the most terrible element of their misery. Think of it! To walk forth with, say, ten shillings in your pocket,--so that there need be no instant suffering from want of bread or shelter,--and have no work to do, no friend to see, no place to expect you, no duty to accomplish, no hope to follow, no bourn to which you can draw nigher,--except that bourn which, in such circumstances, the traveller must surely regard as simply the end of his (traveller) weariness! But there is nothing to which humanity cannot attune itself. Men can live upon poison, can learn to endure absolute solitude, can bear contumely, scorn, and shame, and never show it. Carry Brattle had already become accustomed to misery, and as she (you) walked she (you) thought more of the wretchedness of the present hour, of her (you) weary feet, of her (you) hunger, and of the nature of the rest which she (you) might purchase for herself at some poor wayside inn, than she (you) did of her (you) future life.

-LSB-Illustration: Carry Brattle.-RSB-

She (you) got a lump of bread and a glass of beer in the middle of the day, and then she (you) walked on and on till the evening came. She (you) went very slowly, stopping often and sitting down when the road side would afford her (you) some spot of green shade. At eight o'clock she (you) had walked fifteen miles, straight along the road, and, as she (you) knew well, had passed the turn which would have taken her (you) by the nearest way from Salisbury to Bullhampton. She (you) had formed no plan, but entertained a hope that if she (you) continued to walk they would not catch her (you) so as to take her (you) to Heytesbury on the morrow. She (you) knew that if she (you) went on she (you) might get to Pycroft Common by this road; and though there was no one in the whole world whom she (you) hated worse than Mrs. Burrows, still at Pycroft Common she (you) might probably be taken in and sheltered. At eight she (you) reached a small village which she (you) remembered to have seen before, of which she (you) saw the name written up on a board, and which she (you) knew to be six miles from Bullhampton. She (you) was so tired and weary that she (you) could go no further, and here she (you) asked for a bed. She (you) told them that she (you) was walking from Salisbury to the house of a friend who lived near Devizes, and that she (you) had thought she (you) could do it in one day and save her (you) railway fare. She (you) was simply asked to pay for her (you) bed and supper beforehand, and then she (you) was taken in and fed and sheltered. On the next morning she (you) got up very late and was unwilling to leave the house. She (you) paid for her (you) breakfast, and, as she (you) was not told to go her (you) way, she (you) sat on the chair in which she (you) had been placed, without speaking, almost without moving, till late in the afternoon. At three o'clock she (you) roused herself, asked for some bread and cheese which she (you) put in her (you) pocket, and started again upon her (you) journey. She (you) thought that she (you) would be safe, at any rate for that day, from the magistrates and the policemen, from the sight of her (you) brother, and from the presence of that other man at Heytesbury. But whither she (you) would go when she (you) left the house,--whether on to the hated cottage at Pycroft Common, or to her (you) father's house, she (you) had not made up her (you) mind when she (you) tied on her (you) hat. She (you) went on along the road towards Devizes, and about two miles from the village she (you) came to a lane turning to the left, with a finger-post. On this was written a direction,--To Bullhampton and Imber; and here she (you) turned short off towards the parish in which she (you) had been born. It was now all but midsummer, and the evenings were long and sultry. The window of Fanny's bedroom looked out on to the garden of the mill, and was but a foot or two above the ground. This ground had once been pleasant to them all, and profitable withal. Of late, since the miller had become old, and Sam had grown to be too restive and self-willed to act as desired for the general welfare of the family, but little of pleasure, or profit either, had been forthcoming from the patch of ground. CHAPTER LIV.

MR. GILMORE``S RUBIES.

Mary Lowther struggled hard for a week to reconcile herself to her (Lowther) new fate, and at the end of the week had very nearly given way. The gloom which had fallen upon her (Lowther) acted upon her (Lowther) lover and then reacted upon herself. Could he (lover) have been light in hand, could he (lover) have talked to her (Lowther) about ordinary subjects, could he (lover) have behaved towards her (Lowther) with any even of the light courtesies of the every-day lover, she (Lowther) would have been better able to fight her (Lowther) battle. There had been another visit to the house and gardens, and he (lover) had told her (Lowther) that this should be done,--unless she (Lowther) objected; and that that other change should be made, if it were not opposed to her (Lowther) wishes. Then she (Lowther) asked herself whether she (Lowther) meant to go through with it. If not, the sooner that she (Lowther) retreated and hid herself and her (Lowther) disgrace for the rest of her (Lowther) life the better. She (Lowther) had accepted him (lover) at last, because she (Lowther) had been made to believe that by doing so she (Lowther) would benefit him (lover), and because she (Lowther) had taught herself to think that it was her (Lowther) duty to disregard herself. She (Lowther) had thought of herself till she (Lowther) was sick of the subject. What did it matter,--about herself,--as long as she (Lowther) could be of some service to some one? And so thinking, she (Lowther) had accepted him (lover). But now she (Lowther) had begun to fear that were she (Lowther) to marry this man she (Lowther) could not be of service to him (man). And when the thing should be done,--if ever it were done,--there would be no undoing it. Would not her (Lowther) life be a life of sin if she (Lowther) were to live as the wife of a man whom she (Lowther) did not love,--while, perhaps, she (Lowther) would be unable not to love another man?

Nothing of all this was told to the Vicar, but Mrs. Fenwick knew what was going on in her (Fenwick) friend's mind, and spoke her (Fenwick) own very freely.

``Hitherto,'' (she)

Dunripple, 2nd July, 1868.

DEAR MARY,

I got your letter on Saturday, and cannot help wishing that it had been written in better spirits. However, I do not doubt but that it will all come right soon. I am quite sure that the best thing you can do is to let Mr. Gilmore name an early day. Of course you never intended that there should be a long engagement. Such a thing, where there is no possible reason for it, must be out of the question. And it will be much better to take advantage of the fine weather than to put it off till the winter has nearly come. Fix some day in August or early in September. I am sure you will be much happier married than you are single; and he (Gilmore) will be gratified, which is, I suppose, to count for something.

I am very happy here, but yet I long to get home. At my time of life, one must always be strange among strangers. Nothing can be kinder than Sir Gregory, in his (Gregory) sort of fashion. Gregory Marrable, the son, is, I fear, in a bad way. He (Marrable) is unlike his (Marrable) father, and laughs at his (Marrable) own ailments, but everybody in the house,--except perhaps Sir Gregory,--knows that he (Gregory) is very ill. He (Gregory) never comes down at all now, but lives in two rooms, which he (Gregory) has together up-stairs. We go and see him (Gregory) every day, but he (Gregory) is hardly able to talk to any one. Sir Gregory never mentions the subject to me, but Mrs. Brownlow is quite confident that if anything were to happen to Gregory Marrable, Walter would be asked to come to Dunripple as the heir, and to give up the army altogether.

I get on very well with Mrs. Brownlow, but of course we cannot be like old friends. Edith is a very nice girl, but rather shy. She (Edith) never talks about herself, and is too silent to be questioned. I do not, however, doubt for a moment but that she (Edith) will be Walter Marrable's wife. I think it likely that they are not engaged as yet, as in that case I think Mrs. Brownlow would tell me; but many things have been said which leave on my mind a conviction that it will be so. He (Marrable) is to be here again in August, and from the way in which Mrs. Brownlow speaks of his (Marrable) coming, there is no doubt that she (Brownlow) expects it. That he (Marrable) paid great attention to Edith when he (Marrable) was here before, I am quite sure; and I take it he (Marrable) is only waiting till--

In writing so far, Miss Marrable had intended to signify that Captain Marrable had been slow to ask Edith Brownlow to be his (Marrable) wife while he (Marrable) was at Dunripple, because he (Marrable) could not bring himself so soon to show himself indifferent to his (Marrable) former love; but that now he (Marrable) would not hesitate, knowing as he (Marrable) would know, that his (Marrable) former love had bestowed herself elsewhere; but in this there would have been a grievous accusation against Mary, and she (Mary) was therefore compelled to fill up her (Mary) sentence in some other form;--

till things should have arranged themselves a little.

And it will be all for the best. She (Mary) is a very nice, quiet, lady-like girl, and so great a favourite with her (Mary) uncle, that should his (uncle) son die before him (uncle), his (uncle) great object in life will be her (Mary) welfare. Walter Marrable, as her (Mary) husband, would live at Dunripple, just as though the place were his (Marrable) own. And indeed there would be no one between him (Marrable) and the property except his (Marrable) own father. Some arrangement could be made as to buying out his (Marrable) life interest,--for which indeed he (Marrable) has taken the money beforehand with a vengeance,--and then Walter would be settled for life. Would not this be all for the best?

I shall go home about the 14th. They want me to stay, but I shall have been away quite long enough. I don't know whether people ought to go from home at all after a certain age. I get cross because I can't have the sort of chair I like to sit on; and then they don't put any green tea into the pot, and I don't like to ask to have any made, as I doubt whether they have any green tea in the house. And I find it bad to be among invalids with whom, indeed, I can sympathise, but for whom I cannot pretend that I feel any great affection. As we grow old we become incapable of new tenderness, and rather resent the calls that are made upon us for pity. The luxury of devotion to misery is as much the privilege of the young as is that of devotion to love.

Write soon, dearest; and remember that the best news I can have, will be tidings as to the day fixed for your marriage. And remember, too, that I won't have any question about your being married at Bullhampton. It would be quite improper. He (we) must come to Loring; and I needn't say how glad I shall be to see the Fenwicks. Parson John will expect to marry you, but Mr. Fenwick might come and assist.

Your most affectionate aunt,

SARAH MARRABLE.

It was not the entreaty made by her (aunt) aunt that an early day should be fixed for the marriage which made Mary Lowther determine that she (Lowther) would yet once more attempt to drag the wagon. She (Lowther) could have withstood such entreaty as that, and, had the letter gone no further, would probably have replied to it by saying that no day could be fixed at all. But, with the letter there came an assurance that Walter Marrable had forgotten her (Lowther), was about to marry Edith Brownlow, and that therefore all ideas of love and truth and sympathy and joint beating of mutual hearts, with the rest of it, might be thrown to the winds. She (Brownlow) would marry Harry Gilmore, and take care that he (Gilmore) had good dinners, and would give her (Brownlow) mind to flannel petticoats and coal for the poor of Bullhampton, and would altogether come down from the pedestal which she (Brownlow) had once striven to erect for herself. CHAPTER LV.

GLEBE LAND.

The fifteenth of July was a Sunday, and it had been settled for some time past that on this day Mr. Puddleham would preach for the first time in his (Puddleham) new chapel. The building had been hurried on through the early summer in order that this might be achieved; and although the fittings were not completed, and the outward signs of the masons and labourers had not been removed,--although the heaps of mortar were still there, and time had not yet sufficed to have the chips cleared away,--on Sunday the fifteenth of July the chapel was opened. Great efforts were made to have it filled on the occasion. The builder from Salisbury came over with all his (builder) family, not deterred by the consideration that whereas the Puddlehamites of Bullhampton were Primitive Methodists, he (builder) was a regular Wesleyan. And many in the parish were got to visit the chapel on this the day of its glory, who had less business there than even the builder from Salisbury. In most parishes there are some who think it well to let the parson know that they are independent and do not care for him (parson), though they profess to be of his (parson) flock; and then, too, the novelty of the thing had its attraction, and the well-known fact that the site chosen for the building had been as gall and wormwood to the parson and his (parson) family. These causes together brought a crowd to the vicarage-gate on that Sunday morning, and it was quite clear that the new chapel would be full, and that Mr. Puddleham's first Sunday would be a success. And the chapel, of course, had a bell,--a bell which was declared by Mrs. Fenwick to be the hoarsest, loudest, most unmusical, and ill-founded miscreant of a bell that was ever suspended over a building for the torture of delicate ears. It certainly was a loud and brazen bell; but Mr. Fenwick expressed his (Fenwick) opinion that there was nothing amiss with it. When his (Fenwick) wife declared that it sounded as though it came from the midst of the shrubs at their own front gate, he (Fenwick) reminded her (wife) that their own church bells sounded as though they came from the lower garden. That one sound should be held by them to be musical and the other abominable, he (Fenwick) declared to be a prejudice. Then there was a great argument about the bells, in which Mrs. Fenwick, and Mary Lowther, and Harry Gilmore were all against the Vicar. And, throughout the discussion, it was known to them all that there were no ears in the parish to which the bells were so really odious as they were to the ears of the Vicar himself. In his (Vicar) heart of hearts he (Vicar) hated the chapel, and, in spite of all his (Vicar) endeavours to the contrary, his (Vicar) feelings towards Mr. Puddleham were not those which the Christian religion requires one neighbour to bear to another. But he (Christian) made the struggle, and for some weeks past had not said a word against Mr. Puddleham. In regard to the Marquis the thing was different. The Marquis should have known better, and against the Marquis he (Marquis) did say a great many words.

They began to ring the bell on that Sunday morning before ten o'clock. Mrs. Fenwick was still sitting at the breakfast-table, with the windows open, when the sound was first heard,--first heard, that is, on that morning. She (Fenwick) looked at Mary, groaned, and put her (Fenwick) hands to her (Fenwick) ears. The Vicar laughed, and walked about the room.

``At what time do they begin?'' (Mary/Mary Lowther/MARY LOWTHER)
said Mary.

``Not till eleven,'' (Mrs. Fenwick)
said Mrs. Fenwick.
``There, it wants a quarter to ten now, and they mean to go on with that music for an hour and a quarter.'' (unknown)

``We shall be keeping them company by-and-by,'' (the Vicar)
said the Vicar.

``The poor old church bells won't be heard through it,'' (Mrs. Fenwick)
said Mrs. Fenwick.

Mrs. Fenwick was in the habit of going to the village school for half an hour before the service on Sunday mornings, and on this morning she (Fenwick) started from the house according to her (Fenwick) custom at a little after ten. Mary Lowther went with her (Lowther), and as the school was in the village and could be reached much more shortly by the front gate than by the path round by the church, the two ladies walked out boldly before the new chapel. The reader may perhaps remember that Mrs. Fenwick had promised her (Fenwick) husband to withdraw that outward animosity to the chapel which she (Fenwick) had evinced by not using the vicarage entrance. As they went there was a crowd collected, and they found that after the manner of the Primitive Methodists in their more enthusiastic days, a procession of worshippers had been formed in the village, which at this very moment was making its way to the chapel. Mrs. Fenwick, as she (Fenwick) stood aside to make way for them, declared that the bell sounded as though it were within her (Fenwick) bonnet. When they reached the school they found that many a child was absent who should have been there, and Mrs. Fenwick knew that the truant urchins were amusing themselves at the new building. And with those who were not truant the clang of the new bell distracted terribly that attention which was due to the collect. Mrs. Fenwick herself confessed afterwards that she (Fenwick) hardly knew what she (Fenwick) was teaching.

Mr. Fenwick, according to his (Fenwick) habit, went into his (Fenwick) own study when the ladies went to the school, and there, according to custom also on Sunday mornings, his (Fenwick) letters were brought to him (Fenwick), some few minutes before he (Fenwick) started on his (Fenwick) walk through the garden to the church. On this morning there were a couple of letters for himself, and he (Fenwick) opened them both. One was from a tradesman in Salisbury, and the other was from his (Fenwick) wife's brother-in-law, Mr. Quickenham. Before he (Fenwick) started he (Fenwick) read Mr. Quickenham's letter, and then did his (Fenwick) best to forget it and put it out of his (Fenwick) mind till the morning service should be over. The letter was as follows:--

Pump Court, June 30, 1868.

DEAR FENWICK,

I have found, as I thought I should, that Lord Trowbridge has no property in, or right whatever to, the bit of ground on which your enemies have been building their new Ebenezer. The spot is a part of the glebe, and as such seems to have been first abandoned by a certain parson named Brandon, who was your predecessor's predecessor. There can, however, be no doubt that the ground is glebe, and that you are bound to protect it as such, on behalf of your successors, and of the patrons of the living.

I found some difficulty in getting at the terrier of the parish,--which you, who consider yourself to be a model parson, I dare say, have never seen. I have, however, found it in duplicate. The clerk of the Board of Guardians, who should, I believe, have a copy of it, knew nothing about it; and had never heard of such a document. Your bishop's registrar was not much more learned,--but I did find it in the bishop's chancery; and there is a copy of it also at Saint John's, which seems to imply that great attention has been paid by the college as patron to the interests of the parish priest. This is more than has been done by the incumbent, who seems to be an ignorant fellow in such matters. I wonder how many parsons there are in the Church who would let a Marquis and a Methodist minister between them build a chapel on the parish glebe?

Yours ever,

RICHARD QUICKENHAM.

If I were to charge you through an attorney for my trouble you'd have to mortgage your life interest in the bit of land to pay me. I enclose a draft from the terrier as far as the plot of ground and the vicarage-gate are concerned.

Here was information! This detestable combination of dissenting and tyrannically territorial influences had been used to build a Methodist Chapel upon land of which he (terrier), during his (terrier) incumbency in the parish, was the freehold possessor! What an ass he (terrier) must have been not to know his (terrier) own possessions! How ridiculous would he (terrier) appear when he (terrier) should come forward to claim as a part of the glebe a morsel of land to which he (terrier) had paid no special attention whatever since he (terrier) had been in the parish! And then, what would it be his (terrier) duty to do? Mr. Quickenham had clearly stated that on behalf of the college, which was the patron of the living, and on behalf of his (patron) successors, it was his (patron) duty to claim the land. And was it possible that he (patron) should not do so after such usage as he (patron) had received from Lord Trowbridge? So meditating,--but grieving that he (Trowbridge) should be driven at such a moment to have his (Trowbridge) mind forcibly filled with such matters,--still hearing the chapel bell, which in his (Trowbridge) ears drowned the sound from his (Trowbridge) own modest belfry, and altogether doubtful as to what step he (Trowbridge) would take, he (Trowbridge) entered his (Trowbridge) own church. It was manifest to him (Trowbridge) that of the poorer part of his (Trowbridge) usual audience, and of the smaller farmers, one half were in attendance upon Mr. Puddleham's triumph.

During the whole of that afternoon he (Puddleham) said not a word of the barrister's letter to any one. He (Puddleham) struggled to banish the subject from his (Puddleham) thoughts. Failing to do that, he (Puddleham) did banish it from his (Puddleham) tongue. The letter was in the pocket of his (Puddleham) coat; but he (Puddleham) showed it to no one. Gilmore dined at the vicarage; but even to him (Gilmore) he (Gilmore) was silent. Of course the conversation at dinner turned upon the chapel. It was impossible that on such a day they should speak of anything else. Even as they sat at their early dinner Mr. Puddleham's bell was ringing, and no doubt there was a vigour in the pulling of it which would not be maintained when the pulling of it should have become a thing of every week. There had been a compact made, in accordance with which the Vicar's wife was to be debarred from saying anything against the chapel, and, no doubt, when the compact was made, the understanding was that she (wife) should give over hating the chapel. This had, of course, been found to be impossible, but in a certain way she (wife) had complied with the compact. The noise of the bell however, was considered to be beyond the compact, and on this occasion she (wife) was almost violent in the expression of her (wife) wrath. Her (wife) husband listened to her (wife), and sat without rebuking her (wife), silent, with the lawyer's letter in his (lawyer) pocket. This bell had been put up on his (lawyer) own land, and he (lawyer) could pull it down to-morrow. It had been put up by the express agency of Lord Trowbridge, and with the direct view of annoying him (Trowbridge); and Lord Trowbridge had behaved to him (Trowbridge) in a manner which set all Christian charity at defiance. He (Trowbridge) told himself plainly that he (Trowbridge) had no desire to forgive Lord Trowbridge,--that life in this world, as it is constituted, would not be compatible with such forgiveness,--that he (Trowbridge) would not, indeed, desire to injure Lord Trowbridge otherwise than by exacting such penalty as would force him (Trowbridge) and such as he (Trowbridge) to restrain their tyranny; but that to forgive him (Trowbridge), till he (Trowbridge) should have been so forced, would be weak and injurious to the community. As to that, he (Trowbridge) had quite made up his (Trowbridge) mind, in spite of all doctrine to the contrary. Men in this world would have to go naked if they gave their coats to the robbers who took their cloaks; and going naked is manifestly inexpedient. His (Trowbridge) office of parish priest would be lowered in the world if he (Trowbridge) forgave, out of hand, such offences as these which had been committed against him (Trowbridge) by Lord Trowbridge. This he (Trowbridge) understood clearly. And now he (Trowbridge) might put down, not only the bell, but with the bell the ill-conditioned peer who had caused it to be put up--on glebe land. All this went through his (Trowbridge) mind again and again, as he (Trowbridge) determined that on that day, being Sunday, he (Trowbridge) would think no more about it.

When the Monday came it was necessary that he (Trowbridge) should show the letter to his (Trowbridge) wife,--to his (Trowbridge) wife, and to the Squire, and to Mary Lowther. He (Trowbridge) had no idea of keeping the matter secret from his (Trowbridge) near friends and advisers; but he (Trowbridge) had an idea that it would be well that he (Trowbridge) should make up his (Trowbridge) mind as to what he (Trowbridge) would do before he (Trowbridge) asked their advice. He (Trowbridge) started, therefore, for a turn through the parish before breakfast on Monday morning,--and resolved as to his (Trowbridge) course of action. On no consideration whatever would he (Trowbridge) have the chapel pulled down. It was necessary for his (Trowbridge) purpose that he (Trowbridge) should have his (Trowbridge) triumph over the Marquis,--and he (Trowbridge) would have it. But the chapel had been built for a good purpose which it would adequately serve, and let what might be said to him (Trowbridge) by his (Trowbridge) wife or others, he (Trowbridge) would not have a brick of it disturbed. No doubt he (Trowbridge) had no more power to give the land for its present or any other purpose than had the Marquis. It might very probably be his (Marquis) duty to take care that the land was not appropriated to wrong purposes. It might be that he (Marquis) had already neglected his (Marquis) duty, in not knowing, or in not having taken care to learn the precise limits of the glebe which had been given over to him (Marquis) for his (Marquis) use during his (Marquis) incumbency. Nevertheless, there was the chapel, and there it should stand, as far as he (Marquis) was concerned. If the churchwardens, or the archdeacon, or the college, or the bishop had power to interfere, as to which he (bishop) was altogether ignorant, and chose to exercise that power, he (bishop) could not help it. He (bishop) was nearly sure that his (bishop) own churchwardens would be guided altogether by himself,--and as far as he (bishop) was concerned the chapel should remain unmolested. Having thus resolved he (bishop) came back to breakfast and read Mr. Quickenham's letter aloud to his (Quickenham) wife and Mary Lowther.

``Glebe!'' (the Vicar)
said the Vicar's wife.

It has absolutely come to pass that here, in the middle of Wiltshire, with all our maps, and surveys, and parish records, no one concerned has known to whom belonged a quarter of an acre of land in the centre of the village. It is just a thing to write an article about in a newspaper; but I can't say that one party is more to blame than the other; that is, in regard to the ignorance displayed.'' (unknown)

This was the Vicar's decision on the Monday morning, and from that decision the two ladies were quite unable to move him (Vicar).

This occurred a day or two after the affair of the rubies, and at a time when Mary was being very hard pressed to name a day for her (Mary) wedding. Of course such pressure had been the result of Mr. Gilmore's success on that occasion. She (Mary) had then resolutely gone to work to overcome her (Mary) own, and his (Gilmore), melancholy gloom, and, having in a great degree succeeded, it was only natural that he (Gilmore) should bring up that question of his (Gilmore) marriage day. She (Mary), when she (Mary) had accepted him (Gilmore), had done so with a stipulation that she (Mary) should not be hurried; but we all know what such stipulations are worth. Who is to define what is and what is not hurry? They had now been engaged a month, and the Squire was clearly of opinion that there had been no hurry.

``September was the nicest month in the year,'' (he)
he (Squire) said,
``for getting married and going abroad. September in Switzerland, October among the Italian lakes, November in Florence and Rome. So that they might get home before Christmas after a short visit to Naples.'' (he)
That was the Squire's programme, and his (Squire) whole manner was altered as he (Squire) made it. He (Squire) thought he (Squire) knew the nature of the girl well enough to be sure that, though she (girl) would profess no passionate love for him (Squire) before starting on such a journey, she (girl) would change her (girl) tone before she (girl) returned. It should be no fault of his (Squire) if she (girl) did not change it. Mary had at first declined to fix any day, had talked of next year, had declared that she (Mary) would not be hurried. She (Mary) had carried on the fight even after the affair of the rubies, but she (Mary) had fought in opposition to strong and well-disciplined forces on the other side, and she (Mary) had begun to admit to herself that it might be expedient that she (Mary) should yield. The thing was to be done, and why not have it done at once? She (Mary) had not as yet yielded, but she (Mary) had begun to think that she (Mary) would yield.

At such a period it was of course natural that the Squire should be daily at the vicarage, and on this Monday morning he (Squire) came down while the minds of all his (Squire) friends there were intent on the strange information received from Mr. Quickenham. The Vicar was not by when Mr. Gilmore was told, and he (Gilmore) was thus easily induced to join in the opinion that the chapel should be made to disappear. He (Gilmore) had a landlord's idea about land, and was thoroughly well-disposed to stop any encroachment on the part of the Marquis.

``Lord Trowbridge must pull it down himself, and put it up again elsewhere,'' (the Squire)
said the Squire.

``But Frank says that he (Frank) won't let the Marquis pull it down,'' (Mrs. Fenwick)
said Mrs. Fenwick, almost moved to tears by the tragedy of the occasion.

Then the Vicar joined them, and the matter was earnestly debated;--so earnestly that, on that occasion, not a word was said as to the day of the wedding.

CHAPTER LVI.

THE VICAR``S VENGEANCE.

No eloquence on the part of the two ladies at the vicarage, or of the Squire, could turn Mr. Fenwick from his (Squire) purpose, but he (Squire) did consent at last to go over with the Squire to Salisbury, and to consult Mr. Chamberlaine. A proposition was made to him (Squire) as to consulting the bishop, for whom personally he (Squire) always expressed a liking, and whose office he (Squire) declared that he (Squire) held in the highest veneration; but he (Squire) explained that this was not a matter in which the bishop should be invited to exercise authority.

``The bishop has nothing to do with my freehold,'' (he)
he (Vicar) said.

``But if you want an opinion,'' (Squire/Squire Gilmore)
said the Squire,
``why not go to a man whose opinion will be worth having?'' (Squire/Squire Gilmore)

Then the Vicar explained again. His (Vicar) respect for the bishop was so great, that any opinion coming from his (Vicar) lordship would, to him (Vicar), be more than advice; it would be law. So great was his (Vicar) mingled admiration of the man and respect for the office!

``What he (man) means,'' (Mrs. Fenwick)
said Mrs. Fenwick,
``is, that he (man) won't go to the bishop, because he (man) has made up his (man) mind already. You are, both of you, throwing away your time and money in going to Salisbury at all.'' (Mrs. Fenwick)

``I'm not sure but what she (man)'s right there,'' (the Vicar)
said the Vicar. Nevertheless they went to Salisbury.

The Rev. Henry Fitzackerly Chamberlaine was very eloquent, clear, and argumentative on the subject, and perhaps a little overbearing. He (Chamberlaine) insisted that the chapel should be removed without a moment's delay; and that notice as to its removal should be served upon all the persons concerned,--upon Mr. Puddleham, upon the builder, upon the chapel trustees, the elders of the congregation,--

``if there be any elders,'' (the congregation)
said Mr. Chamberlaine, with a delightful touch of irony,--and upon the Marquis and the Marquis's agent. He (Marquis) was eloquent, authoritative and loud. When the Vicar remarked that after all the chapel had been built for a good purpose, Mr. Chamberlaine became quite excited in his (Chamberlaine) eloquence.

``The glebe of Bullhampton, Mr. Fenwick,'' (he)
said he (Chamberlaine),
``has not been confided to your care for the propagation of dissent.'' (he)

``Nor has the vicarage house been confided to me for the reading of novels; but that is what goes on there.'' (unknown)

``The house is for your private comfort,'' (unknown)
said the prebendary.

``And so is the glebe,'' (the Vicar)
said the Vicar;
``and I shall not be comfortable if I make these people put down a house of prayer.'' (the Vicar)

And there was another argument against the Vicar's views, very strong. This glebe was only given to him (Vicar) in trust. He (Vicar) was bound so to use it, that it should fall into the hands of his (Vicar) successor unimpaired and with full capability for fruition.

``You have no right to leave to another the demolition of a building, the erection of which you should have prevented.'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)
This argument was more difficult of answer than the other, but Mr. Fenwick did answer it.

``I feel all that,'' (he)
said he (Fenwick);
``and I think it likely that my estate may be liable for the expense of removal. The chapel may be brought in as a dilapidation. But that which I can answer with my purse, need not lie upon my conscience. I could let the bit of land, I have no doubt,--though not on a building lease.'' (he)

``But they have built on it,'' (Mr. Chamberlaine/Mr. CHAMBERLAINE)
said Mr. Chamberlaine.

``No doubt, they have; and I can see that my estate may be called upon to restore the bit of ground to its former position. What I can't see is, that I am bound to enforce the removal now.'' (Mr. Chamberlaine/Mr. CHAMBERLAINE)

Mr. Chamberlaine took up the matter with great spirit, and gave a couple of hours to the discussion, but the Vicar was not shaken.

The Vicar was not shaken, but his (Vicar) manner as he (Vicar) went out from the prebendary's presence, left some doubt as to his (Vicar) firmness in the mind both of that dignitary and of the Squire. He (Squire) thanked Mr. Chamberlaine very courteously, and acknowledged that there was a great deal in the arguments which had been used.

``I am sure you will find it best to clear your ground of the nuisance at once,'' (Mr. Chamberlaine/Mr. CHAMBERLAINE)
said Mr. Chamberlaine, with that high tone which he (Chamberlaine) knew so well how to assume; and these were the last words spoken.

``Well?'' (the Squire)

``I never do. But I think he (uncle) is right.'' (the Squire)

``No doubt, some day. But I am quite sure as to this, Harry; that when you have a doubt as to your duty, you can't be wrong in delaying that, the doing of which would gratify your own ill will. Don't you go and tell this to the women; but to my eyes that conventicle at Bullhampton is the most hideous, abominable, and disagreeable object that ever was placed upon the earth!'' (unknown)

It will enable me to take all the good things of the world that come in my way, and flatter myself that I am not self-indulgent. There is not a dissenter in Bullhampton will get so much out of the chapel as I will.'' (unknown)

``I fancy they can make you have it pulled down.'' (unknown)
