Upon that they went back to Bullhampton, and the Squire told the two ladies what had passed; as to the hair shirt and all.

Mr. Fenwick in making for himself his (Fenwick) hair shirt did not think it necessary to abstain from writing to the Marquis of Trowbridge. This he (Trowbridge) did on that same day after his (Trowbridge) return from Salisbury. In the middle of the winter he (Trowbridge) had written a letter to the Marquis, remonstrating against the building of the chapel opposite to his (Marquis) own gate. He (Marquis) now took out his (Marquis) copy of that letter, and the answer to it, in which the agent of the Marquis had told him (Marquis) that the Marquis considered that the spot in question was the most eligible site which his (Marquis) lordship could bestow for the purpose in question. Our Vicar was very anxious not to disturb the chapel now that it was built; but he (Vicar) was quite as anxious to disturb the Marquis. In the formation of that hair shirt which he (Marquis) was minded to wear, he (Marquis) did not intend to weave in any mercy towards the Marquis. It behoved him (Marquis) to punish the Marquis,--for the good of society in general. As a trespasser he (Marquis) forgave the Marquis, in a Christian point of view; but as a pestilent wasp on the earth, stinging folks right and left with an arrogance, the ignorance of which was the only excuse to be made for his (Marquis) cruelty, he (Marquis) thought it to be his (Marquis) duty to set his (Marquis) heel upon the Marquis; which he (Marquis) did by writing the following letter.

Bullhampton Vicarage, July 18, 186--.

MY LORD MARQUIS,

On the 3rd of January last I ventured to write to your lordship with the object of saving myself and my family from a great annoyance, and of saving you also from the disgrace of subjecting me to it. I then submitted to you the expediency of giving in the parish some other site for the erection of a dissenting chapel than the small patch of ground immediately opposite to the vicarage gate, which, as I explained to you, I had always regarded as belonging to the vicarage. I did not for a moment question your lordship's right to give the land in question, but appealed simply to your good-feeling. I confess that I took it for granted that even your lordship, in so very high-handed a proceeding, would take care to have right on your side. In answer to this I received a letter from your man of business, of which, as coming from him (man), I do not complain, but which, as a reply to my letter to your lordship, was an insult. The chapel has been built, and on last Sunday was opened for worship.

I have now learned that the land which you have given away did not belong to your lordship, and never formed a portion of the Stowte estate in this parish. It was, and is, glebe land; and formed, at the time of your bestowal, a portion of my freehold as Vicar. I acknowledge that I was remiss in presuming that you as a landlord knew the limits of your own rights, and that you would not trespass beyond them. I should have made my inquiry more urgently. I have made it now, and your lordship may satisfy yourself by referring to the maps of the parish lands, which are to be found in the bishop's chancery, and also at St. John's, Oxford, if you cannot do so by any survey of the estate in your own possession. I enclose a sketch showing the exact limits of the glebe in respect to the vicarage entrance and the patch of ground in question. The fact is, that the chapel in question has been built on the glebe land by authority--illegally and unjustly given by your lordship.

The chapel is there, and though it is a pity that it should have been built, it would be a greater pity that it should be pulled down. It is my purpose to offer to the persons concerned a lease of the ground for the term of my incumbency at a nominal rent. I presume that a lease may be so framed as to protect the rights of my successor.

I will not conclude this letter without expressing my opinion that gross as has been your lordship's ignorance in giving away land which did not belong to you, your fault in that respect has been very trifling in comparison with the malice you have shown to a clergyman of your own church, settled in a parish partly belonging to yourself, in having caused the erection of this chapel on the special spot selected with no other object than that of destroying my personal comfort and that of my wife.

I have the honour to be Your lordship's most obedient servant,

FRANCIS FENWICK.

When he (FENWICK) had finished his (FENWICK) epistle he (FENWICK) read it over more than once, and was satisfied that it would be vexatious to the Marquis. It was his (Marquis) direct object to vex the Marquis, and he (Marquis) had set about it with all his (Marquis) vigour.

``I would skin him (dissenter) if I knew how,'' (he)
he (Marquis) had said to Gilmore.
``He (dissenter) has done that to me which no man should forgive. He (man) has spoken ill of me, and calumniated me, not because he (man) has thought ill of me, but because he (man) has had a spite against me. They may keep their chapel as far as I am concerned. But as for his (man) lordship, I should think ill of myself if I spared him (man).'' (He)
He (Marquis) had his (Marquis) lordship on the hip, and he (Marquis) did not spare him (Marquis). He (Marquis) showed the letter to his (Marquis) wife.

``Isn't malice a very strong word?'' (she)
she (wife) said.

``I hope so,'' (the Vicar)
answered the Vicar.

``What I mean is, might you not soften it without hurting your cause?'' (unknown)

``I think not. I conscientiously believe the accusation to be true. I endeavour so to live among my neighbours that I may not disgrace them, or you, or myself. This man has dared to accuse me openly of the grossest immorality and hypocrisy, when I am only doing my duty as I best know how to do it; and I do now believe in my heart that in making these charges he (man) did not himself credit them. At any rate, no man can be justified in making such charges without evidence.'' (unknown)

``But all that had nothing to do with the bit of ground, Frank.'' (unknown)

``It is part and parcel of the same thing. He (Frank) has chosen to treat me as an enemy, and has used all the influence of his (Frank) wealth and rank to injure me. Now he (Frank) must look to himself. I will not say a word of him (Frank), or to him (Frank), that is untrue; but as he (Frank) has said evil of me behind my back which he (Frank) did not believe, so will I say the evil of him (Frank), which I do believe, to his (Frank) face.'' (the Vicar)
The letter was sent, and before the day was over the Vicar had recovered his (Vicar) good humour.

And before the day was over the news was all through the parish. There was a certain ancient shoemaker in the village who had carried on business in Devizes, and had now retired to spend the evening of his (shoemaker) life in his (shoemaker) native place. Mr. Bolt was a quiet, inoffensive old man, but he (Bolt) was a dissenter, and was one of the elders and trustees who had been concerned in raising money for the chapel. To him (Bolt) the Vicar had told the whole story, declaring at the same time that, as far as he (Vicar) was concerned, Mr. Puddleham and his (Puddleham) congregation should, at any rate for the present, be made welcome to their chapel. This he (Puddleham) had done immediately on his (Puddleham) return from Salisbury, and before the letter to the Marquis was written. Mr. Bolt, not unnaturally, saw his (Bolt) minister the same evening, and the thing was discussed in full conclave by the Puddlehamites. At the end of that discussion, Mr. Puddleham expressed his (Puddleham) conviction that the story was a mare's nest from beginning to end. He (Puddleham) didn't believe a word of it. The Marquis was not the man to give away anything that did not belong to him (Marquis). Somebody had hoaxed the Vicar, or the Vicar had hoaxed Mr. Bolt; or else,--which Mr. Puddleham thought to be most likely,--the Vicar had gone mad with vexation at the glory and the triumph of the new chapel.

``He (Frank) was uncommon civil,'' (Mr. Bolt)
said Mr. Bolt, who at this moment was somewhat inclined to favour the Vicar.

``No doubt, Mr. Bolt; no doubt,'' (Mr. Puddleham/MR. PUDDLEHAM/Puddleham)
said Mr. Puddleham, who had quite recovered from his (Puddleham) first dismay, and had worked himself up to a state of eloquent enthusiasm.
``I dare say he (Bolt) was civil. Why not? In old days when we hardly dared to talk of having a decent house of prayer of our own in which to worship our God, he (God) was always civil. No one has ever heard me accuse Mr. Fenwick of incivility. But will any one tell me that he (Fenwick) is a friend to our mode of worship? Gentlemen, we must look to ourselves, and I for one tell you that that chapel is ours. You won't find that his (Fenwick) ban will keep me out of my pulpit. Glebe, indeed! why should the Vicar have glebe on the other side of the road from his (Vicar) house? Or, for the matter of that, why should he (Vicar) have glebe at all?'' (Mr. Puddleham/MR. PUDDLEHAM/Puddleham)
This was so decisive that no one at the meeting had a word to say after Mr. Puddleham had finished his (Puddleham) speech.

When the Marquis received his (Marquis) letter he (Marquis) was up in London. Lord Trowbridge was not much given to London life, but was usually compelled by circumstances,--the circumstances being the custom of society as pleaded by his (Trowbridge) two daughters,--to spend the months of May, June, and July at the family mansion in Grosvenor Square. Moreover, though the Marquis never opened his (Marquis) mouth in the House of Lords, it was, as he (Marquis) thought, imperative on him (Marquis) to give to the leader of his (Marquis) party the occasional support of his (Marquis) personal presence. Our Vicar, knowing this, had addressed his (Vicar) letter to Grosvenor Square, and it had thus reached its destination without loss of time. Lord Trowbridge by this time knew the handwriting of his (Trowbridge) enemy; and, as he (Trowbridge) broke the envelope, there came upon him (Trowbridge) an idea that it might be wise to refuse the letter, and to let it go back to its writer unopened. It was beneath his (writer) dignity to correspond with a man, or to receive letters from a man who would probably insult him (man). But before he (man) could make up his (man) mind, the envelope had been opened, and the letter had been read. His (man) wrath, when he (man) had read it, no writer of a simple prose narration should attempt to describe.

``Disgrace,'' (the Marquis)
``insult,'' (the Marquis)
``ignorance,'' (the Marquis)
and
``malice,'' (the Marquis)
--these were the words with which the Marquis found himself pelted by this pestilent, abominable, and most improper clergyman. As to the gist of the letter itself, it was some time before he (gist) understood it. And when he (gist) did begin to understand it, he (gist) did not as yet begin to believe it. His (gist) intelligence worked slowly, whereas his (gist) wrath worked quickly. But at last he (gist) began to ask himself whether the accusation made against him (gist) could possibly be based on truth. When the question of giving the land had been under consideration, it had never occurred to any one concerned that it could belong to the glebe. There had been some momentary suspicion that the spot might possibly have been so long used as common land as to give room for a question on that side; but no one had dreamed that any other claimant could arise. That the whole village of Bullhampton belonged to the Marquis was notorious. Of course there was the glebe. But who could think that the morsel of neglected land lying on the other side of the road belonged to the vicarage? The Marquis did not believe it now. This was some piece of wickedness concocted by the venomous brain of the iniquitous Vicar, more abominable than all his (Vicar) other wickednesses. The Marquis did not believe it; but he (Marquis) walked up and down his (Marquis) room all the morning thinking of it. The Marquis was sure that it was not true, and yet he (Marquis) could not for a moment get the idea out of his (Marquis) mind. Of course he (Marquis) must tell St. George. The language of the letter which had been sent to him (Marquis) was so wicked, that St. George must at least agree with him (George) now in his (George) anger against this man. And could nothing be done to punish the man? Prosecutions in regard to anonymous letters, threatening letters, begging letters, passed through his (man) mind. He (man) knew that punishment had been inflicted on the writers of insolent letters to royalty. And letters had been proved to be criminal as being libellous,--only then they must be published; and letters were sometimes held to form a conspiracy;--but he (man) could not quite see his (man) way to that. He (man) knew that he (man) was not royal; and he (man) knew that the Vicar neither threatened him (Vicar) or begged aught from him (Vicar). What if St. George should tell him (Vicar) again that this Vicar had right on his (Vicar) side! He (Vicar) cast the matter about in his (Vicar) mind all the day; and then, late in the afternoon, he (Vicar) got into his (Vicar) carriage, and had himself driven to the chambers of Messrs. Boothby, the family lawyers.

CHAPTER LVII.

OIL IS TO BE THROWN UPON THE WATERS.

-LSB-Illustration-RSB-

Messrs. Boothby in Lincoln's Inn had for very many years been the lawyers of the Stowte family, and probably knew as much about the property as any of the Stowtes themselves. They had not been consulted about the giving away of the bit of land for the chapel purposes, nor had they been instructed to draw up any deed of gift. The whole thing had been done irregularly. The land had been only promised, and not in truth as yet given, and the Puddlehamites, in their hurry, had gone to work and had built upon a promise. The Marquis, when, after the receipt of Mr. Fenwick's letter, his (Marquis) first rage was over, went at once to the chambers of Messrs. Boothby, and was forced to explain all the circumstances of the case to the senior partner before he (Boothby) could show the clergyman's wicked epistle. CHAPTER LVIII.

EDITH BROWNLOW``S DREAM.

``My dear, sit down; I want to speak to you. Do you know I should like to see you--married.'' (Edith/Edith Brownlow/EDITH BROWNLOW)
This speech was made at Dunripple to Edith Brownlow by her (George) uncle, Sir Gregory, one morning in July, as she (George) was attending him (Gregory) with his (Gregory) breakfast. His (Gregory) breakfast consisted always of a cup of chocolate, made after a peculiar fashion, and Edith was in the habit of standing by the old man's bedside while he (man) took it. She (Edith) would never sit down, because she (Edith) knew that were she (Edith) to do so she (Edith) would be pretty nearly hidden out of sight in the old arm-chair that stood at the bed-head; but now she (Edith) was specially invited to do so, and that in a manner which almost made her (Edith) think that it would be well that she (Edith) should hide herself for a space. But she (Edith) did not sit down. There was the empty cup to be taken from Sir Gregory's hands, and, after the first moment of surprise, Edith was not quite sure that it would be good that she (Edith) should hide herself. She (Edith) took the cup and put it on the table, and then returned, without making any reply.
``I should like very much to see you married, my dear,'' (Gregory/Gregory Marrable/GREGORY MARRABLE)
said Sir Gregory, in the mildest of voices.

``Do you want to get rid of me, uncle?'' (unknown)

``No, my dear; that is just what I don't want. Of course you'll marry somebody.'' (unknown)

``I don't see any of course, Uncle Gregory.'' (unknown)

``But why shouldn't you? I suppose you have thought about it.'' (unknown)

``Only in a general way, Uncle Gregory.'' (Gregory/Gregory Marrable/GREGORY MARRABLE)

Sir Gregory Marrable was not a wise man. His (Marrable) folly was of an order very different from that of Lord Trowbridge,--very much less likely to do harm to himself or others, much more innocent, and, folly though it was, a great deal more compatible with certain intellectual gifts. Lord Trowbridge, not to put too fine a point upon it, was a fool all round. He (Trowbridge) was much too great a fool to have an idea of his (Trowbridge) own folly. Now Sir Gregory distrusted himself in everything, conceived himself to be a poor creature, would submit himself to a child on any question of literature, and had no opinion of his (Gregory) own on any matter outside his (Gregory) own property,--and even as to that his (Gregory) opinion was no more than lukewarm. Yet he (Gregory) read a great deal, had much information stored away somewhere in his (Gregory) memory, and had learned at any rate to know how small a fly he (Gregory) was himself on the wheel of the world. But, alas, when he (Gregory) did meddle with anything he (Gregory) was apt to make a mess of it. There had been some conversation between him (Gregory) and his (Gregory) sister-in-law, Edith's mother, about Walter Marrable; some also between him (Marrable) and his (Marrable) son, and between him (Marrable) and Miss Marrable, his (Marrable) cousin. But as yet no one had spoken to Edith, and as Captain Marrable himself had not spoken, it would have been as well, perhaps, if Sir Gregory had held his (Gregory) tongue. After Edith's last answer the old man was silent for awhile, and then he (Gregory) returned to the subject with a downright question,--

``How did you like Walter when he (Walter) was here?'' (he)

``Captain Marrable?'' (unknown)

``Yes,--Captain Marrable.'' (unknown)

``I liked him (Marrable) well enough,--in a way, Uncle Gregory.'' (unknown)

``Nothing would please me so much, Edith, as that you should become his (Gregory) wife. You know that Dunripple will belong to him (Gregory) some day.'' (unknown)

``If Gregory does not marry.'' (Edith/Edith Brownlow/EDITH BROWNLOW)
Edith had hardly known whether to say this or to leave it unsaid. She (Edith) was well aware that her (Edith) cousin Gregory would never marry,--that he (Gregory) was a confirmed invalid, a man already worn out, old before his (Gregory) time, and with one foot in the grave. But had she (Edith) not said it, she (Edith) would have seemed to herself to have put him (Gregory) aside as a person altogether out of the way.

``Gregory will never marry. Of course while he (Gregory) lives Dunripple will be his (Gregory); but if Walter were to marry he (Walter) would make arrangements. I dare say you can't understand all about that, my dear; but it would be a very good thing. I should be so happy if I thought that you were to live at Dunripple always.'' (Edith/Edith Brownlow/EDITH BROWNLOW)

Edith kissed him (Gregory) and escaped without giving any other answer. Ten days after that Walter Marrable was to be again at Dunripple,--only for a few days; but still in a few days the thing might be settled. Edith had heard something of Mary Lowther, but not much. There had been some idea of a match between Walter and his (Walter) cousin Mary, but the idea had been blown away. So much Edith had heard. To herself Walter Marrable had been very friendly, and, in truth, she (Edith) had liked him (Marrable) much. They two were not cousins, but they were so connected, and had for some weeks been so thrown together, as to be almost as good as cousins. His (Marrable) presence at Dunripple had been very pleasant to her (Edith), but she (Edith) had never thought of him (Marrable) as a lover. And she (Edith) had an idea of her (Edith) own, that girls ought not to think of men as lovers without a good deal of provocation.

Sir Gregory spoke to Mrs. Brownlow on the same subject, and as he (Gregory) told her (Brownlow) what had taken place between him (Gregory) and Edith, she (Edith) felt herself compelled to speak to her (Edith) daughter.

``If it should take place, my dear, it would be very well; but I would rather your uncle had not mentioned it.'' (unknown)

``It won't do any harm, mamma. I mean, that I shan't break my heart.'' (unknown)

``I believe him (uncle) to be a very excellent young man,--not at all like his (uncle) father, who has been as bad as he (uncle) can be.'' (unknown)

``Wasn't he (uncle) in love with Mary Lowther last winter?'' (unknown)

``I don't know, my dear. I never believe stories of this kind. When I hear that a young man is going to be married to a young lady, then I believe that they are in love with each other.'' (unknown)

``It is to be hoped so then, mamma?'' (unknown)

``But I never believe any thing before. And I think you may take it for granted that there is nothing in that.'' (unknown)

``It would be nothing to me, mamma.'' (unknown)

``It might be something. But I will say nothing more about it. You've so much good sense that I am quite sure you won't get into trouble. I wish Sir Gregory had not spoken to you; but as he (Gregory) has, it may be as well that you should know that the family arrangement would be very agreeable to your uncle and to cousin Gregory. The title and the property must go to Captain Marrable at last, and Sir Gregory would make immediate sacrifices for you, which perhaps he (Gregory) would not make for him (Gregory).'' (Edith/Edith Brownlow/EDITH BROWNLOW)

Edith understood all about it very clearly, and would have understood all about it with half the words. She (Edith) would have little or no fortune of her (Edith) own, and in money her (Edith) uncle would have very little to give to her (Edith). Indeed, there was no reason why he (uncle) should give her (Edith) anything. She (Edith) was not connected with any of the Marrables by blood, though chance had caused her (Edith) to live at Dunripple almost all her (Edith) life. She (Edith) had become half a Marrable already, and it might be very well that she (Edith) should become a Marrable altogether. Walter was a remarkably handsome man, would be a baronet, and would have an estate, and might, perhaps, have the enjoyment of the estate by marrying her (Edith) earlier than he (Walter) would were he (Walter) to marry any one else. Edith Brownlow understood it all with sufficient clearness. But then she (Brownlow) understood also that young women shouldn't give away their hearts before they are asked for them; and she (Brownlow) was quite sure that Walter Marrable had made no sign of asking for hers. Nevertheless, within her (Brownlow) own bosom she (Brownlow) did become a little anxious about Mary Lowther, and she (Lowther) wished that she (Lowther) knew that story.

On the fourth of August Walter Marrable reached Dunripple, and found the house given up almost entirely to the doctor. Both his (doctor) uncle and his (doctor) cousin were very ill. When he (doctor) was able to obtain from the doctor information on which he (doctor) could rely, he (doctor) learned that Mr. Marrable was in real danger, but that Sir Gregory's ailment was no more than his (Marrable) usual infirmity heightened by anxiety on behalf of his (Marrable) son.

``Your uncle may live for the next ten years,'' (the doctor)
said the doctor;
``but I do not know what to say about Mr. Marrable.'' (the doctor)
All this time the care and time of the two ladies were divided between the invalids. Mrs. Brownlow tended her (Brownlow) nephew, and Edith, as usual, waited upon Sir Gregory. In such circumstances it was not extraordinary that Edith Brownlow and Walter Marrable should be thrown much together,--especially as it was the desire of all concerned with them that they should become man and wife. Poor Edith was subject to a feeling that everybody knew that she (Edith) was expected to fall in love with the man. She (Edith) thought it probable, too, that the man himself had been instructed to fall in love with her (Edith). This no doubt created a great difficulty for her (Edith), a difficulty which she (Edith) felt to be heavy and inconvenient;--but it was lessened by the present condition of the household. When there is illness in a house, the feminine genius and spirit predominates the male. If the illness be so severe as to cause a sense of danger, this is so strongly the case that the natural position of the two is changed. Edith, quite unconscious of the reason, was much less afraid of her (Edith) proposed lover than she (Edith) would have been had there been no going about on tiptoe, no questions asked with bated breath, no great need for womanly aid.

Walter had been there four days, and was sitting with Edith one evening out on the lawn among the rhododendrons. When he (Walter) had found what was the condition of the household, he (Walter) had offered to go back at once to his (Walter) regiment at Birmingham. But Sir Gregory would not hear of it. Sir Gregory hated the regiment, and had got an idea in his (Gregory) head that his (Gregory) nephew ought not to be there at all. He (Gregory) was too weak and diffident to do it himself; but if any one would have arranged it for him (Gregory), he (Gregory) would have been glad to fix an income for Walter Marrable on condition that Walter should live at home, and look after the property, and be unto him (Walter) as a son. But nothing had been fixed, nothing had been said, and on the day but one following, the captain was to return to Birmingham. Mrs. Brownlow was with her (Brownlow) nephew, and Walter was sitting with Edith among the rhododendrons, the two having come out of the house together after such a dinner as is served in a house of invalids. She (Brownlow) had quite determined that she (Brownlow) would not fall in love with him (Marrable) till he (Marrable) did. CHAPTER LIX.

NEWS FROM DUNRIPPLE.

At the end of the first week in August news reached the vicarage at Bullhampton that was not indeed very important to the family of Mr. Fenwick, but which still seemed to have an immediate effect on their lives and comfort. The Vicar for some days past had been, as regarded himself, in a high good humour, in consequence of a communication which he (Vicar) had received from Lord St. George. Further mention of this communication must be made, but it may be deferred to the next chapter, as other matters, more momentous, require our immediate attention. Mr. Gilmore had pleaded very hard that a day might be fixed, and had almost succeeded. Mary Lowther, driven into a corner, had been able to give no reason why she (Lowther) should not fix a day, other than this,--that Mr. Gilmore had promised her (Lowther) that she (Lowther) should not be hurried.

``What do you mean?'' (Mrs. Fenwick)
Mrs. Fenwick had said, angrily.
``You speak of the man who is to be your husband as though your greatest happiness in life were to keep away from him (husband).'' (Mary/Mary Lowther/MARY LOWTHER)
Mary Lowther had not dared to answer that such would be her (Lowther) greatest happiness. Then news had reached the vicarage of the illness of Gregory Marrable, and of Walter Marrable's presence at Dunripple. This had come of course from Aunt Sarah, at Loring; but it had come in such a manner as to seem to justify, for a time, Mary's silence in reference to that question of naming the day. The Marrables of Dunripple were not nearly related to her (Mary). She (Mary) had no personal remembrance of either Sir Gregory or his (Gregory) son. But there was an importance attached to the tidings, which, if analysed, would have been found to attach itself to Captain Marrable, rather than to the two men who were ill; and this was tacitly allowed to have an influence. Aunt Sarah had expressed her (Sarah) belief that Gregory Marrable was dying; and had gone on to say,--trusting to the known fact that Mary had engaged herself to Mr. Gilmore, and to the fact, as believed to be a fact, that Walter was engaged to Edith Brownlow,--had gone on to say that Captain Marrable would probably remain at Dunripple, and would take immediate charge of the estate.
``I think there is no doubt,'' (Sarah/Aunt Sarah)
said Aunt Sarah,
``that Captain Marrable and Edith Brownlow will be married.'' (Sarah/Aunt Sarah)
Mary was engaged to Mr. Gilmore, and why should not Aunt Sarah tell her (Sarah) news?

The Squire, who had become elated and happy at the period of the rubies, had, in three days, again fallen away into a state of angry gloom, rather than of melancholy. He (Squire) said very little just now either to Fenwick or to Mrs. Fenwick about his (Fenwick) marriage; and, indeed, he (Fenwick) did not say very much to Mary herself. Men were already at work about the gardens at the Privets, and he (Fenwick) would report to her (Mary) what was done, and would tell her (Mary) that the masons and painters would begin in a few days. Now and again he (Fenwick) would ask for her (Mary) company up to the place; and she (Mary) had been there twice at his (Fenwick) instance since the day on which she (Mary) had gone after him (Fenwick) of her (Mary) own accord, and had fetched him (Fenwick) down to look at the jewels. But there was little or no sympathy between them. Mary could not bring herself to care about the house or the gardens, though she (Mary) told herself again and again that there was she (Mary) to live for the remainder of her (Mary) life.

Two letters she (Mary) received from her (Mary) aunt at Loring within an interval of three days, and these letters were both filled with details as to the illness of Sir Gregory and his (Gregory) son, at Dunripple. Walter Marrable sent accounts to his (Marrable) uncle, the parson, and Mrs. Brownlow sent accounts to Miss Marrable herself. And then, on the day following the receipt of the last of these two letters, there came one from Walter Marrable himself, addressed to Mary Lowther. Gregory Marrable was dead, and the letter announcing the death of the baronet's only son was as follows:--

Dunripple, August 12, 1868.

MY DEAR MARY,

I hardly know whether you will have expected that the news which I have to tell you should reach you direct from me; but I think, upon the whole, that it is better that I should write. My cousin, Gregory Marrable, Sir Gregory's only son, died this morning. I do not doubt but that you know that he (Marrable) has been long ill. He (Marrable) has come to the end of all his (Marrable) troubles, and the old baronet is now childless. He (Marrable) also has been, and is still, unwell, though I do not know that he (Marrable) is much worse than usual. He (Marrable) has been an invalid for years and years. Of course he (Marrable) feels his (Marrable) son's death acutely; for he (Marrable) is a father who has ever been good to his (Marrable) son. But it always seems to me that old people become so used to death, that they do not think of it as do we who are younger. I have seen him (Marrable) twice to-day since the news was told to him (Marrable), and though he (Marrable) spoke of his (Marrable) son with infinite sorrow, he (Marrable) was able to talk of other things.

I write to you myself, especially, instead of getting one of the ladies here to do so, because I think it proper to tell you how things stand with myself. Everything is changed with me since you and I parted because it was necessary that I should seek my fortune in India. You already know that I have abandoned that idea; and I now find that I shall leave the army altogether. My uncle has wished it since I first came here, and he (uncle) now proposes that I shall live here permanently. Of course the meaning is that I should assume the position of his (uncle) heir. My father, with whom I personally will have no dealing in the matter, stands between us. But I do suppose that the family affairs will be so arranged that I may feel secure that I shall not be turned altogether adrift upon the world.

Dear Mary,--I do not know how to tell you, that as regards my future everything now depends on you. They have told me that you have accepted an offer from Mr. Gilmore. I know no more than this,--that they have told me so. If you will tell me also that you mean to be his (Gilmore) wife, I will say no more. But until you tell me so, I will not believe it. I do not think that you can ever love him (Gilmore) as you certainly once loved me;--and when I think of it, how short a time ago that was! I know that I have no right to complain. Our separation was my doing as much as yours. But I will settle nothing as to my future life till I hear from yourself whether or no you will come back to me.

I shall remain here till after the funeral, which will take place on Friday. On Monday I shall go back to Birmingham. This is Sunday, and I shall expect to hear from you before the week is over. If you bid me, I will be with you early next week. If you tell me that my coming will be useless,--why, then, I shall care very little what happens.

Yours, with all the love of my heart,

WALTER MARRABLE.

Luckily for Mary she (Mary) was alone when she (Mary) read the letter. Her (Mary) first idea on reading it was to think of the words which she (Mary) had used when she (Mary) had most ungraciously consented to become the wife of Harry Gilmore.

CHAPTER LX.

LORD ST. GEORGE IS VERY CUNNING.

Lord St. George began to throw his (George) oil upon the waters in reference to that unfortunate chapel at Bullhampton a day or two after his (George) interview with his (George) father in the lawyer's chambers. His (George) father had found himself compelled to yield; had been driven, as it were, by the Fates, to accord to his (George) son permission to do as his (George) son should think best. There came to be so serious a trouble in consequence of that terrible mistake of Packer's, that the poor old Marquis was unable to defend himself from the necessity of yielding. On that day, before he (Marquis) left his (Marquis) son at Westminster, when their roads lay into the different council-chambers of the state, he (Marquis) had prayed hard that the oil might not be very oily. I'm inclined to think there must be a mistake.'' (Marquis/Trowbridge/Marquis of Trowbridge)

The unfortunate Marquis groaned deeply as he (Marquis) walked away to the august chamber of the Lords.

These and such like are the troubles that sit heavy on a man's heart. If search for bread, and meat, and raiment, be set aside, then, beyond that, our happiness or misery here depends chiefly on success or failure in small things. Though a man when he (man) turns into bed may be sure that he (man) has unlimited thousands at his (man) command, though all society be open to him (man), though he (man) know himself to be esteemed handsome, clever, and fashionable, even though his (man) digestion be good, and he (man) have no doctor to deny him (man) tobacco, champagne, or made dishes, still, if he (man) be conscious of failure there where he (man) has striven to succeed, even though it be in the humbling of an already humble adversary, he (adversary) will stretch, and roll, and pine,--a wretched being. How happy is he (adversary) who can get his (adversary) fretting done for him (adversary) by deputy!

Lord St. George wrote to the parson a few days after his (George) interview with his (George) father. He (George) and Lord Trowbridge occupied the same house in London, and always met at breakfast; but nothing further was said between them during the remaining days in town upon the subject. MY DEAR SIR,---LRB-Lord St. George had said,-RRB---My father has put into my hands your letter about the dissenting chapel at Bullhampton. It seems to me, that he (George) has made a mistake, and that you are very angry. Couldn't we arrange this little matter without fighting? There is not a landlord in England more desirous of doing good to his (George) tenants than my father; and I am quite willing to believe that there is not an incumbent in England more desirous of doing good to his (George) parishioners than you. I leave London for Wiltshire on Saturday the 11th. If you will meet me I will drive over to Bullhampton on Monday the 13th.

Yours truly,

ST. GEORGE.

No doubt you'll agree with me in thinking that internecine fighting in a parish between the landlord and the clergyman cannot be for the good of the people.

Thus it was that Lord St. George began to throw his (George) oil upon the waters.

It may be a doubt whether it should be ascribed to Mr. Fenwick as a weakness or a strength that, though he (Fenwick) was very susceptible of anger, and though he (Fenwick) could maintain his (Fenwick) anger at glowing heat as long as fighting continued, it would all evaporate and leave him (Fenwick) harmless as a dove at the first glimpse of an olive-branch. He (Fenwick) knew this so well of himself, that it would sometimes be a regret to him (Fenwick) in the culmination of his (Fenwick) wrath that he (Fenwick) would not be able to maintain it till the hour of his (Fenwick) revenge should come. The two men went out and walked round the chapel, and, finding it open, walked into it. Of course there were remarks made by both of them. It was acknowledged that it was ugly, misplaced, uncomfortable, detestable to the eye, and ear, and general feeling,--except in so far as it might suit the wants of people who were not sufficiently educated to enjoy the higher tone, and more elaborate language of the Church of England services. It was thus that they spoke to each other, quite in an aesthetic manner.

Lord St. George had said as he (George) entered the chapel, that it must come down as a matter of course; and the Vicar had suggested that there need be no hurry.

CHAPTER LXI.

MARY LOWTHER``S TREACHERY.

While the Vicar was listening to the eloquence of Mr. Puddleham in the chapel, and was being cozened out of his (Vicar) just indignation by Lord St. George, a terrible scene was going on in the drawing-room of the vicarage. CHAPTER LXII.

UP AT THE PRIVETS.

The whole of the next day was passed in wretchedness by the party at the vicarage. The Vicar, as he (Vicar) greeted Miss Lowther in the morning, had not meant to be severe, having been specially cautioned against severity by his (Vicar) wife; but he (Vicar) had been unable not to be silent and stern. Between these two there had grown up now during a period of many years, that undemonstrative, unexpressed, almost unconscious affection which, with men, will often make the greatest charm of their lives, but which is held by women to be quite unsatisfactory and almost nugatory. It may be doubted whether either of them had ever told the other of his (Fenwick) regard.

``Yours always,'' (unknown)
in writing, was the warmest term that was ever used. Neither ever dreamed of suggesting that the absence of the other would be a cause of grief or even of discomfort. They would bicker with each other, and not unfrequently abuse each other. Chance threw them much together, but they never did anything to assist chance. Women, who love each other as well, will always be expressing their love, always making plans to be together, always doing little things each for the gratification of the other, constantly making presents backwards and forwards. These two men had never given any thing, one to the other, beyond a worn-out walking-stick, or a cigar. They were rough to each other, caustic, and almost ill-mannered. But they thoroughly trusted each other; and the happiness, prosperity, and, above all, the honour of the one were, to the other, matters of keenest moment. ``It was the case. I don't say who was wrong, but the punishment has come upon me only. Look here, Frank; I will not take this message from you. I will not even give her (Mary) up yet. The Vicar stood for awhile to think, and then slowly returned to the vicarage by himself. What Gilmore had said to him (Gilmore) was true enough. He (Gilmore) had, indeed, never been tried after that fashion. It did seem to him (Gilmore) that his (Gilmore) friend was in fact broken-hearted. Harry Gilmore might live on,--as is the way with men and women who are broken-hearted;--but life for the present, life for some years to come, could be to him (Gilmore) only a burden.

CHAPTER LXIII.

THE MILLER TELLS HIS (Gilmore) TROUBLES.

``If father won't speak to me, I'd better go,'' (she)

Our friend the Vicar never before felt himself so utterly unable to administer comfort in affliction. There was nothing on which he (Vicar) could take hold. He (Vicar) could tell the man, no doubt, that beyond all this there might be everlasting joy, not only for him (Vicar), but for him (Vicar) and the girl together;--joy which would be sullied by no touch of disgrace. That which he (Pagan) saw and knew and felt, he (Pagan) would believe; but he (Pagan) would believe nothing else. As he (Pagan) would not believe when things went well with him (Pagan), and when the comfort of hope for the future was not imperatively needed for his (Pagan) daily solace,--so would he (Pagan) not believe now, when his (Pagan) need for such comfort was so pressing.

The upshot of it all was, that the miller thought that he (miller) would take his (miller) own daughter into Salisbury, and was desirous of breaking the matter in this way to the friend of his (friend) family. CHAPTER LXIV.

IF I WERE YOUR SISTER!

Mr. Gilmore in his (Gilmore) last words to his (Gilmore) friend Fenwick, declared that he (Fenwick) would not accept the message which the Vicar delivered to him (Vicar) as the sufficient expression of Mary's decision. She (Mary) had told him (Squire) in so many words that she (Mary) intended to marry him (Squire) without loving him (Squire), and on these terms he (Squire) had accepted her (Mary). He (man) had set his (man) heart sturdily on marrying this girl, and marry her (girl) he (man) would, if, after any fashion, such marriage should come within his (man) power. ``I think I can answer for myself,'' (Mr. Gilmore/Gilmore/MR. GILMORE)
Gilmore had once replied, and his (Gilmore) friend had thoroughly believed in him (Gilmore). Trusting to the assurance he (Gilmore) had persevered; he (Gilmore) had persevered even when his (Gilmore) trust in that assurance had been weakened by the girl's hardness. She (girl) was pledged to be his (Gilmore) wife; and, that being so, he (Gilmore) could reform his (Gilmore) gardens and decorate his (Gilmore) house, and employ himself about his (Gilmore) place with some amount of satisfaction. Of course they all knew why it was that the conduct of the Squire was so like the conduct of a madman.

He (madman) sent down a note to Mary Lowther that evening.

I have seen Fenwick, and of course I must see you. Will you name an hour for to-morrow morning?

The Vicarage, Friday.

DEAREST, DEAREST WALTER,

Do come to me,--as soon as you can, and I will never send you away again. I go to Loring to-morrow, and, of course, you must come there. I cannot write it all; but I will tell you everything when we meet. I am very sorry for your cousin Gregory, because he (Gregory) was so good.

Always your own,

MARY.

But do not think that I want to hurry you. I have said come at once; but I do not mean that so as to interfere with you. You must have so many things to do; and if I get one line from you to say that you will come, I can be ever so patient. I have not been happy once since we parted. It is easy for people to say that they will conquer their feelings, but it has seemed to me to be quite impossible to do it. I shall never try again.

CHAPTER LXVI.

AT THE MILL.

The presence of Carry Brattle was required in Salisbury for the trial of John Burrows and Lawrence Acorn on Wednesday the 22nd of August. Our Vicar, who had learned that the judges would come into the city only late on the previous evening, and that the day following their entrance would doubtless be so fully occupied with other matters as to render it very improbable that the affair of the murder would then come up, had endeavoured to get permission to postpone Carry's journey; but the little men in authority are always stern on such points, and witnesses are usually treated as persons who are not entitled to have any views as to their own personal comfort or welfare. Lawyers, who are paid for their presence, may plead other engagements, and their pleas will be considered; and if a witness be a lord, it may perhaps be thought very hard that he (witness) should be dragged away from his (witness) amusements. But the ordinary commonplace witness must simply listen and obey--at his (witness) peril. It was thus decided that Carry must be in Salisbury on the Wednesday, and remain there, hanging about the Court, till her (their) services should be wanted. Fenwick, who had been in Salisbury, had seen that accommodation should be provided for her (their) and for the miller at the house of Mrs. Stiggs.

The miller had decided upon going with his (miller) daughter. The Vicar did not go down to the mill again; but Mrs. Fenwick had seen Brattle, and had learned that such was to be the case. CHAPTER LXVII.

SIR GREGORY MARRABLE HAS A HEADACHE.

Mary Lowther, in her (Lowther) letter to her (Lowther) aunt, had in one line told the story of her (Lowther) rupture with Mr. Gilmore. This line had formed a postscript, and the writer had hesitated much before she (Lowther) added it. She (Lowther) had not intended to write to her (Lowther) aunt on this subject; but she (Lowther) had remembered at the last moment how much easier it would be to tell the remainder of her (Lowther) story on her (Lowther) arrival at Loring, if so much had already been told beforehand. Therefore it was that she (Lowther) had added these words.

``Everything has been broken off between me and Mr. Gilmore--for ever.'' (Miss Marrable/Marrable/MISS MARRABLE)

This was a terrible blow upon poor Miss Marrable, who, up to the moment of her (Marrable) receiving that letter, thought that her (Marrable) niece was disposed of in the manner that had seemed most desirable to all her (Marrable) friends. Aunt Sarah loved her (Sarah) niece dearly, and by no means looked forward to improved happiness in her (Sarah) own old age when she (Sarah) should be left alone in the house at Uphill; but she (Sarah) entertained the view about young women which is usual with old women who have young women under their charge, and she (Sarah) thought it much best that this special young woman should get herself married. The old women are right in their views on this matter; and the young women, who on this point are not often refractory, are right also. Miss Marrable, who entertained a very strong opinion on the subject above-mentioned, was very unhappy when she (Marrable) was thus abruptly told by her (Marrable) own peculiar young woman that this second engagement had been broken off and sent to the winds. It had become a theory on the part of Mary's friends that the Gilmore match was the proper thing for her (Mary). At last, after many difficulties, the Gilmore match had been arranged. The anxiety as to Mary's future life was at an end, and the theory of the elders concerned with her (Mary) welfare was to be carried out. Then there came a short note, proclaiming her (Mary) return home, and simply telling as a fact almost indifferent,--in a single line,--that all the trouble hitherto taken as to her (Mary) own disposition had entirely been thrown away.

``Everything has been broken off between me and Mr. Gilmore.'' (unknown)
It was a cruel and a heartrending postscript!

Poor Miss Marrable knew very well that she (Marrable) was armed with no parental authority. She (Marrable) could hold her (Marrable) theory, and could advise; but she (Marrable) could do no more. She (Marrable) could not even scold. Mary was provided for with the Squire, who was in immediate possession; and Walter with his (Walter) bride would become as it were the eldest son of Dunripple. It was all as comfortable as could be till there came this unfortunate postscript.

The letter reached her (bride) on Friday, and on Saturday Mary arrived. Miss Marrable determined that she (Marrable) would not complain. As regarded her (Marrable) own comfort it was doubtless all for the best. But old women are never selfish in regard to the marriage of young women. That the young women belonging to them should be settled,--and thus got rid of,--is no doubt the great desire; but, whether the old woman be herself married or a spinster, the desire is founded on an adamantine confidence that marriage is the most proper and the happiest thing for the young woman. The belief is so thorough that the woman would cease to be a woman, would already have become a brute, who would desire to keep any girl belonging to her (girl) out of matrimony for the sake of companionship to herself. But no woman does so desire in regard to those who are dear and near to her (woman). A dependant, distant in blood, or a paid assistant, may find here and there a want of the true feminine sympathy; but in regard to a daughter, or one held as a daughter, it is never wanting.

``As the pelican loveth her (I) young do I love thee; and therefore will I give thee away in marriage to some one strong enough to hold thee, even though my heartstrings be torn asunder by the parting.'' (the mother)
Such is always the heart's declaration of the mother respecting her (mother) daughter. The match-making of mothers is the natural result of mother's love; for the ambition of one woman for another is never other than this,--that the one loved by her (woman) shall be given to a man to be loved more worthily. Poor Aunt Sarah, considering of these things during those two lonely days, came to the conclusion that if ever Mary were to be so loved again that she (Mary) might be given away, a long time might first elapse; and then she (Mary) was aware that such gifts given late lose much of their value, and have to be given cheaply.

Mary herself, as she (Mary) was driven slowly up the hill to her (Mary) aunt's door, did not share her (Mary) aunt's melancholy. To be returned as a bad shilling, which has been presented over the counter and found to be bad, must be very disagreeable to a young woman's feelings. That was not the case with Mary Lowther. She (Lowther) had, no doubt, a great sorrow at heart. She (Lowther) had created a shipwreck which she (Lowther) did regret most bitterly. But the sorrow and the regret were not humiliating, as they would have been had they been caused by failure on her (Lowther) own part. This was all very pleasant for Captain Marrable. CHAPTER LXVIII.

THE SQUIRE IS VERY OBSTINATE.

Mr. Gilmore left his (Gilmore) own home on a Thursday afternoon, and on the Monday when the Vicar again visited the Privets nothing had been heard of him (Vicar). Money had been left with the bailiff for the Saturday wages of the men working about the place, but no provision for anything had been made beyond that. The Sunday had been wet from morning to night, and nothing could possibly be more disconsolate than the aspect of things round the house, or more disreputable if they were to be left in their present condition. The barrows, and the planks, and the pickaxes had been taken away, which things, though they are not in themselves beautiful, are safeguards against the ill-effects of ugliness, as they inform the eyes why it is that such disorder lies around. There was the disorder at the Privets now without any such instruction to the eye. Pits were full of muddy water, and half-formed paths had become the beds of stagnant pools. The Vicar then went into the house, and though there was still a workman and a boy who were listlessly pulling about some rolls of paper, there were ample signs that misfortune had come and that neglect was the consequence.

``And all this,'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)
said Fenwick to himself,
``because the man cannot get the idea of a certain woman out of his (man) head!'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)
Then he (Fenwick) thought of himself and his (Fenwick) own character, and asked himself whether, in any position of life, he (Fenwick) could have been thus overruled to misery by circumstances altogether outside himself. Misfortunes might come which would be very heavy; his (Fenwick) wife or children might die; or he (Fenwick) might become a pauper; or subject to some crushing disease. But Gilmore's trouble had not fallen upon him (Gilmore) from the hands of Providence. He (Gilmore) had set his (Gilmore) heart upon the gaining of a thing, and was now absolutely broken-hearted because he (Gilmore) could not have it. And the thing was a woman. Fenwick admitted to himself that the thing itself was the most worthy for which a man can struggle; but would not admit that even in his (man) search for that a man should allow his (man) heart to give way, or his (man) strength to be broken down.

He (man) went up to the house again on the Wednesday, and again on the Thursday,--but nothing had been heard from the Squire. The bailiff was very unhappy. Even though there might come a cheque on the Saturday morning, which both Fenwick and the bailiff thought to be probable, still there would be grave difficulties.

``Here'll be the first of September on us afore we know where we are,'' (the bailiff)
said the bailiff,
``and is we to go on with the horses?'' (the bailiff)

For the Squire was of all men the most regular, and began to get his (Squire) horses into condition on the first of September as regularly as he (Squire) began to shoot partridges. He (Vicar) arranged the matter with his (Vicar) wife and with his (Vicar) friend's curate, and on the Friday he (Vicar) started.

He (Vicar) drove himself into Salisbury instead of to the Bullhampton Road station in order that he (Vicar) might travel by the express train. That at least was the reason which he (Vicar) gave to himself and to his (Vicar) wife. But there was present to his (Vicar) mind the idea that he (Vicar) might look into the court and see how the trial was going on. Poor Carry Brattle would have a bad time of it beneath a lawyer's claws. Such a one as Carry, of the evil of whose past life there was no doubt, and who would appear as a witness against a man whom she (wife) had once been engaged to marry, would certainly meet with no mercy from a cross-examining barrister. The broad landmarks between the respectable and the disreputable may guide the tone of a lawyer somewhat, when he (lawyer) has a witness in his (lawyer) power; but the finer lines which separate that which is at the moment good and true from that which is false and bad cannot be discerned amidst the turmoil of a trial, unless the eyes, and the ears, and the inner touch of him (lawyer) who has the handling of the victim be of a quality more than ordinarily high.

The Vicar drove himself over to Salisbury and had an hour there for strolling into the court. He (Vicar) had heard on the previous day that the case would be brought on the first thing on the Friday, and it was half-past eleven when he (Vicar) made his (Vicar) way in through the crowd. The train by which he (Vicar) was to be taken on to London did not start till half-past twelve. At that moment the court was occupied in deciding whether a certain tradesman, living at Devizes, should or should not be on the jury. The man himself objected that, being a butcher, he (butcher) was, by reason of the second nature acquired in his (butcher) business, too cruel, and bloody-minded to be entrusted with an affair of life and death. To a proposition in itself so reasonable no direct answer was made; but it was argued with great power on behalf of the crown, which seemed to think at the time that the whole case depended on getting this one particular man into the jury box, that the recalcitrant juryman was not in truth a butcher, that he (butcher) was only a dealer in meat, and that though the stain of the blood descended the cruelty did not. Fenwick remained there till he (Fenwick) heard the case given against the pseudo-butcher, and then retired from the court. He (Fenwick) had, however, just seen Carry Brattle and her (dealer) father seated side by side on a bench in a little outside room appropriated to the witnesses, and there had been a constable there seeming to stand on guard over them. This he (Gilmore) added after a pause, during which the Vicar had been thinking what new arguments he (Vicar) could bring up to urge his (Vicar) friend's return.

That to which he (Gilmore) was most wedded was a plan for meeting Walter Marrable and cudgelling him (Marrable) pretty well to death. Fenwick pointed out three or four objections to this. In the first place, Marrable had committed no offence whatever against Gilmore. And then, in all probability, Marrable might be as good at cudgelling as the Squire himself. And thirdly, when the cudgelling was over, the man who began the row would certainly be put into prison, and in atonement for that would receive no public sympathy.

``You can't throw yourself on the public pity as a woman might,'' (the Vicar)
said the Vicar.

said the Squire, who was not often driven to make his (Squire) language forcible after that fashion.

They were together pretty nearly the whole day. ``As for doing them any good, I never did them any good,'' (he)
he (Gilmore) said, as he (Gilmore) parted from the Vicar for the night.
``If they can't live on the land without my being at home, I am sure they won't if I stay there.'' (unknown)

CHAPTER LXIX.

THE TRIAL.

Exactly at that hour she (daughter) and her (daughter) father were at the place indicated, already having visited their lodgings at Mrs. Stiggs'. (The witness)

The amount of the burly barrister's achievement was simply this,--that for the moment a sort of sympathy was excited on behalf of the prisoners by the disapprobation which was aroused against the wicked man who hadn't cared twopence. Sympathy, like electricity, will run so quick that no man may stop it. If sympathy might be made to run through the jury-box there might perchance be a man or two there weak enough to entertain it to the prejudice of his (man) duty on that day. The hopes of the burly barrister in this matter did not go further than that.

He (Trumbull) had taken them into the Vicar's garden; and then he (Trumbull) gave an account of the meeting there with Mr. Fenwick. After that he (Fenwick) had known and seen nothing of the men. When he (Fenwick) testified so far he (Fenwick) was handed over to the burly barrister.

The burly barrister tried all he (barrister) knew, but he (barrister) could make nothing of this witness. A question was asked him (barrister), the true answer to which would have implied that his (barrister) sister's life had been disreputable. His (Sam) sister had told them all she (sister) knew about the murder, and now he (Sam) had told them all he (Sam) knew. He (Sam) protested that he (Sam) was willing to answer any questions they might ask him (Sam) about himself; but about his (Sam) sister he (Sam) would answer none. When told that the information desired might be got in a more injurious way from other sources, he (Sam) became rather impudent.

``Then you may go to--other sources,'' (he)
he (Sam) said.

He (Sam) was threatened with all manner of pains and penalties; but he (Sam) made nothing of these threats, and was at last allowed to leave the box. When his (Sam) evidence was completed the trial was adjourned for another day.

Though it was then late in the afternoon the three Brattles returned home that night. There was a train which took them to the Bullhampton Road station, and from thence they walked to the mill. It was a weary journey both for the poor girl and for the old man; but anything was better than delay for another night in Trotter's Buildings. And then the miller was unwilling to be absent from his (miller) mill one hour longer than was necessary. When there came to be a question whether he (miller) could walk, he (miller) laughed the difficulty to scorn in his (miller) quiet way.

``Why shouldn't I walk it? Ain't I got to `arn my bread every day?'' (Mrs. Brattle/George/George Brattle)

It was ten o'clock when they reached the mill, and Mrs. Brattle, not expecting them at that hour, was in bed. But Fanny was up, and did what she (Fanny) could to comfort them. But no one could ever comfort old Brattle. He (miller) was not susceptible to soft influences. It may almost be said that he (miller) condemned himself because he (miller) gave way to the daily luxury of a pipe. He (miller) believed in plenty of food, because food for the workman is as coals to the steam-engine, as oats to the horse,--the raw material out of which the motive power of labour must be made. Beyond eating and working a man had little to do, but just to wait till he (man) died. That was his (man) theory of life in these his (man) latter days; and yet he (man) was a man with keen feelings and a loving heart.

But Carry was comforted when her (man) sister's arms were around her (man).

``They asked me if I was bad,'' (she)
she (man) said,
``and I thought I should a' died, and I never answered them a word,--and at last they let me go.'' (she)
When Fanny inquired whether their father had been kind to her (Fanny), she (Fanny) declared that he (father) had been
``main kind.'' (he)
``But, oh, Fanny! if he (them)'d only say a word, it would warm one's heart; wouldn't it?'' (Lawrence Acorn)

On the following evening news reached Bullhampton that the Grinder had been convicted and sentenced to death, but that Lawrence Acorn had been acquitted. The judge, in his (Acorn) summing up, had shown that certain evidence which applied to the Grinder had not applied to his (Acorn) comrade in the dock, and the jury had been willing to take any excuse for saving one man from the halter.

CHAPTER LXX.

THE FATE OF THE PUDDLEHAMITES.

Fenwick and Gilmore breakfasted together on the morning that the former left London for Bullhampton; and by that time the Vicar had assured himself that it would be quite impossible to induce his (Vicar) friend to go back to his (Vicar) home.

``I shall turn up after some years if I live,'' (the Squire)
said the Squire;

This was on the Tuesday, and Fenwick had desired that his (Fenwick) gig might meet him (Fenwick) at the Bullhampton Road station. He (Fenwick) had learned by this time of the condemnation of one man for the murder, and the acquittal of the other, and was full of the subject when his (Fenwick) groom was seated beside him (Fenwick). Fenwick asked twenty questions, but could obtain no other information than was given in the first announcement of these astounding news. And as he (Fenwick) entered the vicarage he (Fenwick) was still asking questions, and the man was still endeavouring to express his (man) own conviction that that horrible, damnable, and most heart-breaking red brick building would be demolished, and carted clean away before the end of the week. For the servants and dependents of the vicarage were staunch to the interests of the church establishment, with a degree of fervour of which the Vicar himself knew nothing. They hated Puddleham and dissent. This groom would have liked nothing better than a commission to punch the head of Mr. Puddleham's eldest son, a young man who had been employed in a banker's office at Warminster, but had lately come home because he (banker) had been found to have a taste for late hours and public-house parlours; and had made himself busy on the question of the chapel. The maid servants at the vicarage looked down as from a mighty great height on the young women of Bullhampton who attended the chapel, and the vicarage gardener, since he (gardener) had found out that the chapel stood on glebe land, and ought therefore, to be placed under his (gardener) hands, had hardly been able to keep himself off the ground. His (gardener) proposed cure for the evil that had been done,--as an immediate remedy before erection and demolition could be carried out, was to form the vicarage manure pit close against the chapel door,--

``and then let anybody touch our property who dares!'' (He)
He (gardener) had, however, been too cautious to carry out any such strategy as this, without direct authority from the Commander-in-Chief.
``Master thinks a deal too much on 'em,'' (he)
he (Commander-in-Chief) had said to the groom, almost in disgust at the Vicar's pusillanimity.

When Fenwick reached his (Fenwick) own gate there was a crowd of men loitering around the chapel, and he (Fenwick) got out from his (Fenwick) gig and joined them. His (Fenwick) eye first fell upon Mr. Puddleham, who was standing directly in front of the door, with his (Puddleham) back to the building, wearing on his (Puddleham) face an expression of infinite displeasure. The Vicar was desirous of assuring the minister that no steps need be taken, at any rate, for the present, towards removing the chapel from its present situation. ``My friend Mr. Puddleham,'' (he)

Mr. Puddleham had now joined them.
