CHAPTER LXXI.

THE END OF MARY LOWTHER``S STORY.

Sir Gregory Marrable's headache was not of long duration. Allusion is here made to that especial headache under the acute effects of which he (Marrable) had taken so very unpromising a farewell of his (Marrable) nephew and heir. It lasted, however, for two or three days, during which he (Marrable) had frequent consultations with Mrs. Brownlow, and had one conversation with Edith. He (Marrable) was disappointed, sorry, and sore at heart because the desire on which he (Marrable) had set his (Marrable) mind could not be fulfilled; but he (Marrable) was too weak to cling either to his (Marrable) hope or to his (Marrable) anger. His (Marrable) own son had gone from him (Marrable), and this young man must be his (man) heir and the owner of Dunripple. No doubt he (man) might punish the young man by excluding him (man) from any share of ownership for the present; but there would be neither comfort nor advantage in that. It is true that he (man) might save any money that Walter would cost him (Walter), and give it to Edith,--but such a scheme of saving for such a purpose was contrary to the old man's nature. He (man) wanted to have his (man) heir near him (man) at Dunripple. He (man) hated the feeling of desolation which was presented to him (man) by the idea of Dunripple without some young male Marrable at hand to help him (Marrable). He (Marrable) desired, unconsciously, to fill up the void made by the death of his (Marrable) son with as little trouble as might be. And therefore he (Marrable) consulted Mrs. Brownlow.

Mrs. Brownlow was clearly of opinion that he (Marrable) had better take his (Marrable) nephew, with the encumbrance of Mary Lowther, and make them both welcome to the house.

``We have all heard so much good of Miss Lowther, you know,'' (Mrs. Brownlow)
said Mrs. Brownlow,
``and she (Lowther) is not at all the same as a stranger.'' (Mrs. Brownlow)

``That is true,'' (Gregory/Gregory Marrable/GREGORY MARRABLE)
said Sir Gregory, willing to be talked over.

``And then, you know, who can say whether Edith would ever have liked him (stranger) or not. You never can tell what way a young woman's feelings will go.'' (Gregory/Gregory Marrable/GREGORY MARRABLE)

On hearing this Sir Gregory uttered some sound intended to express mildly a divergence of opinion. He (Gregory) did not doubt but what Edith would have been quite willing to fall in love with Walter, had all things been conformable to her (Edith) doing so. Mrs. Brownlow did not notice this as she (Brownlow) continued,--

``At any rate the poor girl would suffer dreadfully now if she (girl) were allowed to think that you should be divided from your nephew by your regard for her (girl). Indeed, she (girl) could hardly stay at Dunripple if that were so.'' (she)

Mrs. Brownlow in a mild way suggested that nothing should be said to Edith, and Sir Gregory gave half a promise that he (Gregory) would be silent. But it was against his (Gregory) nature not to speak. When the moment came the temptation to say something that could be easily said, and which would produce some mild excitement, was always too strong for him (Gregory).

``My dear,'' (he)
he (Gregory) said, one evening, when Edith was hovering round his (Gregory) chair,
``you remember what I once said to you about your cousin Walter?'' (Edith/Edith Brownlow/EDITH BROWNLOW)

``About Captain Marrable, uncle?'' (unknown)

``Well,--he (Marrable) is just the same as a cousin;--it turns out that he (Marrable) is engaged to marry another cousin,--Mary Lowther.'' (unknown)

``She (Lowther) is his (Marrable) real cousin, Uncle Gregory.'' (unknown)

``I never saw the young lady,--that I know of.'' (unknown)

``Nor have I,--but I've heard so much about her (lady)! And everybody says she (lady) is nice. I hope they'll come and live here.'' (unknown)

``I don't know yet, my dear.'' (unknown)

``He (Gregory) told me all about it when he (Gregory) was here.'' (unknown)

``Told you he (Gregory) was going to be married?'' (unknown)

``No, uncle, he (uncle) did not tell me that exactly;--but he (uncle) said that--that--. He (uncle) told me how much he (uncle) loved Mary Lowther, and a great deal about her (Lowther), and I felt sure it would come so.'' (unknown)

``Then you are aware that what I had hinted about you and Walter--'' (unknown)

``Don't talk about that, Uncle Gregory. I knew that it was ever so unlikely, and I didn't think about it. You are so good to me that of course I couldn't say anything. But you may be sure he (Gregory) is ever so much in love with Miss Lowther; and I do hope we shall be so fond of her (Lowther)!'' (Gregory/Gregory Marrable/GREGORY MARRABLE)

Sir Gregory was pacified and his (Gregory) headache for the time was cured. He (Gregory) had had his (Gregory) little scheme, and it had failed. Edith was very good, and she (Edith) should still be his (Gregory) pet and his (Gregory) favourite,--but Walter Marrable should be told that he (Marrable) might marry and bring his (Marrable) bride to Dunripple, and that if he (Marrable) would sell out of his (Marrable) regiment, the family lawyer should be instructed to make such arrangements for him (Marrable) as would have been made had he (Marrable) actually been a son. There would be some little difficulty about the colonel's rights; but the colonel had already seized upon so much that it could not but be easy to deal with him (colonel). On the next morning the letter was written to Walter by Mrs. Brownlow herself.

About a week after this Mary Lowther, who was waiting at Loring with an outward show of patience, but with much inward anxiety for further tidings from her (Lowther) lover, received two letters, one from Walter, and the other from her (Lowther) friend, Janet Fenwick. The reader shall see those, and the replies which Mary made to them, and then our whole story will have been told as far as the loves, and hopes, and cares, and troubles of Mary Lowther are concerned.

Bullhampton, 1st September.

DEAREST MARY,

I write a line just because I said I would. Frank went up to London last week and was away one Sunday. He (Frank) found his (Frank) poor friend in town and was with him (Frank) for two or three days. He (Frank) has made up his (Frank) mind to let the Privets, and go abroad, and nothing that Frank could say would move him (Frank). I do not know whether it may not be for the best. We shall lose such a neighbour as we never shall have again. He (Frank) was the same as a brother to both of us; and I can only say, that loving him (Frank) like a brother, I endeavoured to do the best for him (Frank) that I could. This I do know;--that nothing on earth shall ever tempt me to set my hand at match-making again. But it was alluring,--the idea of bringing my two dearest friends near me together.

If you have anything to tell me of your happiness, I shall be delighted to hear it; I will not set my heart against this other man;--but you can hardly expect me to say that he (man) will be as much to me as might have been that other. God bless you,

Your most affectionate friend,

JANET FENWICK.

I must tell you the fate of the chapel. They are already pulling it down, and carting away the things to the other place. They are doing it so quick, that it will all be gone before we know where we are. I own I am glad. As for Frank, I really believe he (Frank)'d rather let it remain. But this is not all. The Marquis has promised that we shall hear from him (Marquis)

``in a spirit of kindness.'' (him)
I wonder what this will come to? It certainly was not a spirit of kindness that made him (Marquis) write to the bishop and call Frank an infidel.

And this was the other letter.

Barracks, 1st September, 186--.

DEAREST LOVE,

I hope this will be one of the last letters I shall write from this abominable place, for I am going to sell out at once. It is all settled, and I'm to be a sort of deputy Squire at Dunripple, under my uncle. As that is to be my fate in life, I may as well begin it at once. But that's not the whole of my fate, nor the best of it. You are to be admitted as deputy Squiress,--or rather as Squiress in chief, seeing that you will be mistress of the house. Dearest Mary, may I hope that you won't object to the promotion?

I have had a long letter from Mrs. Brownlow; and I ran over yesterday and saw my uncle. I was so hurried that I could not write from Dunripple. I would send you Mrs. Brownlow's letter, only perhaps it would not be quite fair. I dare say you will see it some day. She (Brownlow) says ever so much about you, and as complimentary as possible. And then she (Brownlow) declares her (Brownlow) purpose to resign all rights, honours, pains, privileges, and duties of mistress of Dunripple into your hands as soon as you are Mrs. Marrable. And this she (mistress) repeated yesterday with some stateliness, and a great deal of high-minded resignation. But I don't mean to laugh at her (mistress), because I know she (mistress) means to do what is right.

My own, own, Mary, write me a line instantly to say that it is right,--and to say also that you agree with me that as it is to be done, `twere well it were done quickly.

Yours always, with all my heart,

W. M.

It was of course necessary that Mary should consult with her (Mary) aunt before she (Mary) answered the second letter. Of that which she (Mary) received from Mrs. Fenwick she (Mary) determined to say nothing. Why should she (Mary) ever mention to her (Mary) aunt again a name so painful to her (Mary) as that of Mr. Gilmore? The thinking of him (Gilmore) could not be avoided. In this, the great struggle of her (Mary) life, she (Mary) had endeavoured to do right, and yet she (Mary) could not acquit herself of evil. But the pain, though it existed, might at least be kept out of sight.

``And so you are to go and live at Dunripple at once,'' (Miss Marrable/Marrable/MISS MARRABLE)
said Miss Marrable.

``I suppose we shall.

``Ah, well! It's all right, I'm sure. Of course there is not a word to be said against it. I hope Sir Gregory won't die before the Colonel. That's all.'' (unknown)

``The Colonel is his (Colonel) father, you know.'' (unknown)

``I hope there may not come to be trouble about it, that's all. I shall be very lonely, but of course I had to expect that.'' (unknown)

``You'll come to us, Aunt Sarah? You'll be as much there as here.'' (unknown)

``Thank you, dear. I don't quite know about that. Sir Gregory is all very well; but one does like one's own house.'' (Mary/Mary Lowther/MARY LOWTHER)

From all which Mary understood that her (Mary) dear aunt still wished that she (Mary) might have had her (Mary) own way in disposing of her (Mary) niece's hand,--as her (Mary) dear friends at Bullhampton had wished to have theirs.

The following were the answers from Mary to the two letters given above;--

Loring, 3rd September, 186--.

DEAR JANET,

I am very, very, very sorry. I do not know what more I can say. I meant to do well all through. When I first told Mr. Gilmore that it could not be as he (Gilmore) wished it, I was right. When I made up my mind that it must be so at last, I was right also. I fear I cannot say so much of myself as to that middle step which I took, thinking it was best to do as I was bidden. I meant to be right, but of course I was wrong, and I am very, very sorry. Nevertheless, I am much obliged to you for writing to me. Of course I cannot but desire to know what he (Gilmore) does. If he (Gilmore) writes and seems to be happy on his (Gilmore) travels, pray tell me.

I have much to tell you of my own happiness,--though, in truth, I feel a remorse at being happy when I have caused so much unhappiness. Walter is to sell out and to live at Dunripple, and I also am to live there when we are married. I suppose it will not be long now. I am writing to him (Walter) to-day, though I do not yet know what I shall say to him (Walter). Sir Gregory has assented, and arrangements are to be made, and lawyers are to be consulted, and we are to be what Walter calls deputy Squire and Squiress at Dunripple. Mrs. Brownlow and Edith Brownlow are still to live there, but I am to have the honour of ordering the dinner, and looking wise at the housekeeper. Of course I shall feel very strange at going into such a house. To you I may say how much nicer it would be to go to some place that Walter and I could have to ourselves,--as you did when you married. But I am not such a simpleton as to repine at that. So much has gone as I would have it that I only feel myself to be happier than I deserve. What I shall chiefly look forward to will be your first visit to Dunripple.

Your most affectionate friend,

MARY LOWTHER.

The other letter, as to which Mary had declared that she (Mary) had not as yet made up her (Mary) own mind when she (Mary) wrote to Mrs. Fenwick, was more difficult in composition.

Loring, 2nd September, 186--.

DEAREST WALTER,

So it is all settled, and I am to be a deputy Squiress! I have no objection to urge. As long as you are the deputy Squire, I will be the deputy Squiress. For your sake, my dearest, I do most heartily rejoice that the affair is settled. I think you will be happier as a county gentleman than you would have been in the army; and as Dunripple must ultimately be your home,--I will say our home,--perhaps it is as well that you, and I also, should know it as soon as possible. Of course I am very nervous about Mrs. Brownlow and her (Brownlow) daughter; but though nervous I am not fearful; and I shall prepare myself to like them.

As to that other matter, I hardly know what answer to make on so very quick a questioning. It was only the other day that it was decided that it was to be;--and there ought to be breathing time before one also decides when. But, dear Walter, I will do nothing to interfere with your prospects. Let me know what you think yourself; but remember, in thinking, that a little interval for purposes of sentiment and of stitching is always desired by the weaker vessel on such an occasion.

God bless you, my own one,

Yours always and always, M. L.

In real truth, I will do whatever you bid me.

Of course, after that, the marriage was not very long postponed. Walter Marrable allowed that some grace should be given for sentiment, and some also for stitching, but as to neither did he (Marrable) feel that any long delay was needed. A week for sentiment, and two more for the preparation of bridal adornments, he (Marrable) thought would be sufficient. There was a compromise at last, as is usual in such cases, and the marriage took place about the middle of October. No doubt, at that time of year they went to Italy,--but of that the present narrator is not able to speak with any certainty. This, however, is certain,--that if they did travel abroad, Mary Marrable travelled in daily fear lest her (Mary) unlucky fate should bring her (Mary) face to face with Mr. Gilmore. Wherever they went, their tour, in accordance with a contract made by the baronet, was terminated within two months. For on Christmas Day Mrs. Walter Marrable was to take her (Mary) place as mistress of the house at the dinner table.

The reader may, perhaps, desire to know whether things were made altogether smooth with the Colonel. On this matter Messrs. Block and Curling, the family lawyers, encountered very much trouble indeed. The Colonel, when application was made to him (Colonel), was as sweet as honey. He (Colonel) would do anything for the interests of his (Colonel) dearest son. There did not breathe a father on earth who cared less for himself or his (Colonel) own position. But still he (Colonel) must live. He (Colonel) submitted to Messrs. Block and Curling whether it was not necessary that he (Colonel) should live. Messrs. Block and Curling explained to him (Colonel) very clearly that his (Colonel) brother, the baronet, had nothing to do with his (Colonel) living or dying,--and that towards his (Colonel) living he (Colonel) had already robbed his (Colonel) son of a large property. At last, however, he (Colonel) would not make over his (Colonel) life interest in the property, as it would come to him (Colonel) in the event of his (Colonel) brother dying before him (Colonel), except on payment of an annuity on and from that date of L200 a year. He (Colonel) began by asking L500, and was then told that the Captain would run the chance and would sue his (Captain) father for the L20,000 in the event of Sir Gregory dying before the Colonel.

Now the narrator will bid adieu to Mary Lowther, to Loring, and to Dunripple. The conduct of his (Loring) heroine, as depicted in these pages, will, he (Loring) fears, meet with the disapprobation of many close and good judges of female character. He (character) has endeavoured to describe a young woman, prompted in all her (woman) doings by a conscience wide awake, guided by principle, willing, if need be, to sacrifice herself, struggling always to keep herself from doing wrong, but yet causing infinite grief to others, and nearly bringing herself to utter shipwreck, because, for a while, she (woman) allowed herself to believe that it would be right for her (woman) to marry a man whom she (woman) did not love.

CHAPTER LXXII.

AT TURNOVER CASTLE.

Mrs. Fenwick had many quips and quirks with her (Fenwick) husband as to those tidings to be made in a pleasant spirit which were expected from Turnover Castle. From the very moment that Lord St. George had given the order,--upon the authority chiefly of the unfortunate Mr. Bolt, who on this occasion found it to be impossible to refuse to give an authority which a lord demanded from him (lord),--the demolition of the building had been commenced. Before the first Sunday came any use of the new chapel for divine service was already impossible. On that day Mr. Puddleham preached a stirring sermon about tabernacles in general.

``It did not matter where the people of the Lord met,'' (he)
he (Puddleham) said,
``so long as they did meet to worship the Lord in a proper spirit of independent resistance to any authority that had not come to them from revelation. Any hedge-side was a sufficient tabernacle for a devout Christian. But--,'' (he)
and then, without naming any name, he (Puddleham) described the Church of England as a Upas tree which, by its poison, destroyed those beautiful flowers which strove to spring up amidst the rank grass beneath it and to make the air sweet within its neighbourhood. Something he (Puddleham) said, too, of a weak sister tottering to its base, only to be followed in its ruin by the speedy prostration of its elder brother. All this was of course told in detail to the Vicar; but the Vicar refused even to be interested by it.
``Of course he (Christian) did,'' (the Vicar)
said the Vicar.
``If a man is to preach, what can he (man) preach but his (man) own views?'' (unknown)

The tidings to be made in a pleasant spirit were not long waited for,--or, at any rate, the first instalment of them. On the 2nd of September there arrived a large hamper full of partridges, addressed to Mrs. Fenwick in the Earl's own handwriting.

``The very first fruits,'' (the Vicar)
said the Vicar, as he (Vicar) went down to inspect the plentiful provision thus made for the vicarage larder. Well;--it was certainly better to have partridges from Turnover than accusations of immorality and infidelity. The Vicar so declared at once, but his (Vicar) wife would not at first agree with him (Vicar).
``I really should have such pleasure in packing them up and sending them back,'' (she)
said she (wife).

``Indeed, you shall do nothing of the kind.'' (unknown)

``The idea of a basket of birds to atone for such insults and calumny as that man has heaped on you!'' (unknown)

``The birds will be only a first instalment,'' (the Vicar)
said the Vicar,--and then there were more quips and quirks about that. It was presumed by Mr. Fenwick that the second instalment would be the first pheasants shot in October. But the second instalment came before September was over in the shape of the following note:--

Turnover Park, 20th September, 186--.

The Marquis of Trowbridge and the Ladies Sophie and Carolina Stowte request that Mr. and Mrs. Fenwick will do them the honour of coming to Turnover Park on Monday the 6th October, and staying till Saturday the 11th.

``That's an instalment indeed,'' (Mrs. Fenwick)
said Mrs. Fenwick.
``And now what on earth are we to do?'' (The Vicar)
The Vicar admitted that it had become very serious.
``We must either go, and endure a terrible time of it,'' (Mrs. Fenwick)
continued Mrs. Fenwick,
``or we must show him (man) very plainly that we will have nothing more to do with him (man). I don't see why we are to be annoyed, merely because he (man) is a Marquis.'' (Mrs. Fenwick)

``It won't be because he (man) is a Marquis.'' (unknown)

``Why then? You can't say that you love the old man, or that the Ladies Sophie and Carolina Stowte are the women you'd have me choose for companions, or that that soapy, silky, humbugging Lord St. George is to your taste.'' (unknown)

``I am not sure about St. George. He (George) can be everything to everybody, and would make an excellent bishop.'' (unknown)

``You know you don't like him (George), and you know also that you will have a very bad time of it at Turnover.'' (unknown)

``I could shoot pheasants all the week.'' (unknown)

``Yes,--with a conviction at the time that the Ladies Sophie and Carolina were calling you an infidel behind your back for doing so. As for myself I feel perfectly certain that I should spar with them.'' (unknown)

``It isn't because he (infidel)'s a Marquis,'' (the Vicar)
said the Vicar, carrying on his (Vicar) argument after a long pause.
``If I know myself, I think I may say that that has no allurement for me. And, to tell the truth, had he (Marquis) been simply a Marquis, and had I been at liberty to indulge my own wishes, I would never have allowed myself to be talked out of my righteous anger by that soft-tongued son of his (son). But to us he (son) is a man of the very greatest importance, because he (son) owns the land on which the people live with whom we are concerned. It is for their welfare that he (son) and I should be on good terms together; and therefore if you don't mind the sacrifice, I think we'll go.'' (unknown)

``What;--for the whole week, Frank?'' (The Vicar)

The Vicar was of opinion that the week might be judiciously curtailed by two days; and, consequently, Mrs. Fenwick presented her (Fenwick) compliments to the Ladies Sophie and Carolina Stowte, and expressed the great pleasure which she (Stowte) and Mr. Fenwick would have in going to Turnover Park on the Tuesday, and staying till the Friday.

``So that I shall only be shooting two days,'' (the Vicar)
said the Vicar,
``which will modify the aspect of my infidelity considerably.'' (the Vicar)

They went to Turnover Castle. The poor old Marquis had rather a bad time of it for the hour or two previous to their arrival. It had become an acknowledged fact now in the county that Sam Brattle had had nothing to do with the murder of Farmer Trumbull, and that his (Trumbull) acquaintance with the murderers had sprung from his (Trumbull) desire to see his (Trumbull) unfortunate sister settled in marriage with a man whom he (Trumbull) at the time did not know to be disreputable. There had therefore been a reaction in favour of Sam Brattle, whom the county now began to regard as something of a hero. The Marquis, understanding all that, had come to be aware that he (Marquis) had wronged the Vicar in that matter of the murder. And then, though he (Vicar) had been told upon very good authority,--no less than that of his (Vicar) daughters, who had been so informed by the sisters of a most exemplary neighbouring curate,--that Mr. Fenwick was a man who believed

``just next to nothing,'' (Fenwick a man)
and would just as soon associate with a downright Pagan like old Brattle, as with any professing Christian,--still there was the fact of the Bishop's good opinion; and, though the Marquis was a self-willed man, to him (Marquis) a bishop was always a bishop. It was also clear to him (Marquis) that he (Marquis) had been misled in those charges which he (Marquis) had made against the Vicar in that matter of poor Carry Brattle's residence at Salisbury. Something of the truth of the girl's history had come to the ears of the Marquis, and he (Marquis) had been made to believe that he (Marquis) had been wrong. Then there was the affair of the chapel, in which, under his (Marquis) son's advice, he (Marquis) was at this moment expending L700 in rectifying the mistake which he (Marquis) had made. In giving the Marquis his (Marquis) due we must acknowledge that he (Marquis) cared but little about the money. Marquises, though they may have large properties, are not always in possession of any number of loose hundreds which they can throw away without feeling the loss. Nor was the Marquis of Trowbridge so circumstanced now. But that trouble did not gall him (Trowbridge) nearly so severely as the necessity which was on him (Trowbridge) to rectify an error made by himself. He (Trowbridge) had done a foolish thing. Under no circumstances should the chapel have been built on that spot. He (Trowbridge) knew it now, and he (Trowbridge) knew that he (Trowbridge) must apologise. Noblesse oblige. The old lord was very stupid, very wrong-headed, and sometimes very arrogant; but he (lord) would not do a wrong if he (lord) knew it, and nothing on earth would make him (lord) tell a wilful lie. The epithet indeed might have been omitted; for a lie is not a lie unless it be wilful.

Lord Trowbridge passed the hours of this Tuesday morning under the frightful sense of the necessity for apologising;--and yet he (Trowbridge) remembered well the impudence of the man, how he (Trowbridge) had ventured to allude to the Ladies Stowte, likening them to--to--to--! It was terrible to be thought of. And his (Trowbridge) lordship remembered, too, how this man had written about the principal entrance to his (man) own mansion as though it had been no more than the entrance to any other man's house! Though the thorns still rankled in his (man) own flesh, he (man) had to own that he (man) himself had been wrong.

And he (man) did it,--with an honesty that was beyond the reach of his (man) much more clever son. When the Fenwicks arrived, they were taken into the drawing-room, in which were sitting the Ladies Sophie and Carolina with various guests already assembled at the Castle. In a minute or two the Marquis shuffled in and shook hands with the two new comers. Then he (Marquis) shuffled about the room for another minute or two, and at last got his (Marquis) arm through that of the Vicar, and led him (Marquis) away into his (Marquis) own sanctum.

``Mr. Fenwick,'' (he)
he (Marquis) said,
``I think it best to express my regret at once for two things that have occurred.'' (he)

-LSB-Illustration: The drawing-room at Turnover Castle.-RSB-

``It does not signify, my lord.'' (unknown)

``But it does signify to me, and if you will listen to me for a moment I shall take your doing so as a favour added to that which you have conferred upon me in coming here.'' (The Vicar)
The Vicar could only bow and listen.
``I am sorry, Mr. Fenwick, that I should have written to the bishop of this diocese in reference to your conduct.'' (Mr. Fenwick/Fenwick/MR. FENWICK)
Fenwick found it very difficult to hold his (Fenwick) tongue when this was said. He (Fenwick) imagined that the Marquis was going to excuse himself about the chapel,--and about the chapel he (Marquis) cared nothing at all. But as to that letter to the bishop, he (bishop) did feel that the less said about it the better. He (bishop) restrained himself, however, and the Marquis went on.
``Things had been told me, Mr. Fenwick;--and I thought that I was doing my duty.'' (unknown)

``It did me no harm, my lord.'' (unknown)

``I believe not. I had been misinformed,--and I apologise.'' (The Marquis)
The Marquis paused, and the Vicar bowed. It is probable that the Vicar did not at all know how deep at that moment were the sufferings of the Marquis.
``And now as to the chapel,'' (the Marquis)
continued the Marquis.

``My lord, that is such a trifle that you must let me say that it is not and has not been of the slightest consequence.'' (unknown)

``I was misled as to that bit of ground.'' (unknown)

``I only wish, my lord, that the chapel could stand there.'' (unknown)

``That is impossible. The land has been appropriated to other purposes, and though we have all been a little in the dark about our own rights, right must be done. I will only add that I have the greatest satisfaction in seeing you and Mrs. Fenwick at Turnover, and that I hope the satisfaction may often be repeated.'' (he)
Then he (Marquis) led the way back into the drawing-room, and the evil hour had passed over his (Marquis) head.

Upon the whole, things went very well with both the Vicar and his (Vicar) wife during their visit. He (Vicar) did go out shooting one day, and was treated very civilly by the Turnover gamekeeper, though he (Vicar) was prepared with no five-pound note at the end of his (Vicar) day's amusement. When he (Vicar) returned to the house, his (Vicar) host congratulated him (Vicar) on his (Vicar) performance just as cordially as though he (Vicar) had been one of the laity. On the next day he (Vicar) rode over with Lord St. George to see the County Hunt kennels, which were then at Charleycoats, and nobody seemed to think him (Hunt) very wicked because he (Hunt) ventured to have an opinion about hounds. Mrs. Fenwick's amusements were, perhaps, less exciting, but she (Fenwick) went through them with equanimity. She (Fenwick) was taken to see the parish schools, and was walked into the parish church,--in which the Stowte family were possessed of an enormous recess called a pew, but which was in truth a room, with a fireplace in it. Mrs. Fenwick thought it did not look very much like a church; but as the Ladies Stowte were clearly very proud of it she (Fenwick) held her (Fenwick) peace as to that idea. And so the visit to Turnover Park was made, and the Fenwicks were driven home.

``After all, there's nothing like burying the hatchet,'' (he)
said he (Stowte).

``But who sharpened the hatchet?'' (Mrs. Fenwick)
asked Mrs. Fenwick.

``Never mind who sharpened it. We've buried it.'' (unknown)

CHAPTER LXXIII.

CONCLUSION.

There is nothing further left to be told of this story of the village of Bullhampton and its Vicar beyond what may be necessary to satisfy the reader as to the condition and future prospects of the Brattle family. The writer of these pages ventures to hope that whatever may have been the fate in the readers' mind of that couple which are about to settle themselves peaceably at Dunripple, and to wait there in comfort till their own time for reigning shall have come, some sympathy may have been felt with those humbler personages who have lived with orderly industry at the mill,--as, also, with those who, led away by disorderly passions, have strayed away from it, and have come back again to the old home.

For a couple of days after the return of the miller with his (miller) daughter and son, very little was said about the past;--very little, at least, in which either the father or Sam took any part. Between the two sisters there were no doubt questions and answers by the hour together as to every smallest detail of the occurrences at Salisbury. And the mother almost sang hymns of joy over her (mother) child, in that the hour which she (mother) had so much dreaded had passed by. But the miller said not a word;--and Sam was almost equally silent.

``But it be all over, Sam?'' (mother)
asked his (Sam) mother, anxiously one day.
``For certain sure it be all over now?'' (unknown)

``There's one, mother, for whom it ain't all over yet;--poor devil.'' (unknown)

``But he (devil) was the--murderer, Sam.'' (unknown)

``So was t`other fellow. There weren't no difference. If one was more spry to kill t`old chap than t`other, Acorn was the spryest. That's what I think. But it's done now, and there ain't been much justice in it. As far as I sees, there never ain't much justice. They was nigh a-hanging o' me; and if those chaps had thought o' bringing t`old man's box nigh the mill, instead of over by t`old woman's cottage, they would a hung me;--outright. And then they was twelve months about it! I don't think much on 'em.'' (mother)
When his (Sam) mother tried to continue the conversation,--which she (mother) would have loved to do with that morbid interest which we always take in a matter which has been nearly fatal to us, but from which we have escaped,--Sam turned into the mill, saying that he (Sam) had had enough of it, and wouldn't have any more.

Then, on the third day, a report of the trial in a county newspaper reached them. This the miller read all through, painfully, from the beginning to the end, omitting no detail of the official occurrences. At last, when he (miller) came to the account of Sam's evidence, he (Sam) got up from the chair on which he (Sam) was sitting close to the window, and striking his (Sam) fist upon the table, made his (Sam) first and last comment upon the trial.

``It was well said, Sam. Yes; though thou be'est my own, it was well said.'' (he)
Then he (Sam) put the paper down and walked out of doors, and they could see that his (Sam) eyes were full of tears.

But from that time forth there came a great change in his (Sam) manner to his (Sam) youngest daughter.

``Well, Carry,'' (he)
he (Sam) would say to her (daughter) in the morning, with as much outward sign of affection as he (Sam) ever showed to any one; and at night, when she (daughter) came and stood over him (Sam) before he (Sam) lifted his (Sam) weary limbs out of his (Sam) chair to take himself away to his (Sam) bed, he (Sam) turned his (Sam) forehead to her (daughter) to be kissed, as he (Sam) did to that better daughter who had needed no forgiveness from him (Sam). Nevertheless, they who knew him (Sam),--and there were none who knew him (Sam) better than Fanny did,--were aware that he (Sam) never for a moment forgot the disgrace which had fallen upon his (Sam) household. He (Sam) had forgiven the sinner, but the shame of the sin was always on him (Sam); and he (Sam) carried himself as a man who was bound to hide himself from the eyes of his (Sam) neighbours because there had come upon him (Sam) a misfortune which made it fit that he (Sam) should live in retirement.

Sam took up his (Sam) abode in the house, and worked daily in the mill, and for weeks nothing was said either of his (Sam) going away or of his (Sam) return. He (Sam) would talk to his (Sam) sisters of the manner in which he (Sam) had worked among the machinery of the Durham mine at which he (Sam) had found employment; but he (Sam) said nothing for awhile of the cause which had taken him (Sam) north, or of his (Sam) purpose of remaining where he (Sam) was. He (Sam) ate and drank in the house, and from time to time his (Sam) father paid him (Sam) small sums as wages. At last, sitting one evening after the work of the day was done, he (Sam) spoke out his (Sam) mind.

``Father,'' (he)
said he (Sam),
``I'm about minded to get me a wife.'' (he)
His (Sam) mother and sisters were all there and heard the proposition made.

``And who is the girl as is to have thee, Sam?'' (mother)
asked his (Sam) mother.

As Sam did not answer at once, Carry replied for him (Sam).

``Who should it be, mother;--but only Agnes Pope?'' (unknown)

``It ain't that `un?'' (the miller)
said the miller, surlily.

``And why shouldn't it be that `un, father? It is that `un, and no other. If she (Pope) be not liked here, why, we'll just go further, and perhaps not fare worse.'' (Agnes Pope/Agnes)

There was nothing to be said against poor Agnes Pope,--only this, that she (Pope) had been in Trumbull's house on the night of the murder, and had for awhile been suspected by the police of having communicated to her (Pope) lover the tidings of the farmer's box of money. Evil things had of course been said of her (Pope) then, but the words spoken of her (Pope) had been proved to be untrue. She (Pope) had been taken from the farmer's house into that of the Vicar,--who had, indeed, been somewhat abused by the Puddlehamites for harbouring her (Pope); but as the belief in Sam's guilt had gradually been abandoned, so, of course, had the ground disappeared for supposing that poor Agnes had had ought to do in bringing about the murder of her (Agnes) late master. For two days the miller was very gloomy, and made no reply when Sam declared his (Sam) purpose of leaving the mill before Christmas unless Agnes should be received there as his (Sam) wife;--but at last he (Sam) gave way.

``As the old `uns go into their graves,'' (he)
he (Sam) said,
``it's no more than nature that the young `uns should become masters.'' (he)
And so Sam was married, and was taken, with his (Sam) wife, to live with the other Brattles at the mill. It was well for the miller that it should be so, for Sam was a man who would surely earn money when he (Sam) put his (Sam) shoulder in earnest to the wheel.

As for Carry, she (wife) lived still with them, doomed by her (wife) beauty, as was her (wife) elder sister by the want of it, to expect that no lover should come and ask her (wife) to establish with him (lover) a homestead of their own.

Our friend the Vicar married Sam and his (Sam) sweetheart, and is still often at the mill. From time to time he (Sam) has made efforts to convert the unbelieving old man whose grave is now so near to his (Sam) feet; but he (Sam) has never prevailed to make the miller own even the need of any change.

``I've struv' to be honest,'' (he)
he (Sam) said, when last he (Sam) was thus attacked,
``and I've wrought for my wife and bairns. I ain't been a drunkard, nor yet, as I knows on, neither a tale-bearer, nor yet a liar. I've been harsh-tempered and dour enough I know, and maybe it's fitting as they shall be hard and dour to me where I'm going. I don't say again it, Muster Fenwick;--but nothing as I can do now 'll change it.'' (he)
This, at any rate, was clear to the Vicar,--that Death, when it came, would come without making the old man tremble.

Mr. Gilmore has been some years away from Bullhampton; but when I last heard from my friends in that village I was told that at last he (Gilmore) was expected home.

Bradbury, Evans, and Co., Printers, Whitefriars.

was changed to
``begun'' (him)
in the sentence: ... and had long since BEGUN to feel that a few cabbages and peaches did not repay him (captain) for the loss of those pleasant and bitter things, ...

Chapter XXXIX, paragraph 13.

``Gay'' (Mrs. Jay/Jay/Mrs. JAY)
was changed to
``Jay'' (Mrs. Jay/Jay/Mrs. JAY)
in the sentence: Mrs. JAY, no doubt, is a religious woman. We do not know whether this was a typographical error or another example of Trollope's inconsistency with names of minor characters.

Chapter XLII, paragraph 5. A hyphen was removed from

``any-rate'' (he)
in the sentence: His (Trollope) gown was of silk, and his (Trollope) income almost greater than his (Trollope) desires; but he (Trollope) would fain sit upon the Bench, and have at ANY RATE his (Trollope) evenings for his (Trollope) own enjoyment.

Chapter XLII, paragraph 6. The word

``that'' (Mr. Quickenham/MR. QUICKENHAM/Quickenham)
was removed from the sentence: Mr. Quickenham was a tall, thin man, with eager gray eyes, and a long projecting nose, on which, his (Quickenham) enemies in the courts of law were wont to say, -LSB-THAT-RSB- his (Quickenham) wife would hang a kettle, in order that the unnecessary heat coming from his (Quickenham) mouth might not be wasted.

Chapter XLVIII, paragraph 2. The word

``injustice'' (He)
was changed to
``justice'' (He)
in the sentence: He (Quickenham) reminded himself, too, of the murderer's present escape from JUSTICE by aid of this pestilent clergyman; ...

Chapter XLVIII, paragraph 4.

``St.'' (He)
was added to the sentence: He (clergyman) had already told St. George of Fenwick's letter to him (clergyman) and of his (clergyman) letter to the bishop, and ST. George had whistled.

Chapter XLIX, paragraph 21. The words

``much as'' (I)
were added to the sentence: I believe I owe as much to you,--almost as MUCH AS a woman can owe to a man; but still, were my cousin so placed that he (cousin) could afford to marry a poor wife, I should leave you and go to him (cousin) at once.
